 a bank buyout 

H istorically distinguished and so­ cially prominent, the Groos National 
Bank of San Antonio resisted Indian raids and survi\ed panics and depres­ sions. Then along cam e Clinton 
Manges. This is the account of his stunning takeo\er of Groos Bank. 

By M IK E COC HRAN 

 and M IL L E R BONNER 

On March 2H. 1973. directors ol the Groos National Bank as­ sembled iii their elegant board room for a most unusual meet­ ing. 

The mood was solemn, and the men ol money and influence swapped few routine pleasantries. 
Quietly, hastily, as if acting out a scene from “ The Moneychangers." they took pencils and scraps of paper and one by one scribbled out their resignations. 
“ I hereby resign as an officer and director of the Groos National Bank of 
San Antonio." wrote Ernest W. (irons 
•lr., president arid a descendent of the founding family. 
"Please accept my resignation as director." penned another. 
**. . . effective im mediately." con­ cluded a third. 
‘Cleaning house’ 

Thus ended a long, bitter battle of control of the (irons, then a SHU million institution, organized iii Isr>4 and a financial fixture in the "Queen City of the Southwest." 
That was the day. one would recall, 
“ when Clinton began cleaning house." 
It was a thorough job. 
Bv nightfall, aller a second special hoard meeting, the nucleus of a new board was seated and Clinton Manges’ stormy hanking career had entered a new phase. 
For the secretive South Texan, re­ clusive overlord of vast ranch and oil properties, it was a heady coup, alth­ ough in one sense the battle had just begun 
Tin* overthrow was nut easily ac*

Carter plans defense cuts 
COMR1UO THOM WIRT RI PORTS 
PLA IN S. Ga 
— President Carter said Saturday that he would cut the level of defense spending recommend­ ed bv President Ford in .January. 
But the revised budget would still contain a "substantial increase" over the previous fiscal year, he said. 
In what amounted to a brief news conference, ( arter disclosed that he had finished making revisions in the 
Ford defense budget for the fiscal year 
IH7H. which tiegins on Get. I. 
Hi* added that hi* would spend the weekend al Ills house ill Plains study­ ing other revisions iii the spending plan The revisions will go to Congress probably a week from Monday, he said 
VV bile he doubled that there would Im* drastic changes, ( arter said of the defense budget that it will Im* less than 
Ford proposed, which was $123.1 bil­ lion in defense appropriations.

Secret Service training in S.A. 

By ED KINGSHOTT 

Secret Serv ice agents are re­ ceiving military dog handler training at Lackland A FB to beef up security tor foreign di­ plomats in Washington D.C., the 
Express-News has learned. 

The same agents and their dogs also could be deployed to the White House in event of an emergency, a Secret 
Serv ice spokesman said 
The D epartm ent of Defense Dog 
School at Lackland is in charge of the training. 
The school trains dogs for patrol and sentry duties. Dogs also are trained to detect bombs and to attack on com­ mand. 
The Secret Serv ice spokesman—who asked not to he named—said agents at 
Lackland art* receiving patrol dog handling training only. 

'We don't like to folk about protective measures and techniques' 

Patrol flogs arc used to detect and apprehend intruders. Germ an she­ pherds have proved to In* the hest suited for military work as patrol dogs. 
Uniformed 
Agents trained at Lacklan d , the spokesman said, are Executive Pro ­ tective Service officers. They are a uniform branch of the Secret Service. 
The spokesman said dogs and their handlers will he primarily responsible for patrolling foreign missions to as­ sure the safety of the diplomatic com­ munity in the Washington area. 
He said he could not make public the number of Secret Service agents trained at Lackland. He also said he could not talk about Hie training they 

 are reeeiv mg. 
“ We don't like to talk about protec­ tive measures and techniques." lie ex­ plained. "W e won't get into the speci­ fies of training because that's an area of security techniques and procedures aud we usually don’t discuss Biose." 
Training began last year and each course runs 13 weeks. No agents, how­ ever. are now receiving dog handler training, although mort* classes are scheduled, the spokesman said 
Secret 

Secret Service funds pay for the 
Lackland training Total costs could not Im* revealed, the spokesman said, because such figures are made availa­ ble* only Ut C onure**^, which vhurve*** the Secret Service with assuring the safety of foreign diplomats. 
“ W e're constantly evaluating our se­ curity techniques so this is just all­ ot lier method to be used." the spokes­ man said. explaining why the Secret 
Service decided to use the Lackland acility. 

A spokesman for the Lackland dog school said all comments on the train­ ing would have to come from the Se­ cret Service. 
The school trains flogs for use by the 
Army. Navy. Air Force and civilian police organizations Training includes drug and explosives detection. The school also trains military and civilian personnel as dog handlers. 
Most dogs trained are German she­ pherds. Other breeds include Dober­ mans. m iniature schnauzers, cairn terriers, beagles aud m iniature fox terriers 
Others 

The Secret Service is not ihe first non military agency to use the Lack­ land dog school 

Dogs also are trained al Lackland under an Air Force-Federal Aviation 
Adm inistration program , which is funded iii part by tin* Law Enforce­ ment Assistance Administration 
Civilian pollee department officers arc taught to handle dogs specially trained to detect bombs at airports 
Policem en from Honolulu, C leve­ land. Houston. Los Angeles and New 
O ilcans have received dog handler training at Lackland, a base sjMike man said nse: might’ve lost

Pres*, Hadnt and Television Day and 

By JE R R Y D EAL 

One present City Council member might not have been elected if Sun Antonio had sin- gle-member districts two years ago, an Express-News study in­ dicates. 

Too many factors have changed lur close comparisons of political pro­ spects, lint election records show Unit 
Dr. I) Ford Nielsen garnered fewer voles than Ins chief opponent in 15173 iii what is now the new iv-formed council 
District H. 
Dr. Nielsen lives in District H and has filed for re-election to council 
The other seven current Connell members would have won tlieir dis­ tricts, based on vote totals in the 1975 
[Hill. 
The study doesn t necessarily reflect on Nielsen’s re-election chances this year. 
But it does add yet another strong indication that 1977 will in- a year ut sweeping political change tor tile city because of amendments to the ( tty 
Charter w hich were approved l>> voters last month. 
Changes 

With the 1977 election City C ouncil switches from a nine-member, at-large system to a ten-seat, single-member* district system Form erly the mayor was elected from among council members, In the future the mayor alone will run at large to hold an ele­ venth council |H>sition 

The changeover is expected to bring new cam paign styles as well as a larger council. 
Here is a Unik at each of the ten new council districts, where the tncum- benis live and what would have hap- 
[letted two years ago:

Nader talk is 'raided’ 

About a dozen pro-nuclear power dem onstrators stormed the hall in 
Providence, R I., where consumer advocate Ralph Nader was speak­ ing about a New England Power Co. proposal to build a nuclear genera­ tor. 

The dem onstrators were part of a crowd of about IOO demonstrators described by an ironworkers union official as “ .inst unemployed people who feel their future is at stake.” 

The protesters broke through the re a r door of the F irs t B aptist 
Church, shouting. “ We want jobs.” 
One demonstrator was ejected by police but the others were perm it­ ted to stow 

Big Brother taketh aw ay 

The government gives, and the government takes away, Boh Neu­ m ann. a disabled construction worker in Vancouver, B.C.. has found out the hard way. 
Neumann, who received $3o9 as compensation for being a mugging victim, found out the government will now recover it from $2f55 a month handicapped allowance.

Scott has hope on arms 

Form er U. S. Sen 
Hugh Scott says it would not surprise him to see the United States take the lead in nuclear disarm am ent to hasten agreements with the Soviet Union in strategic arm s limitation talks. 
“ I am satisfied the Soviets are anxious to go ahead with those talks.” said Scott, referring to arm s limitation discussions. “ AU that’s holding up the solution is an agree­ ment over B ackfire and C ruise missiles. 
Scott, a Pennsylvania Republican who just stepped down after 24 years in the Senate, made the re­ m arks Friday to a group of young lawyers in Philadelphia. 

Her dream cam e true. 
Brenda 
Howard, I 7, of Barstow, Calif., has been named Cinderella. 
Just 'The Thing’ 

San Quentin Prison officials and inmates say they have cut down the time needed to search trucks for contraband weapons by building 
“ see-through” vehicles. 
"We decided to build a vehicle with very few hiding places.” said 
Henry Harris, the prison's station­ ary engineer superintendent. 

H a rris said he b o u g h t two wrecked sedans from the state and inmates began reconstructing them into trucks, w ith frames of box steel tubing and cargo com partm ents of tough steel mesh 

“We call it ‘The Thing.’ ” Harris said. 

Cinderella headed for the forest 

One girl sent in a nude photo, and there was a 19 - year - old man am o n g th e m o re th a n 2,ooo e n ­ trants. but Hollywood’s search for a modern Cinderella cam e up with a teenager who said, “ this would be my own fairy tale.” 
Brenda Howard, 
17. of Barstow, 
Calif., won Universal Studios’ Cin­ derella contest Friday. Like Cin­ derella, she was orphaned in child­ hood and has lived with relatives ever since. 
“ I’m just a girl with sim ple d ream s,” Miss Howard wrote in the 
25-word statement that accom pan­ ied her contest application. “ One dream is to be someone special. 
C inderella is special. And this would be my own fairy tale.” 
The contest held to publicize 
Universal’s movie “ The Slipper and the Rose,” a Cinderella rem ake already completed, was announced iii ads that said “ Are you the real 
Cinderella?” 
The prize is a vacation at Yose­ mite National P ark in California and a small part in an upcoming feature film, “ High School.” 
The studio has no plans to develop the girl into a star. Miss Carroll said. “ She wants to be a park ranger.” the publicist said. 

Executions on television stir em otion 

Gunman tricked, 
8 hostages saved 

CINCINNATI (AP) - Eight hostages escaped unharm ed Saturday when a sh o tg u n -arm e d m an who had held them overnight at a home for unwed mothers was tricked into believing a police officer was the son he had not seen for 2o years. 
Jesse Coulter, 39. and his ex-wife. 
Rita (libbeon, 37. were barricaded w itll the hostages, including a p reg n an t teen-ager, iii the X ray room at the 
Catherine Booth Home for 13 hours. 
Coulter threatened to “ blow aw ay” the hostages unless the couple's son was returned, police said 
Six hostages escaped when Coulter dropped his shotgun while lighting a m arijuana cigarette. In an effort to free the last two h o s ta g e s , a police officer told the couple he was the son they gave up for adoption two decades ago at the old Catherine Booth H o sp i­ tal 
Satisfied 
“ I’m satisfied.” Mrs (iibbeon said 
"That's my son Let s (put 
Arm iii arm. the couple strolled out of the building. Police took them to jail 
( n i e i n n a ti Police Lt 
Daniel ( a s h said no c h a r g e s would be h i e d u n til 
Sunday Police said they di d not know whether Mrs (iibbeon, who now lives 

 iii I n c a . Midi . w a s a w i l l i n g p a r - 

 lie th r e a te n e d tit ‘b lo w lh em a w a y' aniens author• dies returned his situ, police sa it! 

Unpaid in the siege. 
A spokesman at the home said that. at one point. Coulter held the shotgun in the m outh of 13-year-old Sally 
Heath, the pregnant patient, for HI minutes. He doused another hostage with alcohol and threatened to ignite it but never did, the spokesman added 
Coulter, who now lives iii Detroit, had a crim inal record in M ichigan, where he pleaded guilty in 19fi9 to felonious assault during a gun battle with police. He was s e n te n c e d to three-to-four years in prison 
The episode came less than two days afte r a g u n m an in In d ia n a p o lis released unharmed the hostage he had held for three days. 
Police said Coulter, accompanied by his ex wife, entered the unwed mothers home Friday night and took seven women and one man hostage. tic threatened to “ blow them aw ay” miles-* authorities returned his son. police said 
P olice m et a second demand — allowing the gunman to talk bv telephone with a sister in Detroit 

In addition to Miss Heath, the hos­ tages w ere G race K eller, a n u rse ; 
Angela Taylor, a patient; Angela’s sis- ter, Rebecca, w ho had come to pick her up; John Fisher, a patient at a sickle cell an em ia clinic o p e ra ted by the home; and B everly J o y c e P ry o r. 
Ju a n ita Gain and Mary O w ens, all employes. 
A tactical weapons squad surround­ ed the building through the night, and some officers kept a vigil iii front of tile barricaded room. 
Late Saturday afternoon, police said. 
Coulter dropped the shotgun w hile lighting a marijuana cigarette and the gun discharged, missing everyone. Six of the hostages ran screaming from the room. 
“ It didn’t hit anybody,” said Lf. Ha­ rold Mills. “ It’s a m iracle with all those people in the room. As far as we know, he had only that one shell in his gun,” Mills said. 
Knife 
Coulter managed to hold onto two of the hostages, a man and a woman, and threatened them with a six-inch knife and a pair of scissors. At one point, firemen at the scene strung hose to the building when Coulter doused one of the two with alcohol, threatening lo set the hostage on fire. 
Coulter held the two for several ten­ sion-filled minutes, police said, until he apparently fell for the ruse iii which police officer Stephen Jennings played the part of the son. Coulter’s brother- in-law. Columbus Brown of D etroit, also helped set up the trick. 
The two hostages jumped Coulter as the gunman fell for the police trick 
Maj. David B a x e n d a le. d iv isio n com m ander of the Salvation A rm y, which operates the home, confirmed a son was born to the Coulters at the old 
Catherine Booth Hospital, which was at another location in Cincinnati. 
Other children 
Police said the former wife. who was the mother of the son. contacted the home last week and attem pted to trave her child, but was told records were confidential and unavailable. 
Police were able to piece together sketchy details without Coulter’s help 
They said he had at least three other children in Utica. Mich. 
He spoke little during negotiations with police and often had a pregnant teen ager serve as intermediary . 
Coulter taunted and h ara ssed the hostages, police said. They said one woman was kept for a tim e in hand­ cuffs. 
Mills said police had learned the tentative identity of the son. but did not 

RELEASED h o s ta g e com forted by police is 

 contact him. “ He’ll never know who his father is,” said Mills, "and that s a promise.” 
Best seller author sued 

TYLER (AP) - A S1.5 million libel suit has been filed against Thomas 
Thompson, author of “ Blood and Mon­ ey.” by a Longview police officer. 
John Raymer filed his suit earlier this week in U.S. District Court here. 
Thom pson's book deals with the circum stances surrounding and the investigation of the deaths of Dr. John 
Hill, a Houston plastic surgeon, and his wife. 
On May 15, 1974. Raymer shot and killed Bobby Vandiver, who was want­ ed by Houston police in connection with Dr Hill’s slaying. Vandiver was slain at a Longview cafe. 
Also named in Raym er’s suit were 
Doubleday, the book’s publisher, and 
North Brunch Road Corp , which holds the book s copyright. 

LOS ANGELES news? 
The idea appeals to some broadcas­ ters and leaves others cold. But the discussion is no longer academic since a federal court iii Texas ruled in favor of a TV newsman’s suit to allow film­ ing of executions although the execu­ tion in question, scheduled for Jan. 19, was postponed at the last minute. 
Of the three m ajor networks, only 
CBS has expressed a desire to film an execution — but not for im m ed ia te public viewing. 
“ We have no intention of using the film, except for our arc h iv es,” said 
Dick Salant, president of CBS news. 
“We might use it for a documentary in five or IO years.” 
Executives for NBG arid ABC say they have no plans to film executions but did not rule out the possibility that they might. Bill Sheehan, president of 
ABC news, says any decision by his network would be made case by ease. 
Tony Garrett, a newsman for Public 
Broadcast System’s HERA TY in Dal­ las. won a suit last December before 
U.S. D istrict Court J u d g e W illiam 
Taylor forcing Texas prison officials to permit film coverage of the execution of Jerry Lane Jurck, 2H. 
But even Garrett, who was in state prison with his cam era crew when Ju- rek’s death sentence was stayed, says he isn ’t su re executions should be broadcast. “ My contention all along is that it is an editorial decision. My job is to get the film to the news director.” 
However, at least two broadcasters in Amarillo, had said they would film the execution for their 111 o’clock news A third, HEDA, declined, sav ing it wouldn’t be appropriate telev ision at any time. 
“ I’d hate to look back III years and say I was chicken to do it.” said Ben 
Boyett, news director of KAMR-TV. 
“ It’s a piece of history that television would Im* able to show to p e o p le . ” 
Bill Z o rtm an . news d ir e c to r at 
KVII-TV, said, “ We want to show that capital punishment is indeed suffering and indeed does kill ... I think it will be a deterrent lo crim e if it’s handled right.” 

Good taste 

CBS’ Salant said the possible de­ terrent effect of televising an execution 
“ is a m atter of indifference to us ... 
The sole criteria should be good taste and good news judgm ent.” 
Dr. S eym our F e s h b a c k , a p s y ­ chologist at the University of Califor­ nia Los Angeles who wrote the book 
“ Television and A g g ressio n .” says data on possible viewer effect is un­ available. But he believes “ in the short run, the witnessing of an execution might act as a tem porary inhibition, like witnessing any sort of obnoxious event. But in the long run people will lose it (inhibition)” and begin to think of the death penalty as a routine event. 
Harold Streeter. 73. a veteran news­ man of nearly 5o years who has wit­ nessed seven gas cham ber executions and one hanging, goes even further. He says the public might not be shocked at all. at least by gas ch am b er execu­ tions. 
“ I think most people would be rather disappointed in a gas cham ber execu­ tion ... He (the victim) just bobbles his head a little bit and that’s all there is to it.” said Streeter, who currently works for the San Franciso Examiner. 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
An execution in living color on your IO o’clock 

Executions wanted but not on TV 
Final returns in the Express-News’ capital punishm ent balloting show readers favor executions by a large majority. 
The more than 5.ooo ballots also show readers don’t want executions telev isftl. 
Only about 3o per cent of those voting wanted executions live on TV. 
The balloting showed readers leaned more tow ards executing crim in als after Gary G ilm ore’s execution for murder by a Utah firing squad. 
Only about 12 per cent of those responding in the one-month poll were against capital punishment. 
However the poll shows that about 13 lier cent of the people still haven’t made up their minds one way or the other.

NATO eyeing 
Soviet missile 

>WNTOWN 9 3o TO 5 3o MON THRU SAT 
Ham KINO Al HUND DOWNTOWN 61 G it 
SUBURBAN 9 3o TO 6 OO m on Twiu S a ! 
Alt MAJOi C8IDIT CARO5 HONORIO 

 m a n c h e s t e r g u a r d i a n s e r v ic e 
BRUSSELS — NATO intelligence experts have detected the widespread deployment in western Russia of the 
SS2U in te rm e d ia te ran g e b allistic missile, it was revealed here Friday. 
The missile, with a range of just under 3,ooo miles, is capable of being launched from a railway car or a tracked road vehicle. 
This mobility makes it extremely difficult to detect — and knock out iii time of war 
Unlike Western equivalents, it docs not need a silo for launching The SS2o can he hidden in a railway tunnel or a barn and moved rapidly. 
Not included 
North Atlantic Alliance strategists l*nnt out that as an intermediate ucu pun, it is not included in the Strategic 
Arms Limitation T alks with the So\ let 
Union 
The negotiations a re c u r r e n tly stalled, but Secretary of State Cyrus R 
Vance will visit Moscow next month iii an attempt to get them resturtt*d 
S o u rces h ere su g g e st the SS'JU missile will be high on the list of topics 

 that Vance will want to take up with the Soviet leaders. 
The deployment of this weapon has ta k en p lace w ithin th e last four months, experts here claim. 
They say the Soviets intend to make some bot] such missiles—-BMI of which are intended for use against the Euro­ pean NATO m em ber countries, the rem ainder to be deployed in readiness against Communist China 

Iii addition, Hie Soviets can add an extra stage to the basic two-stage de­ sign of the SS2o, thus converting it into an intercontinental ballistic missile. 
The definition of ICBM* is a range of al least 4 IKR) miles 
Because of the booster possibility, sources here feel Hic SS2o should also 
Im* included in the SALT talks 
Tor their part, tile Soviets are ex­ pected to insist the SS2t) is a reply to the U S cruise missile, winch follows the contours of the ground ii traverses and. so far. is virtually imixtssible to stop once ll has been launched and targeted 
The cruise missile is also outside the defined Mope of the SALT talks. 

Under appeal 

Judge Taylor’s decision, now under appeal, was hailed as an im portant asse rtio n of te le v is io n ’s rig h t to equality with newspapers in the con­ stitutional guarantee of press freedom. 
In his decision. Taylor agreed with the Texas a tto rn e y g e n e r a l that televising an execution might be “ an offense to human dignity ... distasteful 
... or shocking.” 
But he ruled the final decision rested with TV news d ir e c to r s , not the government. 
Gary Gilmore’s execution by firing squad iii Utah last m onth ended a 
19-year moratorium on the death pen­ alty. Currently there are 358 inmates 
(»n death rows iii 29 states, but only the capital punishm ent laws of T ex as, 
F lo rid a and G eorgia have been specifically ruled acceptable by the 
I S Supreme Court, 
I ii F lo rid a, two s ta tio n s h av e requested perm ission to attend any scheduled executions, but neither has asked to bring cameras. 
In Atlanta, executives ut all three network affiliates said they were fairly confident they would not film any 
Georgia executions 
” 1 think it is a question of taste.” said Don S m ith, e x e cu tiv e new s producer of WAGA-TV. “ I'm confident it would Im* nauseating.” 

Luke Week proclaimed bv council 

By LIZ SW EET 
Councilmen Bob Billa and Richard 
Teniente Saturday presented a procla­ mation from Hu* City of San Antonio to 
Eli lac m e m b e rs d e c la rin g M onday through Saturday Dulac Week. 
At ceremonies in the Monger Hotel’s 
Cavalier Room, Teniente said there are no greater people in the com m uni­ ty than those who represent Lulac. 
Agreeing, Billa said he knows of no organization that has a nobler purpose than Lulac. 
M em bers of the League of United 
Latin American Citizens work for the betterment of the com munity with a spirit of patriotism, he said. 
“ Lulac m em bers have their hands out to help people concerned with the good of the country.” Billa said. 
Events 
The week-long events will celebrate the 48th year of Lulac's work to pro­ mote the A m erican way of life and place em phasis on citizenship, free­ dom and peace, tbt* councilman said. 
Accepting the proclam ation. Nick 
Bena. Lulac district director, said he hoped and prayed th** m em bers would bvt* up to Hie words in the document. 
As part of Dulac Week. Council No. 
948 will honor Dr. Jose San Martin, 
Red M cC om bs and Jo h n S teen iii ceremonies at 5 p.m. Wednesday in Mi 
Tierra Restaurant. 
Boh M ontalvo, C ouncil No. 64H chairman, said the three civie leaders will Im* cited for outstanding contribu­ tions to Dulac and the community. 
The three always have been espe­ cially helpful in Dulac’s efforts to raise money, he said. o ther Dulac Week activities will in­ clude a U.S. Civil Rictus Commission press conference at lo a.m. W ednesday iii the Downtown Holiday Inn and a 
Dulac reception at 7 p.in, Friday in the 
Si Anthony Hotel’s Cavalier Room.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S— Sun. Feb. 13 1977 
H 
 abuse began--------- 
PAUL S t 
THOMPSON 

 lo grasp the full rich flavor and salient facts of our roaring fire-police sick pay hassle head­ ed for a showdown in Austin 
Tuesday, let's go back to the roots. 

It s a sad story reflecting badly on certain individuals who should have known better, but home and business owners paying the freight for everything have a right to know. 
Okay: Ready: Roll ’em! 
In the old B P L (before Frank Lombardino) days, each city fire laddy and policeman got 15 - days, or three full work weeks, sick leave per year. 
That meant he could stay off duty recover­ ing from illness or injury for three weeks in any given year without being docked. 

I hus if a guy was on either force for, say. 2o 

 years, lie would have put together 2oo days of 
"accrued sick leave," less whatever days he was actually out sick. 

This accrued sick leave was insurance 

How 

 against some kind of long drawn-out malady in later stages of his career, and that's all it was. It was not cash pay he had coming in case he wasn’t sick. 

However, he could draw upon retirement a lump sum in accrued sick leave up to a top of 
9o days — a going-avvay payment of 18 full weeks salary. 
While this was a neat fringe benefit for po­ lice and firemen unavailable to other city employes, who receive no accrued sick pay at all, it wasn't good enough for some members of the police and fire departments. 

So here’s what happened in the early ’7os 

 during the administration of Mayor John Gat- ti: 

A ranking police officer with nearly 3(5 years service decided to “ ride out" his accrued sick leave of some 4oo days. 
Ile procured a doctor’s certificate stating he was ‘ill.” that is, and presented it to police higherups about a month before he was due to retire. 
Then lie went home, stayed home, enjoyed life, took hunting and fishing trips even, while remaining on the city police payroll with full pay and benefits. 
And he never did go back down to the sta- 

 sick pay 

 tionhouse to formally retire until his 4oo-plus days (O’ accrued sick leave had dwindled down to the 9o days for which he could be paid. 
Of course, while this high-minded old har­ ness bull and paladin of The Law was doing his 
"riding out," he accumulated still another 15 days ut sick leave and a like amount of paid vacation time. 

And he got away with it. 

And soon, other ranking police officers capped their law enforcement careers by picking up on the same shoddy ploy which was nothing more or less than a cold, calcu­ lated ripoff of the taxpayers. 

Some few city smokeeaters tried the same 
"riding out" scam in those years but Fire 
Chief I. O. Martinez proved a tougher admin­ istrator and kept it down to a minimum. 
So far, so good — or bad. The official posi­ tion at City Hall was one of laxity, of gross misfeasance, of unwillingness to go to the mat with these badged finaglers. 

It was into this breach that State Sen. Frank 

Lombardino stepped in 1975 with his unlimited fire-police sick pay bill which provided, still provides: 

—Everybody in both departments lias tbs 15 days sick leave per year instantly converted into cash money, collectible on retirement in a lump sum, less only such days as lie was out sick. 
— The going-avvay handout w ill be at current pay levels, meaning sick leave accrued 2(1 or 3o years back will be paid off at three, four, five or more times its value then. 
In brief, a cash bonus of three extra weeks pay a year to each of 2,2oo fire and policemen for not getting sick. 
The city simply can’t ladle out all those additional millions without hiking its tax rate significantly. 
Moreover, the city liability shoots up every year 
The real losers are police and firemen in­ jured in line of duty or who come down with a chronic illness. They’re SOAKED. 

Many rank and file members of both de­ partments, particularly the younger men, see that, deplore that, fear long range effects of 
Lombardi no's hill on fire-police civil service, and voted against the bill in recent unofficial polls. 

As for Lombardino and Jack Paul Leon, an attorney paid bv SA P!) SA FI) associations, they go right on telling the public and expect­ 

 ing the public to believe that Lomhardino's bill actually saves the city money. 
To believe that would require acceptance of two premises, both false: (I) That every po- lice-firo retiree was "riding out” s ic k leave; 
(2) That the practice of "riding out” can't be stopped. 

From 1971 to 1975, just before Friendly 
Frank’s bill went through, 754 accrued sick leave days in the police department and 3,557 accrued sick leave days in the fire department were "left on tin' table.” another way of saying the men who piled them up retired without collecting on them 

 thief Martinez, in fact, says malingering at 

 the expense of taxpayers was really not a problem in the fire department. 

And if the legal brains operating iii Texas haven’t yet come up with a means of stopping this arrant abuse, they most certain­ ly can and will, IF ASKED. 
Otherwise the flimflammers take over and we’ve all had it 
All in all. it is a courtesy to Lombardino and attorney Leon that the newspaper or TV re­ porter hearing them tell how Lomhardino's bill "saves San Antonio money" d o e sn t bust out laughing right iii their faces.

Aestivation of the theft of a 
I,(KHI grandfather clock Incur- ate Word College officials fe­ inted stolen.

By K E M P E R D IE H L 
A Texas Democratic leader confirmed longstanding reports 
Saturday that he was seriously considering a challenge to State 
Sen. Frank Lombardino in the 
1978 primary. 
Phillip Hardberger said that he feels 
Lombardino is “ vulnerable” and pro­ mised: 
"I ll definitely have my mind made up by summer.’’ 
Hardberger has been considered a possible candidate for some time. He indicated Saturday that support for such a race is being to build up behind him. 
"If I weren’t getting a lot of encour­ agement, I wouldn't be considering it." he reported, adding: 
" I feel this is a time that is ripe not only for Lomhardino’s demise, but for me as well." 
Service 
Hardberger. who grew up iii the small West Texas town of O'Donnell, established an outstanding record of government serv ice in Washington be­ fore returning to Texas to practice law. 
After graduating from Baylor, where he was editor of "T h e L a ria t." he worked for the Texas Baptist (’burel) for a time aud then obtained a masters degree in journalism from Columbia 
University. 
He was an early staffer of the Peace 
Corps and became its director of in­ formation. Later he was named exe­ cutive secretary of the Peace Corps. 
Following this he became special assistant to the director of the Office of

Shriver.

New firm 
Ile came to San Antonio in 197u and launched a law firm that is now Hard­ berger, Brantori and Herrera. 
Last year he headed the Texas cam­ paign efforts of Shriver. 
Heiberger said his interests in a 
Senate race would Im? similar to those of Ins law practice where he has been active in environmental, workmen’s compensation and consumer cases. 
I in anti ‘big,’ " said Hardberger. 
I don't like big government or lug business in terms of what they do to an individual. It s a natural by-product of our society that things get bigger. But the individual gets ground up." 

He said of the possible race that "I don’t approach this as a pushover." 
Last week State Hep. Bob Vale, the county s senior state legislator, an­ nounced he was a serious possibility .

Blockade

House had imposed on us. They had a 
‘Well, we'd belter wail’ attitude.

Sanction

"I cannot condone the failure to ac­ count for public funds and tin* willful disregard of House rules by this man" 
Gonzalez said

Accountability

San M arcos’ gas 

 iPtC IA l IO IMI I KRRtSS N tW S 
SAN MARCOS — A majority of resi­ dents here remained without natural gas Saturday after a fire destroyed a gas company regulator station 

Police said a ear struck the Flit ex, 
Inc. regulator station outside of town about ll p.m. Friday, touching off an explosion and fire winch completely destroyed the station. 

The driver of tile car escaped with second-degree burns to the body 
A spokesman for Fntex, winch supplies San Marcos with natural gas. 

 said Hie gas system has been restored and workmen are iii the process of getting service started at individual homes and businesses 
The blast cut oil service lo about 
4 (MMI customers here, the spokesman said. Only a small portion of the city was not affected, he added 
Kntcx crews worked through the night to restore the gas service, the s|MikcKinan said 
More than 5(1 extra workmen were brought rn from South 
Texas to help 
"It s slow work, lull we should have service to all customers restored by late Saturday." the spokesman said

Dist. 6 hopefuls present issues 

By ALAN BAILEY 

D rain ag e and the proposed gas settlement were the two big issues discussed Satu rd ay by candidates for the City 
Council’s District 6. 
The district includes the heart of the West Side plus the Kelly and Lack­ land AFBs area. 
The gathering of seven candidates at Gus Garcia 
Middle School, 33o6 Ruiz 
S t., w as sponsored by 
Concerned Citizens for 
City Council D istrict 6 and the Edgewood School 
District. 
P a b lo E s c a m illa , a trustee of the school dis­ tr ic t, introduced each can d id ate and allowed each five minutes to give a campaign pitch, plus field ing two questions from the some 5o citi­ zens. 
Four file 
Four of the seven can­ didates have fo rm ally filed while three candi­ dates have announced hut are aw aiting the filing. 
Candidates who have filed and were present included Hay Brow n. 
Jesse R. Diaz, Ja m es J. 
Kelly and Rudv C. Ortiz. 
Councilman Al Rohde, 
David L. Alvardo and 
Robert Lozano have not yet filed, but have a n ­ nounced their intentions to seek the D is trict 6 post. 
Two candidates. Jo se 
Esto la and Bob Thomp­ son. have filed but were not present. 
After giving IO reasons why he opposed the gas settlement, Ortiz showed a list of 16 issues and problems in District 6. 
The issues ranged from a proposed City Hall annex in District 6 to property improvements to an in­ dustrial park. 

Drainage 
Kay Brown said the main problem in the dis­ trict was drainage, and as a m em ber of the council she would work for better drainage. 
Rohde, who was elect­ ed at-large under the old council system, attacked the proposed gas settle­ ment. 
Gas 
“ I have never supported the gas settlem en t. It stinks so bad for San An­ tonio in its present form that I want to wear a gas mask every time I look at it or hear about it. For the best interest of the people of San Antonio, the gas settlement should be sent to the g a s chamber along with Os­ car Wyatt & Co.,” Rohde declared 
He re fe rre d to the proposed out-of-court settlement of the city ’s 
$4H7 million damage suit ag a in st C oastal S ta te s 
Gas Corp. and its board chairman, Wyatt. 
Kelly, a black, empha­ sized the need for unity among the various races of the district and to elect the best person reg ard ­ less of color. 
Stepchild 
Diaz said District 6 has been the stepchild of San 
Antonio and “ no one re­ m em bers us until e le c ­ tion (la y .” 
Diaz also cam e (tut ag ainst the move of Kelly Field Na­ tional 
B ank to 
Leon 
Valley. 
A lvardo, a fo rm e r member of the Edgewood school hoard, urged g re a te r cooperation between the various go­ vernments. 
The group allowed 
John Monfrey. a can d i­ date for mayor, to speak even though candidates for mayor had not been muted. 
M onfrey said he was glad to see a meeting of d istrict ca n d id ates b e ­ cau se he favored the election by d is tr ic ts 
Election by districts, he said, makes candidates responsive to the district and not special interest 
| groups.

ERIE, Pa. (AP) — Bob 
Bliss and Brian Kinal, ignoring warnings from the Coast Guard about thin ice, began a hike across frozen Lake Erie 
Saturday, 

Joined to one another by a rope and to shore by a citizens band radio, the 
; two men kissed their women goodby and set out al dawn for Long 
Point, O n !., 24 m iles away 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— -Sun. Feb. 13 1 9 7 7 
H ress caught 

 in energy dilemma 

I C S A N G U t S T IM E S SER V ICE 
WASHINGTON - Tho United States can't ha\e cheap fuel, a clean envir­ onment and protection from foreign petroleum imports all at the same time, according to the Congressional 
Budget Office. 
The goals are desirable, hut directly contradictory, and Congress faces tin' hard task of choosing among them, the office said Saturday in a study of energy policy alternatives. 
‘ The low-priced abundant supply of energy is no longer available, nor is it 

 ever likely to he again.” said Alice 
Hiving director of the agency. "The problem is more fundamental than the temporary cold weather.” 
A nonpartisan adviser of Congress, the budget office provides the law­ makers with background papers and studies, but never submits recommen­ dations. 

Thus its KJ page survey of energy policy pointed to the various dilemmas facing the current congress, which must decide on auto emission sta n­ dards. oil and gas price controls. 

 subsidies for synthetic fuels and allo­ cation of research funds among nu­ clear power, solar energy and conser­ vation programs. 

In sorting out these problem s tin* 
CUO study said. Congress will face irreconcilable conflicts. 
The CUO calculated the impact of five different packages emphasizing environm ental protection, stre s sin g reduction of imports, keeping costs to consumers as low as possible, relying on the fret' market with no price con­ trols, and continuing current policies. 
Who has the next move? 

Y O U N G and old compete S aturday in Ft. Sam Houston’s second annual U.S. Chess F ederation Rated Chess Tournam ent. W . 
Poundstone Jackson, le ft, matches wits w ith Stephanie Mikkelson during a chess match. — S ta ff Photo by Joe Barrera Jr. 
Threats make 
Frisco’s City 
Hall a fortress 

N E W V O R K T IM E S SE R V IC E 
SAN FRANCISCO — A series of bombings and threats by one of the Bay area's more enigmatic terrorist groups has succeeded in grabbing public- attention and frightening private and public leaders to the extent that City Hall is armed like a fortress and top city officials have 24-hour police protection. 
No one iii this a r e a has yet been killed or seriously injured in the more t h a n 41) b o m b i n g s and a t t e m p t e d bombings over the last two and a half years that the New World Liberation 
Front has said it was responsible for. 
But that m ay be m o r e luck than planning, more fate than policy, be­ cause m any of the explosions w ere powerful enough to m aim or kill. 
A s p o k e s m a n for M ayor G eo rg e 
Moscone called the City Hall security m easures unfortunate but necessary and added that the mayor "does not view them as permanent, only neces­ sary until we catch them or they move away." 
Metal detectors 
The tightening of access to City Hall 
— there are metal detectors at the en­ trances and the corridors are patrolled by teams of policemen — indicates the seriousness with which local, state and federal officials have come to take the terrorist bomb threats. 
Policemen were assigned to guard the ll m e m b e r s of th e B o a rd of 
Superv iso rs a fte r a b o m b m is fire d outside the home of Supervisor Dianne 
Feinstein on Dec. 14. 
The mayor, district attorney and Ci­ ty Hall were added to the protection list late last month after the bombing of District Attorney Joseph F re ita s 
.Jr.'s car in front of Ins home, death threats were m a de against five city officials and an assistant United States attorney, and after shots were fired into the real estate office of Supervisor 
John Barbagelata 
All these attacks came within days of the indictment and arrest of Jacques 
Rogiers. a self-styled courier for the underground terrorists who belongs to an alleged nonviolent above-ground unit of th e New W orld L ib e ra tio n 
Front. 
Reluctant 
Law enforcement officials are reluc­ tant to discuss publicly how much they know about the New World Liberation 
Front, although they hint, as one city official said. " W e know a lot m ore about the terrorists than they think we know." 
"The problem of telling the public where we are at in an investigation is that we are also telling the terrorists." said Jam es L. Browning Jr., the I lilt­ ed States attorney for Northern Cali­ fornia who successfully prosec uted 
Patricia Hearse 
Although some leftist groups believe that the New World g ro u p m ay be c o m p o se d of r ig h t-w i n g " p r o v o c a ­ teurs." most law enforcement officials aud inform ed citizens a s s u m e that they are inheritors of the left-wing 
FAA probing chopper deals 

N E W V O R K T IM E !, SER V ICE

 terrorist practices that have existed in this area since tin' mid-19Hos. 
The most famous of these groups was the one that called itself the Sym- bionese Liberation Army, which kid­ napped Miss Hearst three years ago. 
But there have been m any others, including the Heil Guerrilla Family, the Black Guerrilla F am ily and Hie 
Emiliano Zapata Unit, that have taken credit for the hundreds of bombings in tilt* area in the 197os. 
It is generally believed that the New 
World Liberation F ront, which has used more than nine unit names since its first claim of a bombing attempt in 
August 1974. congealed around Emily and W illia m H a r r i s and P a t r i c i a 
Hearst after tin* SLA was all but des­ troyed d u r i n g th e shootout in Los 
Angeles a few months (‘arber. 
A tape recordin g m a de by H arris after the shootout said the group was taking up Hu* outfit's banner. 
Radicals who have provided as sis­ tance to earlier groups were drawn to more decisive action by the Harrises, according to this analysis, and even­ tually beg a n using b o m b i n g s as a means to denounce American involve­ ment in Chile and tin* role of large 
American corporations both at home and abroad. 
Only one unit 
Most officials believe there is only one underground unit in the NU LF and the name changes are meant to imply a larger, m o n diverse organization than really exists. 
Browning said that the whole organ­ ization probably " h a s less than IOO hard core m em b ers" and others, who would not be quoted directly, put the number to less than 5o. "closer bi 25” . 
Everyone interviewed m a in ta in ed that an effective group actually need have only two or three m em bers, in­ telligent and dedicated, to create the current atmosphere of fear in which the New World units claim credit for half the bombing attempts i i i northern 
California 
The focus on slums and health de­ m a n d s has o c c u r r e d , a c c o r d i n g to radicals observing the N U L F from outside. Iiecause of tin* terrorists need to build a more popular base among the poor and radicals.

WASHINGTON — A Federal Avia­ tion Administration spokesman says the agency is conducting a continuing investigation into allegations that sub­ standard helicopter parts were being sold for m ilitary fleets of foreign countries. 
" W e’ve had an investigation going on for several weeks and it is still continuing.** the spokesman said

U.S. REP. Gonzalez delivers keynote speech at dedica tion facilities 
Hospital lauded at em ergency room dedication

Regular 89'-99'* .... 2 for 1.5o 

Emergency facilities are so­ mething most Americans take for granted until they have need for them, U.S. Rep. Henry B. 
Gonzalez said Saturday. 
“ But they can be great aids,” Gon­ zalez said at the dedication of the new em ergency room facilities at Lutheran 
General Hospital at 7o1 S. Zarzamora st. 
“ Those who have contributed to this project have complied with the m a n ­ date of civilized man to do what he can for his brother.” Gonzalez said. 
“ We have many m ore doctors and facilities than we had just a few years ago.” Gonzalez said. “ But the need is great.” 
“ The average American is confront­ ed with the fact that he is being priced out of average medical c are.” 

Total cost of the project, which ad­ ded n e a rly 9,7oo s q u a re fee t, w as 
$o89,ooo. The completion of the project has upgraded the em ergency room ’s rating from class III to class II. 
Need recognized 
“ I think the completion of this pro­ ject indicates San Antonio recognizes the need for finest facilities where tile m a jo rity of c itiz e n s need t h e m , ’’ 
Mayor Lila Cockrell said. 
Project construction included tra u ­ ma room s, ex am in atio n room s, bed observation and holding areas, a cast room , e m e rg e n c y w a itin g ro o m , a n u rses’ station, ad m ittin g office, la­ boratory and radiology c a p ab ilitie s and a cardiac stress testing laboratory. 
The h o sp ital now p ro v id e s e m e r ­ gency coverage 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

The two c o u n trie s a lre a d y h av e ag reed on tra n s fe rrin g to P a n a m a jurisdiction over the Canal Zone within three years alter a new treaty goes into effect. This would give Panam a auth­ ority o v er all s e rv ic e s — su c h as education and the ad m in istratio n of justice — which are now controlled by the United States under the existing 
19o3 treaty. 
The chief rem aining differences in the negotiations center on duration of a new trea ty and on the q u e s tio n of lion-discriminatory access for all na­ tions to the canal once Panam a gains control. 
TIr* Ford administration reportedly was willing to grant Panam a control over the operation of the canal within 
2o years and defense rights within 4o years.

War prisoner conduct rules may be changed 

WASHINGTON (A P ) 
— Any future U.S. war p riso n e rs would be a l ­ lowed to give more infor­ mation than name. rank, service number and birth date if the Carter adm in­ istra tio n a c c e p ts a special Pentagon panel s recommendations. 
However, the proposed change in the M ilitary 
Code of Conduct would still leave in force a re q u ire m e n t th a t a captured American s e r ­ viceman “ evade answer­ ing further questions to the utmost” of his abili­ ty 
In g e n e ra l, the P e n ­ tagon panel found that the code, written in 1955 after the Korean War, “ is a valid and n e c e s sa ry instrument which estab­ lishes high standards of behavior for all m embers of the a.rmed services." 
It said som e V ietn am war prisoners “ attribut­ ed their very survival to the inspiration provided by the code of conduct.’* 

Anniversary 

The Pentagon com m it­ tee’s report, calling for the first code change in more than 'JO years, was m ad e a v a ila b le S a t u r ­ day, the fourth anniver­ sary of North V ietnam 's release of U.S. pilots and other servicemen im pri­ soned during the South­ east Asia war 
The rec o m m e n d e d changes involve only two w ords of the s ix - p a r a ­ graph code. 
The p re se n t v ersio n says: “ I am bound to give only name, rank, service n u m b e r, and d a te of birth.” 
T he c o m m itte e 

 recom m ended changing 
“ bound” to “ req u ire d ” because it felt the word bound is archaic and not easily understood by ser­ vicem en with lim ite d education. 
Key change 

The key change would drop th e word ‘‘o n ly ” from the sentence, which would then read: “ I am required to give nam e, ran k , serv ic e n u m b e r, and date of b irth ,” and 
•would no longer indicate that this is the only in­ form ation that m ay be supplied under extrem e duress. 
T h e re w ere no legal penalties in the code it­ self for any violations 
H owever, the s e p a r a te 
Uniform Code of Military 
.Justice provides p en al­ ties for actions, such as co lla b o ra tin g with the en em y , that could in elude violations of the 
Code of Conduct. 
The 
G eneva convention, the tre a ty covering the treatm en t and re sp o n sib ilities of p riso n e rs of w ar, requires the information enum erated in the Code of Conduct. 
Disputes 

The new study followed disputes am ong form er 
POWs over just what the code required of them . 
Those disputes started in the prison c a m p s and continued a fte r lib e r a ­ tion. 
T he 
11-m e m b e r c iv ilia n -m ilita ry c o m ­ m itte e , in c lu d in g four former POWs, completed its report last November but the Ford adm inistra­ tion left it for the Carter 

 a d m in is tra tio n to co n ­ sider. The new Pentagon le a d e rsh ip h as begun e v a lu a tin g the r e c o m ­ mendations. 
The 3o-page report by the c o m m itte e says: 
“ The c o m m itte e c o n ­ cluded that the Code of 
Conduct and re la te d tra in in g m u s t -become more realistic co n c ern ­ ing a PW’s disclosure of in fo rm a tio n .” At the same time, it urged “ in­ te rro g a tio n r e s is ta n c e training ... base‘d on suc­ cessiv e lines of r e s is ­ tan ce and a ‘r e b o u n d ’ philosophy.” 
'Bounce back' 

E x p la in in g th is , the report said: “ A PW who is coerced into g iv in g more information than he feels he should must not allow h im self to feel 
‘broken* but m ust 
‘bounce back.' continue to resist and provide as little information as pos­ sible during subsequent interrogations ” 
A fter rev iew in g the 
1955 proceedings which led to the code, the com­ mittee said in effect that th e o rig in al a u th o rs never in ten d ed 
U.S. 
POWs to hold oui at all costs. 
“ Experience of PVVs in h ands of C o m m u n ist ca p to rs d u rin g the Ko­ rean War made it clear that a skilled and deter­ mined interrogator could extract virtually any in­ form ation he w an te d ," the report said. 
Realistic 
‘‘T he 1955 ad v iso ry co m m itte e d esig n ed guidance to insure that our se rv ic e m en u n d e r­ stood this fact and to as­ 

 sis t th e m in r e s is tin g such in te rro g a tio n realistically rather than dogmatically.” 
The current committee found that the individual armed services varied in their views of the code s meaning, often m isinter­ preting it. 
T h is led to w ide differences in p r e p a ra ­ tion of men for possible capture, the report said, and “ these differences often cau sed frictio n w ithin a g ro u p of p r i ­ soners.” 
To c o rre c t th is , the panel recommended that 

 training on the Code of 
Conduct be cen tralized under the office of secre­ tary of defense. 

The panel proposed a n u m b er of a d m in is tra ­ tive directives to elim in­ ate ambiguities and clar­ ify policies re la tin g to 
POW conduct. 

The committee recom ­ mended that the Code of 
C onduct should not be converted into a law . 
“ B ehavior cannot be effectively legislated, but it can be affec ted by tra in in g and le a d e r ­ ship,” the report said.

New Lu lac group plans mayoral forum 

The Northside Sun Antonio Lu lacs (League of 
United Latin American Citizens) was chartered 
Saturday durum a Lulac National Supreme Council meeting in Houston 
New president of the Northside Lu lacs is Javier 
Banales. 
Other officers are Margaret Rios, vice president; 
Robert Tame/, secretary. Cruz Chavirra. treasurer. 
Rebecca Barrera, parliamentarian, and Santiago 
Mendoza, chaplain. 
The new council has 21 members, who are all residents of the North Sid** me .Winside Lulaes has begun to plan its first major activity, a public forum tor candidates for mayor 
The public forum will be March 17 at Trinity 
University, and it will be open to the public. 
Lulac was first formed in 1929 and now has councils iii more I hun 3o states

EASTER SEAL C ha irperson M rs. 
John Steen Sr. poses with B exar 
County Easter Seal child Jake V a ­ lenzuela, age 6 

Nell Steen to run Easter 
Seal drive 

Civic leader Mrs. Nell Steen has been named chairperson of the 1977 Easter Sea 
Campaign in San Antonio and Bexar Coun­ ty. 
Jerome K Harris Sr., president of the Bexar 
County Easter Seal Society, said Mrs. Steen will lead about 4.o99 v olunteers iii the annual appeal for funds conducted by the Easter Seal Society for Crippled 
Children and Adults of Bexar County, Inc. 
The Easter Seal Campaign will begin March I and continue through Easter Sunday, April IO. 
“I am deeply honored to take on this responsible role. The Easter Seal Society is a voluntary agency which has taken leadership in providing help for the handicapped for some 25 years, and the needs for rehabilitation are growing,” said Mrs. Steen. 
Mrs. Steen has taken active roles in the Junior 
League of San Antonio. Battle of Flowers Assn , 
Fiesta San Antonio Commission. San Antonio Con- servation Society, Charity Ball Assn and numerous other civic organizations. She is married to John 
Thomas Steen Sr. and is the mother of five children 
The Easter Seal Campaign is conducted annually bv 234 local affiliates of the Easter Seal Society for 
Crippled Children and Adults of Texas. 
In Bexar County during 197(5. 343 children and adults received 2(5.o51 treatments of physical ther­ apy. occupational therapy and speech therapy at the 
Easter Seal Center. 2818 South Pine St.

THE ROCKY MOUNTAIN MAN 
Rabies in bats jumps in East 

ATLANTA (A P ) - An unusual, but nut alarm ­ ing. concent rat ion of rabies in bats has been reported in the North­ east. the national Cent er­ ror Disease Control says. researchers say they do not know whether t he* upswing reflects an ac­ tual increase iii the dis­ ease or a greater public awareness of the prob­ lem 
Rabies iii animals lias posed a greater threat to humans iii recent years and bats are a m ajor source of exposure, the 
CPC said. 
Native 
Hats are native throughout the I Tilted 
States and rabies among them generals has been evenly distributed. 
However, for the third quarter of la s t year — duly, August and Sep­ tember, the latest figures available — rabies iii bats showed a marked increase iii the N orth­ east. 
For that period, .‘{ti cases were reported iii 

Hollies iii a n im a ls has p o se d a g re a te r threat to hum ans iii recent years a m i hats are a m a jo r source o f exposure* the CAH] sa id 

 of humans treated for rabies last year, but in 
1975 about 3o,ooo su­ spected cases wore treat­ ed 
Since 197o. only one in 
Lf rabies victim s has siirv iv cd. Of these, four had been bitten by bats 
The only fatality caused by rabies from bats last year involved a 
55-year-old woman in northeast Maryland. She had been bitten on a linger as she brushed away a bat which landed on her apron 
The bal was captured and found to be rabid. 
The woman began treat­ ment 44 hours later. The 
CPC recommends that treatment begin w it Inn 24 

 h o u rs after exposure. 
One thing that has concerned public health officials iii the Northeast is that bats seem to be getting into houses more often. 
“ We have received a lot of complaints of bats in residences iii that area,” 
Bak er said. 
“ Maybe this has been a problem iii the past, but people are just beginning to report it/*_____________ 

M aryland. 17 in New 
Jersey. 15 in Delaware and 14 in eastern New 
York. 
That compared with 52 cases in California, 32 iii 
Florida and .‘IK in Texas 
— all scattered over a much greater area. 
In the first quarter of last year. 549 cases of rabies iii all anim als were reported from 32 static. 
Figures for previous periods were not availa­ ble immediately. 

No explanation 
“ We don't know why the increase.” said Dr. 
Fverctte Baker, a veter­ inary epidemiologist at the CIX'. “ We don't know if it is an increase iii rabies iii bats or if it is an increase iii the report­ ing.” 
Baker said the CPC has no reports on the number

Drifting out o f bounds 

A 9o-foot high hot air balloon drifts over western Brooklyn in New York Saturday en route to a landing near Jam aica Bay. The pilot, Sidney Cutter, 43, of Albuquerque, N .M ., was ticketed for flying too low and for landing at other than an airfield. — AP Wirephoto

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. 13 1977 

Miss Black San Antonio 

TRACY MITCHELL, who wants to become a registered nurse, has been crowned Miss 
Black San Antonio in ceremonies which lasted until early Saturday at the Carver 
Cultural Center. Miss M itchell, whose hobbies include skating, sewing and dancing, sang 
Mr. M elody” during the talent portion of the contest. The outgoing 
M iss Black San Antonio was Donna 
Spence and the contest is sponsored by 
Miss Black San Antonio Board, Inc. — 
Staff Photo by Steve Campbell. 

 changing direction 

W A SH IN G T O N (A P ) 
— The rodent! govern­ ment's new program for battling urban blight lot uses on preventing marginal neighborhoods from d eteriorating further rather than rebuilding low-income, inner-city neighbor­ hoods. according to two new reports 
The two studies of the 
M 2-billion federal Com­ m unity 
Developm ent program, including one by the Brookings Institu­ tion released Saturday, conclude that poverty neighborhoods fared bet­ ter under Model Cities projects initiated iii the lHtitis. Other sections of the cities are faring bet­ ter. 
In cities around the country*, there has been a shift. I'm it Ii iii funding and decision-making, “ away from the poorest pimple and areas to a more mixed pattern,” says the 
Brookings report 
Congress and the 
< arter admininistration are expected to study that trend when tilt* 
Community Development 
\ct of 1974 comes up for renewal later this year. 
Focus shifts 
A separate study by researchers at the liar- vard-M IT Jo in t Center tor Lilian Studies agreed with the 
Brookings conclusion that the focus of the com m unity development programs 
How being funded by the 
Department of Housing and I ’rbun Development has changed from social services, such as Ileal!Ii or education, to short­ term capital spending, such as for parking lots or downtown rehabilita­ tion. 
“ Issues of who should benefit and how benefits should be provided have been raised by those favoring social ser­ vices," said the Brook­ ings study. “ It was, in fact, this point of view that ted to the adoption i i i 
I HHH of the Model titles program — the premise tieing that saving cities involves saving people. 
S.KiaI services spending 

 between investments in the poorest areas versus what are considered transitlonal neighbor­ hoods.” 
The IHIilis anti poverty programs in H LD were replaced iii 1974 by com­ munity developm ent grants which give cities mnnty for a variety of projects with few strings attatched 
The Brookings report 
Naid 29 per cent of those funds currently go to aid low-income persons. 
Because the program eliminated many federal requirem ents that pro­ gram s aul the poverty stricken, many cities are using their federal funds for community-w ide projects. 
Keel tape 
The 
H arvard -M IT 
Jo in t Center says the 
( nmmunity Development 
Act has had dram atic success iii reducing red tape in federal programs, but the analysts conclude the benefits were “ at tile expense of the poor. 
“ Community Develop­ ment is doing less than ll eotild, and much less than Model Cities did to give poor people a piece of the action,” said Ber­ nard Frieden and M ar­ shall Kaplan of the Joint 
Center 
“ Between 
19H8 and 
1972, tile Model Cities st-nt 18 per cent of IIL D ’s total com m unity development aid budget into poverty neighbor­ hoods. According to one study, only 12 lier cent of current com m unity development funds are going into com parable low-income areas ” 
Brookings' research team, led by senior econ­ omist Bichord Nathan. concluded that 
“ the block grant program is a better instrum ent for aiding transitional neighborhoods and preventing blight than were the fold-tn grants, but ii is more limited an instrum ent for redeveloping the most 
.seriously deteriorated urban areas." 
P a tric ia 
H arris, 
Carter’s H LD secretary, says she will seek an ex­ tension of the 1974 legis­ lation. hut with a i hance 

 i i i the funding formula that w ill target more money to needy cities 
The Brookings report. which suggests that the pity steal deterioration ut a city bt* considered in determining how much money a com m unity should receive, was paid fur bv U LU 

Who benefit 

 r.

EXPRESS NEWS CAPITOt BUREAU 
AUSTIN — After three full weeks of legislative action. Gov. Dolph 
Briscoe appears to be at the top of the batting column. 
His most cherished hills, like the high­ way financing h ill (HH .‘I) and Omnibus 
Courts B ill, have up to now met little re­ sistance from legislators in cither House. 
Even threats that Briscoe's highway hill would drain too much of the state's giant spending surplus too soon in the session haven't hurt the governor’s legislative program. 
The highway h ill whizzed through the 
House last week, passing by a convincing vote of 121-27. The h ill goes before the 
Senate Finance Committee Tuesday. 
The highway hill would clear Hit* way for a transfer of over $6o6 m illion into the highway department over the next bien­ nium. 
The funds would come from existing revenue derived from sales of vehicles, lubricating oils and tires. 
Meanwhile, Bexar County's 15-member delegation in both houses have run up their total number of hills introduced to the 12o mark. 
By Friday, the House had 1.oo7 bills on record In the Senate 561 hills have been introduced

O ral R o b e rts kin die in plane erasli 

ANTHONY. Kart. (AP) — A daughter and son-in-law of evangelist Oral Roberts were among six persons killed when a private plane carrying them home from a ski holi­ day in Colorado crashed near her. author­ ities said 

Rebecca Roberts Nah, 37. and her hus­ band. Marshall. 38, died when the twin-en- gine Piper Navajo airplane went down in heavy rain Friday night, cutting a swath about threequarters of a mile long through a muddy wheat field on a farm 6>2 miles south of Anthony.

ASSOCIAUO PRISS 
V\ itIi his Southeast Texas drawl, drooping forelock and good old boy grin. Wayne Peveto is an unlikely .Jeremiah. 
He slipped on lits h air sh irt last week. however, and laid on the bad news about "int new taxes.” 
You can't meet all legitim ate de­ mands for new state spending and grant relief from some of the more onerous state and local taxes without new sources of revenue, lie told the 
House. 
M od erate 
Not that Peveto, a moderate Demo­ crat from Orange, wants new taxes. He merely was doing his hest to delay 
Gov. [jolph Briscoe’s bill to strip $561.2 m illion from other state programs and perm anently dedicate auto-related sales tax revenue to highways. The bill passed, however, and now awaits 
Senate action. 
The Legislative Budget Board’s re­ commended general appropriation bill leaves SI IN billion on the table for other spending, lit' pointed out. 
Then Peveto added up the demands on that money; 
• Highways, the $585.1 m illion d if­ ference between Briscoe’s total pro­ gram and th** LBB's recommendation. 
• School finance, a $749.2 m illion difference. 
► Teacher pay raise, not recom ­ mended by the governor or the LHB but sought not only by leachers but bv powerful coalition of vhool admin­ istrators’ organizations. $385 m illion. 
• Kepeal of the sales tax on u tility bills, a Briscoe recommendation. $216 million. 
• Inheritance tax relief, the goal of many rural-based organizations with political clout, a conservative estimate of $36 million. 
‘‘There is not enough money here to go around and fund a ll these p ro ­ grams. Father we will have to reduce 

'There is not enough m oney here to go a ro u n d a n il fu n d a ll these p r o g r a m s P e v e to s a id . 
No one lins c h a l­ lenged his figures 

 the LBB recom m endations by $786 million or have a $786 m illion tax b ill," 
Beveto said. 
Nobody has challenged Peveto's f i­ gures. 
“ Let me tell you about this 
Legislative Budget Board,” he said, rattlin g off the names of its almost u n ifo rm ly conservative m em bers, starting with Ll. Gov. B ill Hobby and 
Speaker B ill Clayton. 
“ These people are not spendthrifts. I don t think you can go through and cut the LBB budget by $7N6 m illion. Tile fat*s not ln-there." he said. 
It all went to show that even a $966 million surplus and projected general revenue growth of $2 billion really a r­ en’t infinite. 
Hep. Bill Hollowed. D-Grand Saline, had something to say about the options to Hep. .lim Faster, D-Fl Paso, a sup­ porter of the highway hill. 
“ I am going ti* get with Mr. Faster and find out what he wants to cut from the Cmversity of Texas at El Paso, and 
I am going to accommodate h im ." said Hollowed, a member of the House 
Appropriations Committee. 

And Hep. H ill S ullivant. D-Gatnes- viJle. had the quote of the week about the teachers’ demands. If you missed it before, here it is. 
“ We are going to give a teacher pay raise. Some of you new members mai­ llot believe it but just ask the older ones. I know the governor says you don't have to give one. hut political realities are such that if you believe that, on hts word you would believe the aurora borealis is a flashlight in the hands of an Eskimo."

Every Day in the Expren. 

A M O NO FLEX ROOF is being applied to this house, that will not only seal the surface against leaks, but will also insulate it against heat and cold. A Monoflex roof can save you hundreds of dollars by reducing your utility costs over the years. No matter what type of roof you have, Monoflex can be expertly applied directly over your old roof, whether it’s shingles, gravel, metal, or roll roofing. Monoflex can also be applied on your exterior walls for extra insulation. 
Stop by Coating Specialists at 
1181S 
Warfield or call 349 -6 2 o4 for a courteous estimate.! 
(Rd. Adv,)

OOOO MONDAY, FtBBUABY 1 4 (E-N) j 
Arabs clamp down on rebels 

COMPILED FROM WIRE SERVICES 
B E IR U T , Lebanon — 
Arab nations imposed drastic new curbs on 
Palestinian guerrillas 
Saturday to try to bring the entire resistance movement under firm 
Syrian and Lebanese control. 
The decision aims at ending Lebanon's role as the last unrestricted commando base with far-reaching effects on 
Palestinian ability to wage war and influence 
Arab policy. 
Although the 
Arab countries did not an­ nounce details of the res­ trictions, it was learned the provisions would res­ trict substantial armed commando presence to specified border regions near Israel. This means an end to fortifications of 
15 refugee camps that had become self-ruled states within a state.

SANAA. North Yemen 
— American weapons are arriving for the first time in North Yemen, putting this country firmly in the pro-Washington 
Arab camp and signaling a decline of Russian in­ fluence. 
Until the first U.S. weapons arrived, the 
Soviet Union had been 
Yemen’s exclusive arms supplier for 22 years

W A SH IN G TO N 
- 
South African Ambassa­ dor ILF. Botha advised 
Secretary of State Gyrus 
Vance Saturday that a negotiated settlement re­ mains possible for 
Rhodesia 
“ The only alternative is war and conflict and bloodshed,” Botha told newsmen after the 
75-minute session at the 
State Department 
Botha gave Vance a report from South Afri­ can Prime Minister John 
Yorster on Yorster’s meeting last Wednesday) in Capetown with Prime 
Minister lull Smith of 
Rhodesia. 
“ The gist of it is,” 
Botha said, “ that we lie- lieve there are possibi­ lities w hic h might lead to a negotiated settlement.”

MOSCOW — The Sun id 
L iihhi has defended it* current campaign J against dissidents, den­ ouncing them as pawns in a coordinated Western assault on detente and socialism. 
The arguments, con­ tained iii a lengthy edi­ torial in the Communist party newspaper Pravda. formed the most com­ prehensive response to date to the Carter ad­ ministration criticisms of Soviet human rights v adat ions 
Branding dissidents out sicken enemies of so­ cialism. Pravda said they 
“ are just a handful of individuals who do not represent anyone or an­ villing and the> are fat from the Soviet people 
What is more, they exist only because they are supported, paid and praised bv the West

Vernon Bippert, IT. daughter of Mr. and M rs. ernor E. Bippert of 
Floresville, showed the hampion broilers in the ready-to-cook poultry show of the San Antonio 
Livestock Show and Ro­ deo Saturday. 
A 23-pound turkey en­ tered by Sharon Meier of the Johnson City Future 
Farmers of America was named c hampion turkey. 
Miss Bippert. a junior it 
Floresville 
High 
School, has been feeding birds for six years but this was her first win in the San Antonio show. 
She is a member of the 
Wilson County 4-H. lier three broilers weighed IO pounds, 14 ounces. 

Top turkey

23 pounds. It was the second straight win for Johnson 
City in the turkey contest as Ted Artlike won it in

A bull consigned in Donald Haynes of Pleasanton was judged champion bull in the fourth annual futurity sponsored by the South Texas Brahman 
Assn. Saturday ut the leone Star Livestock Commis­ sion Co. 
The champion hull was bought by George Wilson of Hondo for $2,ooo. the top price of the day, in the sale that followed the futurity. 
The 124 Brahmans in the sale brought $o5,OOO. an average of $771 per head. Sixty-one bulls sold for 
$5o,34o, an average of $825 lu r head, and the o3 females sold for $45,2oo, an average of $718 per head.

Success was a long time coming 

Rv urn I.,, . . __ 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S— Sun. Feb. 13 I 977 

By WILEY ALEXANDER 
It took Mickey Gilley 15 years to become an overnight success 
Yet, a success he is and San Anton­ ians can see why when he unpacks his unusual style for a three-day perfor­ mance at the Rodeo beginning Monday night,. 
The past three years have seen six of 
CI ii ley’s records and three of his al­ bums hit the top spot on C&VV charts 
His style resembles that of his first cousin, .Jerry Lee Lewis. As a matter of a fact. Gilley used to be introduced as .Jerry Lee Lewis cousin. Not any more. Now. .Jerry Lee is introduced as 
Mickey Gilley's cousin. 
“ Tile past three years have been un­ believable,” Gilley said from his motel loom in ( a ii ad a during a telephone 
. interview. 
On tour 
(iiiley is on a tour of Canada with 
Loretta Lynn. He will be at the rodeo 
Monday through Wednesday, then head out for the County Music Festival 
Awards show Thursday where lit* is up for awards in five different categories. 
“ I'm real excited about the awards show.” Gilley said. “ I'm1 been nomin-x ated for entertainer of the year, male vocalist of the year, song of the year, album of the year and record of the year.” 
Gilley’s climb up the fame ladder started in 1974 when he recorded un old 
George Morgan song, "Room Full of 
Roses.” The song took off and became 
Gilley’s first number one hit. 
Five other number one songs fol­ lowed, ‘‘I Overlooked an Orchid,” 
"City Lights.” "Window l ’p Above.” 
"Bring It on Home to Me.” and "Don’t 
All the Girls Look Pretty at Closing 
Time.” 
His “ Bring It on Home to Me” is in nomination as record of the year and 
"Don’t All the Girls Look Pretty at 
Closing Time” is up for song of the year. 
‘Smoking' 

His album "Smoking” is nominated as album of the year. 
His latest single. "She’s Pulling Me 
Back Again.” already has hit the na­ tional charts and appears headed to the top. 
Gilley has come a long way since he and .Jerry Lee were kids in Fereday, 
Lu. Gilley now makes his home in 
Houston and has a club there called 
Gilley's. 
"I had .Jerry Lee in for a show about four months ago,” Gilley said. " I don’t get to appear there very much as I’m on the road all the time.” 
The constant separation from his fa­ mily is the only part of success Gilley dislikes. 

MICKEY GILLEY 

"I enjoy my home life and really dislike being gone so much but my family understands the situation and that helps. 

"M y parents still live in Fereday and my success really shocked them. I don’t get to sec them as much as I would like, either,” Gilley said. 

Gilley has his ow n television show in the Houston area but has no desire to go national with it until he has more time to put into the production. 

"Television is a tough business,” 
Gilley said, "and until I have the time to make the show what I want it to be. 
I’m content with keeping it like it is.” 

Television 

Television is a part of Gilley's life now . as he has made guest appear­ ances on all the major TX' shows. He will make his third appearance on llee-llaw March 12. 
Gilley has two brothers in Corpus 
Christi and a nephew, Cand Gilley, who lives in San Antonio and is trying to get his big break in the entertain­ ment field. 
"Be sure and tell Carol hello,” Gilley said. 
Whatever a star like Mickey Gilley wants, he gets. 
Hello, Carol 
Maine-Anjou entries win in quality b eef 

Matne-Anjou entries won both top spots in the quality beef contest Satur­ day iii the San Antonio Livestock Show and Rodeo at Joe Freeman Coliseum. 
The grand champion beef carcass caille from a Maine-Anjou entered by 
G. L. Thomas of Corsicana. 
It weighed Lion pounds on the hoof and had a dressing percentage of 63.3 per cent on its dressed w ight of 728 ixiunds. The boneless retail cuts came to 53.5 lier cent. The animal placed second iii the on-the-hoof judging. 

Reserve honors 

Reserve champion honors went to the entry of James Marek of New l im. 
It placed first in the on-the-hoof judg­ ing and had a live weight of 1.o8o pounds. 
The dreased weight was 685 pounds for a percentage of 63.4 per cent with 
53.3 per cent in boneless retail cuts. " 
A 258-pound Hampshire-Chester hog owned by N. W. Voigt of Hallettsville took grand champion honors in the quality pork contest. 
Its dressing percentage was 77.5 per cent oil a dressed weight of 2oo pounds. 
It placed first i i i the on-hoof judging. 

The reserve champion was a 
258-pound Hampshire-Chester entered by James D. Epperson. Valley Spring. 
It dressed out at 2o8 pounds for a per­ centage* of 79 4 per cent and placed second in on-hoof judging. 
A fine wool cross lamb entered by 
Cody Carruthers of Del Rio was judged grand champion in the quality lamb contest. It weighed 1o4 pounds on the hoof and dressed out at til pounds, a percentage of 58.7 tier cent. It placed fifth in on-hoof judging. 

The 12o-pound medium wool lamb of 
Sidney McWilliams of Brady won re­ serve honors. It had a 55 per cent dressing percentage on a live weight of lit) pounds and a dressed weight of 66 jHiunds. It was first in on-hoof judging. 

First place among Southdowns went to the 82 pound lamb of Russell Ress- mann of Harper. Its dressed weight was 49 pounds for a percentage of 59.8. 
It placed first in on-hoof judging. 
The entry of Beppo Speck of Faint 
Rock placed first in the fine wool di­ vision. Its dressing percentage was 
52.5 on a live weight of HH pounds and dressed weight of 53 pounds. It was first in on-hoof judging.

Man argued but $11o,ooo kept coming 

W IN T E R PAUK. Flu. (A P ) - B is checks kept arriving, no matter how much Christopher Cosset Ie protested, so he hanked the money — more than 
$1 KLIMM) Before he nave it hack, it earned enough interest to pay for a sports car and a sw miming pool 
“ Pm not a con artist,” said Cossotte. 3H. about his windfall, which was eventually attributed to coni* puler errors. “ J just .stumbled into this. and I'm fascinated.” 
Cossette. a resident alien from Canada, had previously done public relations work for Eaton's department store i i i Hamilton. Ontario, through Ins firm. Spectators Unlimited. 
Then he moved to W in ter P a rk , where he is semi-retired and does limited work for his Canadian firm . The Eaton checks, for varyin g amounts, started arriving in 1974, lie wrote to tile firm, ex­ plaining he was no longer doing business with them and asking to whom he could return the money 
But the checks kept com ing, until he had 
*1 MI KKI IMI of Eaton's money in his hank account. 
Finally, last September, he took along a cashier's check with him while oil a business trip to Canaria and urged the company to accept it. 
The store then discovered that it had assigned the old account number for Spectators Unlimited to a newspaper i i i Hamilton named The Spectator 
( ossctte had been receiving checks meant to pay for the store's full-page advertisements in tin* new­ spaper The computer was making out checks lo 
Cossette's firm limier the code name “ Spec.” 
Newspaper accountants had contacted Eaton s when the account went unpaid for some months, and 
Hu* firm had paid up. 
"But they were shocked to learn their accounting was apparently so loose” that they were paying twice* for the same thing, said Jim Bv slop of The 
Spectator. 
At least you get vitamin C 

CHICAGO ( A P ) - T h is is the week to honor the food that fed the workers who built China s Ureal 
Wall iii IMM MI B.C. and fed the hordes of Genghis 
Khan iii the- Kith Century, or so c laims a trade or­ ganization promoting it. 
If s the* food that put hair on men's ehests — aud then stood it on end 
— sauerkraut, kraut for short. 
It saved seagoing ex­ plorers from the* scourge of scurvy iii the* lHOOs because the* fermented cabbage is a convenient, storable* source of v I* t a nil ii C. 
The 
Royal 
Dutch 
Navy ordered sauerkraut, or “ /our* kook” se*rve*d on long sea voyages. 
Pilg rim s brought kraut to the New 
World for the* same* rea­ son 
But the saga sauerkraut doesn't the re, according to M il ham R Moore of the Na­ tional Kraut Packers As­ sociation. 
Ihe* pe*op!e* make tons of the* stuff by soaking shredded cabbage i i i salted water until it ferm ents aud pickles i i i its own juices. 
History 
To celebrate the color­ ful history of sauerkraut 
— and to try to sell more of it — kraut packers have* designated Feb. lo lei 17 us “ National Kraut and Frankfurter Week ” 
(Moore* says real kraut alficjonados find the* kraut and franks com ­ bination a rather dull way of eating the stuff ) 
Moore says he prefers a uke kraut juice cock­ tail, followecj bv an ap­ petizer ut shrimp nc*st!eci on a bed of kraut, a sauerkraut and pineap­ ple* salad roast pork anti kraut mixed with apples and caraway seeds. 

 of s l o p 

For dessert after a meal like that, lie likes a piece of thunderbolt sur­ prise take. 
T h at's chocolate cake — with sauerkraut, honest! 
There s even sauerk­ raut lee* cream . Moore swears it tastes great. 
Ile says most kraut lovers consider it hearty wintertime lure aud that sauerkraut m akers would In* just us satisfied if recent freezing temperatures never warmed up. 
They've ftiund that the* colder it gets, the more sauerk­ raut people eat 
More consumed 

This winter has been enough to make the hearts of nation’s kraut m akers sing 
Iii 
December, 
Am erican kraut fans consumed more than 79.ikmi barrels of the briny pickled cab­ bage, compared with a paltry i.VI M M ! barrels dur­ ing last year's warmer 
December. 
Taste, however, is not the only reason Moore and his coworkers think people should love their product. One serving costs only about six cents. 
And on top of that, he cites from Eastern Fu- ropean tradition, eating it supposing brings good luck
