WASHINGTON (A P ) — The day after Jim m y Carter pledged to cut government regulations and make them more under­ standable. the Social and R eh ab ilitation Service of the 
Department of Health, Education and Welfare published a new regulation. 
Iii relation to eligibility for welfare, the regulation said: 
“ A state plan under title IV A of the Social Security Act must provide that the determination whether a child has been deprived of parental support or care by reason of his death, eontinued-absence from home, or physical or mental in­ capacity of (if the state plan includes such cases) tho unem- ploymment of his father, will be made only in relation to the child's natural or adoptive parent, or in relation to the child’s stepparent who is ceremonially married to the child's natural or adoptive parent and is legally obligated to support the child under state law of general applicability which requires step­ parents to support stepchildren to the same extent that natural or adoptive parents are required to support their children.” 
That sentence is 12.3 words long. 

Hug thief repents 

CONCORD, N.H. (A P ) — Was it a curse — or just a guilty conscience — that led to the return of a 
$3,IMM) Oriental prayer rug stolen recently from the 
New Hampshire Historical Society? 
/ The rug was found “ all crumpled up" on the steps of an Episcopal church building F riday. The 3-by 
4-foot prayer rug was reported stolen last week by its owner. John Gregorian, from a collection of antique 
Oriental rugs he lent to the historical society. 
"I truly feel the story about the curse must have influenced its return.” said Joyce Gregorian, a member of the owner's family. 
"I would like to know if the person who returned it experienced had luck which promoted the return,” she said, adding, “ I’m just so glad it came hack.”

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. 13 1977 
Building starts at Ward store 

Kc‘iiiember When "Comics” Were 
"Funnies”? THEY STILL AKE! 

In the Sunday Express-News 

Construction has begun on a $5 million expansion of Montgomery Ward’s retail store in the 
McCreless shopping center, according to J. V. 
.Johnson, the company's metro district manager. 
“ This project reflects our continued confidence in the strength of the San 
Antonio economy,” 
.Johnson said. 
“ The McCreless store has established a broad base of loyal customers since it opened in 19H2 and its sales and earn­ ings, particularly in the last five years, have jus­ tified this effort to im­ prove the shopping faci­ lities we offer our customers.” 
.Johnson said the store’s shopping area will be increased by ap­ proximately 
5o,ooo 

 square feet and the ex­ isting departments com­ pletely renovated. The remodeling and expan­ sion is expected to be completed this fall. 
“ We’ll add more than 
35,ooo square feet to the first floor at the south side of the existing building,” .Johnson said. 
“ Another 17,ooo square feet will be added to the auto service center, in­ creasing the number oft service bays from eight to IK. These will be ar­ ranged in a herringbone design to facilitate ac­ cess.” 
Total gross area of the store will be increased from 1o8,434 to 1oo,8o7 square feet. 
Remodeled depart­ ments will not only be larger, with more com­ fortable, colorful sur­ 

 roundings, they will offer a much wider variety of merchandise. 

As examples. .Johnson cited the fine jew elry department where car­ peting, display cases and comfortable chairs will give customers th? feel of shopping on 
Park 
Avenue. 

“ There w ill be new carpeting throughout the store and the outside of the building will have a completely new look,” 
.Johnson said. 

Besides renovating ex­ isting departments. 
Wards w ill also add a number of new depart­ ments in the McCreless store. 

These include the 
Swiss Colony Cheese shop, with 13o varieties of 

ARTISTS concept of the expansion of W ard McCreless store 

 domestic and imported cheeses; the Flower Gar­ den, a pavilion boutique featuring arrangements of dried flowers; a 
“ Frontier Room” coffee shop and many others. 

Of interest to local area residents is the fact that the remodeled and ex­ panded store will provide employment for ap­ proximately 
IOO addi­ tional people, Johnson 

 noted. 
The McCreless expan­ sion is part of Ward s long-range plan of up­ grading and expanding the shopping facilities for its 
San 
Antonio 

 customers. Johnson said 
Last year, the com­ pany's Wonderland shop­ ping center store was ex­ tensively remodeled with some 1o,ooo squre feet of shopping area added.

Homer D. Trevino. United Way as­ sociate campaign director in San An­ tonio, has been appointed UW cam ­ paign director in Waco and McClennan counties effective Monday. 
He will be responsible for organizing and c o n d u c tin g th e an n u a l Waco- 
McClennan fund-raising campaign. 
T re v in o is one of 
14 p e rs o n s throughout the nation selected to p ar­ ticipate in a national executive deve­ lopment program 

The total program being conducted for the first tim e by the United Way of 
America, Alexandria, Va., is funded by the W K, Kellogg Co., Eli Lilly Foun­ dation, Rockefeller Foundation and local United Ways

Ju d son grads honored 

Two 1978 Judson High School graduates have been named Young Texan and Young Texanne for 1978. 
Young Texan is Steve Stine, son of Mr. un J Mrs. 
Samuel O. Stine of 311 Cordoba St. iii Universal City. 
Stine currently attends Texas A&M University. 
Young Texanne is Sharon Pike. daughter of Mr. and Mrs Bobbie R. Like of 2527 Crown Lane. She currently attends San Antonio College. 
Each w inner receives a trophy and a $1,ooo scholarship 
The awards arc made each year by the Young 
Texan-Texanne Foundation in cooperation with the 
Optimist Clubs of Texas. 

SASH exec is consultant 
Jean Sweeney, volunteer services coordinator at 
San Antonio State Hospital, has been appointed one of two Texas consultants for the .National Center for 
Voluntary Action in Washington, DC. 
Sweeney will assist anyone who needs help in any phase of v o lu n teerin g said Jean Beasley oi Austin, regional consultant for Texas. O klahom a, New 
Mexico, Arkansas and Louisiana 
The SASH coordinator is one of ten consultants in the five stales. 
Sweeney will attend the first meeting of all state consultants in Dallas Thursday and Friday. 
Before joining SASH five years ago. Sweeney was director of (he Voluntary Action C enter in San 
Antonio. 
She holds a m aster s degree in microbiology from the University of Chicago and a m aster's degree in allied health adm inistration from Southwest Texas 
Slate University. 
“ With her m any years of experience in the volunteer field, we know Ms. Sweeney’ will In* a big asset to the group,” said Beasley

The deputy director of the Logistics Plans and 
Program Directorate at Air Force H eadquarters iii 
Washington, I) (’., has been named vice com m ander of the San Antonio Air Logistics Center at Kellv 
AFB. 
Col. Theodore D. Broadwater, a brigadier general selectee, is expected to report to his new assignment as second iii com m and of the large logistics center 
Tuesday. 
Broadwater served as depot supply officer in the 
Air Force Cryptologic Depot. USAK Security Ser­ vice. at Kelly in 1984 
A native of Isaliella, Pa., the 48-year-old Broad­ water l>egan his military career upon commission­ ing through the University of Pittsburgh ROTT program in 1952.

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS 
HONG KONG - Hong 
Kong is a long way to go to get baptized and Re­ gina Nicole Schultz of 
San Antonio will not re­ member anyway. 
But in a most unusual cerem ony 
Regina, daughter of Lt. fig .) and 
Mrs. Clarence VV. Schultz of 5654 G reen Manor 
Drive, was baptized re­ cently on board the guid­ ed missile destroyer USS 
Decatur in Victoria Har­ bor. 
The b a p tism , p e r­ formed by the Rev. Fer­ gus T. Cronin, is believed to be the first ever held aboard a U.S. Naval ves­ sel in Victoria Harbor. 
R egina's godparents are the ship's command­ ing officer and his wife. 
Cmdr, and Mrs. James 
D. Korthe. 

Schultz is assigned to the ship's engineering d e p artm e n t and was visited by his wife and d au g h ter du rin g the ship's port visit to Hong 
Kong. 

The D ecatur's home port is San Diego.

Windsor Homes debut gets strong response from hundreds in S.A. 

W IN D S O R H O M E S fe a tu re d in b o th B risto l P lace a n d B ria rw ic k this w e e k e n d 
Country atmosphere, homes on wooded lots highlight Tanglewood 

Since their recent opening. 
Windsor hom es has received most favorable response from the hundreds who have visited them. 
One visitor co m m e n t e d , “ Windsor homes are definitely quality b u ilt.“ 
His wile added her delight with the spacious garden kitchen. 
Combined top priorities 
There are definite reasons for Wind­ sor homes’ popularity After re search­ ing what todav s b u ye rs consid ered most important in a new home. Wind­ sor Homes combined top priorities 
Quality is emphasized, buyers would prefer to pay a little extra than have to fa ce r e p l a c e m e n t s i i i two to th re e veal s. That 's whv Windsor Homes uses 

 only high g r a d e m a t e r ia l s that will give m a x i m a l life to your home. S u ­ perb craftsmanship and close attention to detail are more contributions to your home s durability. 

Many people P un their new home after having lived in a luxury a p a r t ­ ment for several years In that time, they have grown a cc u s to m ed to lux­ uries like c a rp etin g , fir e p la c e s and c e n t r a l heat and a ir ; so. W in d s o r homes include these features, as well as others very, very few apartm en ts offer; sunken living areas, cathedral ceilings, indoor utility rooms, m aste r suites with sitting rooms and garden kitchens with serve-outs Ii* backyard patios. 

Speakin g of kitchens, they include 

 range, vent hood, dishwasher and dis­ poser for m a x i m a l convenience and efficiency 

Windsor Homes builds creatively for you. The firm s research has revealed the most preferred floor plans; to these plans they have added innovations that have re c e iv e d p o p u l a r a c c e p t a n c e . 
Mach Windsor home is built iii such a way that you. too. can add your own cr e a m ity.

San Antonians art* deciding 
1977 is the year they’ve been waiting for in their hopes and d r e a m s for a new home, and those dreams are coming true in 
Ray Ellison’s Tanglewood, with its beautiful wooded countryside a tm o s p h e r e and its splendid con tempo ra ry designs. 
Located within easy driving distance of the neighboring L T S A cam pus, the i m p o s i n g US AA c o m p l e x a nd the splendid medical facilities of the South 
Texas Medical Center, Tanglewood is at the heart of the dynamic movement m a r k i n g S an A n t o n io 's t h r u s t i n g northwest growth 
Amid gracious oaks 

At th(* sa m e time. Tanglewood offers the p e a c e f u l s e r e n i t y of c a r e f r e e country living amid gracious oaks and 

 rolling landscapes. 
Innovative, contemporary designs by 
Hay 
E l l i s o n a r c h i t e c t s m a k e 
Tanglewood an interesting c o m b i n a ­ tion of three- and four-bedroom, one- and two-story homes beginning in the low 4os and available with YA, EHA and conventional financing. 
F i r e p l a c e s featured in most plans bring c r a c k li n g w arm th and ru stic glamor to crisp Tanglewood evenings. 
But rustic ch arm is mixed with con­ tem porary convenience iii beautiful, functional k it c h e n s that t r a n s f o r m cooking chore s into culin ary a d v en ­ tures. Rich, handcrafted wood cabin­ etry; self-cleaning, double-oven elec­ tric ranges; dishwashers and disposer units: and st a i n l e s s steel sin ks and fixtures all combine to allow kitchen chores to be performed with more fun and less fatigue. 
Although the benefits of Tanglewood livin g a r e m a n y and v a r i e d for 

 housewives and mothers, children and teenagers from the wooded subdiv ision enjov o u t s t a n d in g e d u c a tio n a l f a c i ­ lities of the Northside School District, along with interesting and diverse so­ cial pro gram s and extracurricular a c ­ tivities for young people of all ages 
For weekend or evening recreation in the great 
Tanglewood out­ doors. tennis courts and s w i m m i n g pool a r e n e a r b y . F o r th o s e w h o se entertainment tastes lean to the night life, discotheque dancing and unique cuisine abound in exciting northwes­ tern San Antonio, with the most popu­ lar spots located only minutes away via expressways. 
To I each the Tanglewood sales office where professional and courteous Hay 
Ellison re pre se ntativ es are ready lo assist you, drive out NAV 
III ll) past

FREEDOM 
HOME models are open in four San Antonio communities 

Freedom Homes are still affordable 

WE JUST LOVE OUR BRICK] 
FIREPLACE 

Af La Plaza Apartment> stunt- of oar standard amenities in­ clude separate Limits and single section • tennis courts • free membership to Racquetball (Huh • large icalk-in closets • tiro pools. sauna and health Auh • security sen ice • and covered assignat pinking • anne lit << a itll us at La Plaza, you ll enjoy the lifestyle tee offer. 

The affordable home? 
Is it just a myth these days? 
It’s for real. and. in­ deed, it is a reality that not only exists but awaits the young families long­ ing to set themselves free 
— yearning to set them­ selves free from renting to enter an environment that gives them a true sense of belonging. 

Freedom Homes 
What these young fa­ milies need to discover are Freedom Homes by 
Morton/Southwest. 
Morton/Southwest, one of the more successful building 
- developing firms in recent years, had to undertake much research and experimentation to find the right home for those misled by the pessimism that maintained the average American fami­ ly on the way up might have to wait forever to buy a new house. 
Not only that, because 
Morton/Southwest has built these kind of homes in communities which more than satisfy the needs and desires of those looking for a home affordable today. 
In these ways, families who have had to rent ac­ 

 tually sacrifice nothing at all when they buy and move into a new Free­ dom Home by Morton/ 
Southwest. In fact, they gain all they’ve ever wanted in the way of a nice place to live! rills is because Free­ dom Homes feature all the frills modern fa­ milies hav e come to ex­ pect in a new house. 
Ibis. indeed, is inst one of the maiiv reasons 
I* reed nm Homes hav e become so popular 
Their three- and four- bedroom plans include two complete baths and other fine features gen­ erally sought by home buyers today, and. as it happens, they don't fall short of anyone's expec­ tations, instead, they ex­ ceed them considerably. 
These affordable houses are loaded with surprises because of their extremely moder­ ate price range begin­ ning as low as $28,5oo. 
Fan try kit idle ns fea­ ture the right kind of ap­ pliances to lessen the workload for today's homemakers. 
Dish­ washers. disposers, ranges with hoods and abundant cabinetry are provided among Free­ 

 dom Homes. All ap­ pliances carry the relia­ ble Magic Chef brand name. 
Other extras Morton/ 
Southwest has made available to bargain hunters are wall-to-wall closets with storage space extending all the way to the ceiling and sliding doors of panel designs, finished two-ear garages, utility anil work areas, patios with sliding glass doors, clever blends of masonry and wood worked into strik­ ing exteriors, carpeting buyers can choose, effi­ cient Friedrich central air and heat systems and, in most, woodburning fireplaces. 
Freedom Homes are featured in Lakeside, 
V alley Forge, Cimarron and a recent addition to 
Valencia. 
They are represented by fur­ nished, decorated models in most of these residential areas. 
Lakeside, a southeas­ tern Bexar County area ideally suited to active, reereattonal lifestyles, lives up to its name with an actual lake for boating 
.and fishing. Other amen­ ities are a park by the lake, tennis courts, a 

 swimming pool and playground. 
Valley Forge, a resi­ dential community uni­ quely arranged in north­ eastern San Antonio, carries over a Bicenten­ nial theme and offers a svv miming fool, tennis courts and clubhouse. 
Cimarron, a northeas­ tern Bexar County area by Universal City and its many shopping and en­ tertainment facilities, yields almost immediate access to a number of recreational amenities. 
Valencia, a long estab­ lished community, has 

 just opened a series of 
Freedom Homes. 
Valley Forge and Va­ lencia, each in the North 
East School District, can be reached by driving north of N E. Loop 41o on 
Nacogdoches Road. Signs lead the way to each. 
Cimarron, in the .Jud­ son School District, can be found bv exiting from 
N E . HI 35 to N.E. EM 
1oo4 and following the signs. 
Lakeside, in the East 
.Central School District, can bi* found by exiting from S.E. Loop 41o onto 
U.S. Hwy. 87 and going

K EESE HENRY

Homecraft 
Corp. houses in Woodstone w ill be among the building- developing firm ’s high­ lights for home hunters this weekend. 
The northeastern San 
Antonio community is where the interest rate for VA home loans is as low as 8 per cent. Other advantageous VA terms here include a total move-iti cost of only $l to qualified veterans.

Woodstone homes.

NORTHWEST SAN ANTONIO’S FINEST COMMUNITY 

Twin Creek has country setting 

Professional planning by Homecraft Corp. has made Twin Creek one of the fastest growing com­ munities in the area. 
The northwestern Bex­ ar County development opened in the tall of 1973. 
Streets in the neigh­ borhood necessitate slow traffic and house exter­ iors create a blending of colors and styles. 
The community fea­ tures a private club­ house. with fenced, lighted tennis courts, a swimming pool, wading pool, clubhouse with kit­ chen. and a playground 
Although surrounded by nature. Twin ( reek has a convenient location a mile from Bandera 
Road and two miles from 
Loop TIU. 
No city taxes 
No city taxes apply to home payments made by 
Twin Creek residents. 
In the Northside School 
District. Twin Creek is close to E T H A , IJS A X , 
South Texas Medical 
Center, Southwest Re­ search Institute and Kel­ ly and Lackland A ir 
Force bases. 
Homes may be pur­ chased by VA financing, requiring a 
$1 total move-in cost and an an­ nual interest rate of 8 per cent. 
Homecraft houses in 
Twin ( reek. priced from 
$34,95(1, have either three or four bedrooms, two baths and two-car

I'm Buddy Burns. And I'd like to shed some licht on your old home. It your home is 
5 years old or older, chances are it's obsolete 
That's right, obsolete Be­ cause at the time your home was built, there were virtually no energy-etfi- nency standards As a result, many Sjn Antonians are laced with utility bills that may soon exceed their house payments' 

Why NOW Is The Time To Buy. 
Let s look at the tacts Since you invested in your home a tew years ago, two things have hap­ pened For one, you've been making house payments tor sev­ eral years, so your et jutty has grown Tim», since the cost of building a new home has stead­ ily increased, the cost ut replan mg your home has increased 
BUT, because your old home isn t energy’ emcient, it wastes valuable energy And believe it or not, homeowners around the country are actually beginning to lose money when they sell their older homes Because no­ 

 body wants to buy a home where the cost ot heating and cooling exceeds the monthly payments. 
My advice is this With the money you can make by selling your old home right now, you an probably make the dow n­ payment and move into a new 
Burris Co. bower Saver home today. And, while your house payments may he a little higher, the lower utility bills should easily offset the difference. The only thing you can't afford to do is wait much longer

Success Homes featured today 

The long established 
Morton / Southwest com­ munity, Valley Forge, this weekend will feature the building / developing firm's highly successful, most recent series of new houses, Success Homes. 
Valley Forge, by its name alone, carries over the nostalgic Bicenten­ nial themes of last year, but the neighborhood off 
O'Connor Road in north­ eastern San Antonio is 

 able to offer the well planned houses in a price range starting as low as 
$34,ooo. The firm takes great pride in presenting 
Success Homes as “ af­ fordable,” invalidating the pessimism maintain­ ing average American families are unable to afford a new home today. 
A visit to any of the 
Success models in Valley 
Forge will show how a new home remains as the one planned for all of the one “ great American tomorrows. dream’’ that can be rea-

They include shag carpeting in living rooms, master suites and hallways; privacy fences; woodburning fireplaces; abundant cabinetry in pantry kitchens; com­ partmented baths; walk- in or wall-to-wall closets; handsome paneling; carefully chosen wall fa­ brics; and beamed cathedral ceilings.

Bach Success home features a utility area and a finished two-car garage.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. 13 1977

& r 

A s housing costs con­ tinue to increase, today s home buyer is looking for more than inst shelter. 
He wants long-lasting quality and durability to insure that his home and neighborhood w ill be as desirable in five years as it is today. 
Hidden values in 
Schaefer homes insure that lasting quality. lower utility lulls and old-fashioned comfort 
Quality craftsmanship and individuality distinguish Schaefer’s philosophy of concern for the individual home buyer. 
Schaefer has a definite opinion about what con­ stitutes as well-built home. and it i s apparent from a 
\ i s i t to any 
Schaefer subdivision 
It is evident in the planning of each home, the grading of each lot. the placement of the house and tile design of the floor plant and eleva­ tion to maximize views, privacy and distinctive­ ness. 
There is a sense of community in each 
Schaefer subdivision. 
There are recreational facilities, drainage sys­ tems and established school and shopping centers nearby. 
The quality of crafts­ manship is also evident throughout the homes 
Its evidence is copper wiring, steel exterior doors with dead holts. 
3/8-inch wood decking. 
1/2-mch carpet padding and professional interior designs. 
Quality workmanship is evident in the hand- land ceramic tile; colon­ ial handcrafted molding, marble vanities, wall fa­ bric. handle sets on doors arid furniture-finished cabinetry. 
Homes also im lude country kitchens, vaulted ceilings, garden atriums and formal living and dining areas. 
When it comes to con­ serving energy, each home has a custom-en­ gineered. high-efficiency central air and heat sys­ tem, ducts for optional air flow 31/’inch wall in­ solation and six to eight inches of blown attic in­ sulation with Thermo Ply insulation on the sides 
There are also power attic ventilation and win­ dows designed to mini­ mize air infiltration and maximize light and v lews 
There are a variety of designs and door plans to 
(bootie from in Northern 
Hills and Devonshire, with design features like wood-burning fireplaces, country kitchens with garden patios and muster bedroom suites with pri­ vate dressing areas and baths 
S{wh tai VA, FUA and conventional financing is available.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. 13 1 9 7 7 

Country living, urban lifestyle fits Wildwood 

Country liv in g with urban convenience is a familiar phrase used so often by advertisers that its meaning is diluted by repeti­ tion, and a p p lic a tio n s of the p hrase d o n ’ t a lw a y s bear up under close scrutiny. 
However, Hay E llison’s Wildwood, one of the most popular developments in the northwestern quadrant of San 
Antonio, really measures up when it tomes to offering the peace and quiet of country living, as well as a key lo­ cation with immediate access to all the demands and pleasantries of city life. 
In lact Wildwood measures up so well that Ray Ellison representatives invite wmjrr 

 the closest kind of scrutiny for W ild­ wood and all that it has to offer to the family that believes this is the year for buying a new home that they were waiting for last year. 
Outside city limits 

Although Wildwood is readily acces­ sible to the growing commercial faci­ lities in the northwest, such as UTSA, 
USAA and the South Texas Medical 
Center, its homes are outside the city lim its, providing lower monthly pay­ ments on new home investments that range from the low S:iOs to the mid 
$4os. 
Wildwood homes retain the w ilder­ ness touch, surrounded by tree-cov­ ered slopes and wooded horizon. classm en rom .**----------------------- u i » i>h b a tm i v 

Fireplaces in most Wildwood homes recall the rustic touch of country liv ­ ing, bringing warmth and cheer to the brisk evening air. 

Children and teenagers of Wildwood families attend the excellent schools of the Northside Independent School Dis­ trict. with educational programs that not only instill the “ three R’s” but also offer rich and diverse extracurricular programs which emphasize leadership and initiative. 

Wildwood kitchens are designed for beauty and functional convenience. All are fully equipped with dishwashers, disposers, ranges w ith self-cleaning ovens and range vents, plus fine-qua- litv wood cabinets which typify the fine gussffiio oisnAT cuninnrBwTTy 

W ildw ood measures up to homebuyer expecta­ tions and then some with its exquisite combination of rustic charm and contemporary design in an environment that beckons “ back to the country.” 

 craftsmanship found throughout a Ray 
Ellison home.

 carpeting, and complete with wood-burning fireplace . . . an area truly designed for living and entertaining. 
Patio 
Emphasis on indoor/outdoor liv­ ing with outdoor patio viewed from the Living area through sliding glass doors. A trite plant lover’s dream. 
Storage Space Galore! 
A separate storage area in a double garage . . . a great place to store your bicycles, cars, boats and all the other stuff you never seem to have room for. 

And When We Say Affordable 
We Mean It! 
Special VA, FHA and Conven­ tional financing. Available in three distinctive subdivisions. 
Just check the map to find the one that suits you. Furnished models open daily.

Large tracts set in Trailwood 

W. R. CRAIG CO. built this four-bedroom air conditioned home which sells for only 
$28,5oo at 21 3 James Bonham in Thunder­ bird Hills. W. R. Craig homes contain such 

 energy-saving features as Thermo glass win­ dows, added insulation and a rotary air con­ ditioner. Thunderbird Hills is inside Loop 41o near the Ingram Road exit.

CLASSIFIED DISPLAY 
CLASSIFIED DISPLAY 
CLASSIFIED DISPLAY

1 9 4 6 N .E . lo o p 4 1 o

8 2 6 -2 3 5 5 
FEATURES 
TWO BEDROOMS 
TWO BATHS 
First & Second level 
$217. per month 

Third Floor W/Fireplace .. $228. per month 

A couple will find this plan perfectly suited to their growing needs. The master bedroom has an extra large 9 foot walk-in closet, private dressing room and bath. W hile the huge wall-to- wall closet in the second bedroom, linen closet and pantry provide an enormous amount of storage space. There’s formal dining, and a kit­ chen that’s big enough for a snack table. It has a frost free refrigerator, too. The washer aryer connections are located off the deck. And the penthouse level has a fireplace, bookshelves and beamed and vaulted ceiling. 

LIVING 
DINING 

Affordable country liv­ ing is now available in the San Antonio area in 
Trailwood. 
In the hill country 15 minutes northwest of 
Wonderland Shopping 
City out IU IO. Trailwood offers 1*2 to three-acre wooded tracts priced from $7,15o. 

The natural environ­ ment. featuring rolling hills with vistas and fertile valleys, is ideal for the family seeking country serenity and privacy. 
Lots leave space for gardens and fruit trees, as well as a horse or two. 
The winding drives throughout the area offer bikers a challenge. 
A number of homes have been constructed in 
Trailwood by the Don 
Smith Co., featuring entries, rock fireplaces, wooden decks overlook­ ing the hill country, three 

 or four bedrooms and carpet. 
The surrounding pro­ perties require little maintenance because of their formal setting. 
Each home has been de­ signed and situated to take advantage of the prevailing summer breezes. 
These homes contain all the luxuries and con­ veniences expected in homes of the $61 .HOO to 
$92,5oo range. 
Other homes in Trail­ wood are available from builders Carl Rage. HCN 
Co., Hon Macon. Boerne 
Community . Builders and Homes by Yicki 
(Scheleyer). 
To reach Trailwood. drive 16 miles north on 
NYV lino to the Tarpon 
Road exit, U-turn south on the access road and watch for the Trailwood entrance. The sales office is open daily. IO a.rn 
.until dusk 
TRAILW OOD entranceway

Conway, speaking at ibis 
R E I/ ) educational meet­ ing. “ This growth re­ flects both expansion of company transfer activi­ ty, as well as R E I/ ) op­ portunities for service based on wider recogni­ tion of RF,LO service availability,” Conway re­ ported.

Rosow of Rosow & Kline, 
Realtors, R E I/ ) service is now available in more

LO for its members

H ELO , offers special, personalized service to transferring families and individuals moving any­ where i i i the united 
States, and to many areas around the world.” stated Rosow.

SA BO R named third largest 

As increasingly more people enter the real es­ tate profession and qua­ lify to become Realtors, membership in San An­ tonio Board of Realtors 
Inc. has reached an all- time high 
According to 
Ray 
Ragsdill, hoard presi­ dent, the number of members came to 2,65k in 1976. more than eve! tiefore in the 67-year his­ tory of the organization 
The San Antonio hoard is 

 the third largest hoard of 
Realtors in the state of 
Texas, exceeded in size only by the Houston and 
Dallas boards 

Origin 

Board records show that, in 191o, some 22 ol the city's real estate met met for lunch al the St 
Anthony 
Hotel and formed what was first known as the San Antrum 
Real Estate Exchange

Woodhill for country living 

 itNTRY 

D IN IN G 

AKLA 
L IV IN G 

AKLA 

A convenient location, country - fresh atmos­ phere and striking inter­ iors are what make 
YVoodhill Apartments the choice address in north­ western San Antonio. 
Some recent residents at the apartment com­ munity, 451o9 Woodstone 
Dr. off the Huehner Road exit from N.W. Ill ll), moved there because it’s only minutes from the 
South Texas Medical 
Center and the new 
USAA complex. Others include m ilitary base personnel who chose 

Woodhill for its esthetic value as well as its near­ ness to the air bases. 
Woodhill’s spacious one- and two-bedroom studios and one-, two- and three-bedroom apartment homes art now leasing. Furnished model apartments are on display at the Leasing 
Information Center open daily until B p.m. 
Woodhill is reached most easily by exiting from N.W. Ill IO to lluebncr Road and pro­ ceeding north to Wood- stone Drive

PROGRAMMER 
Swearingen Aviation Corporation has immediate re­ quirement for experienced Programmer. Position re­ quires at least 2 years experience programming business type applications Also, requires 18 to 24 months experience with COBOL. RPG must be learned in minimum time, if not already proficient 
BAL is desirable. IBM 36o or 37o is desired, but experience with ony medium to large scale main frome is acceptable A good working knowledge of IBM, OS job control language. 

This position provides stable employment, good starting salary, and fringe benefits. 

Interested applicants should apply in person at the employment office, Swearingen Aviation Corporation, 
International Airport, San Antonio, Tx. (Come East on 
Bitters Road past Blossom Athletic Center, turn right on 
NE entrance toad.)

How to live happily with your leased car for the next two or three years... 
Include Red Mac s Maintenance Lease Program 

For a fixed fee, your new 
Ford autom obile is covered anyw here in the U.S. fo r inspections and em ergency repairs. 
C om plete scheduled m aintenance, oil changes, tune-ups and norm al repairs, beyond those listed in the standard w arranty, are covered for 4o,ooo m iles on a 36-m onth lease or 
24,ooo m iles on a 24- m onth lease. 

The M aintenance Lease 

Program can be added to your Red M ac lease for only $11 98 per m onth. 
T hat's a bargain for peace-of-.mind, sm oother ru nnin g and better m ileage. 

Tires, state inspections and a few other item s are not covered. For com plete details, get a copy of FALS 
M A IN T E N A N C E 
LEASE PR O G R AM at 
Red M ac Leases and 

 live happily w ith your car for the next tw o or three years.

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. 13 1977 

B u lle tin 
B o a rd 

W HATS jOMING UPI 
SAN__________ft 
THIS WEEK I ; 

Hospital garage going up 

Construction of the six-story Dallas Street Parking 
Garage, across the street from Baptist Hospital, starts Monday. 
When completed, the garage will accommodate cars for patients, visitors, doctors, pastors and employes. A helistop for air evacuation helicopters will be located on the sixth floor level and will be directly tied into surgery by an overhead bridge. 
The Dallas Street Parking Garage is a continua­ tion of the major $11 million expansion project underway in the hospital system. 
Officials estimate construction of the garage will be completed in about one year. 
Kelly sets surplus sale 

The Defense Property Disposal Office at Kelly 
A FB will conduct a local spot bid sale Thursday. 
Surplus items included in the sale are carboys, steel and fiberglass partitions, gas heaters, tubular steel beds, steel drums, beverage coolers, office machines, washers, dryers, chairs, and a battery charger. 
The sale items are available for inspection at 
Bldg. 3ooo, East Kelly, on regular work days from 8 a m. to 3 p.m. Inspection passes may be obtained by reporting to Bldg. 3o3o, Room 114. 
On tin* day of the sale, parking will be provided at the NCO Open Mess parking lot in East Kelly, with transportation and pusses into the sales area avai­ lable from 7:3o a.m. until the end of the sale. 
Beautify to hear Burke 

Scan Burke, philosophy professor at Incarnate 
Word College, will be the guest speaker at the monthly meeting of the Beautify San Antonio Assn. at 5:45 p.m. Thursday. 
The association will meet at the San Antonio 
Garden Center. 331o N. New Braunfels Ave. 
All State Insurance Company, 62o7 Pecan Valley 
Drive, and the Texas Hotel and Motel Assn., 852o 
Crownhill Blvd., will be recognized as dedicated beautifiers. 

Cadet choir to visit S.A. 

The United States Air Force Catholic Cadet Choir will visit San Antonio Friday through Feb. 21. 
Under the direction of Edmund L. Ladouceur, the choir has appeared on national television and radio programs. 
The group has scheduled performances at 7:3o p.m. Saturday in the Antonian High School auditor­ ium. at IO a.m. Feb. 2o in Kelly A FB Chapel No. I and at 12:15 p.m. Feb. 2o in St. Mary's Church. 
At 8 p.m. Feb. 2o. the choir will perform in 
Lackland A FB Chapel No. 8. 
The final appearance will be at the Bexar County 
Retarded Children's School Feb. 21. 
The San Antonio Academy Parents Club, which is sponsoring the choir, needs assistance in providing lodging, meals and transportation. 
To volunteer, phone Terry Krew inski at 494-3349 or 
Mary Louise Romo at 333-o621. 

Black history celebration 

Kila Austin Community Center will observe the occasion of Black History Month with a program entitled 
“ Black Genesis — From Africa to Ameri­ ca” Friday. 
The center's activities will begin at ll a.m. with a 
"Roots” Day in the senior citizens facility. 
Activities also will include a special program from 
5:3o to 7:3o p.m. featuring un Afro-American food festival, exhibits and displays, music, dunce and dramatic presentations. 
Keynote speaker will be State Rep. Lou Nelle 
Sutton. The public is invited. 

Classicists will convene 

The San Antonio Classical Society and the Texas 
State Junior Classical League will hold their annual 
City Convention at St. Mary’s Hall Saturday. 
TSJCL members from more than 25 high schools throughout the state w ill participate in the activities. 
Students will present dramatic interpretations of 
Roman poetry, learn Greek Folk Dancing and participate in a Roman costume contest. 
Members also will compete in Roman history, vocabulary and Greek mythology’ contests. 

KOA lo hear '‘wills’ talk 

Problems often encountered in drawing up and probating wills under Texas law will be the subject of a talk by David G. Jayne to a Thursday luncheon of the San Antonio Retired Officers Assn. 
Jayne is a retired Army lieutenant colonel, a member of the law firm of Tinsman & Houser and 
SAROA's newly installed legal counsel. 
The association meeting will be held in Ft. Sam 
Houston's Officers Club at noon Thursday. Reser­ vations are $4 5o per person and must reach asse­ dat mn headquarters (Box 8o37, Wainwright Station) by Monday. 

Group lo study passivity 

Drug Abuse Central will sponsor “ Passivity 
Confrontation” from 8:3o a.m. until 4 p.m. Friday at 
321 N. Pecos St. designed to bring about a better awareness of passive people and how this type of personality lends itself to drug abuse. 

Lila to talk to Southeast 

Mayor Lila Cockrell will address the Southeast 
Dei elopment Foundation at a noon luncheon 
Wednesday at the Pecan Valley Country Club. A question and answer session with Mrs. Cockrell will follow her prepared remarks. 
The mayor’s appearance is part of a monthly program for the group where city officials are muted to speak to the southeast area residents, businessmen and professional people. 
Reservations for Mayor Cockrell’s talk can be made by phoning the foundation at 333-8411, 

Book Fair set for mall 

M IC H A E L 

... guest speaker 

The 
San 
Antonio 
Branch of the American 
Assn, of University Wo­ men will have its annual 

Book 
F a ir Thursday through Saturday in Cen­ tral Park Mall. 

Mary Frances Sween­ ey. chairman of the Book 
Fair, said there is still time to donate books, 
National Geographic ma­ gazines and phonograph records for this year’s fair. Call 824-o47o or 
733-1318 for free pickup. 

Principal beneficiary of the sate is the {educa­ tional Foundation Pro­ grams of the American 
Association of University 
Women, 

N a t i o n a l U S O 

 c h i e f t o s p e a k 

Michael E. Menster. USO national executive director, will be the guest speaker at the USO 
Council of Metropolitan San Antonio’s annual luncheon meeting. 
Menster, 36-year-old graduate of Villanova Uni­ versity, is the youngest national USO executive director ever appointed. 
At the luncheon, at noon Thursday at 41o S. Alamo 
St., officers will be elected and committee chairmen will present their annual reports.___________________

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. I 3 1977 

Assorted r a c k s ...A I L MUST GO! 

In a warehouse of over 3 Vi million cubic feet, some things ore bound to be over­ looked So, periodically, we at lack's Coliseum Warehouse check our warehouse racks. Everything that is odd, discontinued, overlooked, lost, found, abandoned, mis-markea, forgotten or otherwise out of place, is brought down to our selling floor. We found over 275 items, large and small, to be cmposed of . 
. and to­ day's the day they go! You'll find tremendous bargains on everything in stock on our floor, because IT S A ll ON SALE! living room, bedroom, dining room, bedding, carpeting, aopliances and much more! SAVE ON EVERYTHING! . . . whether it lust came off the rack or was already here. Don t miss this 
. . it s really worth the trip!

H a rd coal 

Could you advise me where I might purchase hard lump coal suitable for a fireplace or a Franklin stove? 
A local iron works company advised me that they carry soft. "blacksmith coal not suitable for home use. 
I believe I am looking for anthracite coal — a hard coal that gives off little smoke 
W. A. I). 

Alamo Fuel Company, 
A IOO pound bag of 
oo5 Buena Vista St., hard coal will cost you 
226-7331, has the hard $6.23 plus tax. coal you are looking for. 

W om en 8 soccer 

Some time ago you printed information about the formation of a women's soccer team in San Antonio. 
Would you please reprint the item, or alternative­ ly. give me the names of people I should contact about playing for a soccer team? 
B. ii. 

Mike Burr of Soccer 
International said there were two women's soccer teams in San Antonio at the present time. 
They ha\e been playing for about two years. 
One team is sponsored by Gibson 
Plum bing 
Company. Call 681-3163 

 and ask tor Ava or Larry for information about getting on the team. 

The other team spon­ sors itself. For informa­ tion about playing for this team, call 223-3417 and ask for l)a\e or 
Mary. 

M iss San A n to n io 

Can you tell me how I can enter the Miss San 
Antonio pageant? Also, is 17 too young for participants? 
M. C. 

The deadline for registration for the Miss 
San Antonio contest is at noon. Feb. 21. 
This year’s pageant will be held March 19 at 
Theater San Antonio at 8 p.m. 
Donna Axum. Miss 
America 1964. will emcee the pageant. 
4\omen between the ages of 17 and 27 are eli­ gible and entrants will be judged on talent, person­ ality and visual projec­ tion (the swimsuit com­ petition). 
In addition, contestants must never hate been married even if the mar­ 

 riage has been annulled. 
I he scholarship the winner of the pageant receives must he used to further her academic education. 
Since Miss San Antonio must be available to represent the city in var- ious parades and events throughout the year, contestants should live within the city or a rea­ sonable driving distance. 
Met reless Shopping 
City is sponsoring this year s pageant. 
Ii you are interested in competing, call 532-359! and ask for Mrs. Fdwin 
Warnceke. 

M a il o rd e r Hack 

Help’ Several weeks ago I ordered some mer­ chandise from a company advertising in the Family 
Weekly insert into your newspaper. 
I figured Fam ily Weekly was reputable and I would be getting my merchandise soon 
I normally don’t mail order anything, but I figured my money was safe with them. The advertisement said I should wait four weeks for delivery. 
The check has been cashed and it has been six weeks! Is there anything I can do to trace the merchandise.? 
I know the advertisements iii Family Weekly have nothing to do with your advertising department, but 
I thought you might have a name I could contact about getting my merchandise or my money re­ funded. 
Thank you in advance for any help you can send my way. 
( •deemed 

There is something you an do. Contact Mary lyres ol Family Weekly it S II Lexington Ave., sew York. V Y ., 1oo22. 
•’Please allow up to our weeks for delivery then you order by mail rom Fam ily Weekly,*’ 
Ars. Ayres said. 
"Fam ily Weekly's ads ire placed by reputable ompanies. The items md copy are checked for 

 reliability," she said. 
"Fnintentionul delays occur because thousands ol orders come in to our advertisers from all over 
Hie country," she said. 
‘We at Family Weekly want lo assist you as much as possible when these infrequent delays occur, lf they do. send me a card or letter and 
I II look into it immedia­ tely.” she said.

L. S. 

 exercises into dance rou­ tines.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. 13 1977 

 and lh** Lower Rio Grande Valley. 
Temperatures remained mild — in ads and Bbs ut midday — in spite of moderate to strong north to northwes­ terly winds. Some gusts of 2a to 3o miles per hour were reported over 
North Central and South Central Texas and the Pecos River Valley of South­ west Texas. 
Thunderstorm s that buffeted the eastern part of the state Friday night moved into Louisiana early Saturday, 

ASSOCIATED p b e s s 
Sunshine and mild tempera­ tures art* forecast for Sunday in the wake of a Pacific cool front that left lingering clouds in some areas. 

West Texas had sunshine Saturday, but considerable low clouds and fog lingered in extreme Northeast Texas

Card slurps report valen­ tine sales are zooming. The clay is second only to 
Christmas in volume out­ running 
Caster and 
Mother's Day. 
Young lovers choose con­ temporary while the pre­ maturely gray lovers still hunt the old-fashioned sen­ timental style with turtle­ doves and lace. 

T w o p e n n i e s 

Penny valentines have vanished. Children can buy tray packages for about 2 to ll cents each, including one for teacher. 
Cost of lov m g has in­ creased — adult cards now begin at 23 cents. 
School children still print lists for all their c l a s s ­ m ates. (We didn't have lists and while I could ac­ cept Louis or Louise for 
Lois, I cried w hen one card read “ to Louse with love.” ) 
Valentine box decorating contests in home rooms are past history. Teachers rea­ lize it's difficult for a six- year-old to compete with a

 there will bring smiles to someone special. 

V alentine’s Day is a time for love. And it seems lov­ ing will never go out of style. 

A cheek of the city shows the day is growing in pop­ ularity! 

But attention R om e o s and 
J u lie t t e s 
— most valentines are not sent by sw e e th e arts and lovers. 
Children outsend them three to one. 
M others and s ch o o l­ teachers will receive more v alentines Monday than anyone else. 
Sw e e th e a rts even trail aunts, sisters, brothers and uncles in the valentine stakes.

EXPRESS-NEWS 
Sun. Feb. I 3 I 977

M o u th full of plaster 

 eatee lauder 
SWtii6 perfornr«n9 extract 

Sn I embarked on se­ veral c onsecutive a p ­ po in tm en ts to w ard reaching my goal — min ­ or repairs and a movie star smile. 
My first appointment was with the hygienist. 
“ Oh my,” she sighed. 
“ W h a t ’s w r o n g ? ” I wanted to ask — but my mouth was filled with mirrors, sharp pointed objects and her fingers. 
After an ete rn ity of picking and scraping, she spoke again. “ You may rinse now.” (That was her way of asking me to spit out the blood.) 
She gave me a dental care packet containing a m i r r o r , a to o th b r u s h , floss and a booklet enti­ tled “ Plaque Is Not A 
4-Letter Word — But It 
Should Be!” 
The m u s c le s of my neck tensed as I leaned toward the professional w ho pu ked at my plaque 
I had to agree with the booklet’s title — it should be a four-let ter word! 
The ordeal reminded me of a friend's friend who is an all time record setting toothbrush sales­ man. Ile keeps dip and chips beside his to oth ­ brush display. Shoppers are invited to have a snack 
Taste 

After tasting what ap­ pears to be sour cream and chives, the customers grimace and exclaim, “ This dip tastes like plaster’ 
“ It i s ! ” the s u p e r s a l e s m a n re ponds. 
“ Want to buy a toothbrush?" 
Just as his customers. I rinsed again. After an hour in the dental chair, I took my new toothbrush and headed for the park­ ing lot. 
“ In S a ltb u r n . E n g ­ land,” the ca r’s radio re­ lated, “ Kim ‘The J a w s’ 
Tinkler (w ith his abnorm­ ally healthy set of ivories) has lust pulled a in ne-and-a* ha lf-ion bus with his t e e t h ! ” The newscaster went on to say that a fter 
T i n k l e r 's dubious a c c o m p l i s h ­ ment, lie announced to witnesses. “ It's left me with a stiff neck!" 
It occurred to me as strange, as I drove home to my Excedrin bottle. that with my mouthful of cracked enamel — I had the same symptom from lust sitting in the dentist’s office!

Nothing can make you appreciate the fact that your teeth are internal as much as seeing a full scale model of your mouth in muddy pink plaster. 
“ Actually, your teeth are very h e a lth y , ” my dentist said after show­ ing me the model and lull set of X -rays. “ H ow­ ever," he added, “ You do have a few p r o b l e m s which can be overcome with a lot of good care.” 
(And a lot of good dol­ lars. I th o u g h t to m y ­ self.) 
“ How long will these crowns l a s t ? ” I as k ed him as we discussed my road to dental happiness. 
“ They will last longer than your teeth will in their present condition," he w as honest.

MCELDOWNEY and Mrs. L. Lowry 
Mays meet in the garden of Christ 
Episcopal Church to make plans for the 4 o th annual 
Home and Garden 
Pilgrimage 

Tour dates announced 

Christ Episcopal 
C hurch will sponsor its 4oth annual San 
Antonio Home and 
Garden P ilgrim age 
Saturday and Sun­ day, March 26-27. 
Each year several outstanding homes and gardens in San Antonio are featured on the tour. 
This year the homes of 
Ct. Gen. and Mrs. Allen 
M. Burdett dr.. Mr. and 
Mrs. dames I*. Robinson 
II. Don Morris. M r. and 
M rs. W a lte r F. Brown and Robert Daubed will be shown 

\ is i t o r s 

Started by the Women ot 
Christ Episcopal Church at the suggestion of Mrs. doseph R. Murphy, tin' first pilgrim age attract­ ed 3oo people. 
Now more than 5,ooo visitors attend the annual event. 
The tour will be from noon to H p.m. each day. 
Tour buses w ill leave 
M u n icipal A ud itoriu m between 11:3o a.m. and 2 p.m.

$2 and $1 for children.

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. I 3 1977 
Love fosters a happy life 

The day before Valentine’s 
Day is a good day to learn that 
Marvin and C’leta Foster agree 
Z that love is one of the magic 
“ ingredients that make a mar- 
* riage and family life successful. 

Pieta says. “ Other important things in our family plan include being in the 
1 church, having respect for each other and doing m any things together." 
Marvin agrees and adds, “ M arriage is a cooperative thing. We work to­ gether towards the sam e goals and feel like we accomplish things together." 
The F osters have been m arried 17 years and have a seven-year-old son, 
Kevin, and a 13-year-old d a u g h te r, 
• Krisie. 
Marvin 
Marv in grew up on a farm in the Red 
River Valley near Vernon and Cleta was born and raised in a small rural town, Oklaunion, near the Oklahoma border in Texas. 
“ We knew each other all of our lives, practically,” Cleta says. “ We were in school and church together. We noticed each other the last couple of years of high school and started dating." 

M arvin received his B S. degree from Midwestern University, his m as­ ter’s degree in science from University of Montana and his m aster s in educa­ tion from Trinity University. 
Cleta and Marvin m arried after she had graduated from Midwestern Uni­ versity and he resumed his studies. 
For three sum m ers, he received a 
National Science F oundation Grant and he and his family camped in Big Bend 
National Bark where he did research for his m aster’s in science. 

The family moved to San Antonio in 
I DHI and Marvin taught science and coached at Connell Junior High. Ile ta u g h t biology ut H ig h lan d s High 
School for four years. 
H<> is now vice principal at Sam 
Houston Senior High School after serv­ ing as dean for two years. 
Active m em bers at Baptist Temple, 
M arvin has se rv e d on m any committees. Ile is a third grade Sunday 
School te a c h e r, an ac tiv e d eaco n , chairman of Education Loan and office committees, on budget com m ittee and just retired as chairman of deacons 
He also sings in the choir and is a s s is ta n t coach for th e w o m e n ’s softball and basketball teams. He did 
Wom be honored 

“ W om en of A ch ie v e­ m ent” is Hie theme of a 
Saturday meeting of the 
W om en’s Clubs of San 
Antonio being held at ll a in. in the ballroom of 
San 
A ntonio C ou n try 
Club. 
Special tribute will be paid to the IO Outstand­ ing Women of the Year chosen by Express-News readers. 
Clubs participating are 
Altrusa, Business & Pro­ fessional Women, Mexi­ can-A m erica ii Business 
& Professional Women. 
Pilot, Quota. Soroptomist aud Zonta. 
G eneral ch a irm an of the meeting is Mrs. Dor­ othy Pukka, prsesident of 
Soroptomist ( lull 
The program will begin with a luncheon followed by a style show coordi­ nated by Col Mary Bag- gan, president of Quota 
Club. Fashions from Mi­ chael's of Colonies North will bi> featured

MEDICAID PATIENTS WELCOME 

 som e basketball officiating for the 
Southwest Conference but no longer has the time. 
Golfing and fresh arid salt water fishing are hobbies of his. 
The fam ily loves to ca m p at state parks. 
“ I guess I’ve still got farming in my blood,” Marvin says. “ I love yard work and gardening.” 
He grows straw b erries and other berries and he turns these and Mustang grapes into jelly for the family. He enjoys playing chef in the kitchen and at the barbeque grill 
Cleta 
Pieta taught a year at Weaver, Okla., before m arriage and then was secre­ tary' on cam pus while he finished col­ lege. 
In San Antonio, she taught eight years at Herman llirsch, a year at Inez 
F oster and is now in her third year at 
Pecan Valley Elem entary School She taught different ages and finds her first graders, with 32 iii the class, to be very challenging. 

'Marriage is a coopera­ tive thin p. H e work to­ gether towards the same goals a n d f e e l like we a t ea rn p I is h 
I h i ii gs t o g e th e r — 
Marvin hos­ ier 

She is director of the third grade department in Sunday School and on the Education Committee. She plays 
Sunday School Athletic League basket­ ball and has pitched quite a few years out of the past six on the softball team 
Sewing is her “ relaxing” hobby. She makes most of her own wardrobe. Shi* bas made pants and ties for Marx in, 
T-shirts for Kevin and a bedspread witll over 3(1o squares. 
“ I used to m ak e all of K ris ie ’s clothes, until she hit the jeans age.” 
Pieta laughs, “ Jeans are out of my line.” 
She enjoys cooking and housekeeping 
— on the run. Her family likes her beef stroganoff, pizza and ham burgers. 
The family would like to return to 
Montana where they made friends and do more mountain camping iii neigh­ boring stales 
Last sum m er, the family attended a 
Southern Baptist Convention at Virgin­ ia Beach aud enjoyed a trip through 
Jam estow n, colonial W illiam sburg, 
Washington I) P and other beautiful and historically interesting spots 
K risic* 
Krisie is a seventh grader in Salado 
Middle School. She finds working in the office very interesting. 

She s in the Art Club, Patriots pod squad and Student Council. She hopes to continue in pep squad at East Cen­ tral High School. 
Keeping her busy are piano and gymnastic lessons which she’s taken for about four years. There was a break 
— due to an arm with a break. 
Look out Nadia — Krisie is becoming I better all the time on the bar, beam, vault, floor and trampoline. 
She likes to collect jewelry. She has competed in swimming at Pecan Val­ ley Country Club, likes to skate, skate­ board, bike, go to the coast and to slum ber parties. 
“ I really like to ride horses, but I only get to when we visit my G rand­ mother at Vernon,” she says. 
Krisie took home the grand prize this week iii the Junior High Science fair on her biological entry. Her radish and bean seedlings were winners. 
At church she’s in the Youth Choir, 
A ct-T een s and P o w e r Line S tudy 
Group. The young people are planning a trip to Glorietta, N M. this sum m er. 
They have enjoyed overnight camping at “ His Hill” at Comfort. 
The young people have an “ Adopt a 
G ra n d m o th e r P r o g r a m ’’ to c h e e r housebound elderly church members. 
Cards, visits, calls and gifts are part of the project. 
She would like to be an interior decorator when she is grown. 
Kevin 
Kevin is a second grader at Pecan 
Valley E lem entary. He’s just disco­ vered Social Studies and he likes it — but he can’t really explain yet what it is. 
He knows they’re studying jobs and be knows he wants to be a fireman when he grows up. Kevin’s basketball team at church just won a first place trophy in the 7-9 year old division 

He enjoys bicycles, jum ping on Ins tram p o lin e,aiy l s k a tin g and s w im ­ ming 
Last year he started to learn golf and after taking lessons he goes out with his 
Dad. 

He collects “ s tic k e rs ” or decals. 
"Y ou’ll find them everyw here,” Ins family laughs. 
He likes to draw and Army and war pictures are his specialty. 

He would bkt* to go exploring iii outer space if he could go anywhere he wanted to. Star Trek is a favorite show of his and he likes to make airships and moon landings. 

He tried ice seating once but said the ice hurt his knees — so he may not rush back. 
His household chore is the standard uninteresting one for small boys — carrying out the garbage. 

Kevin is quite happy when he’s play­ ing with som e of the fam ily pets. 
There s Charcoal and Tiger, the cats; 
Taffy, the dog; and Jum per, the huge white friendly rabbit. 

The Festers believe that Valentine theme song. “ What the World Needs 
Now is Love Sweet Love.”

The MARVIN FOSTERS, Kevin and Krisie

MARY SLE MILLER 

A smoky, hazy look is desirable in eye shadow , but the Upline should be clearly defined. Unless it is neat, lipstick s e e m s unfinished — unkempt. 
Owing to weather- winter - rough, chapped skin — m any L ovelies find a clean line im pos­ sible to draw . 
B e tte r c a r e would doubtless help lo smooth the skin and c le a r th e line. Here are a few lip- care tips: 
G uard against the h a­ bit of wetting or licking the lips. T h e h a b it is harder on lip complexion than the weather 
Cleanse the lips several tim es daily and at b ed ­ tim e w ith c le a n s in g cream. 
Keep a lip-healing stick beside your tied, ap p ly ­ ing it last thing at night and first th in g iii th e morning. 
Redo lip color often 
The lip co n tain s no oil g la n d s and n eed s the m o is tu riz in g a good cream y lipstick provides 
And just in time for a rescue is new, automatic lipcolor — super-shiny," frcsli and lovely. The co­ lor comes in a wand with a sponge up that shapes 

 while it colors. 
V ou can choose your s h a d e s at a g la n c e b e ­ cause the wand is a see- thru th at’s unbreakable. 
The shades, such as v iv id rose pink and real red. look wet and wonderful. 
A great way to patch split lips. 
Model lips 

F ifty ways to ideal skin and natural makeup for young adults — ages 13 to 
19 — are detailed in nix booklet. M ODEL T IP S 
FOK TEENS.

Cauliflower contest 

Of all the vegetables to choose from—fresh most of the year and always available in the freezer case, cauliflower p roba­ bly is the one home cooks do the least with 

Yet th e re a re s u p e r ways to dress up” this excellent vegetable that will he the category for the next San A ntonio 
News food section con test 
Five dollars will go to 
Hie person entering the liest recipe using cau li­ flower by m ailing it to gi'LMid Editor. The News. 

Pox 21/1, hun Antonio, 
Tex. 78297 before Feb. 17. 
Write your recipe on one side of a sheet of palier, tell why it is your favorite and sign your n am e, giv m g your a d ­ dress and daytim e tell** phone number 
Oilily tested reel J ms are elig ib le , and only one entry from each contes­ tant will bt* considered 
The w inning recipe using cauliflower wilt he p u b lis h ed 
M arch 
3

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S— Sun. Feb. 13 1977 ornia Fashion 

Monday marks the official opening of Frost’s “California 
Fashion Rush.’’ 
The tribute to the Sunshine 
State will continue throughout 
February and will feature fa­ shions, designers, executives, art, wines, cheeses, coiffures and displays keyed to California. 

All three F ro st’s stores in San An­ tonio will participate, as well as the store in Austin’s Northcross Mall. 
T he sa lu te was launched w ith a weekend style previewing sprint-into- sum m er fashions from California de- signes S aturday in F ro s t's C ourt, 
North Star Mall. 
Monday and Tuesday, the ‘‘Fashion 
Hush” gains momentum with informal modeling of the award-winning collec­ tion of H olly’s H arp, cu rren tly the toast of American fashion. Jim Harp, husband of the Los Angeles designer, will be here both days.

NORTH STAR MALL 

Feminine 

Holly has been advocating the softer side of fashion for at least nine years. 
In an Express-News story from the 
Los Angeles Times News Service, fa­ shion editor Mary Iou Luther writes: 
“ For Holly Harp, the current fashion movement away from classic, man- tailored clothes to the soft, sexy clothes she staked out as early as I RHS is directly attributable to what she calls the evolution of woman's identity.” 
In other words, Holly explains, wo­ men started wearing mannish clothes to prove they weren’t the “ stereo-typi­ cal” female — “ dainty little things,” that is. 
After awhile, she continues, they began to feel they were m issing so­ mething and wanted to look pretty, too. 
Holly creates the soft sexy styles, but she is an advocate of. alternative dressing. 
“ Be tailored or be a cream puff,” she says. “ It’s an exercise in choice.” 
Her spring-sum m er collection, pre­ viewed for the fashion press in New 
York earlier in the season, features dreamy, sheer, drapey fantasies for day as well as evening. But they an* easy-to-wear for women with figures for soft fabrics. (M ore about Holly below). 
\ ineyards 

During the informal showing of the collection, visitors will be invited to sip wine from the Beaulieu Vineyards in 
Napa Valley and champagne from the 
Korbel Winery in Guerneville. 
They’ll also taste original sourdough breads from San Francisco’s Boudin 
Bakeries (established in 1849), as well as original Monterey Jack cheese first m ade on the Jack fam ily ranch in 
Monterey, Calif. 
All this will be against the back­ ground of fresh flowers flown in from 
California by American Airlines and an exhibition of works by C alifornia s contemporary artists.

Designer Holly Harp has Texas connection 
FINAL CLEAN UP 
SHOE SALE 

California’s Holly Harp, who sends her collection to Frost 
Bros, this week, has a definite 
“Texas connection.'’ 

Today, Holly is well-established on the fashion m ap. But she got her lool-hnld a few years back in what be­ gan as a sandal designing stin t in 
Mexico. 
Frustrated because there was no fa­ shionable ready-to-w ear around to complement her designs, she had her own wardrobe custom-made from w hat was available—“ funny old Mexican fabrics.” 
The clothes w ere such a hit with everyone, she was encouraged to return to school and study art and fa­ shion design at N orth T exas S tate 
University. 
There she not only got a degree, but a husband who just happened to also be her English professor. 
In I9K8, with a small loan from her father, she opened a small boutique on 

L.A.’s fabled “ Sunset Strip.” Holly’s boutique pros|»ered, becoming a refuge for well-to-do rock stars. 
( hanging h er sty le from the 
“ feathers and fringe” costumerie for which she became known, she gained a whole new clientele— such stars as All, 
McGraw, Liza Minnelli, Dinah Shore, 
Barbara W alters. 
Holly Harp became a star in her own right with innovative fashion shapes and handpainting on fabrics. 
By 1973 her clothes attracted enough attention to warrant a wholesale line and to pick up two Coly Award nomin­ ations. 
By 1978, a $1o,ooo investment in the little boutique had been parlayed into a million-and-a-half dollar corporation. 
However, Holly Harp still does not take her success for granted. As the 
.designer, recently turned 37, says,’* 
W henever I’m try in g to m ake an aesthetic decision. I always go in the direction of taking chances. I think that’s an im portant element in any art," 

 la d ie s F oot-S o-P orl - D ick erson 's - F ool Savers

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. 13 1977 
Jet gala takes off 
Saturday 

Want t(t take an imaginary flight aboard a 
727 jet? You can do so Saturday. 

You’ll have cham pagne, fashions and music. Plus one of Braniff’s much talked about 727 jets decorated by A lexander 
(’alder. 

Ala Cortada, an organization of former flight at­ tendants representing all airlines, is presenting the gala — complete with Kleig lights on the aircraft — from 6:3o to IO p.m. Saturday. The public is invited, to meet and mingle aboard the aircraft and Braniff’s 
Departure Lounge No. 27 at International Airport. 
Entertainment 

Fashions from Clothes Etc. are being selected to dress women for a trip around the world. Entertain­ ment will be provided by the Harlaridale High School 
Stage Band and by strolling musicians Donna Pea­ cock and Carol Adams.

Seventh Avenue is striking gold 

NEW NORK — When they bundle into their furs and scarves to leave the show­ rooms where summer collections are being shown, most viewers are smiling. 

B y 
That isn’t because Se­ venth Avenue is less fri­ gid than anyplace else 
If s because, collective­ ly, the clothes are the li­ veliest and gayest in years. 
Designers haven’t been necessarily struck with inspiration, nor do the collections display a wild streak of inventiveness. 
They’re simply good hu­ mored and easy, and that's enough to put an­ yone rn a pleasant frame of mind. 
While the mini revival is stirrin g up a sm all amount of concern (will or w on’t women wear them off the beach?), it s the only area of unease. 
For the rest, the summer clothes are loose and re­ laxed and there’s so ­ mething for everybody. 
G litter 

There s a tendency to add a bit of glitter to both silk and cotton — Un* do­ m inant fab rics — by rim m ing the clothes iii gold braid or, at least, adding a gold kid bell. 
There can, of course. 
Im* tiMi much of a good thing and there are mo­ ments when the gold standard is overwhelm ­ ing Oscar de La Ha ma, in 

BERNADINE 
MORRIS 
* lIU E w rw ;, SERVI 
N tW VORK 

 cates of gold edging and also know how to keep it under control. 
Oscar de la Renta lets his clothes move as if they had a life fit their own. The movers include gauzy caftans presum a­ bly geared to the to evening separates in pleated silks that float as the wearer moves. 
None of his things make any kind of drama­ tic fashion statement. 
They are sim ply the sort of light, pretty de­ sign that brighten a wo­ m an's spirit, when the sun is high — or after it goes down. They look ef­ fortless from the ca ­ m isole tops to the ai- most-strapless flowered dresses held up by spaghetti strings 
Those gold edges are everywhere, from the beach caftans to chiffon evening floats 
De la 
Itenta has his practical side loo. The evening clothes have interchan­ geable tops, from bare to billowy, so that a clever his evening things, and ' woman could build an 

U b a r l e s s u p p o r t in h i t 
I d o U n w sty blk. g f u A ds ie extensive wardrobe from a couple ut tail tits

"F o r the romantic woman, there will be long flowing coverups which lead a dual life — from poolside to dinner parties.**

Cruising into spring fashions 

Fashion goes cruising Saturday. 
Rhodes will present its first spring cruisewear fashion show' of 1977 at I p.m. in the Grand Court of Wonderland Shopping 
M all. 

Mrs. John Duce is chairman of the event. Mrs. M. 
V. Ehlers is president of Ala Cortada. 

Tickets are available through all Ala Cortadq 
•members or by calling Mrs. Ehlers or Mrs. Buddy 
Miller. 

Purpose of the gala is to raise funds for charities and for a flight attendant scholarship. 

Says M rs Ehlers: "P a rt of being a flight hostess means caring for people and serving them. Although 
Ala Cortada members no longer serve people in the air, we do so on the ground, particularly three local charities. We invite you to share the evening with us and assist us in our charitable endeavors.” 

The event is being planned by Juanada Teas, 
Rhodes’ fashion coordinator. She says: 
"T he runway show will bring out the magic of early spring. Leading off will be beautiful coverups with a ‘hint’ of a bathing suit beneath. 

1 
"Cuffed walking shorts and blouson jackets will In* a featured combination, as will drawstring pants with short cropped jackets — both rn wheat-colored silk.” 
The color story will include the important spring brights as well as the lights. Among fabrics will be such “ naturals’’ as cotton, linen and silk plus easy-care , look-alike blends. 

FR O M London Fog coot collection at Frank Bros. 

All-weather coats will be in the fashion spotlight this week. 
The London F o g col­ lection will be presented by Frank Bros, from ll a.m. to 7 p.m. Monday in the Central P a rk M all store, and at the sam e hours Tuesday in the' 
Windsor Park Mall store. 
Bob Mayer, New York representative of London 
Fog, will be here with the collection. It not only features regular sizes but petites and a new group of half-sizes. 
Mayer points out that the coats are "clim ate- right” for San Antonio. 

President's ball slated 

Canyon Creek Country 
Club will hold its Presi­ dent’s Ball beginning with cocktails at 7 p.m. 
Saturday in the country club. Dinner and dancing to the m usic of Larry 
Herman will follow. 
Tribute will bi* paid to the new board of direc­ tors as well as the outgo­ ing board and past board members. The new pre­ sident is Worley Camp­ bell. The outgoing presi­ dent is J, D. Wysong. 
The President’s Ball is the highlight of the club's social events.

D IA M O N D TIFFANY SO LITARIES 

Skaters learn to cut the ice 

You don't have to fly to Sun 
Valley to learn to ice skate. San 
Antonio has a year around skate school open to all ages and skill levels. 

Whether you are age three or 73, you eau learn to skate for pleasure, Lee 
C arroll Owen, school director and former competitive skater, said. 

Since the skate school opened at the 
Quadrangle Ice Hails last .July, about 
1,ooo persons have gone through it. and 
Kl stu d e n ts have gone on to competitive skating. 

“ F o rm e r northerners living here bring their kids over and start to skate again. Others come because they have never had the opportunity to ice skate.” Owen said. 

There are classes for 3 to 3 year olds, housewives, teens and employed adults of all ages. 

“ Adults tend to think ice skating is dangerous, so we have to overcom e their fear of falling,” Owen said 

He begins by teaching adults how to fall down to avoid injuries. 

It a skater relaxes and bends his knees, he will seldom hurt him self, 
Owen said. 

“ After one practices fallin g down three or four times, he gets the idea.” 

By 
KUNA MCGAFFEY 

Auk) C s 

What is the remedy for ankles that collapse? 
"T h e re is no such thing as weak ankles.” Owen declared. 
"A t first the m uscles in the ankle's get tired, but it is not a weakness.” 
To provide good support, ice skates must fit like a glove. Owen said 
"W e have been taught to get shoes a half-size larger than our feet. I m ea­ sure each person’s feet and put skates on him the exact size of his feet. 
"T h e first couple of weeks the shoe bothers the skater, then he becomes accustomed to it.” 
Those who progress beyond interm e­ diate' d o sse s usually buy custom boots made for their feet. he said. 
I ii teaching. Owen aud his assistant, 
Heidi Drench llahn, use the badge program of the I S 
Figure Skating 
Association. 
Each badge rep resen ts a p e rfo r­ mance test on ice. Skaters com m only sew the badges earned on a skate sweater. 
The basic badge program is divided into eight-week courses for beginning, intermediate and advanced students. 
A skater may repeat any course, with­ out criticism or tim e limit, until he is satisfied with his own performance. 
"T he se three courses teach everyth­ ing one needs to know to enjoy recrea­ tional ice skating.” Owen said. 
The lessons cover lorward and back­ ward skating, some jumps, spins and basic dance steps. 

For more intensive training, skaters pursue the com petitive and dance badge program s. There are prelim in­ ary plus eight tests in the competitive program and 2o dances and six badges in the dance program . 

To complete each program a skater usually practices four to five hours, six days a week during the school year and 
IO hours a day during the sum m er o.er a seven to IO year period. If the pro­ gram s are pursued together, more ice time is required. 

Instruction at the skate school, con ducted on one of the two studio size rinks at the Quadrangle Ice Hails, is limited to the basic badge program. 
Prix ate instruction is available for com petitive skaters. They also are eligible for m em bership in the San 
Antonio Figure Skating Club organized last November. 

On the scale for m easuring physical activity, ska tin g is about 111 tim es better than running. Owen said. 

“ Ii requires total coordination. A l­ most every m uscle is used.” he said. 
Housewives report that ice skating m akes them relax, loosen up. lose pounds and tighten m uscles, Heidi explained 
Owen hopes to start a noon class for businessmen. 
“ Men w orking iii this area could come here and skate for half an hour and feel good the rest of the day.” lie said. 
Although some youngsters begin to skate at age two. they m ostly have a good time at that age, Heidi said. 
“ lf tots fool around on the ice a couple of years, they take off like crazy at age 5 or Ii.” she said. 

Heidi is a ninth test skater from 
Standford, Conn. Since she is in her 
2o s. she still does the difficult m ultiple rotation jumps. 

Owen won 132 m edals in national competition before he gave up skating iii 1935 to attend Purdue University. 
His coach was Eddie Seholdin, killed with his Olym pic team iii a 19H1 B ru s­ sels air crash. 

After a stint in the Navy. Owen en­ tered tin* electronics business aud be­ came a computer expert. Six years ago. he changed careers and returned to ice skating because he enjoys it more than anything he had ever done. 

Before com ing to San Antonio last 
July, he m anaged the Palace Ice Arena in Richardson and served as assistant m anager and “ pro” at the Ice Age in 
Austin. 

His wife. Debby. is a basic skater. 
Their boys. Scott, ll, and Brett, 14, love ne hockey. Their daughter Denise, 13. practices four to ll) hours daily working lier way through the competitive badge program.

TREASURE Discovery Night committee members include Mmes. Andrew Olejer, 
George Bristol, chairman, and Neill 
Baldrick Jr., co-chairman. 

Five expert appraisers from the auction house of 
Sotheby 
Parke 
Hemet will give a free verbal appraisal from 7 to 9:3o p.m. of family treasures thr* guests bring. Appro­ priate items will be ac­ cepted for sale on con­ signment with the auc­ tion firm 
Guests who have no desire to part with their fam ily heirlooms, but would like' to know ex­ actly how much they are worth may discover this fact for themselves. 
The' auction firm's ex­ perts include John E. 
Parkerson, vice presi­ dent, with 
Kenneth 
Winslow. Peter Malone and Pamela Maher from the1 Los Angeles g al­ leries. and Claudia Gian- 

N EPALESE jewel-encrusted open dome carriage from the W itte's 
McFarlin Collection will be appraised at Treasure Discovery 
Night 

 gola from the New York galleries. 
Parkerson w ill ap­ praise paintings and sculpture, Winslow will look over fine furniture, rugs, tapestries, clocks, porcelain and glass; and 
Malone’s specialty is 
Oriental art and objects. 
Miss Maher is interest­ ed in silver and small decorative arts, and Miss 
Giangola is an appraiser of pre-Columbian and ethnographic arts. 
A regional expert will also be on hand to ap­ praise Texana arts and crafts. Guests art1 re­ sponsible for the care and security of their own ob­ jects. 
Items specifically ex­ cluded from the appr­ aisals include stamps, coins, jew elry, dolls, weaponry, Roman, Greek and Egyptian antiquity objects, and American indian. 
One free appraisal will be offered with each $15 admission ticket. Appr­ aisals of additional ob­ jects may be made for $5 an item. Those who prefer may return Satur­ day or Sunday during 
Heirloom Discovery Days and have their items ap­ praised at that time. 
The first of the evening contests will be to locate 
Kl specified objects from the Museum’s permanent collections and guess their value. The objects will be appraised by the visiting experts, and the total value w ill be matched against the answer of each guest. 
Answers nearest the 
Sotheby Parke Hemet to­ tal will receive gift certi­ ficates for SKM). $75. $5o and $25 from the Witte’s 
Museum Shop. 
The second contest will be for members of the 
Museum Association at­ tending the party, as well as for new members who join that night. Coupons will be given to each, and tin* winning name will be drawn. 

M RS. C H ARLES K N IG H T introduces Teri Tillman and 
Janet Brown to sorority life. She is chairman of the 
Panhellenic Forum. 
PHOTO BV RON JO N IS 
Sorority forum 

The San Antonio Panhel­ lenic Association will hold its annual forum for rush and sorority education at 2 p.m. 
Sunday in the Chapman Gra­ duate Center at Trinity Uni­ versity. 

Graduating high school seniors and college transfers who plan to attend a college with National Panhellenic sororities on campus are in- 
\ited, along with parents. 

Each girl should bring a wa I let-size photograph of herself, her college board score, class rank and grade- point average. 

Mrs. Charles Knight is chairman of the forum. 

Active collegiate members from various affiliated soror­ ities will disc uss sorority life, and a panel will present an orientation. 

Learn to 
Super Sew. 

After 8 easy, inexpensive lessons you will have made at least: 
One T-shirt 
One pair of perfect-fit pants 
Three fashion tops 
One skirt 
One sweater 
One suit jacket 
One swimsuit 

Using Ann Arson's unique sewing methods, you sew in a fraction of the time of ordinary sewing You'll learn to fit and to design. 
And its so simple. The classes are fun like a special club meeting. You learn But you love it 

You can make it. We will show you how.
