M E LISSA CARTER m a k e s other W in d cre st first 

C IN D Y C O U N C IL w an ts a perfect heart 

C arp et 

 b y T ed O 'k r e n t 

Youngsters Have Needs; Oldsters Have Needs 
W hy does each of us act as we do? Our youngsters passionately protest and clearly classify their complaints. They see everything as black or white. The black is today with all of its ugly demands of discipline, of traditional faith and thankfulness. The white is tomorrow with all of their personal needs fulfilled. When we sit in session with them and make our plea for reform, they don a con­ venient “hearing-aid” that registers but res­ ponds with muted vagueness. 
We oldsters, on the other hand, set ourselves up as their judge and jury, quickly become despondent about our youth and readily lose faith in the future. We impatiently look for an early happy ending for our every effort and ap­ peal. We seem to forget that we, their elders, are far from perfect. Man must know that he too is neither devil nor angel, merely a blend of each. We must patiently learn to see with their eyes, live with their heartbeat and then con­ scientiously combine our thinking. Let us con­ quer our ego, and admit that there is a reprobate in every ark, a flaw in every dia­ mond and a weed in every garden. 
Every Human Has Three Needs 
Success is found in six simple words: “Find a need and fill it.” Both youngsters and oldsters have three basic needs that motivate them . . . the need for identity, for stimulation, for security. 
Dr. Manslow has wisely said: “As the lack of a needed vitamin will spread disorder through the body, so will the basic starvation of a psychological need spread disorder through mind and emotion.” 
Identity is m ans most powerful need. 
Several years ago, I asked a bored old bachelor millionaire why he worked seven days a week, was interested only in his in­ dustry’s periodicals and never traveled . . . what was his motivating force? He thought for a moment, smiled and answered in one word: 
Pride.” Now he owned two of man s basic needs; identity and security, but lacked the third . . . stimulation. His wealth brought him identity but the smugness of his security became the birthplace of boredom. The effect of unbroken and uninterrupted worldliness had so destroyed his mind that his life became monotonous. 
Boredom Breakers 
There are three ways to break the monotony of life. (I) ... A man is no seven day calculating machine. He should, at least one day each week, take his hands out of his pockets and fold them in prayer. (2) ... Create a new and in­ spiring venture that brings about a break in routine. Though this may become a gamble and even create a crisis, it furnishes a much needed vitamin . . . stimulation. (3) ... The third way to overcome boredom is found in self-denial, in the killing of the ego. Discover a higher love, find and fill another's need compassionately. 
The death of your self-seeking low priorities will automatically create a higher love that furnishes m ans third need; the stimulant that could be our bachelor's additive for a healthy and wholesome life. 
To you youngsters and to us oldsters, let s now take our own inventory; Identity, Stimulant, 
Security. Find your missing need and fill it. 
Two Types of Carpet Mechanics, The Butcher ami the Tailor 
Just as deep concern grips every carpet shopper . , . concern about color, quality and cost; so should her deepest worry be about the quality of workmanship that tailors her broadloom in place. There are two types of men installing carpets today; the butcher and the tailor. 
Having been in this carpet industry for over 
5o years. I know now, more than ever before, that today's carpet construction demands a vast variety of specialized equipment and dedicated study so that long-lasting strength may be added to each carpet yard installed. I know too that there is a specialized and particular way to lay carpet in certain kinds of rooms sub­ jected to different kinds of use and even abuse, 
I Not all carpet mechanics have the ex­ perience, the patience, the tools or even the desire to approach perfection in their work. Not dll carpet buyers are careful enough to de­ mand a 5 year certified, written and registered workmanship warranty. 
Madam carpet buyer, for goodness sake, don't trust to luck. 
Next* Week 
We will discuss: “Buies for recognizing a practical carpet”. Until then, think this over: 
Ifs easy to find your station in life — sooner or later someone will tell vou where to aet off.*'

 parent who is an art major.

Now’ th e c h ild r e n d e c o ra te c o n ­ tainers in class — all alike: 
U n sig n ed v a le n tin e s a re u su ally special. 
I still have a crumpled one complete with a big question m ark. It cost at least a dollar and was a frilly, beauti­ ful trolley car with accordion pleated crepe paper and a “ m ushy” verse. 

Flowers 

Flowers are another way of saying “ I love you.” Florists find it busier than alnipst any holiday. 
“ Since a red rose m e an s love.” 
Manny Luna of the Rose Shop says, 
“ they are still the favorite with pinks and yellows next. 
“ I always suggest a personalized message. Women appreciate a card reading ‘To the greatest love of my life, alw ays’ instead of ‘F ro m your hus­ band. Ja c k .’” 
Rumors have been flying that roses would be sky-high due to the fuel crisis and severe cold weather. W K . Cordts of Kelly-Scherrer says, “ Our roses were ordered long ago and prices will lie the same as last year, $25 a dozen. 
“ To help make the path of true love run smooth we’ll even stay open Sun­ day to see that all Valentine posies 

 reach their destination on time. 
National plant fever has inspired some to give pot plants. 
; 
Spring bouquets with red tulips or hyacinths are also sent to lucky lovers. 

Candy 

For the valentine with a sweet tooth,* there s always candy. A local candy w h o le s a le r d ro p p e d h e a rt-s h a p e d boxes from his line this year due to cost. Others are still turning them out. 

Heart shaped candy boxes in all* colors, sizes and prices arc available. 
King’s and Russell Stover begin w ith a five and a half ounce heart for $1.45 and 
King s has a huge five pound ruffled red heart box for $33. Chocolate ca­ lories are still popular. 
Youngsters still lik.* pastel message hearts and heart shaped lollipops. 

Generous sweethearts give gifts, but not always on a large scale. 

Jewelry, perfume, decorative gifts and stuffed anim als will please her, and comic T-shirts, briefs and towel wraps are available for him. 
Our first Valentine’s Day after m a r­ riag e , I w as th rille d to rec eiv e a heart-shaped box of chocolates I over­ heard a woman shopping say she had received a red Buick. I thought, “ How unsentim ental!” 
Card styles change, candy may be in a plain box with a strip of plastic hearts, and roses may give way to devil’s ivy — but there’s no doubt — love still m akes the world go round. 
Happy Valentine’s Day. Honey!

 lakes. Townspeople used to ride out in buggies for picnics and boat rides, and dan cin g u n d er the s ta rs on a pax Ilion. 
‘Maverick Park in ISH?, a n o th e r scen e, was o r i ­ ginally given by Sam Ma­ verick for the first rail­ road depot. An old train engine is now displayed iii the park that is what s left of tin* original depot. 
Roosevelt 
P a r k was named Riverside Park in 
1898. but was renamed to honor Teddy Roosevelt, who tr a i n e d his Rough 
Riders in that area before 
(hex went to Cuba. 

Iii the s a m e y e a r the 
( hilt Q ueens sold their fare on Alamo and Mili­ tary Plazas, as well as other locations. San An­ tonio became widely ren­ ow nod for chili, wliich or­ iginated here.

Bones Island in 1917 is now the site of the Tower 
Life Building. Originally. this p e n in s u la w as tin* setting for carnivals aud lairs, but it was eliminat­ ed in 1921 when the beild rn the river was straight­ ened for flood control.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS—-Sun. Feb. I 3 1977 
M ondale’s manners are ron the fritz 

T h e re a c tio n in 
Washington drawing rooms to Vice P resi­ dent 
M o n d a le ’s treatm ent of a couple of U.S. am bassadors serving abroad was one of astonishment . 
Those who discussed it cannot recall another such example of ungra­ cious manners in the world of diplomacy. 
The unusual treatment include thi? Vice Presi­ dent 's exclusion of Am­ bassador 
Anne A rm ­ strong from his talks with British officials and from the dinner iii Ins honor. 
Mondale told respected columnist David Broder that “ the political am­ bassadors” were being excluded everywhere “ in the expectation that it might inhibit discussion of new policies . ” 
Such conduct, so con­ trary to .Jimmy Carter's 
“ open government” po­ licy. say the critics, was 

 tantamount to telling 
Ambassador Armstrong that she has been repre­ senting Republicans on­ ly, not the United States of America, while serv­ ing in London, and that nothing she learned as ambassador could possibly add anything of value to the talks 

S n u b 

The British here, who have repeatedly called 
Armstrong “ a fantasti­ cally good ambassador.“ believe that Foreign Se­ cretors Anthon' Cross- land made a point of praising Armstrong at the airport welcome for the Vice President to ease the snub. 
After all, Anne. whom he called “ one of the most effective and popular ambassadors we have ever had here.” i> the 
Republican who wouldn't come back for the COP convention last summer because she w a s in Lon­ don as a representative of the whole United States

I 

She was the only serious­ ly -considered v ice-presi­ dential candidate miss­ ing 
“ I think it was un atro­ cious way to treat a gal­ lant lady and a fine am­ bassador.” said 
House 
Republican leader .John 
Rhodes at a small dinner 
I had thought better of 
Fritz Mondale.” 
Exclaimed a friend to 
Evangeline 
Bruce, 
“ t an’t you imagine the uproar if Spiro Agnew had gone to London for official talks and excluded David from participation’."” 
Though David Bruce served as ambassador to several countries he was not a Foreign Service of­ ficer and Mondale per­ mitted only 
FSD en­ voys to take part 
Replied Mrs. Bruce. 
“ Nixon and Kissinger went to London iii 1969 when we were packing up 

 to leave and David was included in the talks w ith 
Prime Minister Wilson and was invited to the dinner in their honor.” 
Japan 

And London was not the only place where the 
American ambassador was belittled. It didn’t happen in 
Rome or 
Brussels where .John 
Yolpe and Leonard F ir ­ estone had cleared out, or in Paris where Ken Rush must have been tipped off because he left town. 
But in Japan, where 
Ambassador 
Jam es 
Hodgson met the V.P. at the airport. Mondale twice announced in pub­ lic that President Carter was going to appoint a high caliber ambassador to Japan. A man of 
Hodgson's standing de­ serves something better. 

( ^ outp u t 

Elizabeth Taylor has gained 2ft pounds since her engagement to John 
Warner. “ That's from contentment.” said 
Warner's secretary, who still speaks glowingly of 
Liz's happy nature and thoughtful ways. 
Elizabeth’s content­ ment must derive from a full life and the together­ ness she and John have virtually around the clock. When John had a 

 speaking engagement that delayed his arrival in 
L.A. last week where she w as filmed for her cameo role in “ Winter K ills.” she began burning up the telephone wires. 
When they w ent to New 
York for her fittings for the role he went with her. 
When they walk into a party it's arm-in-arm. 
Even when engaged in conversation with so­ meone else* he reaches for her hand. Her expression is that of a woman who is loved and is loving it. 
Any doubts as to whether Elizabeth would help her new husband win the next Virginia gu­ bernatorial or Senate race have been dispelled. 
John exclaimed at the 
Heart of Gold ball in 
Richmond, “ W e’ve had the most wonderful time traveling all over the state! 
And if “ all over the stale” was anything like their Richmond recep­ tion. 
Liz has been mobbed, kissed, grabbed and charged by fans, au­ tograph-seekers and pho­ tographers 
That’s the way it was at the pre-ball cocktail par­ ty in the Michael Ballan- tines’ beautiful Georgian mansion where 3oo peo­ ple fought for a glimpse or touch. 
Even so, the Warners 

PLUMPLY beautiful Elizabeth 
Taylor and husband John Warner 

 personally shook hands with all the hall guests at the 
Richmond 
Hyatt 
House, and when it was all over said they would be glad to be honorary chairmen again next year. 
And through it all Liz was nursing a sore right 
A sale on wheels!

Elans for a traveling thrift shop will be pre­ sented at the second an­ nual luncheon meeting of 
Hie Alamo Boy's Ranch 
Auxiliary on Saturday. 

Judge Carol liaherman will speak at the Plaza 
Club session and Mrs. 
Richard B Parker will outline plans for the sh op 

The Auxiliary has been given use' of an old home in northeast San Antonio and will use tin1 resi­ dence for thrift item storage. 

At periodic intervals auxiliary members will move the items by van for regional rummage sales all over San Anton­ io 

Guests of honor for the luncheon meeting will be 
Miss Helen Campbell and 
Mesdames Jack Lam ­ bert. Alton Newell, and 
Otto Linhurt. 

 hand from breaking the main bone of her middle finger when she slipped on the ice in Gestaad, 
Switzerland. 
That was her third ac­ cident since she and John started going together. 
The first time she fell off his son’s motorcycle, the second time, off one of his horses. 
So what did John mean when he announced last 
October, “ We want to lead basically a quiet life and I ’m sure we can achieve that” ? 

Candidates will speak 

San Antonio Republi­ can Women’s Club will meet in the TeePee Steak 
House for coffee at 9:3o a.m. Monday. The four candidates for mayor have accepted invitations to speak and answer questions. 

The candidates include 
Mayor Lila Cockrell. L. 
C. Glasco. Dr. Jose San 
Martin and John Mon- frey. Anyone interested is welcome. 

With the film ing in 
L.A. over they were to head back to Virginny to take to the road again — 
John making speeches, 
Liz lecturing on theater at Madison College, Mary 
Baldwin College and 
Stuart Hall. 

Praise 

They are a powerhouse pair with genteel ap­ proach and people are beginning to wonder w hat other candidate pair can match them individually or collectively. 

President Carter’s No. 
I assistant, Hamilton 
Jordan, was praised to the skies by former De­ mocratic national chair­ man Bob Strauss at an 
Iranian embassy dinner the other ev ening. 

The party was in honor of Her Imperial Highness 
Princess Shams Pahlavi, eldest sister of the Shah and owner of the fabulous 
Moon Palace in Teheran, and Jordan wasn’t even there. 

But when his name came up during cocktails 
Bob couldn’t say enough nice things about him. “ I wish he were my son. 
Th at’s the way I feel about him. I think he’s first-rate, a sensitive, warm able human be­ ing,” stated Strauss and that was only the begin­ ning. 

Princess Shams’ beau­ teous young daughter 
Princess Shahrzad and her 
American bride- 

Howard Burris, Jr., were at the dinner along with her brother Prince Shah- baz w ho is a look-alike for 
Burris. 
Spoiled 

 groom. handsome 

Out-of-towners among the 5o-some guests were d oris Leachman’s hus­ band. producer George 
Englund. and his sweet young traveling compan­ ion Bonny Graves. 

Englund ignored the pretty wife of an Iranian diplomat on his right and spent the entire meal talking business to an 
Iranian man. 

And when his host. 
Ambassador Ardeshir 
Zahedi, came over to the table and smilingly sug­ gested a switch of guests because three men were mistakenly seated in a row, Englund quashed the idea because he hadn’t finished talking business. Are all Hol­ lywood producers spoiled rotten? 

'Natty Ivory Coast Am­ bassador 
Timothee 
Ahousu, who escorted bis gorgeous wife Germaine, said they had been glued to “ Roots” on TV like everyone else. 

Said the African envoy, 
“ This is the only country in the world where this kind of show would be put on. No other country would present a film so critical of itself.” 

Ahousa was also im ­ pressed with the even­ handed treatment. He did not think it was racist.

DEAK JE N N IF E R : 
I work eight to 1ft h o u rs a d a y iii the legal department cit a large company. I love my job, Gilt my body shows signs of aging a lot laster than my 
27 Nears. 
I used to be iii top shape, played v iii ley bull. tennis and went to a water ballet class two evenings a week 
Now I do nothing but work, and my diet is catch as catch can. I have gained IO pounds and al! that girlish muscle has turned to middle-age flab. 
I abhor the condition I ’m in but 

 r By 

JENNIFER ANDERSON 

 don’t know how to change it with my present lifestyle. Do you have some miracle rehabilitation pro­ gram lor a “ body gone wrong” ? 
— Denise D.. Cleveland. 
Twenty-seven is too early to talk of middle-age flab As busy as you are. vou’ll have to take your ex­ ercise standing up. 
Here is a workingwom an* guide to exercise. Since some of these will look a little provocative, you might want to take cover behind a filing cabinet! 
T U M M Y 
T U C K : 
Interlace fingers and place them over the fullest part cd’ your stomach. 
Breathe in deeply and press hard, with your bunds. Count to five and repeat 1ft times. 
Now hook thumbs around the 

 waist and pull the rib cage up. 
Spread fingers and press down and in. Exhale a s vou press to the count of five. Do ii). 
BREAST FIRM : Stand tall and put the hands on the waist, elbows bent. Try to touch your elbows behind your back. Thrust the chest out. raise the rib cage and let the head fall naturally bac k. 
I Did to a count of fiv e and do 111. 
(This is a wonde rful relaxer for tight, tense upper shoulder mus­ cles as well.) 
ARM TONER: Extend the arms tint I rom the* shoulder. Clench the fis ts and make the* arms rigid. 
Rotate artus t rot ii shoulder 1ft times forward and 1ft times bac k 
LEG SH A PER: Slip off vour shoes and walk on high tiptoes. lense the entire leg from hip to toe. luke ll) steps aud sink to the heels. Walk on the heels for IU steps anil switch back to the toes. 
Do live of each interspersed.

T rin ity ’s continuing education department will hold a one-day workshop for educators from 9 a.rn. to 4:3o p.m. 
Feb. 18 in the Refectory conference room. 

The course is designed for school adm inistra­ tors. principals, depart­ ment heads, supervising teachers and all those in­ terested in the accounta­ bility and assessment of teachers. 

In a simulated teaching session, participants will study the relation of teacher behavior to stu­ dent achievement, and' will identify observation­ al techniques for rating the teacher. 

Continuing education units will bi* awarded 
The Soft fee charged will include lunch.

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. I 3 1977 

Go easy on child 

DEAR ABBY: I have a prob­ lem that is positively driving me up the wall. Our 7-year-old son still wets the bed — every night! 
W e’ve tried everything, including taking him to several doctors. They all say there is nothing physically wrong with him. 
I am sick and tired of washing sheets and pajam as every day. Please tell me how to h an d le this. — READY TO 
GIVE EP 
DEAR READY: 
You say y o u ’ve tried “ e v e ry th in g .” lf you h a v e n ’t tried the “ Wee Alert Buzzer” (Sears catalogue), please do. If that doesn’t work, continue to wash the sheets and pajam as every day and say nothing. 
Now I’ll tell you w hat NOT to do: 
DON’T tell your son that he could quit if he really wanted to — that he’s just too lazy to get up and go to the bath­ room; that he’s a “ baby” ; that you’re asham ed of him, and he is driving you up the wall. 
Resign yourself to the fact that you are only one of ab o u t 2o m illio n 
A m e ric a n m o th e rs w ith th e s a m e problem , and although it’s not plea­ sant, there are worse fates. 
If there are no bedw etters in your family, there probably were on your husband’s side because bedwetting is usually hereditary. And be sure to tell your son that, too. It will m ake him feel less guilty. 

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. 13 1 9 7 7 

Good Samaritans disappear 

Everyone has a problem. What's yours? For a personal reply, write to 
ABBY: Express-News, Box 2171, San 
A ntonio, T ex ., 78297. E n close a stam ped, self-ad d ressed envelope, please. 

DEAR ABBY: 
I am engaged to a wonderful fellow. He is kind, consider­ ate and polite. Ile is almost perfect. 

Ours is a long-distance romance, as he travels, but when we get together with other people, I find he has one fault that is very irritating. 

He likes to do more than his share of the talking. With me alone, this is not true. I am a rather quiet person and seeing him dominate every conversa­ tion in public irritates me. 

Should I mention this to him. or let it go? I am afraid that after we m arry, this may be a sore spot with us. — 
IRRITATED 

DEAR IRRITATED: Yes. tell him in as kind a way as you can. Not in criti­ cism. but in “ love." 
If you let it go, the irritation will grow, and the first tim e he leaves the cap off the toothpaste y o u 're apt to clout him with a skillet. 

You m ay have heard the story. In the midst of a winter blizzard in Iowa, a young woman d riv ­ ing alone skidded off a country road. 
U n ab le to m ove h er car, she started walking to w ard th e n e a r e s t dwelling. 
When she knocked on the fa rm h o u s e door, a voice answ ered through the door telling her to go away. She stru g g le d to the next farmhouse. The sam e thing happened. It h a p p e n ed yet a th ird tim e b efo re sh e w as spotted by a bus driver. 
B e cau se she w as not dressed for the elements, she had already suffered some frostbite. She was saved from a worse fate by the good S a m a rita n action of the bus driver. 
She was quoted by re ­ p o rte rs as p la n n in g to return, when the weather was better, to the farm s where she had sought re­ fuge to ask th e folks, 
“ Why?” 

In recent years, the re ­ luctance of people to be 

 good Sam aritans and be­ com e “ involved” when others cry for help has been well publicized. 
Most widely reported was the 1984 rape-m urder of Kitty Genovese in New 
York City. There, not one of 38 people who heard or saw w hat was going on did anything to help. 
Almost everyone h a s been in a position of being s tr a n d e d and n e e d in g help sometime in life. I recall running out of gas at one o ’clock in the morning on a turnpike. 
Ten or 12 of the few cars on the road at that hour w hizzed by u n til one pulled over. 
In it, a young m an was traveling with his wife and two small children; the backseat was full of b elo n g in g s. 
He had stopped in spite of his wife’s protestation that he shouldn't. the argum ent continued until 
I got in. And he gave me a lift to th e next i n t e r ­ change. 
Most people don’t like to think of themselves as 
“ u n -carin g .” Most say they would help someone in distress. Yet, not all actually do. and there are 

INSIGHTS 

Y et a n o th e r p e r s p e c ­ tive on this dilem m a is offered by three psycho­ logists at the 
City 
University of New York. 
Writing in “ Psychology 
T o d ay ,” they re p o rted reactions to a lost child asking for help in several la rg e cities and sm all towns. 

Dr. \1enninger invites >our com m en ts and questions 
Write to him in care of the San Antonio Express, P.O. Bov­ i l l ! , San Antonio Tex., 78297. Because of the volume of mail, he cannot answer each individually hut will handle questions of general interest in his column 

H t s 

 d iffe ren t rea so n s why. 
The two most striking are fear of the stranger and a personal com m itm ent of higher priority. 

Commitment 

Think of the last time you were driving down the road and saw a car stranded. You may have given a prayer of thanks that it w asn’t you, as you drove on. 

You were late for an- appointm ent or com m it­ ted to s o m e th in g that didn’t allow for any time out to help others. 

Besides, you probably 

 assu m ed that else would help. Or the police or highway patrol would stop as p art of their job They are more p rep a re d to cope with emergencies, anyway. 
In addition, you m ay have had sufficient look at the cur and the people to have d o u b ts about whether you could trust them. 
F ear of the stranger is a powerful deterrent to helping, despite the fact that this fear is generally out of proportion to reali­ ty. The vast majority of people seeking help are not robbers or rapists or m urderers. 

Less than half (48 per cent) of the large city dwellers responded with an offer to help a lost som eone ch ild ; n e a rly th re e - fourths (72 per cent) of the small town folks did 
And in the small towns, 

 even those who d id n 't help w ere usually sy m ­ pathy. 
In the big cities, most who refused to help “ did so a b ru p tly ,” ignoring the child, swerving, s id e s te p p in g . 
O th e rs , with hardly a pause, put se o m e m oney in th e child’s hand and moved on. 
Not all the large cities were the sam e. Boston and P h ilad e lp h ia w ere most u n sy m p ath etic — two-thirds refused to help. In New York City, it was 5o-5o. In Chicago, two-thirds helped. 

Mean cards nothing new 

Dear Ann Landers: 
I went shopping for a really sweet Valen­ tine a few days ago 
— something special for a person very dear to my heart. 
You w o u ld n ’t believe what the stores have on their rac k s th ese days. 
For every V alentine ex­ pressing tenderness and iove there are at least a dozen that are downright mean and insulting. 
Will you please give me 
(and others) your opinion of this rotten new idea? 
Am I c ra z y or is it a s y m p to m of a sick 

 society? — Betsy in Du­ buque 
Dear Betsy: 
I hate to disillusion you, dear, but very few ideas, good or bad, are really new. 
A cc o rd in g to 
Sally 
H o p k in s, 
D ire c to r of 
H a ll m a r k ’s H is to ric a l 
Collection, some peculiar

They were called “ Penny 
Dreadfuls,” “ Rudes and 
C rudes,” also "V inegar

 d a p p e r stick in g out of her mouth. The message; 
“ Y our tongue is ever on the swing and has a harsh, discordant ring. 
“ How- I hate its scold­ ing tone. Your clapper is the curse of home.”

Som e say th e P e n n y 
D read fu ls wfere a r e a c ­ tion to the stuffy morality of the mid-Victorian era. 
People w anted to get aw ay fro m th e s ic k e n ­ ingly sw eet se n tim e n ts and phony P u r it a n is m expressed in Valentines. 
T hey gobbled up these insulting cards and sent th e m a n o n y m o u s ly , of course. 
One year in the 18oos, the Chicago Post Office refused to deliver 2o,ooo of the nasty m essages on the g ro u n d s they w ere 
“ vicious and obscene." 
If those folks could see what passes through the mails TODAY, they’d be whirling in their graves!

Girl is normal 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: 
My daughter started her period exactly one month after her ninth birth d ay . 
Is this normal? I think she is too young, and wonder it so­ mething can be done to stop them. — Mrs. A.D.L. 
Take this in stride, it is young, of co u rse, but not su fficien tly young to be abnormal. 
There has been a trend toward earlier onset of m enses in modern society. A re c en t study am ong 
British girls indicates that m en­ struation begins th ere between the ages of 9 and 17. 
The average is about 13, with as many beginning before the aver­ age as after it. In 189o the average age was 18 months later. The U.S. average is just below 13. 
Y our d a u g h te r pro b ab ly has shown other signs of sexual m a ­ turity. A thorough physical at this point should verify that she is a normal youngster. 
.lust be su re you explain the p henom enon to h er and avoid sh o w in g any of y o u r co n c e rn . 

Nothing need he done or should he done to sto p h e r cy c le s. 
Incidentally, this first m enstrua­ tion can occur without ovulation. 
The medical definition of p re­ cocious puberty is that which oc­ curs before the age of Kl in boys and before 8 in females. 
One theory accounting for the younger age of puberty involves the more favorable nutrition and general health of fem ales today as opposed to that of years ago. 
Thus, while 14-year-old Juliet m ay have m a rrie d her Romeo, the couple most likely would have been childless for several years, had their rom ance not ended in tragedy. 

Feet 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: Are there exercises that help strengthen the arches of the feet? I have flat feet and have worn special lifts and heels on my shoes all my life. As a hom em aker I am on my feet all day. I am 5-foot-5 and weigh 118 pounds. 
My arches are getting so bad that I am stretching my shoes out 

By L 
GEORGE C. 
TH O STESO N , M D. 

 of shape in two months. — Mrs. 
M D . 
While there are m any sm all muscles in the foot, flat feet are usually caused by structural de­ fects in the bones and their con­ necting ligam ents. Many folks adjust to flat feet with no sym p­ toms. For others, like yourself, pain can he great. 
It is doubtful that exercises will help much in relieving discom ­ fort. You get enough of that walk­ ing around doing your chores all day. W arm foot baths can provide some relief. 
Exercises, such as curling your toes over the edge of a telephone book or attem pting lo pick up such objects as a pencil or a m ar hie with the toes, have been sug gested. These exercises are worth trying.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. 13 1977 
Elegant cast iron beds are at a premium 

Q. “ Our fancy cast iron bcd is quite an attention getter.” — 
Bill and Linda, Fort Worth. 
A. Cast iron furniture sprang into vogue during the second half of the 
19th century. Because it could be cast in almost any conceivable shane and easily painted to blend with existing furniture, it proved enormously popu­ lar. 
Cast iron beds vied for sale with brass beds and many had brass trim­ ming. Most beds had ornate foot and head boards often featuring scrolls and leaves. 
One firm sold them in a white ena­ mel finish, although other colors in­ cluding an all-gold finish were also available. 
In the 189os many designs were be­ ing offered for under $5 each, although nowdays it takes a wide-awake browser to locate one for under $175. 
B usts 
Q. “ Please assist me in evaluating my collection of parian busts.” — 
Susan, Anaheim, Calif. 

A. This hard-paste unglazed porce­ lain introduced by Copeland & Garrett in the 184os was originally known as 
"Statuary Porcelain” . 
Eventually it was produced by other leading potters such as Minions, Wor­ cester, (loss and Ridgway. The portrait busts, especially signed specimens, fetch heady prices! 
Value guide: Beethoven. 8” tall, $58; 
Cromwell. 8” tall, $82; Garfield, IO” tall. $8o; Longfellow, *5” tall, $75; 
Robert Burns, Copeland, 5” tall, $88; 
Shakespeare, 4 1/2” tall, $8o 
(/ luss 

Q. “ For the past few years I’ve been acquiring Goofus g la ss” — Millie, 
Concord, N C. 
A. 
Like its second cousin Carnival 
Glass, this glass was distributed at fairs and carnivals in the early 19oos. 
Originally known as Mexican glass, it has painted embossed designs, gen­ erally floral or fruit motifs, in red, purple or pink, enhanced with bronze or metallic highlights. 
The red and gold pieces appear to be 

 the most plentiful. Such industry giants as the Northwood Glass Com­ pany and the Imperial Glass Company produced this bold and brassy glass­ ware. 
Despite the peeling on some speci­ mens, collectors find it most a p ­ pealing. Value guide: bowl, large size, red and gold, $28. 
Q. 
“ We discovered several O la 

F’arker Bros, games in the attic” — 
Mr. and Mrs. R. W.. New Orleans. 
A. 
Early Parker Bros, games can best be described as flea market win­ ners. This still-existing firm, founded in Salem, Mass., in 1883. furnished the younger set with innovative board games, card games, puzzles and other productions. 
They purchased the rights to many 

 games originally published by the VV. 
S. & B. Ives firm. 
Any game in its original box is con­ sidered best. Value guide: authors, card game, 1897. $8; professional game of baseball, 19oo, $28. 
Appraise your antiques with Dan 
D’Imperio’s book and value and guide, 
“ The ABC’s of Victorian Antiques” 
Dodd. Mead & Co., $9.95.

Use antiseptic 
, 
• i i 
1 fo n m u fa , with cleanser 

Bacteria and fungi are everywhere, so even the most metienlously kept home harbors millions of them. 
It’s a paradox that some are harm­ ful, causing disease and property des­ truction, while others are highly bene­ ficial and even edible. 
There are areas around any home that are favorite gathering sjxits Fun­ gi, such as mold, seems to thrive in damp areas, and harmful bacteria in garbage cans, sinks, bathtubs, shower stalls and decomposed food 
But because they can be anywhere it seems sensible to use an all-purpose cleaner that has antiseptic qualities for general cleaning purposes. Here’s the formula. 
You’Ll need one pint of pine oil (from a hardw are store), one-half pound powdered soap and one pint water. 
Gently stir the soap and water wit Ii slow mixing. Remove suds from sur­ face of liquid. 
Now pour in the pine oil very slowly 

By 
N O R M A N H. STA R K 

 with constant stirring. To use, dilute solution with water or use full strength, depending on job to be done. 
Store in glass, metal, or plastic con­ tainer 
Like any chemical product you use at home, you should store this one safely, label it — listing ingredients and not­ ing any cautions — and keep it out of reach of children.

Computers come into the home 

By RIC HARD SMITH 
(XPP! SS NEWS BUSINESS EDITOR 
Tired of balancing the fami­ 

 ly 's checkbook? 
Fed up with compiling the monthly grocery list. or teaching your eight- year-old multiplication? 
Well.then, let the family co mputer do it 

The computer age has finally come to the kitchen. Once the exclusive pro­ perty of the large corporations which could afford them, they are now within reach of the common man 
F o r the d o - i t - y o u r s e l f e r , p r i c e s range from $4oo for a basic learner s kit. on up to a s high a s anyone wants to go. depending on the sophistication of the equipment. 
That m e a n s a boon for the infant 

 industry know as personal computing, already recognized as one of the fastest growing fields in the country. 
‘‘Within just two years , it s grown from practically nothing to a roaring i n d u s t r y . ” s a y s C ar l Z e t t n e r . who heads up an informal club called the 
Alamo Computer Enthusiasts. 

No one really knows how extensive the personal computer cult is. but one report published a week ago says that from 2o.ooo to 1oo.ooo individuals have been buying the computers for tin* past couple of years 
The sudden appearance of as many a s 3oo neighborhood co m pu ter stores 

The com puters will really catch on when sm a ll businesses fidapt them, says one user. 

One indication of the mushroom ing interest in kitchen-table c o m p e e r i n g has been the s k y ro c k e t in g m e m b e r ­ ship of the club. Form ed in November with eight m embers, it now has a roster of over OO m e m b e rs 

 a cro ss the country has been another result. 
Dr. John E. Howland, president of 
V angu ard S y s t e m s . Inc. which owns the Computer Store at 6812 San Pedro, sa y s the concept of the neighborhood 

COMPUTERS for the kitchen table, like the one Don W right is using, are now within reach of the individual, with prices ranging from $ 4 o o on up. Literally, a room ful of 

 equipm ent can be squeezed into integrat­ ed circuits like the central processing unit above which contains the com puter’s func­ tions. — Staff Photos by H.M. Dean, Jr. 

 store is already widespread, with two or three franchise operations thriving nationally 
He s a y s the* m a in r e a so n for the sudd en s u r g e in the industry is the successful blending of miniaturiza­ tion and economics 
“ A whole roomful of equipment can be packed into one integrated circuit roughly two and a half inches long and a half-inch wide.” says 
Howland 
“ This integrated circuit is the c o m ­ puter's central processing unit which now costs an ave rage of $ 3 o " 
One c o m p a n y wh ic h h a s been a pioneer in the c o m p u ter kit field is 
Southwest Technical Pr oducts Corp.. which has been in the electronics bu­ siness here for about 12 years 
Electronic gadgets 
Up until two years ago, the company m a d e. and sold by mail. a m p lifiers, strobe lights and assorted electronic gadgets. Then, in 1975, the micr ocom ­ p u t e r b oom s t a r t e d , s a y s D a n iel

Hundred outlets

D espite the vast m a r k e t i n g poten­ tial. the industry is still dominated by the sm all m a n u f a c t u r e r s. Meyer ex plains 
“ The c o m p a n i e s , like IHM have tra ditio nally ha ve been orie nted to sellin g to the la rge b u s i n e s s e s that could afford them, a s well a s all tin* so f tw a r e . They w e r e the only o n es which could afford a computer costing between $2o.1 HH) and $3o,ooo" hi* said 
Central processor 
Basically, the computer is m a d e up of the central p ro c e ss o r, which c o n ­ tains the de cisio n -m a k in g p r o c e s s e s like adding and subtracting, the m e ­ mory w h e r e the i n s t r u c t i o n s a nd a n s w e r s a r e c o n t a i n e d , a nd the input /out put devices winch enable the computer to co m m u nicate.” sa ys 
Zettner.

T h e s e d e v i c e s a r e the k e y b o a r d , through which tin* instructions can he given, and the display screen

NEVA VOKE — Bache Halsey Stuart Inc . the securities firm. is taking a measured view ut this season s most controversial accounting innovation 
— the replacement cost disclosures due from the nation's largest companies by the end of March 
It is “ too co m ple x an issue for the stock m a r ­ ket to react to quickly but too i m p o r t a n t for the market to ignore. 
Bache concluded iii a HH-pa go research study released 
Monday 
In Bache s vtow both those who are braced for 
.I d i r e m a r k e t i m p a c t trotii the r e p l a c e m e n t data and those who p re­ dict little or no effect are hound tor d i s a p p o i n t ­ ment.

New orders increase 

Tin* December new order index rose to 178.7. up H 8 points or 4 four per cent from November, marking a 3o.5 point increase, or ’JOH per cent. over De­ cember a year ago, according to fi­ gures supplied bv the American Sup­ ply & Machinery Manufacturers’ As­ sociation. Inc.t ASMMA). 
The 197H new order index average is 
1o5.4, up 23.1 points, or 1o.2 per cent

The Federal Reserve Board Index of 
Production Manufactures for durable goods seasonally adjusted for 
De­ cember rose to 124.7, up o.3 points, from November 
This represents an increase of 1o.3 points, or nine per cent, over De­ cember figures a year ago. 
The F R B 197B average index jumped to 121.ti, which is an increase of 12.2 points, or 11.2 per cent, over the 1975 average. 
Also charted is the composite index of 12 leading indicators, reverse trend adjusted According to ASMMA re­ ports. this is the first indicator that starts up when business is picking up and is included here for comparison purposes

KH) for the base periods. 

By HOBART ROWEN 
WASHINGTON - The hitter and cruel cold wave from which the nation has been suffering has caught the Carter adminis­ tration in a bind. 
It had carefully worked out a “ ba­ lanced” economic stimulus package designed to “ tread the fine line,’’ as chief economic adviser Charlie 
SchulUe put it. between doing too much and doing too little. 
In moving cautiously, mostly to as­ sure the business community that wild-eyed radicals hadn’t moved into town, Mr. Carter took the chance that his allies among the blacks and labor leaders would give him a break, and not push too openly for more. 
Mostly, although there has been some grumbling that the package does too little for young people and blacks, and almost nothing for the hard­ pressed cities. Carter seemed to be getting away with it. 
Schultze, along with Treasury Se­ cretary VV. Michael Blumenthal and 
OMB Director Bert Lance, convinc­ ingly sold the pitch that there was only so much that could be done to create public jobs or start new public works. 

 and that the only way to crank some quick stimulus into the economy is via the tax rebate route. 
Even so, unemployment would bare­ ly edge under 7 per cent by the end of this year. 
Program skids 
But then Mr. C arter’s program skidded on the wintry ice. The devas­ tating weather clearly has boosted the 

Real estate named new 

John 
I) 
Baines has announced 
Hint lits commercial and investment real estate firm. .John I). Baines Pro­ perties, has been named exclusive agent for Ray Ellison Industries. 

As agent for Ray Ellison Industries. 
Baines said his firm will coordinate sales of commercial properties and assist primarily in tin* development of shopping centers and allied projects. 

Baines revealed plans for a major retail shopping facility in the southwest quadrant of the city. 

•John I) Baines Properties recently closed the largest commercial real estate land transaction in the city’s history with the $5 million sale of a 
7o-acre tract of land located on YValzem 
Rd., a block east of Windsor Park 
Mall The site, sold by Ray Ellison 
Industries to Charles VV. Windham, will feature the nation’s largest Fed 
Mart Store with 22o.(KHI square feet 

Baines claimed that the listing with 
Hay Ellison Industries coupled with his firm s previous listings tops the 
81oo million mark. 

 firm is agent 

JO H N D. BA IN ES 

The Week 
In Business 

 cost of heating fuels, and resulted in factory shutdowns that mean a loss of pay for hundreds of thousands. 
No one really knows how many or how much, but Schultze concedes that the extra cost of keeping warm this winter may total more than $5 billion. 
Other studies suggest a figure of $8 billion to $1o billion. 
The extra dollars paid the utility companies are “ like an excise tax on consumers,” Schultze told a sobered 
Carter Cabinet. Put it another way: It’s like another big OPEC price increase, the very opposite of a tax stimulus. 
Making a conservative guess, it would appear that about half of Mr. 
Carter’s projected IIH billion stimulus for this fiscal year has already been chewed up. Yet. the administration postpones a decision on a bigger pack­ age. 
Unrecoverable 
Why? As Schultze says, it is always possible, if the cold spell ends quickly enough, that much of the loss will be recovered later in the year as factories process hack orders, and workers catch up in overtime. 
But it seems inevitable, at this stage, that there will be some net loss to the cold spell which will have to be com­ pensated for with a large stimulus. 
And here’s the rub. which fairly drives labor and civic leaders up the wall: In all probability, the Carter ad­ ministration, if forced to beef up its original package, will ask for more tax cuts, not more jobs programs in 1977. 
If heating bills rise about $17o per household, as a calculation by the Li­ brary of Congress shows, a tax rebate of $2oo for a typical family isn't going to leave enough for anything but bub­ ble gum. 
The weather crisis reinforces, rather than weakens, the tax-cutting strategy. 
The hard fact is that Congress could authorize more billions for public ser­ vice jobs or public works, but almost everybody who knows anything about these things (including labor leaders) will admit privately that such a step would be a phony gesture. 
It would create few more jobs in 1977 than are in the Carter progtam. The 

 devastating effects of the 1974-75 re­ cession can't be cured with a wave of the congressional checkbook. 
The evidence, based on what hap­ pened in other tax-cutting episodes, is that the Carter package (augmented if necessary to offset whether effects) will set off enough “ macro” waves in the economy to boost the Gross Na­ tional Product and increase the growth rate some. 
It is less likely to have dramatic, beneficial results on the unemployment rate. especially among blacks, until some time in 1978 when more direct job aids can be swung into line. 
“ Cutting taxes,” according to Ver­ non Jordan of the National Urban 
League, “ is always popular, but it does hing for the poor and near-poor, who pay no taxes or minimal taxes.” In other words, as Adelaide, the hoofer in 
“ Guys and Dolls” complains, “ the medicine doesn’t seem to get anywhere near where the trouble is." 
Clicked heels 
The meaning of all of this. I believe. is that having paid homage to the con­ cerns of the business community, Mr. 
Carter is now going to have to move out, and be a little bolder. The Nixon and Ford administrations clicked heels for eight years, to the demands of the business community, and managed to produce recessions in four of them, with record federal deficits to boot. 
But there are encouraging signs in 
Mr. Carter’s accelerated feelers this week for some kind of a voluntary 
"incomes policy” to subdue excessive wage and price pressure. 

Salespeople are honored 

Outstanding salespeople in the com­ munity will be honored Feb. 14 at the 
Distinguished Salesman Award Ban­ quet. according to Ladd Little, general chairman for the banquet. 
Featured speaker will be I. Thomas 
Sheppard, director of the Bureau of 
Business and Economic Research at the University of Texas at El Paso. 
The banquet w ill be held at the Plaza 
Club. 
He said the awards banquet is held each year during National Salesman’s 
Month and is designed to give public recognition for outstanding proficiency in salesmanship. 
Those honored this year are: Penny 
Dyer, Autophone of San Antonio: John 
Guerra and Charles Trainmen, South­ western Bell Telephone Co.; Jim Has­ sell and Dave Huddleston, Plains Ma­ chinery; Gus Riojas, Knowlton’s; Pa­ tricia Kamperman and Bill Henderson, 
Deanie Owens Co.; and Duane Ahern, 
George Hodges and Charles Starr, New 
York Life Insurance Co.

With much of his career in the banking industiy spent in execu­ tive posts, Mr. Both© brings dyna­ mic leadership qualities to the 
American Bank. We look forward to continuing as a major financial force in growing north San Antonio.

Grand champion will be judged Monday afternoon 

Early Munday after­ noon one young person is going to be the happiest person in Texas. 
That moment w ill come when Dr. Bill Able, associate professor of department of animal science, Kansas State 
University, will slap one of 14 breed champions and thus name it grand champion steer of the 
San Antonio Livestock 
Show and Rodeo. 
This final judging i i i the steer division will be in the Dairy Arena of Joe 
Freeman Coliseum. 

Ihe happiness will come from pride in the knowledge that he or she has done a great job in raising the steer and from the realization that a big sum of money will be paid at the auction 
Friday for the winner 
Last year’s champion steer, raised by Wendell 
Geeslin of Hamilton, brought $2o.(M(t) from the 
Sehlitz Brewing Co.

Pressing job 

T E C H N IC IA N S clamber over the heaviest tire in the world to get its “ footprints.” W eighing in at I 2,5o o lbs., the I I -foot-tall tire, is subjected to a stress test of 3 5 o ,o o o lbs. Developed by

CONTINUED FROM PAGE I G about 5.ooo copies of a 3o-page maga­ zine,” he says, “ but the actual publi­ cation num ber of the publication.” first issue was 5o,ooo copies of a 
1oo-page 
Nou. a year and two months lajer. he says, the circulation is 75,ooo. 
So. what do you do with these new computers? 
“ The uses are almost as diverse as those people who buy them,” says one electronic' aficionado. 
A lot of people just enjoy tinkering with machines." says Meyer. “ It s the idea of having a device that can play against you — trying to outguess the computer " 
Howland says the uses range from preparing simple tax records to con­ trolling household appliances like burglar alarms. One owner uses his computer to set up annuity tables for figuring out loan payments. 

A nother uses his to teach his da u g h te r fou rth -grad e m ath. The com puter has been program m ed to teach the fundamentals in the guise of a game where she is rewarded with inputs for scoring correct answers. 

Entertainment 

Currently the computer is mainly used for personal entertainment, says 
Meyer. “ We're only just beginning to think about, the practical uses as well” 
He says he feels the real applications will come when the small businesses and professional people begin to use the devices for figuring payrolls and keeping patient files. 
But that may still be only the begin­ ning. says Howland. “ Some experts say that 5(1 per cent of the dollar vo­ lume generated in the industry by 198o will come from ideas not vet thought of”

Personnel departments changing their names 

NEW YORK — More and more com ­ panies have renamed the head of their personnel departments, and it appears to be more than cosmetic. 
The new title often in­ volves the term “ human resources,” perhaps vice president of human re ­ sources. perhaps director of human resources. 
The H ew lett-Packard 
Co., the Bendix C orp. and the Brunswick Corp. are am ong those to have made the move. 
The 
“ hum an r e ­ sources” aspect carries the implication that the post involves a broad group of w ork-reJated activities and helps put the personnel head in top 

By 
ELIZABETH M. 
FOWLER 
N EW YORK t im e s s e r v ic e 

 management. 
Arnold H. Deutsch of 
Deutsch, Shea and Ea- vans, Inc., a m a n a g e ­ ment consulting firm , likes the new term and wishes the government would adopt it. 
He would like to see 
President-elect Jim m y 
C arter renam e the De­ partm en t of Labor the 
D epartm ent of Human 
Kesouroes. _____________ 

He explains his thinking partly in terms of three econ nm ic basics 
— land, capital and la­ bor. “ We speak of capital resources, we speak of land as a resource and now why not more e m ­ phasis on labor as a resource?” he said in an interview. 

Overdue 
Deutsch believes that better allocation of hu­ man resources with go­ vernm ent help is long overdue and would help reduce unemployment as well as help m a n a g e ­ ments plan ahead. 
For example, there is the problem of mobility. 
There are many specific

 ploys 27 people, makes and m a rk e ts chem ical dispersal equipment for use in the pest control and food processing in­ dustries as well as in ho­ spitals and government installations overseas, said Coleman. 

He said the local oper­ ations will rem ain unchanged. 

 job openings in various parts of the country long unfilled because the par­ ticular talent is not avai­ lable locally. 

A few y e a rs ago, 
Deutsch pointed out, a major bus system offered cheaper fares for persons needing to relocate to find jobs “ Why couldn’t the government do this on a widespread basis?” he asked, adding, " It would be cheaper than paying u tieiiipIoyinent insurance.” 

The D e p artm ent of 
Human Resources might have the mobility of labor 
— enabling w orkers to move where jobs are — as a prime responsibility. 

"W e have m anpow er m yopia." he said. "We need more planning for human re so u rc e s.” Ile believes that effective planning on the govern­ ment level w ill help close the “ ever-widening gap between the character of the work force and r e ­ q u ire m e n ts of the job market.”

 lh> points out that cur­ rently there is little ef­ fective forecasting of la­ bor needs, and he suggests that this should becom e an im ­ 

 portant assignment lot a 
D epartm ent of Human 
Resources 
“ It should sound the alarm when a shortage of 

 certain workers appears or when we are produc­ ing too m any train ed persons for job,” he said particular

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. 13 1977 
Our best customers were Xerox users. 

More than one out of every two customers who purchase the Savin 
77o plain paper copier do so at the expense of Xerox. 

One reason thousands of offices have switched to the 77 o is its reputation for reliability. A lot of other copiers who repute to be reliable end up getting more service than they give. Our machine has been designed to keep working. Our paper moves in a simple paper path from storage cassette to reproduction through the shortest possible distance. Fifty percent of all paper jams are caused by long, twisting paper paths. Obviously, less distance travelled means less chance for jam-ups. The Savin 77 o copy travels a total of twelve in­ ches. In some Xerox machines, copies travel over four feet! 

Another reason is the copy itself. Ours are always clean, clear and needle sharp— regardless of the original. Even the most difficult copy to make, colored ink on colored paper, reproduces flawlessly. 
That’s because the Savin 77o has a mind. 

An electronic brain scans each document first, then automatically makes whatever adjustment it thinks necessary to produce a perfect copy every time, whether you copy on to one side or two. 

The clincher is economy. You’ll be amazed at how inexpensive it is to copy with the Savin 77 o. 

Whatever the reasons, the facts are clear. The Savin 77 o plain paper copier is turning up everywhere you turn today. You can’t miss it, it s where the Xerox used to be. 

Call us for a demonstration— we’ll do it right in your office.

It could pay to check around for credit rates 

NEW YORK - Bankers are forever com­ ing up with new credit packages to accom­ modate changing needs — like the 48-month automobile loans because tilt' old 38-month limit just isn’t enough. 
Some customers can he given more room to cope wilh rising auto prices with variable payment mortgages that help cou­ ples tailor monthly charges closer to income. 
Interest rates on auto­ mobile loans vary all over the lot. So do mort­ gage rates. Depending on who handles your financ­ ing, the cost of auto loans, for instance, can range from IO per cent to 
13 per cent or more. On m ortgages, the spread can vary from 8 per cent to 9 per cent. 
I ut (‘rest rates are tax­ deductible, of course, but for most borrowers the saving is likely to he sig­ nificant only if they are in a high income bracket. 
As the difference iii rates suggest, it pays to shop. 
Where to go? 
Commercial banks, for 

By 
RICHARD 
PHALON 
NfcW VORK TIMES SERVICE 

 example, usually offer lower rates than auto­ mobile dealers. 
Thanks to the Truth- 
In-Lending Aet, lenders are required to translate interest charges into an annual percentage rate that takes the declining balance of a loan into ac­ count and makes it easier to compare costs. 

Rates 
In general, the longer the term of a loan, the larger the total interest the borrower pays 
Often, however, lenders will charge a lower basic rate on longer-term automobile loans than on shorter loans. 

Thus the rate might he 
1o.97 per cent on a 
48-month deal but 11.o8 lier cent on 38 months. 
For m ortgage loans, thrift institutions — sav­ ings banks and savings and loan associations — are often cheaper than commercial hanks. 
That is so partly 1><*- cause the thrift institu­ tions tend to specialize in m ortgages, just as the commercial banks tend to concentrate on installment loans. 
Credit unions and fin­ ance companies account for a good chunk of the installment loan field, too. Credit unions usually offer comparatively low rates — randy more than 
12 per cent on the unpaid balance. 
The rates generally re­ flect the not-for-profit orientation of tin* credit unions. 
Finance companies, on the other hand, are very definitely profit-oriented. 
Their interest rates are usually higher than at most commercial banks. 

 partly because — they will often take on loan risks that the commer­ cial banks will not. 
Finance com panies usually will lend on a signature alone, but so­ metimes demand a co­ signer. and under some circumstances will insist on security — a chattel mortgage on household furnishings, for example. 
Lower 
I ut (‘rest rates on s e ­ cured loans are generally lower than on unsecured loans. Savings banks in 
New York City, for ex­ ample, w ill lend up to 9o per cent of the value of a custom er’s savings a c ­ count at rates ranging from 5 3/4 per cent for six months to 7 per cent for up to three years. 
The rates on other col­ lateral — securities, for instance — arc higher thail on passbook loans. 
Many suburban com ­ mercial banks will lend at H percent on listed se­ curities, but generally for not more than 5o 

 percent of market value. 
The restriction gives the lender protection against a possibility of a decline in the v alue of the stock. 
Tin* paid-up v aloe of 

 life insurance can he borrowed against, too. also at comparatively low rates — 5 per cent in New 
York Stale and 8 per cent in New Jersey and Con­ necticut. 

Winn’s reports record 
Winn’s Stores, Inc. re­ ports that its 1978 net income was the highest ever by the variety store chain. 
The chain's not income for last year was $3 9 million, a 31 4 per cent increase over over 1975 figures of $2.98 million 
Der share earnings for 
1978 were $3.89. com ­ pared to $2 98 for 1975. 
Lynn ll 
Sp ears, the company’s board chair­ man 
He also said that sales for 1978 rose to $8o 4 mil­ lion. also a record for the company. This compared to 1975 sales of $53.2 mil­ lion. and represented a 
13.5 per cent increase over 1975 sales 
Net income for the fourth quarter was $1 91 million, compared with 
$1.3 million for the simi­ lar 1975 period 
Der share earnings for the fourth quarter of 1978 were $1 92. compared to 
1975 fourth quarter earn­ ings per share of $1.31. for an increase of 48 3 per cent 
Fourth quarter sales reached $19 8 million, a 
12.2 per cent increase over 1975 fourth quarter sales of $17.7 million, said Spears.

Inside 
John Denver 

By JAMES MARTIN 

Despite his radiant smile, the young RGA recording artist looked uncomfortable. Behind the b ea m in g facade there seemed to lurk, quite naturally, the n agging question that plagues everyone in the enter­ tainment business at some point on his way up: 

 lias it all been worth it? Or, mor e specifically, in .John D e n v e r ' s case: 
Were my folks and fr ie nds in T exas right all along? Was I crazy to drop out of college and forego a c a r e e r as an architect for a life of one-night stands 

Sugar or saccharine? 

 hadn t he? H e ’d been for mally in tro ­ duced to the Hollywood music writers. 
F a r O u t ! 
A c o u p l e of d a y s b e f o r e , G r e l u n bandon of RGA had sent te le g ra m s to a b o u t 4(1 rock c r i ti c s a n d e n t e r t a i n ­ m ent edit ors, inviting th e m to m ee t 
J o h n D e n v e r . L e s s t h a n h a l f t h a t n u m b e r showed up, and they seem ed less in t e r e s t e d in the a r t i s t th e y ' d come to meet than in what was on the menu. 
The Hollywood m u s ic w r it e r s , p e r ­ haps the most jaded, insensitive press corp in the world, had expected — and pre f e rred — b rea k f a st with the new with c a tn a p s in an e ndles s s t r i n g of 
Dylan or J a g g e r , not this guy na m ed i a ,iiri.j,- i n n o 
John Denver. 
Holiday Inns 
But here he was, finally on the verge of M ak ing It as a solo a r t i s t — Me, 
Henry Jo hn Deutsehendorf Jr ., a Star! 
He had come to the Ontra Cafeteria that m o rning. March 24, 197(1. within one block or so of Hollywood and Vine, to m eet the press at breakfast. 
So what if it wasn't the Brown Derby a c ro s s the s t re e t; h e ’d still a rr i v e d . 

D e n v e r y e a r s a g o — b e ­ fo r e th e t r e n d y g l a s s e s an d h air a n d sm ile 

Provincial Puck 

They w e r e n ' t th e least im p re s s e d 
Who is this provincial P u c k with the g o l d - r i m m e d g r a n n y g l a s s e s , t h e flower print shirt, and the c h ip m u n k s m i l e ? 
T h e s m i l e , p a r t i c u l a r l y , seem ed phony. One critic would later refer to it as a “ galactic g r i n . " 
What the rock writers didn't know was that Jo hn Denver was already po­ p u l a r in p l a c e s like K a n s a s , Iowa, 
Texas and Missouri, and in cities as large as Washington. D C . They didn't know that with the release of "C ountry 
R oa ds" only one* y e a r hence. Denv er would become a m onste r h it -m aker in his ow ii right 
They d id n ’t know that he was d e s ­ tined to outsell E lto n J o h n and to become almost as big an attraction as 
EK is himself. 
During the next five years, he would record several gold and platinum r e ­ cords. have all of his best hits “ co­ v e re d " by m a jo r recording artists, act dra m ati call y, host talk shows, do his own specials on TV, and a p p e a r before crowds of 2(l.(i(lll or mor e on extensive concert tours both in the I Cited States and Gre at Britain. 
John Denver's parent s were “ Okies" 
— his father from a wheat-and-eotton fa rm outside the little town of Corn, near Washita River west of Oklahoma 

City; his m o th e r from the oil boom city of Tulsa 

D u t c h , a s b t. Col. H e n r y J o h n 
D e u t s e h e n d o r f Sr. is kno wn to i n t i ­ mates, was ail Air Forc e pilot when the couple met. an d he w a s st ati oned at 
W a l k e r Air F o r c e B a s e in R oswell, 
New Mexico when their first son was born. 
It is a curi ous fact that the future 
" J o h n Deliver'' — Henry Jo hn Deuts­ ehendorf. Jr. — c a m e into the world on the very eve of 1942. to the a c c o m p a n ­ iment of firecrackers, penny whistles and the strains of “ Auld b a n g Syne." 
Bul there was a w ar going on, and although Dutch would not fight iii it. he went on the first atomic bombing test flights while stationed at Kwajalein in 
194-). only mo n th s after the U.S. c a p ­ ture of that island from the Ja p a n e s e 
When tin' w ar iii the Pacific ended, occupied J a p a n b e c a m e the home of several U.S. military bases, including 
Tokyo 's Johns on Field, w h ere Dutch w a s a s s i g n e d in 194K. His wife and th eir baby joined h im th e re the fol­ lowing year. Another child. Ronald Loo 
Deutsehendorf. arrived in 194S 

T h e following y e a r Dutch w a s a s ­ signed to Dav is -M o n th an Air F o r c e 
Base at Tucson. Arizona, the family's home for the next nine years. It was the longest thev'd stin a l l w h e r e . 

When the family used H enry Jo h n 
S r . ’s JU day le a v e s fro m d u ty , they made pil gri mag es to O klaho ma, to see r e l a t i v e s iii T u l s a . Co rn a n d C lo ud . 
Chief. It w a s on one of th e s e tr ip s , d u r i n g a st o p - o v e r in R o sw ell, th a t 
J o h n J r . , r e c o r d e d h is first so n g s . 
John won t tell you the story today, but his m o th e r will 
" O u r friends in Roswell had a wire recorder, and we used to go throu gh there on the way from Tucson to O k la ­ h o m a . And we would sto p at t h e s e 
People's house, and Jo h n was always singing. So this m an taped John si ng­ ing. and John said he was seven years old . 
" B u t . uh. J o h n s a n g ‘T h e Hills of 
Virginia.’ and he couldn't say ‘V irgin­ ia’ you know; In' couldn 't pro n o u n c e the ‘V . 
. 
When we got out of the s e n ice, this m a n put it on tape, so then we each had . . . a copy." 
J o h n ’s m a t e r n a l g r a n d m o t h e r w as p ro fic ie n t on both piano an d o r g a n , havin g played both si nce youth 
She als o ha d an old G ib so n g u i t a r that she'd bought new but never learned to play. 
In what mus t rank as the most pro­ pitious event in J o h n 's life, his g r a n d ­ m o t h e r g a v e h im th e g u i t a r . Y e a r s later, he would pay h o m ag e to his s a ­ gacious gran n y throu gh the song " T h i s 
Old G u ita r ," which he says is “ a true sto ry " Aud he still h a s th e i n s t r u ­ ment. 
Boring 

 h o r a while he took lessons on the 
Gibson in T u cso n . But like m a n y a youthful, would-be virtuoso, he found daily practice to be dreadfully boring: scab's and chords. So lie set the Gibson aside and quit the* lessons. 
But it was not just his contem pt for practice which turned him off; there was no im p etu s iii the form of m usic iii the a ir , m u s i c w ith which h e could identify, m u sic he could feel. 
T h i s w ould c h a n g e in 1957* in th e form of gyrating , g a m bolin g whirling derv ish of an e x - t r u c k e r from M e m ­ phis n a m e d Elvis Presley. 
"All of a sudde n there was m u sic on the radio that really appealed to m e . " 
John recalls "I started playing again and just got d e e p e r and d e e p e r into it." 

D e n v e r a s he is k n o w n n o w , sm ile a n d all 

Life in N. Ireland: Bombs, bullets and barbed wire 

By PETER ALMOND 

B E L F A S T - M g *. 
Agnes Nichols, a ho­ mey, m id d le -cla ss woman living in a semi-detached house 

 i i i a suburb, had just discovered that she lived in a war zone. 
For across the street is 
— or was — the Balmoral 
F u r n i t u r e Co. w orkshop and showrooms. 
She had lust found out what h a p p e n s when the 
Irish R e p u b l i c a n A r m y a t t a c k s a c o m m e r c i a l target 
M rs. Nic hols w a s u p ­ s t a i r s m a k i n g th e beds when she he ard a series of s h a r p c r a c k s outside her window. T he startled woman watched a shoot­ out between a gang of 
Provisional IRA bombers who h a d j u s t p l a c e d 

The conflict in Northern Ireland has actually lasted for centuries, and for those who have been living in the latest of It. its violence has become a way of life. 
Their neighborhoods have become “ war zones." City dwellers live and work surrounded by bombproof barricades and guarded by British Army soldiers. Store em ployees frisk custom ers for bombs. 
_ 
Journalist Peter Almond recently spent one week in Northern Ireland, the province in which Catholic and Protestant refuse to live together peacefully. In this first part in a six-part series on the war in Northern 
Ireland. Almond describes the conflict as it is seen by those people who face real or potential violence every day — the middle- and working-class people to whom the “ war zone" is home. 

M P s put lier rn a e a r to se a le d at th e c e n t e r so await her children at the tr a ffi c — a n d p o te n tia l 

 b o m b s in th e f u r n i t u r e sh o w ro o m ', a n d p o li c e and troops win; had a m ­ bushed them. 
" T h e r e w a s s h o o t in g eve rywhere. I saw a sol­ dier on one knee firing an au to m ati c rifle down our street — you know. bung, bun g, bun g, b u n g , v e ry fast," a shaken Mrs. Ni­ c h o l s s a i d t h r e e h o u r s later. 
" T h e r e was a m a n ly­ ing wounded in the road by the front gate calling 

 s o m e t h i n g to h ts p a ls. 
One of the IRA men went a r o u n d the b a c k of o u r h o u s e — we fo u n d th e gun he threw aw ay ." 
As the shooting stopped and the police and troops a d v a n c e d . Mrs. Nichols saw the show room only a few y a rd s aw ay explode in f l a m e a s f o u r g a s - fueled b o m b s d e to n a te d inside. 
“ T h e y w e n t off o n e a f t e r t h e o t h e r . 
T h e w h o le h o u s e s h o o k 
A 

 la m pshade c a m e off. T h e windows blew out of the ho uses along the stre et, lint o u r s a r e o k a y b e ­ c a u s e we h a d t h e w i n ­ dows open."

U. S. should help M exico 

P r e sid e n t Carter will m e e t this w eek with M ex ico's P r e s i ­ dent J o s e Lopez P o r t illo . T h e agenda is likely to include w ater rights, the troubled peso, a v a il­ ability of Mexican oil and — the p e r e n n i a l 
— d o p e a n d min sm u g g lin g across the U .S .-M ex­ ican border. 
There is room for important progress to be m ade. Mr. Carter m e t with Hi m e m b e r s id' C o n ­ g r e ss from states with borders c o m m o n to Mexico. Reports on that m e e tin g indicated a thrust t o w a r d rn u t u a 11 y - b e n e f i c i a I goals between the two countries. 
South T exans feel keenly the problem s and opportunities that a r i s e f r o m b e i n g 
M e x i c o ' s neighbor. San Antonio is a key city affected by M exico's actions and problems. 
It is unquestionably good bu­ sin e ss for the' U.S. to do what can usefully be done to bring 
Mexico to better eco n o m ic sta ­ tion. 
M e x i c o is o n e of tin s co untry ’s best trading partners. 
The U.S. is. furtherm ore, one of 
M exico's best trading partners. 
There are m a n y p r o b l e m s , p a r tic u la r ly a lo n g the border. 
S m u g g le r s are m ore active than they should be and that ought to be c h a n g e d . S m u g g l i n g which must have cooperation of border g u a r d s is at least s u s p e c t e d . 
C l a n d e s t i n e d o p e and gun 

 sm u g g lin g by aircraft is clearly out of control. 
But t h e r e are h u m a n p r o b ­ l e m s . too. that d e a l w ith the ability to m a k e a living honest­ ly. with the old battle between exploitation of cheap labor and the s c a r c i t y of labor for h a r ­ vests. 
M e x i c o ' s h ig h b ir th ra te stays ahead of efforts to house, feed and educate the people at an adequate pace. P erso ns who are willing to risk im m igration laws for a job keep the i m m i ­ gration service in constant high g e a r w i t h o u t a c c o m p l i s h i n g anything useful. 

It s tim e for a new approach. 
M e x ic o has oil to e x p o r t. Her trade fair iii San A nto nio has becoom an important show case and sales room for a wide v a r ­ iety of goods shown to be in d e ­ m a n d in the U. S. T h e two c o u n tries should work hard to find a p r a c t i c a l p r o g r a m , perhaps within a limited border band of land, where ex p e r i­ m ents in an open-border policy might be tested, 

L o p e / P o r t il l o has s e a l e d down Ins federal budget to try to bring the peso back to its former 
\ aine. I Ie has a formidable job a h e a d 
It w ill be a f o r w a r d ­ looking U. S. policy that would e n c o u r a g e p r a c t ic a l help. We hope h can be found

Being taken 

Sir. Someone's not paying atte n tio n ’ 
I w o u ld li k e to i l l u s t r a t e how consumers of gas and electricity in 
Texas are tieing taken by our elected officials: 
The Texas state comptroller re port­ ed that natural tax receipts, based on wellhead prices, increased to $391.ti million iii 1976 from $264.3 million in 
1975 and $199 million in 1974. despite declining production. (A 48 per cent increase.) 
Th e c o m p t r o l l e r ’s re p o r t advis ed th a t w h ile oil p r o d u c t i o n s l i p p e d slightly, higher prices increased oil tuxes 2.6 per cent to $428.7 million. 
The comptroller further advised that his total tax receipts in 1976 rose 16.8 per cent from 1975 to $4 billion, the biggest source being the retail sales tax. inc reasing 18.3 per cent from the previous y ear to $1.5 billion. 
The City of Sun Antonio, un we know . takes 12 to 14 per cent off the gross City 
Public Service Board bill, lf the ( PSB was a p r i v a t e c o r p o r a t i o n a n d a t ­ tempted to give a 12-14 per cent return to its investors on gross sales, it would bo the best stock ever offered. 
( PSB. after paying the City of Sun 
Antonio, now mus t affix a reasonable surcharg e to pay for its ongoing op e r­ ations plus franchise fees and e x p a n ­ sion req uiremen ts. 
I would estim ate that over 3o per cent of our gas and electric bills go for taxes and surch arge s, lf our elected r e p r e s e n t a t i v e s w a n t to h e l p th e co nsu m ers and lower bills they have a m ple opportunity to do so by lowering the tuxes and surcharges. 
G. Vt . Schat/man

Senator Tower is a very expensive luxury for the people of Texas. Ills one first in his years in the Senate has been in spending money on his own election. 
He was national champion on his lust time out. spending $2.2 million in 1972 
I wonder why there has never been an investigation of his finances? It would in* interesting to see how often he had voted iii the Senate for the donors’ betterment, and how often this vote was a vote against the interests of the people of Texas. 
We do know that when an im portant 
Hill c o n c e rn i n g Kelly w o r k e r s was lH*fore the Senate, lie was not present, and did not vote, FII wager he would have been there if one of his big donors had a problem.

The hard life o f a fire 

By KEM PER DIEHL 

F ire D epartm en t Lt. Joe R. 
F lo res is a man en m e sh e d in two contradictory im ages of his job. 

One im ag e is reflected in the proud eyes of his three y oungsters. They are a v id f o llo w e rs of th e TV s h o w . 
“ E m e rg e n c y .” which d ra m a tiz e s the work of firem en and EMS crew s. 
They have actually seen their father fighting a ragin g three-alarm blaze. 
When they think of his w ork, they see it in te rm s of exciting, dan gerou s and heroic action. 

But there is a contradictory view of firem e n . T h is is held by cy n ics who like to paint m e m b e rs of th e d e p a r t­ m e n t a s a d d ic te d to s o ft-c u s h io n e d chairs, coffee and television. 
T hat is a picture which F lo res feels is not only terribly unfair, but totally 

 untrue. 
As pu blic re la tio n s s p o k e s m a n for the San Antonio F irefig h ters, he w ants to scru b it out.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sun. Feb. I 3 I 977 
Leary likes space, isn’t spaced out 

By WILLIAM OVEREND tos a n g e le s tim es s m v ic l 
LOS ANGELES — Dr. Timothy Leary, one of the most contro­ versial figures of the ‘BOs because of his views on LSD, now lives in 
Los Angeles and has returned to the college lecture circuit with a new 
Here are excerpts I rom an in te rv iew with the former Harvard psycho­ logist. who is on parole from federal prison alter almost seven years as a convict and fugitive: 
QUESTION - You say you’re not interested in talking about LSI) a n y ­ more. Why is that? 
ANSWER—I said in the 
‘Hits th e re would be a point when we wouldn't need LSL) anymore. I al­ ways saw it as a training de\ ice to teach us more about o u r b ra in s . We needed d ru g s like LSI) once to make us aw are that we could aller our c o n s c io u s n e s s , do our own rewiring. But we’ve become much m ore so­ phisticated as a society now. and we understand those things better. 
Today I see drugs like 
LSI) us primitive aud at one point necessary evo­ lutionary steps that are rapidly outm oded, like fossil fuels 

Q. 
How im portant is biochemistry going to be in the future as far as the brain is concerned'.’ 
A. 
In the future we ll be teaching our children how to use their brains by the age of ‘J or .‘I, so biochemistry won’t be as necessary. It s inevitable that t r e m e n d o u s a d ­ vances iii the biological sciences will give us a1 most total control of our bodies and. more impor­ tant . our brains. So there won t be any need for d r u g s , ex c ep t when somebody gets blocked. 
They won't be needed unless so m ebody gets stuc k aud c a n ’t do it himself 
Q. 
Do you still take 
LSI).’ 
A. 
I don't ta k e any illegal d r u g s or do a n ­ ything that’s illegal 
Q. Y ou're on parole, of course, lf \ou did take d r u g s , would you talk about it? 
V 
AV«• 11, after all. the 
A m e r ic a n g o v e r n m e n t isn t Russia, particularly now with the Carter Ad­ m i n i s t r a t i o n and with 
(Gov 
E d m u n d 
CL) 

W e n ettled dru gs like L S D ' 

Q. There's been a lot of talk that you informed on some of your old friends when you were in prison in the hope of getting out sooner. What did you do? 
A. 
I n ev e r testifie d about dope d e a lin g or about the W e a t h e r m a n underground. I made no deal with the g o v e r n ­ m e n t. As it was. they kept me i i i prison seven tim es longe r th an the guidelines. The fact that there haven't been any a r r e s t s ought to prove something. 
I did testify to a grand 
.jury in San F ra n c i s c o about t w o law vers w ho helped put me in prison aud rip ped off a lot ol money and put me i i i a very bad situation And I testifie d exactly what they did. But I think it s ironic that the fanatic left wing is m a d d e r at me now than the fanatic right wing. which pleases me very much. 
I think if I can get both the fanatic left and right m a d at me I m ust be doing something right 
Q. 
You r e f e r r e d to your Irish background Is that a key to your personality? 
A. 
Absolutely lf y ou’re probing for psy- cho-historv and you want to know about that. I m your classic happy Irish­ man It’s embarrassingly corny. 
Q. 
W hat do you mean when you describe us all as genetic robots’’ 
A. 
Our behavior is 9!l per cent determined by our neurological and an­ ato m ic al wirin g. Each anthill has its tiny little differences, due of course to the nature of the soil or the e n v i r o n m e n t . But these th ings are u n i m ­ portant compared to the vast majority of things which a re p r e d e t e r ­ mined 
The mind is simply a robot-program of condi­ tioned responses, but I think it is evolutionarily predeterm ined that the 

Let’s face it. America has been an evolutionary experiment for the rest of the world. 

Scientists wade back into evolution fight 

 w a s h i n g t o n M AR 

TIMOTHY LEARY, onetim e high priest of 
LSD, winks at newsmen during a recent news conference in Berkeley, Calif. 

W ASH IN G TO N STAB 
WASHINGTON - 
I t s an old argum ent with a new twist. 
The issues dramatical­ ly raised in the Scopes 
“ m o n k e y t r i a l ’’ m o re than 5o years ago — evo­ lution versus crea­ tionism — continue to be debated today with crea­ tionists battling scien­ tists for equal time in the schools.

Gaylor Simpson, author 
Isaa c

Novel 
P riz e w in n e r s

Pauling and .lames Wat­ son. and psychologists 
Carl R o g e rs and B.F. 
Skinner — are fighting

 hack, ta king the offen­ sive with a strong state­ ment affirming evolution as a principle of science and d ec r y in g c r e a t i o n ­ ism as a purely religious issue. 
The statement, sent to m a j o r school b o ard s a c ro s s the co u n t ry , arg u e s that “ for many y e a rs it has been well est a b I i s bed se ie n t i f ic a 11 y that all known forms of life, in c lu d in g h u m a n beings, have developed by a lengthy process of evolution.”
