California. Thought po­ lice hav e less power 
Ironically enough, drugs were never that im p o r ­ tant to me personally. 
I saw drug taking as a duty, something I had to do to broaden my mind 
Rarely did I look forward to taking drugs. It was like a good Catholic Sun­ day Mass I was doing it the way you take v H a ­ ulms for your health 

Q- 
You used to d e ­ scribe LSD as a religious experience, but there was an a r t i c l e in P layboy magazine that pictured you in a much more he­ d onistic ty pe of d r u g scene when y o u were iii 
Switzerland 
V 
Let s nail it right away. T h e artic le said there was a lot of drugs around me th e n , even heroin, and implied there was group sex. Totally wrong. 
I d o n ’t like hippies. I don’t like com­ munes. I despise heroin. 
I ve never participated iii an orgy. It may ruin my reputation, hut I iii very monogamous. 
As a m a t t e r of fact, b e c a u s e of my 
Irish 
Catholic h eritag e. I ve sometimes thought p e r ­ haps I ve been too puri­ tanical. I’m not sensual enough . . , On the other hand I ani a fun lover. I have dedicated my life to the study of p l e a s u r e , aud I ve tried to hang around exquisite, sophis­ ticated. intelligent plea­ su re lovers, l e a r n in g every tip and clue they could give me 
I think pleasure is an art, and to live the he­ donic, full. beautiful life is just like learning how to play 
Die piano. 
Number one, you iiave to learn from taut* who do 
It better 

 h u m a n s p e c ie s will evolve to th e position where it can rewire its own nervous system. 

Q. And you think that s going to req u ir e a m i ­ gration into space? 
A. 
I see e v e r y t h i n g that happened iii the ’Bbs. both technologically and neurologically, including d rugs, a s p r ep a ra tio n s for leaving the planet 
I ve predic ted the next s e rie s of evolutionary steps the human species is going to go through, and they can only happen 

 iii spare. It involves in­ telligence expansion and a tremendous increase iii the life span. 
Ultimately we will be able to c o m m u n i c a t e with other species and we will meet intelligences from o th e r so la r x y v leins. Down here, ifs like 
(lie baby iii the mother’s womb The baby can’t be taught the English la n ­ guage until he is born. Or look at the whole evolu­ tionary process of life on this planet 

(J. 
Who will want to migrate to space? What about the people who want to slily down here? 
A. V\ ho left Europe to collie over here? I fs al­ ways the genetically pre­ d isposed. the restless, the kooks. Hie visionaries and the most intelligent.

Pollution is killing a river and a way o f life 

 grand son buys oysters from o th e rs who have had to go elsew here for them. 
“ This used to be one of the major oyster-produc­ ing areas in the state of 
M a r y la n d ,” 
H a rry 
Shorter dr. said the other day. 
“ Y e a rs ago, w hen I w as a y o u n g s te r, the whole d am n village d e ­ pended on it. at least HO per cent of them anyway 
Oysters would always get fat here. But with pollu­ tion and se d im e n tatio n down in the riv er, they just don’t grow like they used to.” 

 w a s h in g t o n po st

WASHING IoT #o5T 
BENEDICT, Md. — “ I will be 9(1 in a couple of m onths,” the waterman said. 
“ They all say, ‘You can't 12o on a boat anymore.’ Miss it? Sure I do. I miss it very much.” 

Charley Thompson, the oldest living waterm an in this Charles County village of 54KI on the Patuxent 
River, told how it was: 
"People here had a living in oyster, oyster arn! fish That w.is the livelihood around here, 4o years ago Things is changing, you know I can’t under­ stand it quite myself Everybody lived here got their living out id the water, out of the river. All the old fishermen I knew are gone, died . . .” 
There are wisps of yellowish-white hair on Charley 
Thompson’s head, a good set of tiottom teeth and a wide gap above There is a faint Scandinavian lilt to 
Ins voice, mixed with a slight southern Maryland accent, lh* retains a rugged look, iii his cap with a ship's-wheel ornament and the new rcd-and-grccu plaid wool shirt he got for Christmas. 
His face is lined, his eyes peer sharply through or over a pair of sunglasses as he recalls the past. "I fished all my life. When I was a kid in Norway, I used to fish. fish, fish,” hi* said. 
Ile works two days a week sharpening knives in 
Shorter's Place, a riverfront restaurant opened in 
192o by the late “ (’apt. T u b e" S horter and now presided over by Ins grandson, Harry A Shorter, Jr. 
"T h a t’s the only job I gfd,” In* said, almost apo­ logetically, as In* sal in a booth at Shorter's T here's univ a SJO monthly union pension aud $25o in Social 
Security, "I can live on it, but I can’t do much on it,” he said. 
What was it like 4o years ago on lite river? " I'm talking about (Iii* old times now,” lo* said, as if to underscore tin* difference "I would say there was a lot of competition Everybody was oystering, but you didn t get nothing for it tw o or th ree dollars a bushel. That was Uh* high price,” 
Part id Hie compensation was the river itself. 
"You siait your Ixml There's no wind or nothing,” the old man said, “ I f s calm, nice, md too cold. You go 25-JO miles upriver, all around the neighborhood

Lindsay won’t be stopped 

LOS ANGELES TIMES 
“ When I was first in theater and went to ‘cattle calls,’ I’d look around and feel threatened by women who were very much unlike me, who had matching accessories and had their hair in place. 
“ But it took me a very short time to1 realize I could never compete against that in the sense that I can’t compete with a very classical kind of beauty. 
Why should I spend the tim e to cry about that?’’ 
She may have felt threatened at au­ ditions, but Lindsay Crouse got the parts she wanted. 

I ii person she seems rather poetic, eth erea l, not one of the voluptuous b eau ties who seem in d o m in an t d e ­ mand. Her range of acting abilities has landed her two female film leads in the* past year and a half. 
At 27 she has gone from a cameo role in “ All the President's Men” (as re­ porter Kav Eddy) to leads in two fea­ tu r e s — G eo rg e Roy H ill’s “ Slap 

'I fe lt so inadequate fo r so lon g 9 

S hot,” s ta rrin g P aul N ew m an, and 
■Joan Micklin Silver’s “ Between the 
Lines.” 
Her Kay Eddy obtains a C R E EP file from her former boyfriend for Wood­ ward and Bernstein. “ You expect me to. . .?’’ she asked Woodward (Robert 
Redford) incredulously, revealing her still te n d e r feelings tow ard the old boyfriend — but she realizes the im ­ portance of the file as she silently coo­ perates — the cool professional, yet one who is not without sensitivity. 
In “ Slap S h o t,” C rouse plays the unhappy w ife of a minor league hockey player w ho resorts to violence in order to survive. 
“ I would like to portray women who accept them selves,” she said. “ I felt inadequate for so long that I couldn't look really great in a pair of pants. Too bad. I’m a woman. I’m not supposed to have a behind like a man. I’m so happy 

 about being a woman. 
“ P a rt of this feeling of accepting m y se lf h a p p e n e d in d a n c e ,” said 
Crouse, who choreographed and p er­ formed in dance shows as an under­ graduate at Radcliffe in the late ‘6os. 
She studied with Twyla Tharp. Alvin 
Ailey, M eree C u n n in g h a m , am o n g others. 
Crazy 

“ But it didn’t finally happen until I got out of the dance world. People in dance are crazy about th eir bodies. 
When I realized that without being a dancer I could be loved. I could have great experiences in life . . . it helped a lot. I gained IO pounds on the set of ‘All the President’s Men' while waiting to shoot my scenes. I felt very self-cons­ cious when I watched the film. But the third tim e J saw it I saw feelings being tran sm itte d , and I thought, ‘If you 

 don't accept yourself, nobody is going to.’ ’’ 
Her inauspicious acting debut was in 
New York in 1971: “ I was a table, so­ meone ate their breakfast off me. I was' also a sea anemone, a moon monster and a fish — it w as an a c tin g and dancing combination.” 
After her brief dance career follow­ ing graduation from Radcliffe in 197o, she began acting in New York, “ but I began to get restless, and felt I was pushing m yself in the w rong area. 
.Dance is a very silen t w orld, very self-contained. I felt I w asn’t able to ex p re ss m yself totally. A cting w as tough, but much more exciting. 
In “ Between the Lines,” she plays a photographer named Abby, who works for an underground newspaper (loosely based on the V illage Voice, w here 
Lindsay’s brother. Timothy Crouse, is a co lu m n ist). The film , due out in 
May. traces the changes in the lives of the staff m em bers when the paper is bought out by a rich publisher. 
Ironically. Rupert Murdoch, a well­ known publisher, just bought the Vil­ lage Voice.

San Antonio E X P R E S S - N E W S — Sun. Feb. 13 1977 

Oak Park chooses managed integration 

B y D W ID T H E A D W E L L 
A S S O C IA T E PR ISS 
OAK PARK, 111.—“ Don’t buy a home in 
Oak Park. This place is going to ‘go’ in about five years.” 
Modern living 

HARRIETTE R O BIN ET , with daughter Linda, and O ak Park village m anager Jack Gruber share pleasure in their community and the w a y it works. They're photographed in front 

 of Frank Lloyd W rig h t's form er home and studio, one of the assets of a town they have seen “ enriched” rather than ‘‘g h e tto iz e d ” by its unusual system of gradual integration. 

Richard 
Yanek. a stockbroker, recalled a fellow churchgoer whis­ pering those words to him during services one 
Sunday. That was in the late 196os after Pierre devise, a University of 
Illinois urbanologist who specializes in demogra­ phics, said the town would follow neighboring 
Austin, where sections were changing from white to black at rates as 

 high as four blocks a year. 
But Yanek. then an apartment dweller in 
Oak Park, didn’t panic. 
Neither did the commun­ ity. 
Instead of fleeing the 
\ illage and leaving it open to the classic pat­ tern of rapid population change followed by gen­ eral decline, the white residents of Oak Park set up an unusual system of 

 managed integration 
Oak Park's population of 82.5oo - about half homeowners and half apartment dwellers — is 
94 per cent white, 4 per cent black and 2 per cent other minorities. Before 
197o, the percentage of blacks and other minori­ ties was less than I per cent. 
“ We want the change to be slow .. We want to axoid the shock syn­ drome t hat most com*

 triunities go through when they are experienc­ ing racial change.” said 
Village Manager Ja ck 
Gruber. "It just leads to resegregalion, beginning from when the first black moves in to when the last vt bite moves oui." 
Jam es Compton, ex­ ecutive director of the 
Chicago Urban League. calls 
Oak 
P a rk ’s measures "a margin of progress." Ile said the village could absorb mort minorities but should be commended for its efforts. 
" I think a managed si- iuation tends to bring about a better pattern of integration,’’ lie added. 
"It s unfortunate that a managed situation is necessary, but I don’t oppose it ” 
No signs 

 limier Oak Park s pro­ gram of managed inte­ gration, "Fo r Rent” and 
"F o r Salt'" signs were banned. Building codes

RIC H A R D V A N E K , clears off the snow in front of the home in O ak Park, III., that in the early I 9 7o s he was advised not to buy. 
The prediction then w as 

 were s tlffened'Yo guard ,hat ° ak Pa/ k was 9oin9 against deterioration. to cha” 9e fr°m ct white and low-1 it ter est loans for action to a black section home or apartment building improvements were made available from the village govern­ ment. 
Real estate agents were prohibited from go­ ing door-to-door asking residents if they wanted to sell out 
A private housing referral agency was created to encourage prospective black and white residents to dis­ perse throughout the community rather than form enclaves, and a reporting system was devised (ti permit v illage officials to keep tabs on racial makeup of neigh­ borhoods and apartment buildings. 
Villagers concede that some of the policies de­ signed to smooth inte­ gration come close to in­ fringing upon constitu­ tionally protected rights and freedoms 
But many residents believe that things never havc*been so stimulating in the community where 
Frank Lloyd Wright per­ fected his 
“ prairie houses.” Edgar Rice 
Burroughs wrote his 
"Tarzan” novels and Er­ nest Hemingway grew up. 

What's gone 

“ The only I lung that’s gone' iii Oak Bark is that fellow in church and bigots Bkt* him ,” said 
Vgnek, whose four-bed* rnnm home has nearly doubled in value since he purchased it for $2K,o(111 iii 1o6o 

 llarriette Robinet. a black who moved here 111 years ago from Chicago with her husband, a health physicist who specializes in radiation safety, and two children, said that the controls prevented ' ‘unnatural ghetto-ization” of the community by realtors and financial institu­ tions, " I ’ve seen it every­ where I've been, from 
Washington, ILC., to the west side of Chicago,’’ bile said. “ You have to have these controls to have racial enrichment 
It’s a strain, but that s v ital to living and im ­ proving a community” 
Gruber says the key to flak Park s success has been an innovative, if of­ ten controversial, ap­ proach to racial change, 
"The community had iHith the resources lo develop new idcus and 
(he authority to implement them,” bt* said ' ‘But without the willingness of the people to attempt them, we wouldn't have stood a chance.” 
Central to Oak Park” integration program is the policy statement un­ animously adopted by village trustees in 1973 committing Hie village to scattering residents by race and ethnic group throughout the eommu* 
IUD 
A network of controls and incentives helps to accomplish this goal by keeping white demand for housing high and preventing a black enclave from forming, especially in the cast side bordering Austin That section tit Chicago’s west side is a poor, high-crime area w uh a population UH per cent black lf a black (amity wants 

 to buy iii an Oak Park neighborhood where blacks already comprise 
25 per cent of the re­ sidents, realtors ask them to talk wUh the vii luge human relations department where they are counseled on the \ ii* lage's dispersal policy. 
"W e don’t It'll them they can’t buy iii that neighborhood,” said 
Shirty nn Reid, common tty representative of the human relations stall 
"We attempt to sell them on the community as a whole and its com m it­ ment to diversity. We make sure they under­ stand thai they an* si ill free by law to buy anywhere they please. 
"Sure, it s walking a fine line sometimes between an individual’s basic rights, bnf we’re open about it We don I hide anything. Aud we counsel whites as well as blacks.” 
The result, Mrs Reid said. usually is coopera­ tion. 
"Most of the time these pt'ople wanted to move lo 
Oak 
Park precisely because of our policy," sla* said "They re quite willing lo let lls help them find another place to their liking.” 
Sim ilar counseling with similar results takes place at the Oak Park 
Housing ( enter, a private referral service created 

 iii IH72, which last year interviewed more than 
4,(NNI apartment hunters 
Racial concern arose in 
Oak Park in 195o when black m illionaire chemist Percy Ju lian moved from Chicago into an Oak Park mansion, and his porch was Arc­ hon ii a*d 
“ That’s when the change came into the community,” said Ver* nette Schultz, account supervisor for a public relations firm hired by the village "There were a lot of us who looked ut ourselves and were lust sil k at what we saw ” 
Villagers set up a ci­ tizens committee on human rights, and the village government tormed a com inunih relations commission 
The groups were iii strumentai iii Oak Park becoming in I HHH one el the first municipalities iii the nation to adopt an open housing ordinance 

Solutions 

Gruber said other communities fating decay and rat tai tension from the "white fright* flight syndrome” might find difficulty adopting 
Oak Park 's solutions because few have its re- sou recs. 
More than three­ quarters ut Oak Park’s residents are in proles 
»iorial, managerial, cler­ ical and sales jobs The median family income ut 
I HTH was SU ,823. almost 
I t , HOO higher than the median for the six-county 
( hicugn area. 
The community also 

 contained a treasure trove of h o m e s and 

 buildings designed by 
Wright, including the home and studio in which he lived from I HHH to IMM and Unity Temple, con* sintered among his mas­ terpieces 

San Antonio EXPR ESS-N EW S— Sun. Feb. 13 1977 
War 
Training to stop 

 terrorism 

-sp- 
' 
' ' , v . \ rn- lr 
W -M '' 

Brenda Gambill of Quartz Hill, Calif., gets camouflaged by Airman Dave Brown of St. Paul, Minn. 

Five-foot-four Theresa Over­ holt is in San Antonio learning how to fire an MHI) machine gun. 
Madeline Moreney is learning hew lo throw hand grenades at would-be ter­ rorists. 
JoD i Hoogstra traded her waitress lob in Crivitz, Wis., tor combat boots, 
( ’ Rations and an M IB rifle. 
The three are among HIH enlisted women recruited by tin* Air Force for its rugged four week anti-terrorist course at Camp Bulbs. Training for women began last month 
The I SAK Security Police Academy at Lackland A F B runs the combat skills course, which for women is on a one-year trial basis. 
Women receive no special consider­ ations and train side by side with males. Combat skills are emphasized. 

Women, like their male counterparts, fire rifles, machine guns and grenade launchers. 

Air Force officials quickly point out, however, women are not being trained for combat 
“ W e ’re not putting women in a combat role,” says L L Col. Donald 
Plummer, chief of the combat studies training division. 
He added, “ W e’ve had women in the law enforcement field a long time. 
They carry a weapon and could at any tim e be placed in an environm ent where they could use that weapon purely as a defensive tool. 
"Combat as we think of it means to go outside a perimeter and search the enemy. This is purely a defensive role 
. . . defending Air Force resources.” 
To qualify, women had to meet the 

 same physical requirements as men, including being able to lift 7(1 pounds th a height of six feet. 

Into the mud 

Airm an Thelm a Sands, 19. left a sales job iii Hollywood, Fla., for the mud of Camp Bulbs. 
“ It’s really been a lot of fun,” she said of the training. “ Women should have a chance to prove themselves, and, if needed, they owe allegiance to their country as the men do, and they (women) should have to serve, too. 

Madeline Moreney. IM. her fatigues coated with mud and her face d ar­ kened by camouflage paint, munched on a dinner of C Rations containing 

Story bv 

El) KINGSHOTT 

Photos bv 
J 
TAR KY TARSIKES 

 pork and beans. 
“ The food wouldn’t be so bad if it wasn’t cold.” she said, picking at the C 
Rations. 
“ There’s talk we can’t do what men can,” she added. “ I wanted to prove to myself we could. If men have to be in combat, then women should, too.” 

Others 

Here’s what other women trainees said: 
Theresa Overholt, IS, Bradenton, 
F la .: “ I like com bat form ations p arolin g the woods and ambushes. 
The guys haven’t tried to pamper us. 
They’ve let us prove ourselves.” 
.loDi Hoogstra, IS, Crivitz, Wis.: “ I like to do something that is challeng­ ing because I want to do as much as I 

Six months ago JoDi Hoogstra was a waitress

Judy Golden, 19, Springdale, Ark.: 
“ W e’re getting to do things a lot of people will never get to do. . .Yeah, women should be in combat. You never know when they’re going to pass the 
FR A (Equal Rights Amendment) and send us to war.” 
Beverly Voyles, 2o, W estm inster, 
Calif.: “ The guys have shown they’re not prejudiced against us. They want­ ed us here. My folks, they think it’s great. My mom says she would like to learn some of this stuff.” 

Challenge 

Teresa Knapper, 19, Eldridge, Iowa: 
“ If s a great challenge proving we could do it to everyone who thinks we 

 can’t.” 
By the time the women have com­ pleted the Bulbs course, they will have finished 15 weeks of Air Force train­ ing. 
This includes six weeks of basic and five weeks of security police technical training at Lackland and the four weeks of combat studies and skills at 
Bulbs. 
The Air Force will review the pro­ gram in about a year to decide if it will bo permanent for women 
Male recruits wholeheartedly sup­ port the training for women. 
“ They’ve done great,” said Airman 
Randy Denker, 2o, of Myers Flat. Ca­ lif. “ No problems at all.” 
Col. Plum m er is even more enthu­ siastic: “ They (m en) love it. Their reaction is, “Why not? It’s the same job we’re doing’. .

% Veseo still at large 

WASHING ION OOST 
WASHINGTON - W ill 
America's most famous fugitive ever be returned to this country to face trial? 
For several years, 
41 -year-old Robert Lee 
Yeseo has been fluking off criminal indictments, subpoenas and private lawsuits like so many pesky mosquitos as he seeks to fade into the lush background of his Costa 
Rican retreat. 
Hut recently there wa* a change in that country's extradition law that made Yeseo sudden­ ly vulnerable. 

Adding a measure of immediacy to the Veseo situation is that in June he becomes eligible for 
Coala Rican citizenship. 
If granted, it effectively would rule out extradi tion front that country. 
The son of a Detroil auto worker, 
Vesct gained notoriety in 197? when he used 
Im modest-sized New Jersey electronics company tt take control of giant In 
Nestors O verseas Her vices, Ltd. 

I ii 1972, the Securitle and F.xehange Commis sum charged Veseo w ill stealing $224 million o lO S's assets. In ail al tempt Iii quash the SKC probe, Veseo alleged!) made a secret $29o.ink t ash contribution iowan 
President N ixon’s re election,

“ Here It Is. the Beauti­ ful. the Promised Land!”

Diego freew ay and a la ndscape p o lk a-dotted with Denny s Drive-Ins and Taco Bells.

 w h e th e r 
A m e r ic a n v ie w e rs a r e re a d y for westerns again, at least westerns along the lines of ABC’s “ How the West 
Was Won.” 
A few years ago. Mis­ ter W e s te rn h im s e lf. 
John Wayne — who in­ troduced the first te le­ cast of “ G unsm oke" on 
CBS in IB55 — was asked if he thought the western would ev er die. 

Will westerns die? Heck no, sax the veterans 

The MGM version had already been aired twice by the networks, but ABC ap p a ren tly thought the m a t e r i a l could be e x ­ ploited further. Besides, the televised version of 
“ How the West Was 
W on” was w hat one might consider visually expurgated. 
Wide screen 

The film was the last to be shot in the w i d e ­ s c re e n . t h r e e - c a m e r a 
Cinerama process. When it was shown on tele- v ision, v lowers saw just a little more than one-third of the original three-pan­ el im a g e — alth o u g h 

 series scheduled. NBC’s 
“ The Q u e s t , ” w hich, with its tendency to d e ­ bunk w e s t e r n le g e n d s and c o n c en tra te on the se a m y and the bawdy, might better have been titled. “ How the West 
W as Wanton.” 
The series bit the dust after a short run. ABC’s 
“ W est” got a trial run last >ear and earned re ­ spectable ratings, partly perhaps because viewers have fond m e m o rie s of the motion p ic tu r e on which the TV movie was b a s e d , M G M 's supe r- s p e c t a c u l a r 1963 epic, 
“ How the West 
Was 
Won." 

N atu ra lly , the g ran d and im p e r i a l cowpoke took this suggestion as v irtu a l s a c r i l e g e lie chose to answer it with another question. 
“ Will 
S h a k e s p e a r e ever die?" Wayne coun­ tered. Then, he answered his own question: “ No. 
And n e i t h e r will w e s ­ terns. B's our folklore. 
It’s our tradition." 

ABC. perhaps sensing a certain declining inter­ est in TV westerns, pro­ m oted “ How th e West 
Was Won” in a way that m a d e it sound like a white "Hoots” — another saga about "the triumph of an American family." 
One would almost think the network was trying to convince v ie w e rs that this western was not ab­ solutely, rea lly q uite exactly a western

Mexico City to be w o r ld s largest city in 25 years 

WASHINGTON POST StPVICf 
WASHINGTON - 
In less than 25 years. 
Mexico City will be the world’s largest city, with nearly 22 million people — two and a hall' times the projected population of London in the year 
2o(H). 

S . i i i I *;iii Ii» w i l l b r dost1 behind with ii population of ‘JU million — triple the current size of Paris 
According to a recent report from the Popula­ tion Hderelict* Bureau, a 
\\ ashinglon-based organ­ ization that studies world population and migration trends, cities in underde­ veloped countries are growing so (piickly that. by t he end of I Ii is cen­ tury. more than two- thirds of the world s total urban populat iou will 11 \ e 

 i i i them 
Third World 
For tlie first tline i i i history, the report sn,vs, the largest Third World cit ies w ill be bigger I hail any of their counterparts 

 i ii developed nations. 
11 current populat iou trends continue for the next (| Hart er-cen t ii i v . cities like Bogota. Mani­ la. Karachi and .Jakarta will triple iii size. Lagos, w itll a current populat ion of ‘J I million, w ill <) ii a - dimple 

Some cities, w itll po­ pulations already over Kl m illion, w ill double in size i ii the next Kl years 
London and Tokyo, in contrast, will grow less than I per cent. 

Problem s resulting from such rapid growth, the study says. w ill be 
“ gargantuan.” 

Nearly all of the new urban population, half of wInch will be rural emi­ grants aud half oat iv o- boru. w ill be poor Slums ami illegal shuntytow us that surround 
Third 
World cities will balloon; transportation systems that are already night­ m arish W ill get worse; the number of unskilled unemplovcd will multip­ ly. 

W hile nut ny of the problems are tin* unavoi­ dable results of rapid de- v elopm eiit. populat iou growth and scarce re ­ sources. they have been exacerbat cd. the st tidy says, by poor adlumin- 
I ration aud policy makers whose “ attention is elsew here 
Vicious circle 

I ii a v minus circle i i i w Inch tile rich Kiev it ably get richer and the poor got nowhere, the study outlines lund-use policies and land speculation bv the wealthy that provide nowhere for the poor to 

 live 
Forced to set up provided with the most first in line” for services vested in roads for the housekeeping in illegal basic public services. like running water and cars of the rich and uni- shanties on the city peri- 
“ Those with political heat, the study notes, vers Mi es for their offspr- pliery. the poor are not - anfl economic clout are “ P u b lic funds are in- big.”

W riting’s fun fo r these kids 

N ew vow TIMES SESVICE 
WALNUT CREEK. Calif. - w riting courses have become so popular at Los Lomas High 
School in this bedroom com­ munity on the edge of San 
Francisco’s suburban sprawl that students now have to be screened to get into the over­ subscribed classes. 
Los Lomas High’s emphasis on the teaching of writing at a time when high schools elsewhere in the country are being criticized for graduating students who cannot or­ ganize ideas on paper is the result of the influence of an unusual three-year-old program called the 
Bay Area Writing Project. 
Based at the nearby Berkeley campus ol the University of Cali­ 

 fornia, the project is an ambitious effort to improve the way that ele­ m en tary and secondary school youngsters write by helping their teachers do a better job of teaching writing skills. 
The project, which operates in nine Bay Area counties, will be ex­ panded to reach students in other parts of California and various ar­ eas of the country as a result of a 
$4til),848 grant just announced by the 
F ederal G o v ern m en t’s National 
Endowment for the Humanities. 

Critique 
What the Bay Area Writing Pro­ ject does is bring together groups of school teachers to share their most successful ideas for the teaching of writing. 

In the sessions, the teachers are required to write and then discuss and critique their writing and the w riting of others. They usually em erge with an appreciation of writing that inspires them to per­ suade their own schools to reassess the approaches use in teaching of writing. 

“The project is different in that it does not involve a group of college professors telling high school teachers what to do,” said Jam es 
Gray, the originator and director of the program at Berkeley. 

“ The idea is that th ere is so­ mething known about how to teach writing and most teachers aren't aware of what's known. We bring the teachers together and let them 

 pass around the information like a from the freshman year through the baton in a relay race." senior year.” 

Berkeley*’* dismay over the writ­ ing deficiencies of its incom ing freshmen was the impetus for the project, which the university says has apparently helped raise scores on the writing sample done bv new students. 

Furthermore, a preliminary eval­ uation of the project indicates that stu d en ts at p a rtic ip a tin g high schools are also doing better on 
College Board tests. 

“ The writing project affected the whole w riting pro g ram in this school,” said Jean K. Jensen, the head of the English Department at 
Los Lomas High “ Because of Jim 
Gray, we rewrote our curriculum 

Los Lomas no longer depends on writing boing taught in connection with re g u la r E nglish courses, which often tend to stress litera­ ture. 

Specific courses in composition and writing skills that were for­ merly not taught until the junior or senior years now are taught in the first two years. 

B ecause stu d e n ts often w rite papers with only the teacher in mind, a common suggestion iii the 
Writing Project sem inars is that they be made to read their papers aloud to encourage them to handle their subject in a way that will ap­ peal to a broader audience.

 began his career 
By VERONICA SALAZAR 
Krum the classroom to a police boat was a dramatic change for Alfredo C. Gonzalez. 

Central Park 
228-5123 

I e n tra l H ark S |« re 
San IN dm al I iMtp I 111 
M on ibm Sat, 
*»;,Ul-H 

Suddenly he was in a position of enforcing tile law in a city five tunes larger than Ins old home 
Iou n 
And it all started on a dare. Gonzalez was at tending college one sum mer when a friend dart'd him tit join Un' police de­ partment 
A career was the least thing Gonzalez expeeted. 
He was c e rta in lie wouldn't qualify Itocause of Ills height and weight 
— he is short and stocky. 
But if he got the job, young Gonzalez re a ­ soned. at least ll would supplem ent the family income. 
But he did gel the job, and that led Gonzalez lo become one of the first IO 
Mexican A m erican pa­ trolmen to he hired by the Kingsville Police De­ partment He was e\en- ttially to become the first 
Mexican-American chief of police for the City of 
Edinburg and the first 
Mexican-American pre­ sident of the Texas Police 
Association since 1895 lh* is now a leading can d id ate for a P r e s i­ dential appointment as a 
I S Marshall, according to government sources. 
Intelligent 
Gonzalez m ade it be­ cause he is intelligent. 
He is firm straight and fair. It doesn’t make any difference to him whether a person’s name is Garza, Jones, Garcia or Smith The law is the law and his goal is to do a good job enforcing the law as fairly as he can 
The 47-year-old native ol Hebbronville has tx*en 

DEDICATION 
REWARDED 

 enrolled at St. M ary ’s 
University. After one se­ mester he dropp'd out to join the A rm y. He r e ­ turned home in 1952. held different jobs for a year and finally enrolled a1 
Texas AAI under the G I. 
Bill. 
In 
1956 he sta rte d teaching in Hebbronville and coached football. 
Three years later he re­ signed his teaching job to go to work for the Kings­ ville Police Department. 
He recalls the chief of police telling him ‘‘he was not tall enough for the p o sitio n .” hut his high re e o m m e n d a tions made up for his size. 
Captain 
Gonzalez was a patrol­ m an for two y e a rs, skipjMsl sergeant and be­ came patrol lieutenant. 
In two years he was pro­ moted to c a p ta in . He hoi [ant bring more Mexi- ean-A m ericans into the force. 
When Gonzalez (‘ame to 
Edinburg he had 12 per­ sons in the pollee depart mon! and a budget of 
$74,9oo. Today he e m ­ ploys 24 and has a budge! that exceeds $3o7,927. lie started with a three car department and now has 
IO vehicles. 
“ We had one thing then that we don’t have now,” said Gonuzalez, recalling his youth "As a young­ ster, I learned to respect the law. Not very many people today have that respect and they d on’t feel that resp ect can chief of police in Edtn- bring peace,” he said. burg since 19HH. lh* was

Gonzales for outstanding service 
Gonzalez is one of six children born to Alfredo 
T. and Severa .VI. Gonza­ lez He says he learned lo work al the age of seven liecause he liked to work. 
Ile becam e a shoe shine boy and later got a job in a drug store as a delivery boy earn in g 
$2 5o a week. He soon learned the soda iounlaui business. 
Advanced 
Ills first five years of schooling were at “Cole- gio A ltanuruno under the direction of Srta 
F.milta 
D avila. 
AH courses were taught in 
Spanish and the students were very advanced, especially in m aih arui history, by the time they enrolled in public school

Studying for money 

,.t 

WASHINGTON POST 
WASHINGTON - 
On a recent Saturday morning, a group of 
6o F airfax County, 
Va., teachers bustled into a heatless class­ room at Fairfax High 
School, armed with thermoses and little snacks, to begin a cou rse that would help them obtain m aster’s degrees in education and. as a resu lt, higher s a ­ laries. 

T h e c o u r s e . 
School 
C o m m u n ity R d a I ions, would be co m p leted in three weekends, just like all the c o u r s e s the te a ch e rs are taking for their degree. When they get it, their degree will co m e from St. T h o m as 
C ollege in St Paul. Minn. 
— a school that most of the* te a ch e rs will never see. 
St. Thomas is one of a g ro w in g n u m b e r of out-of-state schools that h ave c o m e to the W a ­ shington are a in recent years — cam pusless and fro m s e v e r a l h u n d red miles away — to tap what many educators consider to I m * a lucrative market for the adult student. 
T h e m a r k e t is rich here, the educators say. b e c a u s e so m a n y r e s i ­ d e n ts a r e w ell-p aid t e a c h e r s , g o v e r n m e n t w o r k e r s and m i lita r y p e rso n n e l. 
A h ig h e r degree can mean higher salaries for them and the cost of the extra co u rse s is often paid by the tax- payers. 
The som ew hat uncon­ ven tio n al m a n n e r in w hich m an y of th e se out-of-state schools oper­ ate has spawned skepti­ cism among local school o f f ic ia ls about the degrees tieing granted. 
In the 1975-7K school y e a r there w ere 27 out of-state institutions oper ating in Virginia — IK in 
Northern Virginia — w db a to tal e n ro llm e n t u 
31 .(MMI for the courses of fered. As of last fall then were IK such institutions o p e ra tin g in M ary lan d with an estim ated 5,(MHI students enrolled. The ll o u t-o f -s ta te s c h o o ls li­ censed to operate i i i the 
District of Columbia had an e s t im a t e d to ta l e n ­ rollment of KIMI. 
More 

(Education officials in all t h r e e ju r i s d i c t i o n s said there a re probates many m ore out-of-staU sch o o ls o p e ra tin g h e n without their knowledge. 
W ashington a re a re si­ d e n ts ca n ta k e a widt r a n g e of c o u r s e s from such institutions as L a ­ v e r n e .C o lle g e of La*

N ova it w as a c h u r c h basement — to serve as a cla ssro o m 
The schools offer degrees and courses they feel certain will al tr a c t a re a re sid e n ts — ra n g in g from m a s te r s degrees in public admin 
(stratum and education to cou rses in transactional a n a ly s is and t r a n s c e n ­ dental meditation They then often hire local re­ sidents as teachers. 

S o m e e d u ­ cators doubt value o f the courses. 

 las al college officials said they are concerned th at th ese o u l-o f -sta U schools are cutting into their turf But, like many educators across the na 
Uon who see the concept of a “ university without w a lls” catch in g on. (hi o ffic ia ls said they also fear that som e students a re being shortchanged by schools that are m o n in terested in tellin g di 
Plumas than offering an education 
D e a n s of th e out-of sta te schools insist they a re pro\ uUng a s e n ice lo local students by offering them the kinds of degre* p r o g r a m s they want us students 
— and by holding classes at hours convenient to the adult w o rk in g s tu d e n t. They 

More e d u ­ cation m eans b i g ­ g e r p a y ­ checks 

 say the “ university with­ out w a l l s " is the way of the future — and a means of survival for financially strapped schools. 
Needs 

“ We arc identifying the needs of education which exist out t h e r e . . . in­ stead of saying to a stu­ dent. here is a group of c o u r s e s , t a k e t h e m or le a v e t h e m , we a r e willing to design a curr i­ culum that the students w an t, t h e n b r i n g it to t h e m . ” e x p l a i n e d Dr 

P au l M otzkus, dean ol field studies for L averne 
C ollege, one of the first schools to begin offering courses locally.

2o,ooo s tu d e n ts ta k e courses the school offers off campus.

Fro st’s staging 
California fete 

Hyatt Regency Los Angeles 

The state of California is bring hon­ ored this month by Frost Brothers in a salute beginning this weekend. 

In coming weeks there will be p er­ sonal ap p earan ces of 21 desig ners, p rincipals and fashion a u th o rities, representing IS of the foremost Cali­ fornia designing firms at F ro st's three 
San Antonio branches as well as the 
Austin store.

 for a week’s stay at the Hyatt Regency 
Hotel. 
Three trips, each for two persons,, will be awarded. Everyone 18 or older is invited to register in any F ro st store. 
No purchase is required to register or to win. 
The winners will also receive c o m ­ plimentary tours of Lion Country Sa­ fari, Magic Mountain, the Queen Mary and Universal Movie Studios. 
F ro s t’s salute to California also in­ cludes the “ California 77 Art Exhibi­ tion.’' at all F ro s t’s branches.

Secret agents 

I believe the agents n ill cause the next sea nihil in spurts . . . " — . ii 
McGuire. Marquette I nirersily. 

By DAN LAUCK 

NEWSDAY SERVICE 

They are there because thens is money. Lots of money. Money to be banked and invested and secured and insured. 

And. with some of them, money to be diverted and swindled and stolen and rolled in. They are the agents of sport. 
They do not like that word — agents. 
The law vers among them usually re­ mind you they are attorneys. The ones who are not prefer to be called sports representatives. 
Agent, sports representative, what* ever, they are an outgrowth of the industry of sport, and they are every­ where. 

They befriend 13-year-olds who can 
.jump up and see themselves in glass backboards. At that age. in the 
Bedford-Stuyvesant ghettos of the country, a pair of sneakers and occa­ sional subway fare are all it costs to buy a player. 
By the time the 13-year-old is 19 or 
2(1. the agent might have to send the player a couple of hundred a month, or an advance of $5.oo(1 or a new Fddorado before the draft 

But even a $5,ooo advance is nothing if the player is a first-rounder. The agent can make that much back in an hour of negotiation. And. if the player is a A nims Erv ing, all the agent has to do is guard the player with his life and he can retire wuh him. 
So. to secure someone like a .blinis 
Erving some agents will go to almost any length They will sax anything. 

First of four parts 

 i 
North Carolina basketball coach Dean Smith said he was offered a bribe of 2*^ per cent of a player’s contract by a New York agent who wanted to sign one of his players. 

 i New York agent Norman Blass secured former Morgan State basket­ ball star Marvin Webster as his client, then arranged for Webster’s coach to be paid bv the Denver Nuggets as a scout. 

 i Detroit Pistons guard Ralph Simpson, in a sworn deposition, said his former agent told him that he was afraid of going to jail for falsifying federal income tax returns. 

 i Pat Thomas and Jackie Williams, football players at Texas X&M two sears ago. sa> the> were told by a Houston agent they could sign a contract with him before A&M’s appearance in the 1975 Liberty Bowl, which they did. v 
They did not find out until a few days before the game that their signatures had made them ineligible. Eventually, Thomas signed with live agents and W illiams three before going to the pros.

Arkansas clinches title tie 

Jeff Grossman,

All-Star game 

 in Milwaukee 
Stars clash today 

By JEFF DROSSMAN 
O f THE EXPRESS N EW S SiA ff 

M ILW A U K EE - The chaos known as All-Star weekend swung into high gear here 
Saturday as NBA and learn officials as well as coaches, players, publicists and writers created the largest invasion since D-Day. 

There was the Doctor and Big 
Mao fighting through a crowd <d young autograph hounds al the air­ port a bggage claim: the Bourd of 
Governors acting like a hung jury. minding for hours on end; and Pete 
Vlaravieh saying tin* game should lie a winner take ail proposition. 
And through it all. Tommy llein- sohn did not get thrown out of tilt bar. 
Although many dispute the fact the main event of this veritable three-rum circus takes place Sun d ay ut 12 45 p.in. when the East meets the West in the 27th annual 
NBA All-Star game at Milwaukee 
Arena. 
The East leads the series. 17-7 
M aravich. the Jazz guard vvh< will start for the East. claim s i would add incentive ii the winners were awarded $2.(Min and the losers received only expenses 
Currently, the winners get $1 .(NKI and the losers $H5(i, which is not exactly your minimum wage. 
But Deliver s L in y Brown, coach of the West team, sounds like In wotild come here even if he had pay hts own way 
Three Nuggets — forwards David 
Thompson and Bobby Jones along with center Dan Issei — join guards 
Paul Wcstphu! Phoenix) aud Norm 

Nee (.ERV IN, Page HIS 

L IT T L E ROCK (A P ) - Tho 
Lith ranked Arkansas Razor- backs wrapped up at least a share of the Southwest Confer­ ence championship by beating 
Rice 78-51 Saturday night. 

The Razorbacks broke the game open by reeling off 18 unanswered points midway through the firs! half. 
The victory also gave Arkansas a bye to the finals of the SWC postseason tournament March 5 at Houston. 
1941 

Arkansas is 13-1) in the SWC and 22-1 for the season. The championship is 
Arkansas’ first since the Razorbacks shared the title with Southern Meth­ odist University iii 1958 Arkansas has not won a SWC basketball title outright since 1941. 
The Razorbacks can wrap up the undisputed title Tuesday night by heating hapless Texas C h ristian 
University at Fort Worth. 
Arkansas hit its first five stints from the Held and got off to a HI-4 against 
Rice. Arkansas led 2o-13. lint then ran off 18 straight points to take a 38-13 lead. 
Arkansas led 44-21 at the* half 

24 points 

Marvin Delph led the Razorback* with 24 points before leaving the game seven minutes deep i i i the second half. 
Delph had 14 points in the first half, 
Senior Ray His Buckner came off the bench and scored a career high 14 points

M ustangs rally to down A ggies 

DALLAS (A P ) — Freshman Richard 
Harris hit a 15-foot jump shot with two seconds remaining to give Southern 
Methodist a 7o-68 Southwest Confer­ ence victory over Texas A&M Saturday night. 
The Mustang triumph tightened the battle for the vita) fifth-place spot in 
Hie SVVt standings Fourth-place A&M is now 7-5 Texas is 7-B and SMU 7-7. 
The fifth-place team gets the last home berth of the first round of the SWC postseason tournament. 
The Mustangs shot Btl per cent i i i the first half in taking a 51-41 lead at intermission, lait they shot only 33 per cent in the second half and scored only 
19 points. 
A&M led 16-6 in the early going but 
SMU fought back to tie I ho game at 
3o-3o with 6:5o left in the half. Then in the next four minutes, the Mustangs outscored the Aggies 2o-4 to take a 
16-point lead ut 5o-34. 
Harris, freshman from Miami, ria., who scored only eight points in the game, hit hts winning basket after 
SM I s Pele Lodwlek stole the hall with a minute left to play.

PA LM SPR IN G S. Calif. L \ P ) - Rik 
Massengak*. a front-runner all,the way, built his round on an eagle-birdie burst,

Desert Golf ( lassie.

Ford. Mussengale compiled a 72-hole total of 27o. a 

✓ r n A I lo:, st tilths 
;;s 

 whopping 18 under par for one round over eac h of the four desert courses used for this, the longest tour­ nament the touring pros play ail season. 
A deeply frustrated Bruce Liet/ke. whit has chased 
Mussengale throughout the tournament, could do no belter than a round of par 72 on the 6.911-yard lac 
Quinta Country ( lid) course and fell from four strokes back to six behind at 276 
Liet/ke, suddenly one of the game s brightest stars with two victories to his credit this season and an unbroken string of 25 consecutive rounds at par or better, admitted he had “ very little confidence going into the* last round. 
“ B lk is playing aw fully good g o lf." said the 
25-year-old Liet/ke. whose round required 36 putts from his cross-handed style “ All I can tin is try to play my own game, throw some birdies at him and hope he makes a mistake. But he hasn't made any yet aud the way he's playing it looks a little doubtful that he will, "

LU BBO C K (AIM — Mike Russell scored 32 points, including three key Ihrce-pomt plays, to lead Texas 
Tech to an H7-69 Southwest Conference victory over 
Texas in a regionally -televised game Saturday. 
Consecutive three-pomt plays by Sieve Dunn and 
Russell climaxed a run of 12 straight points by the 
Red Raiders after Texas had taken an early 12-6 lead 
Tlu* Longhorns never led atter that although they tied the game 32-32 inst before halftim e, but substitute guard Keith Kitchen* hit a basket to give the Red R a id e rs a

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sunday February 13 1977 
Secret agents stir sports furor 

Continued from Page IS prom ise anything, do anything. Mon­ ey. ears, anything. Just sign. 
Many of the players do sign, e n s ­ n a rin g th e m s e lv e s in lev els of w heeling and d ea lin g they a re not prepared to handle. Those players are white and black, poor and not, but a preponderance of those who suffer are black. 
The reasons are simple: the percen­ tage of blacks in football and basket­ ball is high. And, too, when a white all-American halfback graduates from 
College some sophisticated white bu­ sinessman is often there to help him. lf the halfback is black, a businessman seldom is around. 
Wooden got offer 
It s not just players who become in­ volved. Northwestern basketball Coach 
Tex Winter doubts that more than a 
Couple of coaches in the country who have couched lirst-round draft choices have not been subjected to “ offers.” 
* Even John Wooden, whose priestly im a g e w ould seem to m a k e him beyond approach, said he once was offered m oney and the p ro m ise of 
£ re a t high school p ro s p e c ts to in ­ fluence his players to sign with one agent. 
E ven people in the b u sin e ss a re amazed that some agent would have the gall to offer John Wooden money. 
“ You gotta re m e m b e r, th o u g h .’’ iaid Texas Coach Abe Lemons, “ that if the money gets big enough, the name

And so no one is beyond question. 
Not agents, not players, not coaches, not owners, not leagues. 
“ It’s gone on so long, said retiring 
M a rq u e tte b a s k e tb a ll

Under the table 
And. yet, hardly any of this is known publicly because it is a business that o p e ra te s tin d er th e ta b le . Not all agents are devious or dishonest, of course. Maybe not even most of them. 
But, a fte r a len g th y in v estig atio n . 
Newsday has found the world of sports agentry team ing with Hie contem pti­ ble. 
Marvin Webster was a valued com ­ modity at Morgan State, lh 1 was 7-1 and 24o pounds and known a s “ The 
Human E rsaser.” 
Ile w as a v e ra g in g 2o rebounds a game and seven blocked shots. Ile was about to become the second choice in the 1975 NBA draft when a New York agent, who asked that his nam e not be used, w ent to see W e b ste r ab o u t representing him. Eventually. Georgia Tech Saturday.

8o of 88 for the season.

Blass said.

“ It had nothing to do with Marvin 
W ebster,” Blass said. “ Marvin W eb­ s t e r ’s c o n tra c t w as a lre ad y signed when I got (Frazier) that.” 
Frazier himself adm itted after some questioning that the job had been a r ­ ranged, but he said it fell through. He denied that he had ever been paid by the Nuggets. 
Scheer 
But Nuggets owner Carl Scheer said 
Frazier had been paid. “ We paid him a sum of money as p art of W e b ste r’s contract,” he said. Scheer said he did not know why. “ That was just part of the negotiations.” 
Two sources close to the Denver* 
Frazier deal say that Frazier original­ ly was supposed to receive ap p ro x i­ mately $35,ooo from Denver. Scheer would not confirm the amount. 
Such arrangem ents by Blass are not unusual.

N orth C a ro lin a and the 1978 U.S. 
Olympic coach, said he was offered 2>2 per cent of a player’s contract in the spring of 1972 by Blass. It was the year that Bob McAdoo, Bill C ham berlain and Dennis Wuycik went pro. 
“ He tried to pass it off as a finder’s fee.” Smith said. “ He tried to put it in a nice way.” 
Smith didn't take it that way: Blass was asking Smith to push his player to 
Blass. Smith said he ushered him out. 
Blass denied S m ith 's story. “ I ’ve never been in Dean Sm ith’s office,” he said . “ T h a t w as ( ’huck K au fm a n 
(Blass' business partner at the tim e). 
Ile came back and said he wanted to make Dean Smith a partner (in one of the player’s contracts). I said. ‘A ren’t you an idiot ? ” ’ 
Smith certain 
Smith is certain. “ I know who Chuck 
K aufm an is. I never saw him until about a y ear and a half ago. It was 
B lass." And Chuck K aufm an is c e r­ tain. too. He said he never went to 
North Carolina. 
Other agents have m ade the sam e kind of offer. Al McGuire said an agent offered him two per cent of Dean Me- rninger’s contract when Meminger was a senior at Marquette. 
Southern Illinois Coach Paul L am ­ bert was anonymously offered a trip to the Bahamas and a new car if he would deliver Joe M eriw eather, then L am ­ b ert’s center and now Atlanta’s. 
Sometimes it is a mother or father or close friend who is offered a payment. 
Sometimes, when it s a college coach, it s not money that’s offered but high school players. The agent will say: You get me your player, coach, and 1 11 get this kid to come to your school. 
There are variations in the them es that agents throw out at players. One of the basics is the one that Wayne 
Rodgers, an agent in Kansas City, gave to Mitch Sutton when Sutton w as a football p lay er at the U n iv ersity of 
Kansas. Sutton said it went like this: 
“ He said, ‘Hey, man, you’re black. 
You’ve never had money, m an. You don’t know how to handle it. You can trust me, I'm a brother.’ And you don’t feel when you get outta school like gi­ v in ’ all your m oney to so m e w hite dude. So you let him handle it.” 
Power of attorney 
At the end of one of those speeches. 
Sutton signed a document which gave 
Wayne Rodgers his power of attorney. 
“ It (the power of attorney) is tile most abused thing in s p o rts ," says 
Kick Stanczyk, an agent in Denver. “ It allows an agent to do everything but get m arried for his client . . . and I’m not sure that hasn’t happened.” 
That power of attorney m ight well have been what led to the dem ise of m aybe the c o u n try ’s la rg e st sp o rts agency. Pro Sports Advisors Inc., iii 
Cleveland. 
Pro Sports Advisors, which was put to g e th e r by fo rm e r B row ns p la y er 
John Wooten and E rn est P s a r ra s of 
Salt Lake City, was representing 125 to 
15o athletes in 1975 when three PSA clients — the Detroit Pistons’ R alph 
Sim pson, D enver Bronco Otis A rm ­ strong, Seattle Supersonic center Mike 
Green — sued, alleging that PSA had used the power of attorney to m ishan­ dle their funds. 
According to the players’ attorney. 
Dan F ricdland of Indianapolis, they d iscovered th at PSA would se c u re bank loans iii the nam e of Simpson and 
A rm strong, would send p art of the money to the player or pay some of the clien ts’ bills, and the rest would bt1 in v ested in P S A ’s in v e s tm e n t p r o ­ g ra m . which basically consisted of condominiums around the country.

According ta F ric d la n d , Sim pson and Armstrong did not sign for most of their loans — that was handled through 
PSA's power of attorney — and did not even know how m u ch m oney w as loaned them each tim e.” 
Within a couple of weeks after the first suit was filed in behalf of Simp­ son, A rm stro n g and G reen. P sa rra s settled with them out of court, repay­ ing all of the money they had invested by PSA. Pat M cFarland, then an ABA player, sued and was repaid shortly thereafter, too. 
Retractions 
Wooten, after the players w ere re ­ paid by Psarras. went to the players and asked them to sign statem ents re­ tracting everything they had claimed iii their suit. 
Simpson and Armstrong signed. 
Just before the Super Bowl, Minne­ sota star Chuck Foreman said he was owed $35,o9o yet from his investments in PSA. 
Wooten, according to published re­ ports, said Forem an would be repaid over the next three years. But F o re­ m a n 's a tto rn e y . Tom R eich , who represents about a half-dozen players who had m oney in PSA, in c lu d in g 
Cincinnati baseball star Joe Morgan, said they have not been repaid. 
Jackie Williams and Pat Thomas are cousins. T hey grew up to g e th e r in 
Plano, a small town outside Dallas. 
T hey w ere in th e s a m e c lass all through school, played on the sam e football team, went off to Texas A&M together, and w ere A&M's s ta rtin g cornerbacks during the ‘75 season. 
T h at’s why they liked what Arthur 
May wus selling them. 

May, who was working for Clifford 
Paul Associates, a sports agency in 
Houston, began talking to W illiam s and Thomas after the Texas gam e the last week of November. 

In the three-week interlude before the 1975 Liberty Bowl gam e and while 
T hom as was out of town. W illiam s went to Houston where May, he said, pushed him to sign. 
“ I rem em ber askin’ him twice: ‘Is it illegal to sign before a bowl g am e?’ He said. ‘No, no problem. 
“We talked a little more and I asked him again. He said no. He said, ‘No­ body is ever gonna see it anyway. It’s goin’ into a safe.’ He said he would not date it. I asked him point-blank cause I wanted to make sure. He said no.” 
Clifford Paul, the head of the agency, disavowed any knowledge of T hom as’ and Williams’ story. Arthur May den­ ied it. too. The Williams contract that 
May has is dated Jan. 22. 1978, one month after the Liberty Bowl gam e, just as May told Williams it would be. 
T h o m a s’ co n tract, May said, was dated Jan. 28. Thomas said he actually signed a few days after Williams, also before the Liberty Bowl. 
McDonald 
N e ith er T h o m a s nor W illia m s thought anything else about all of this until three or four days before the Li­ berty Bowl when Coach Emory Bollard called the seniors together after prac­ tice. B o llard had ex -p ro T o m m y 
McDonald talk to them. 
“ McDonald said, ‘I hope none of you guys have signed with an agent yet, cause it'd make you ineligible,’” Tho­ m as said. “ Ja c k ie and I just kinda looked at each other funny.” 
Said Williams, “ It was like, ‘Where do we go from here?” ' 
They tried to get out of the contract with Paul. 
“ He (Paul) said he would fight us over it.” Williams said. “ He said we could sign ag a in at a low er percentage.” 

Monday in the Express: How agents persuade players to sign. 

Dan Cook 

Sensational jockey is still growing 

It isn t often that a little guy leaps from his weight class to make world news. The first time it happened Goliath caught a rock between the eyeballs. The last time it happened Willie Shoemaker pulled up early, misjudging the Kentucky Derby finish line. 
But now w e’ve got a skinny, little 16-year-old who is making far more headlines than any of the huge horses he rides. Steve Cauthen is the hottest thing to sit a saddle since Lady Godiva. 
The kid has averaged almost three winners a day at New York’s Aqueduct since the track opened its new season six weeks ago. Tuesday he rode four winners, four more firsts on Wednes­ day and then three w inners and two seconds on Thursday. His mounts have hauled in more than a million dollars in purses and it w asn’t until the last few weeks that they started pushing him up on chalk horses. 

There is a problem, however, lacing this >oung apprentice. As mentioned, he's only 16. He's still growing. This is like a kid who sings like Tom Jones but his voice is changing. And Steve’s m other, so proud of him now, is pulling against him in the long haul. 
She d like for her son to grow to 
“maybe 5-5 or a little more." 

You can look from Santa Anita to 
T anfuran, from Oaklawn to Hialeah and you’d be hard-pressed to locate a 
5-5 jockey these days. 
Old race hands tell about one jock, getting on in years and heavy around the middle, who ate Ex-Lax for three weeks as lie fought to keep Ills weight down. He ale so much lie got fat on the chocolate. 

Mrs. Cauthen knows much about her son’s profession. She’s pleasantly sur­ prised at his fantastic success but she still wants him to grow to five-feet-five or more. Both Mrs. Cauthen and her brother. Tom B ischoff, are horse trainers by trade so they’ve been up to their arm pits in jockeys for years. 

And now you know why young eve has a special feel for racehorses, lie s been around them all hts life. Once he drops his small fram e into a saddle he iMHomes a part of the animal s move­ ments. one of those rare naturals. 
Last year, when Steve was just get­ ting ready to launch Ins career, a cou­ ple of old pros. Don B rum field and 
Bemoil Savior, offered to teach him the ropes. 

.After a few weeks Sayler backed off, confiding to friends, “ you can offer him a few pointers, like telling him where the restroom s are at certain tracks, hut nobody can teach what lie’s got because he s* a natural rider, through and through. 

And so it is thai 16-yeur-olU Stove 
Cauthen continues to amaze folks with fresh strings of triumphs. At the rate h e ’ s going he figures to In* a million­ aire before h e ’s 18 But h e ’d better hurry. He’s got a little brother who already is IO pounds heavier than he is se by the tim e Steve is 18 he might have to ride naked and leave off the saddle to make weight. 
Well. Lady Godtva did it and they’re still talking about her. 
Smile* xvi thin 
The H arlem G lo b etro tters always m anage to sm ile through thick urn! thin but things have been rather Huck 

STEVE ( ALTHEN 

 for them lately so their smiles might 
!>c thinning. 

Alter their performance here last week two ut the Trotters were injured iii a car-tmck accident near Shreve­ port. D allas Thornton and Robert 
Bulge were released from a Shreveport hospital atter treatment but one of the 
Iruek passengers still is in critical condition. 

Two nights later the T ro tte rs a p ­ peared in Mobile and while they were perform ing thieves broke into their dressing room and stole $875 in cash, ta p e r e c o rd e rs , c lo th e s and so m e jewelry. 
The Trotters keep right on smiling and performing but things are n ’t too funny for them these days. 
Expensive din-din 

Those fund-raising politicians can ’t hold a candle to the spread the Miami 
University baseball team has set for next Thursday. The cost will be $5.OOO a person and it will be held—of all places—on the school s baseball d ia­ mond. 

Two master chefs will br flown in 
Irom Washington and Los Angeles and the menu will consist of turtle soup 
Lady (u u r r ie se . pat en crute with 
Cumberland and Madeira spic, vol au vent P arisien ne with veal, sw e e t­ breads, truffles and m ushroom s, pheasant a la Georgienne and mango champagne sherbert. 

Somewhere on a sidecar there will be offerings of b ran d y , coffee, G rand 
Mariner, charlotte russe, cheeses and 
I*ct lf fours. 
Still, even alter all that. It’s going to be tough for somebody to go drop a 
$1o OOO tab beside som e c h a rm in g couple 
Only 34 guests will attend but unless somebody ru n s a ch eck M iam i Uni­ versity should wind up with $17o,OOO to start eon sir uct ion on its new baseball stadium. Of course, if that menu hup* liens to grab any of you folks with a loose five or IO thou they say they can squeeze iii one or two more.

Classic Saturday 
AP in Hope 

WIREPHOTO 

MIAMI (AP) - Sandra Post, trying to end a two-year victory drought, shot her second straight two-under-par 7(1 Satur­ day for a one-stroke lead after two rounds in a $5o,ooo Ladies 
Professional Golf Association tournament. 

A shot off the pace for Sunday's final round in the first stop on the 1977 
I .PCI A tour are Silvia Bertolaccini and 
Roberta Albers Speer at 141 
Miss Bertolaccini shot a three-under 
69 and Mrs. Speer had a 7(1 on the 
6.25o-yard Kendale Lakes Country Club course. 
Defending champion Judy Rankin. w ith a 72, headed a group of four at 142. 
Tile others were Clifford Ann Creed. 
Pat Meyers and Susan Downer. 
First-round leader Kathy Whitworth soared to a 7H and stood at 144 
Miss Post, who had four birdies and two bogeys, finished second three tunes last year. The 28-year-old Cana­ dian, who now lives in Boynton Beach, 
Fla., hasn’t won since taking the Far 
Fast in 1974. 
Her two chief challengers have never won. 
Miss Bertolaccini. 27, of Houston. has one second place to show in her two years on the tour. Mrs. Spear, 3(1 and ffTrm Richmond, Iud., has never done better than fourth iii a four-year career which shows $27,786 in total earnings. 
Miss Post said she couldn't explain not winning. Shi* has made $176,472 iii nine years, with two \ ictories and eight second-place finishes. 
“ You just can't get frustrated.” she 

 said. “ You never give up. I believe my day will come if I just keep in there." 
She predicted that a s i x -under-par total would win the $7,5oo top prize but said she wasn't going to worn about her competition 
“ When you're playing golf, von really lack control over anybody else I can't worry about what Bertolaccini or 
Creed or Rankin do I ve just got to go out and play my own game” 
Miss Bertolaccini said she set's this event as a calming ground 
“ The reason I played well today and yesterday is that I didn t put any 

 pressure on myself,” slit1 said *“ In the first tournament, you just want to get the feeling. I really went out without feeling nervous today.” 
She lists her favorite athlete as fel­ low Argentinian Roberto de Yicenzo. 
He gained fame on the men s tour by losing tin' 1968 Masters when he failed to sign his score card. 
Miss Bertolaccini said the mistake eventually made her form er South 
American playing partner more mon­ ey. because of the publicity, than if be had signed and won. But she said she didn t want to tr\ it that way.

M AN ILA (A P ) - Bur­ ma's Mya Aye fired a three-underpar 69 Satur­ day and grabbed the third round lead of the 
$4o,o91) Philippine Mas­ ters In vitatio n al golf championship with a to­ tal of 2o9. 
The top 
Burm ese 
Roller, a veteran cam ­ paigner on the Asian cir­ cuit. had almost perfect putting for his 34-35 as he advanced from third place, where he started 
Saturday’s round behind the Philippines’ Ben A r­ du aud Taiw an's ( hen 
Chien-Chen. 
All alone in second place, one stroke back at 
21o, is American Gaylord 
Burrow s, who fired a 
35-35 two-under-par 7o on tin* 7.222-yard Niche golf course here. 
Ardu, who had a one over-par 73, slipped third with 211 
Bunched with him were Taiwan’s 
Hsu Seng-San and Amer­ icans Bal Underwood and 
Roger Simpkins. 
Hsu earned $1oo for turning in the day's best round with a 67. 
The tournament ends 
Sunday with the winner receiving $1o,ooo and a blue .jacket.

M EXIC O C ITY (A P ) - 
Wojtak Fibak of Poland, easily elim inated Ken 
Rosewall of Australia 7-6, 
6-3 Saturday and moved into the men’s singles finals of the $3o,ooo Mex-. ico C ity International 
Tennis Tournament. 
Fibak gained the first set by winning the tie­ breaker 7-5. 
Rosewall. displaying only occasional good form, had trouble with his service for the second consecutive day. He also had difficulty with some of the Pole’s volleys and serves. 
The World Champion­ ship Tennis event ends 
Sunday with a total of 
$1oo,ooo in prizes, $3o,ooo for the singles winner. 
$15.(MMI for the runner-up and $14,ooo for doubles. 
Fib ak, 24, also took advantage of the 
41-year-old Australian's obvious cliffitiily with the altitude. 
Rosewall was extended in the first set as the steady, powerful volleys of Fibak and some pre­ cise passing shots demo­ lished the Aussie’s play. 
In the second set, F i­ bak broke R o s e w a ll’s service four times and served three aces. Three double faults by Rosewall enabled Fibak to take command. 
The match took 9o minutes.

Gervin has made r it iii the N-B-A 

MILWAUKEE - It w a s ll iii the m orning but only nine in 
George Gervin's Portland hotel ro o m when tin' telephone rang. 
‘ Hey. lee. congratulations." tin* nailer said. "You m ade the all- star team ." 

‘ Hex. man. that's beautiful." m u r­ m ured h e . s ta rtin g Ins day on so­ mething of a high note. . "Playing u itll 
.ill tin' superstars of the N-B-A 
. hey. that’ll be great, Who else made it?" 

"Big Iv. Hudy T., Havlieek. Cowens. 
.lo .lo White and Monroe on tIk* E ast." replied the caller, "and Walton. Lan­ ier. dahlia?*. Lucas. Phil Smith. Barry and Billy Knight on the West " 

 lee em itted a long sigil, whistling so ftly at the company he was keeping now that he was in tin' "N-B-A ” 

By the way." inquired (le n in , what team am I oil?" 
Although it was early in the m orning, the question was indicative of Icem an's gam e and personality. Forget the frills, just give nu* the b a s­ ketball and let me work lee doesn't study shooting percentages, and he probably can't tell you who leads the league in assists By the sam e token, lie can't tell you how he cam e by those 
Svcnguli m oves lie d isp lay s on the court. 
Ciervin led a se co n d -h alt S p u rs ' com eback last season, securing the victory almost personally by rebound­ ing and sco rin g freely in the final quarter. His explanation "I moved to forward in the second half.” 
The next day iii practice ('ouch Bob 
Bass aahed him if he had indeed told a reporter that 
Ice confirm ed the re ­ port "You were playing guard.” Bass moaned "Don't you know when you’re play tug guard?” 
There are professionals in all lines of work who go through life gnawing at their fingernails like beavers, w orry­ ing about everything from their stock portfolios to their mortgages. The good natured G en in goes through life with a smile and a laugh Let the good times roll 
"The world is round." Gervin says ill response to many questions lie s hard his share of problems Ile left Eastern Michigan under duress. 
(hanged agents after an unprofitable experience, and carried the weight of a 

 concealed weapons charge around for over a year. Through it atl. his easy p ersonality has p ersis ted . The gun charge bothered him most 
"I could’ve,” says Ice slowly, "been playing ball it) Jackson Prison." 
But he is not. and it is fortunate not only for George and the Spurs, but for all the fans around the NBA When Ice is playing well. there are a few who are more entertaining to watch. 
He doesn't run so much as he glides. lbs willowy body can seemingly bend iii every direction, and this allows him to put up some of the most improbable shots. 

Ice developed his eloquent moves on 
Detroit's East Side at places like the 
Franklin Sullivan Recreation Center. 
It was in a competitive inner city a t­ mosphere like this Hie Iceman learned how to rock and roll on the basketball floor. 
"There were always UMI guys waiting to play over there." recalls Gervin "If

Spurs’ spouses find friends, joy in a bowl 

 you d id n 't win, you m ight not get picked to play the rest of the day. The winners kept the court 
"T h a t’s where I learned my game. 
It’s a finesse game, and that’s the way you have to hang on . . . to keep the court. 
It’s a scene that is repeated every day iii this country Iii tlit' cold weather city gyms of Detroit. Washington and 
Philadelphia kids imitate tile stars s o they can keep on play mg. 
Out of this kind of survival of the fittest atmosphere some of the greatest stars have been produced Wilt Cham­ berlain. Dave Bing. Phil Chenier . . . and now George Gerv in 
This afternoon George G ervin b e ­ come'' the first San Antonio Spur to play in an NBA All-Star gam e. The gam e itself is a conglom eration of great one-on-one players They play, for the most part. shoot when you see the whites of the backboard — at least for one afternoon. It is tin* honor of being a part of it all that is most im­ portant 
(ieorge Gervin. all-star. 
" I t ’s hard to put in words what it m e a n s to make the team ." s a y s lei' 
That’s okay. George. just play. That ability speaks for itself. 

They do not have the form of a P aula Sperber. And they are not to the point of threatening the high standing of Judy Soutar. 
But, Jane Moo and Marty D um pier give it "the old college try" 
(*ach Monday m orning in their Oak Hills bowling league. 

The twosome, wives of Spurs’ Dong 
Moo and Louie Dumpier, play for se­ parate teams at Oak Hills. Jane is with a team sponsored by the Spurs, while 
Marty plays with a Country Corner group. 
Gale Calvin, wife of Mack, was also iii the Monday group. However, with 
Mack s release and pending move to 
Denver, sin' will no longer be involved. 
Grabbing a cup of coffee and reach­ ing for the nearest chair. Jane looked pleased, reviewing her results. 
Good day 
"I had a good dav for m e ." she laughed. "I had a ISI. 162 and 152. My average is going up here." 
The amiable dark-haired gal really got into bowling when she was attend­ ing Meredith, a small, Baptist school iii North Carolina. 
"I took bowling as a physical educa­ tion c o u rse ," she reported. "T h en . when Dong and I started dating, we would go out bowling quite a bit. 
"And I was involved in a league a r­ rangement for the past few years iii 
Denver (where Moo was coach before laking the head job with till' Spurs).’’ 
With her involvem ent in D enver, 
Jane said she immediately looked a r­ ound for a bowling league when she moved to San Antonio. 
Sponsor 
"I just signed up for a league at Oak 
Hills," she said. "Then, after we got a team together. I asked John (Begzos. 
Spurs* general m anager) to sponsor the team 
"It costs them a few dollars, but it is great publicity 
We got sh irts and everything.’’ 
Jane said the biggest reason she en­ joys the Monday league is the co m ­ panionship of the other wom en in ­ volved. 
No pressure to win 
"There is no pressure to win." Jane said “ Everyone is out to have a good time. The gals I have met are really nice. And. von know, there are really quite a few super bowlers here. 
Jane said she talked both Marty and 
Gale into joining She regrets that they could not be on the sam e team. 
Jane, who has been over 2oo (2o1) once this year, goes to bowl at least one afternoon a week, taking sons. Dong 
Jr., or David. 
"D o u g J r . is so good he s h a m e s m e." she joked. "And big Doug, he really doesn t bowl often. His knee bothers him too much I also beat him once, so I think he uses thilt knee as an excuse." 
Marty was struggling before she be­ gan her games. 

A t h o m e w i t h 

 t h e S p u r s 

B y Kevin O 'K e e ffe - 

M ARTY DAMPIER 

"I lost my earring,” the diminutive 
(5*2) lady said, trying desperately to grab the earring from her shirt collar.. 
NBA HI 
TIPOFF L f 

JANE MOE 

 lf I don’t have it on, I don't bowl." 
She got the earring on. And despite a 
Hitter ball during the picture-taking. 

 she was pleased with her day. 
“ I have gotten my av erag e up to 
IID." she said. bringing out her little book, which contains that vital infor­ mation. “ I started out this year at 112, but slipped to 111. “ So, now I am up to 
119 and that is good for m e.” 
Marty admitted the she does not eat,; sleep and drink bowling. She said she still prefers outdoor sports. 
“ I am d e fin ite ly not a do-or-did bowler,” she said. “ I really juat bowl once a week with my team. But I would much rather do things outside. 
"Like Jane. I enjoy the league be­ cause of the people. The ladies on my team are really great. They are a crazy bunch.” 
Substitute 
M arty, who bowled in a league iii 
Louisville when Louie was with the 
Colonels, started as a substitute this year. 
" J a n e said they w ere looking for someone to fill in," she recalled. "So. I bowled a few tim es before I joined permanently. Now. I look forward to it. 
We usually eat lunch together after­ w ards.” 
M arty s ta r t e d bow ling in high school. She and Louie bowled in a d o u b les le ag u e in L ex in g to n and 
Louisville. They also bow led while they were dating. 
However, neither she nor Louie bowl much now. 
Best score 
"And we will never bowl during the sum m er months," she said "Then, we are always doing things outdoors." 
M arty quickly said her best score has been more than 16o. “ And I hit that three different tim es,” she added. 
But she was a little hesitant about giv ing her lowest pin total. 
“ Here, in San Antonio," she replied. 
"Well, 98. But. I used to get in the 7os back in high school." 

Nose fine, 
Davis says 

TEM PE, Ariz. (AP) — University of 
New Mexico President Bud Dav is said 
Saturday his nose is intact following a 
Friday night scuffle after his school s basketball victory over Arizona State 
Early reports said Davis might have suffered a broken nose but he said he w asn’t seriously injured after the game, won 91-84 by New Mexico iii overtime. 
Arizona State University police said 
Saturday the investigation into the incident, which resulted in Davis being punched by a spectator, is continuing.

L .A .’s \\ ash H ilto n undergoes surgery 

LOS ANGELES (AB) — Forw ard 
Kermit Washington of the Los Angeles 
Lakers, injured in Friday night’s gam e against Denver, underwent successful surgery Saturday to repair a ruptured tendon in his right knee, a spokesman for the NBA club said. 
Dr. Stephen Lombardo, the Laker team physician who perform ed the operation, said the surgery took one hour and was a "complete success”

ROMERO ANAYA 

Ayala tickets on sale 

Son Antonio EXPRES5-NEW5— Sunday February I 3 1977 

Tickets for the Mike Ayala-Romero 
Anaya super “ bantamweight fight go on sale Monday. 
San Antonian Ayala w ill defend hie 
North American Boxing Federation super bantamweight crown against 
Mexican Anaya Feb. 21 in the M unici­ pal Auditorium. 
A four-bout card lined up by pro­ moter Tony Padilla begins at 8:3o p.m. 
Ducats are available at The Audi­ torium. in the lobby of the Gunter 

Hotel from 9:3o a.rn to 8 p m . and at the Atlas Bar. IOO N. Medina. 
The ticket scale is $5-7-8. 
Ayala, who sports a 13-o professional record, won his title with a seventh- round TKC) over Cesar Deciga of Mex­ ico. 
Anaya is ranked as the No. 5 super bantamweight by the NABF. 
Anaya, who has been fighting pro- feionallysince 1oH8. has won bantam­ weight titles once defended them twice 

 and lost twice. 
His overall record through 197o was 
42-9-1 
Padilla had hoped to line up Cana­ dian A rt Hafey for Feb. 21 but ar­ rangements could not be confirmed. 

Padilla said Hafey. tin' No. I con­ tender for Ayala’s crown, w ill fight the winner of the Ayala-Anaya fight 
The Canadian bantamweight owns a 
49-7-4 record through 1975, according 

 to King Record Book That mark in­ cludes 3o knockouts and ll straight in 
1973 
Padilla said the rem aining three bouts on his card would feature San 
Antonians G ilb e rt Galvan. Robert 
Casque/ and Roy Hernandez. 

Galvan and Casque/ are lightweights and Hernandez a bantamweight 
Their respective opponents are ex­ pected to bt' announced later this week.

CHILDREN UNDER 6 EAT 
FREI W ITH M O M OR DAD 

Tessm an’s visit could end hassles 

Happy days may be here again — hopefully. 
Roger Tessman, chief of the American Bowling Congress’ Rules 
Department, will be here Sunday and Monday. 
Tessman will talk to the San Antonio Bowling Association’s Board of Directors Sunday at Sports Palace, and meet with local proprietors, managers! mechanics and other concerned lane personnel Monday at Wonder Bowl. Both meetings start at 9 a.m. 

“ Mr. Tessman’s primary purpose on lins trip is to show how lanes should be dressed and, also, to demonstrate some illegal lane dressings,” said Red 
Holland, the S.\B/\ secretary. “ There’s a lot of people in town that really don't know how to dress lanes according to 
ABC rules. He will also show us some inspection procedures. 
“ Hopefully, we will have the same lane conditions in each house after his visit, The primary complaint of most of the bow let's is tilt1 inconsistent lane condition in houses around the city. 
Sometimes the lanes are spotty, others are overly oiled, and others are not dressed properly. z\ll the bowlers want is the same lane condition iii each house. Maybe Mr. Tessman s visit will remedy the situation.” 
Members of the San .Antonio Bow ling 
Proprietors Association and non­ members, including proprietors of bowling establishments on the military bases, have been invited to attend 
Monday's meeting. 
“ We're hoping that Mr. Tessman will straighten things out,” said Joe 
Carmack, proprietor of Wonder Bowl, who, along with others, has been un­ happy with some of Mr. Holland's de­ cisions and the rejection of scores bv 
ABC; 
“ There's no way oil can be evenly distributed after 411 or 5(1 games have been bowled on the lanes. The whole purpose of ABC’s Rule 4 on dressing is gutter to gutter oil....it’ll start out that way but it won’t end up the same after bowling so many games. 
“ Mr. Holland is mistaken in the way he is doing his job, He is new on the job and lacks experience, I feel. 

“ There was an interesting quote in the Strikes 'n Spares column last week about a bow ler possibly suing a house for a rejected score,” Carmack con­ tinued. “ If the bowler is going to sue anybody, it should be ABC for denying the award — not the house. If (Keith* 
Hershey’s 3oo isn t eventually sanc­ tioned. I might want to sue .ABC my­ self. I hope we can get everything worked out so we can go in harmony for the good of bowling.” 
Around the lanes 
Joe Vito Bucnrostro and Freda 
Cockrell of Harker Heights will repre­ sent Texas in the Western sectional of 
Bowling Spectacular ‘77 in Denver. 
Colo,, Feb. 26*27; Bucnrostro and Mrs. 
Cockrell won the right to represent 
Texas by winning scratch all events titles in the ABC and WIBC state asso­ ciation tournaments last year. The top eight scorers in both men's and wo­ men's competition will qualify for tin* finals to be held at Wonder Bowl in 
May. 
Frau Trenkelbach won the women's all event crown with a I.HIH total and 
James Rochester captured the men s title w itll a 1.733 total during the Senior 
Citizens Tournament at San Pedro last weekend
