Bruce Daudelin aud Rick Clarkson will represent District 15 and Frank 
Maldonado of New Braunfels will be one of the two District 16 representa­ tives in the Texas ( lassie Bowling A v soeiation's men s all-star champion­ ship tournament Saturday and Sunday at Expressway Lanes in Dallas. Dau­ delin had his district's top average with a 191. while Clarkson finished with a ISO Both represented District 15 last veal'

Snake sub stars 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS NEWS 
LO N G V IEW 
- 
Brian 
Schroeder, subbing for Mike 
Cunningham who missed the game with the flu, pumped in 17 points in a starting role Satur­ day night to lead the 
St. M ary’s Rattlers to an easy 71-4o romp over Le Tourneau. 

The victory was the ninth in a row for the 
Rattlers, who ran their record to 19-5 on the season. 

Schroeder hit six of eight field goal tries and 
[laced a balanced attack, where two other reserves were the only Rattlers in double figures. Youral 
Means had ll and James 
Gray. 

The Rattler regulars played sparingly. Bobby. 
Reid and Roy Leggett had only four points each. 

St. Mary's built a 34-15 halftime lead and was never threatened. The 
Rattlers hit 3o of 58 field goal tries. Le Tourneau converted 15 of 43. 

The 
Rattlers held high-scoring 
Bonnie 
White to just 12 points, thanks to the defensive work of Leon Walls and 
Darrell Brogden. 

St. Mary's will play 
East Texas Baptist at 
7 3o p.m. 
Monday in 
Marshall in a key Big 
State Conference game.

HOUSTON (A P) - Otis Bird­ song pumped in 41 points Satur­ day night to lead Houston to an easy 114-74 Southwest Confer­ ence Basketball victory over 
Texas Christian. 

Birdsong’s 41 points in 33 minutes of playing time gave him 751 points for the year, a conference record, break­ ing the old mark of 737 scored by Gene 
Phillips of Southern Methodist in 1971. 
Houston led all the way as the 
Cougars hiked their season mark to 
2o-6 and their conference record to 
1o-3. 
, 
Daryl Braden led TCC with 22 points as the Horned Frogs remained winless in conference play with a o-14 mark. 

They are 3-19 for the season. 
The Cougars, who now have scored 
IOO or more points in 13 games this* season, led 24-5 early in the contest and took a 59-3o halftime edge. 
Charles Thompson’s two free throws with 12:23 left in the game gave Hous­ ton a 4o-point margin, 85-45, and the 
Cougars maintained a 4o-point or bet­ ter lead the rest of the game.Thomp-’ son had 2o points for Houston while 
Cornelius McFadgon added 12 for 
TCL1.

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS NEWS 
SALISBURY, Md. - 
Sandy 
Stap, 
Carrie 
Fleming, and Erick Is- kersky will be par­ ticipating in the ISTA 
National Amateur Indoor tennis tournament, start­ ing Sunday. 

Tile amateur indoor. which ends next Sunday, features most of the top women players in the nation, including Bar­ bara Hallqutst of South­ ern California; Barbara 
Jordan of Stanford, and 
Sherrv Acker of Florida.

T R O scores 

SAN JU A N , P R. (A P ) - 
Esteban De .Jesus of Puerto Rico retained his World Boxing 
Council lightweight champion­ ship crown Saturday by stopping 
Buzzaw Yamabe in the sixth round. 
The end came at 2:o6 of the sixth round when referee Tony Perez signaled the end after the Japanese challenger went down for the second time.

EXT. 4o 

A vicious right cross to the chin sent 
Yamabe to the canvas early in the round for the count of eight. Seconds later. De Jesus connected with another right cross to the chin and Yatnabe went down once more. 

The referee started a second count­ down. but when he noticed the chal­ lenger’s poor condition he declared De 
Jesus the winner by technical knockout. 
The Puerto Rican champion domin­ ated the match from Regluing to end. 
Trinity gains finals 

SPECIAL TO THI EXPRESS NEWS 
MADISON. VV ls. 
- 
Trinity advanced the fin­ als in the men’s Intercol­ legiate Team Tennis tournament Saturday at the 
University of 
Wisconsin. 
The Tigers, sparked by 
Erick Iskersky, Ben 
McKown. and Dave Ben­ son, downed Stanford, 
6-3, in the semifinals. 
Trinity will play in the finals at I p m. Sunday.

Dibbs in 

MIAMI 
(A P) 
- 
Second-seeded 
Eddie 
Dibbs of Miami rallied from a 4-o deficit in the first set to edge third- seeded Harold Solomon of Fort lauderdale, Fla., 
7*5. 6-2 Saturday in semifinal* adion in the 
15o.out) Miami Grand 
Prix Tennis Classic. 

Bv JOHN HINES 
O f the EXPRESS news STAFF 

The Ja y girls did not sit out this dance and as a result brought the school its first district basketball cham­ pionship with a 49-2o romp over Edgewood 
Saturday night at 
Taylor Gym. 

Jay completely domin­ ated the 
District 
3o-AA AA playoff, scoring the game’s first eight points and leading com­ fortably at the end of each quarter. 14-4. 21-6, and 35-16. 
The main reason was because the Mustangs forced the action instead of sitting back and watching 
Edgewood, whose stall game ended a 
16-game Jay winning streak, 15-14. just nine days previously. 
“ We were ready for it this time,” said Jay 
Coach Deanna Richard­ son. “ We were prepared with a special defense which we never had to use,” because Edgewood came out playing and never had the opportun­ ity to use the control game with a lead because it was always trailing, mostly by a big margin 
Now 27-2, Jay meets the Judson Rockets in the bidistrict round at 7:3o p.m. Monday at Blossom 
Athletic Center. Jay will be home team. Prices are 
75 cents and $1.5o. 
Title 
The district title is the second in Richardson’s career, for she guided 
Comfort to the District 
29-A crown in 1973. 
She said the Mustangs’ defense deserved the credit for the most part. 
"We forced bad passes, double-teamed them and closed up the key so it was not possible for them to drive in.” 
Asked if it surprised her that Edgewood did not stall this time, she replied. “ No, because there’s no way you can stall all the way to the state championship. 
“ Their stall last time was devastating. They never came anywhere near the basket and it was obvious. 
Hoggish 
“ We just kept the ball the majority of the time. 
“ The thing that proba­ bly decided the outcome, though, was the positive attitude my team had about their ability to play. 
Forwards 
Eleanor 
Bilotta, Veronica Aguilar and Angela Carrington 
(all seniors now ) and the all-junior guard starting trio of Yvette Douglas, 
Beverly Brock and Cas­ sandra Rice have all been playing three years and have steadily improved, posting a 2o-7 record a year ago. 
“ Jay is a well-disci­ plined ballclub," admit­ ted Mrs. Carolyn Taylor of Edgewood. 
“ We thought we could beat them playing straight-up. My girls are young (no seniors on the team) and have come a long way. They have done real well. Look for us next year." 
Third 
The win was Ja y ’s third over Edgewood in four games, the first two coming by margins of 38 and 37 points. The Mus­ tangs came lo play again for this one, led by the hustling Bilotta with 2o points. 

JA Y (4*1 —

 special to the e x c e s s n e w s 
D A LLA S — D ar­ rell W illiam s en­ joyed his best col­ legiate effort as 
Trinity rallied to beat Dallas Baptist, 
81-78. Saturday night at Dallas Baptist. 
The former Highlands star scored 24 points, 2o in the second half, and scored tin' game’s last four points as Trinity won its fifth game in 2o outings. 
Trailing 78-77, Danny 

Murphy stole a pass and passed ti* Williams, who scored on an eight-footer with IS seconds left to give the Tigers a 79-78 lead. 
Williams later dropped in two free throws with one second remaining for insurance measures. 
Danny Ivey scored 21 points and .Jeff Spillane had IO fur the Tigers, who trailed 
41-34 at halftime. 
Chris Byler had 17 points, Carlos Blackwood and Clayton Coliz each had 13. and Dwight High 

 tallied 12 for Dallas Bap­ tist, which dropped to 
7-25 on the season. 

The Tigers jumped on to an 11-4 lead with 13:37 remaining in the first half. Dallas Baptist, however, outscored Trin­ ity, 9-2, to tie the score at 
13-13 with 1o:32 showing. 
Dallas Baptist broke a 
24-24 tie and raced to its biggest lead at 41-32 with seconds remaining in the first half.

LAREDO — Laredo 
Junior College collected their first conference victory as they slipped past St. Philip’s 65-83 
Saturday night. 
St. Philip’s owned the lead with 2o seconds remaining in the game, but an untimely turnover gave Laredo the break it needed St. Philip’s is now 8-14 for the year while Laredo is $-22.

Sunday February 13 1 9 7 7 
A, s ^ 
'k 

Many gators no longer endangered 

 threatened category iii all of Florida and the coastal portions of Georgia, 
Louisiana. South Carolina and Texas, 
About 75 per cent of the U.S. alliga- tnr population inhabits these areas. 
The gator remains classed as endan­ gered in all of Mississippi. Alabama. 
Oklahoma and North Carolina, us well a> inland areas of South Carolina, 
Georgia. Louisiana and Texas. 
An earlier action in 1975 had re­ moved alligator populations in V erm i­ lion. Cameron and Calcasieu Parishes, 
Louisiana, from the endangered list. 
The new rule will allow state ann federal wildlife agency employees to capture and remove nuisance alliga­ tors. It also permits employees to kill nuisance animals if there is no place near to relocate them. 
Twenty years ago the alligator was headed toward extinction. Improved management programs have brought it back. 

SPtCIAl IO Tnt IXPKfSS NTW& 

WASHINGTON — Most of the na­ tions alligator populations have been removed from the C S. endangered species list. according to the Wildlife 
Management Institute. 
The alligator was removed from the endangered category and placed iii the 

 and w ere given the run of the '/.err household. It didn t take them long to shred the living room furniture with their claws, and visitors to the '/err home often were som ew hat startled whenever a half-grown bobcat leaped upon their shoulders and began p u r­ ring like a Garwood motorboat. 
Picky 
T he k itte n s w ere finicky e a te rs . 
They wanted their rabbits skinned and chilled and th e ir doves picked and w ashed. 
The cats were not confined. They had the run of the country, and it w asn’t long before they prowled most of the night, often not retu rn in g until just before dawn. 
The female. Tiger, disappeared dur­ ing the w in te r of 1974. T h e m a le. 
Shorty, stayed longer. Ile disappeared around the m iddle of Novem ber the same year. 

 bobcat is the only spotted fur that le­ gally can be taken, sold or brought into the United States . 
Most of the furs taken iii this country apparently are being shipped to the 
Orient and Europe, especially Europe. where they are used to trim clothing. 
Fur out 
“ I heard the other da> that some of it is being used on Women s panties and bras.” Boone said. “ But I don’t know how true that is.” 
T h a t’s g e ttin g p retty fur out (or under), even for the fashion world. 
It is easy to see why someone might become concerned with the future of the bo b cat. One doesn t .inst w alk through the woods and sec one any day of the week. 
The cat is wary and secretive. Most people have never seen a wild one alive. Most people who do see one get only a fleeting glimpse. Unless you do a let of looking, even tracks aren ’t easy to locate. 
Photo 
A few years ago I had an opportunity to photograph a couple of young bob­ cats as they grew up iii a sem idom es­ ticated state. 
Tony / e r r of H ondo w atc h ed a female heavy with young going to and from an isolated hay barn in southern 
Medina County, and he guessed cor­ rectly she would have her kittens in it 
When she did, he took two, a male and a female and raised them 
The kitten!? were liorn in May of 1973.

SPtCIAl TO THI UPRtSS Ntws 

INGRAM — Parks and Wild­ life Department biologists at the 
Heart of the Hills Research Sta­ tion are beginning work on a hybrid bass which is a combin­ ation of Florida largemouth and 
Tennessee smallmouth. 
First work with the hybrid was done iii Illinois. The cross was aggressive to the point of being v tennis. 
Biologist John Prentice at Heart of the Hills said work will begin in March to obtain some fish from largemouth and smallmouth parents. 
"W e need to answ er several ques­ tions about such a hybrid,** said Pren­ tice. “ Is the fish self-producing? At this point. I doubt it. wh u h means it would have to bt* produced in labora­ tories, 
“ Are future generations of the liy- brid self-producing? What are growth rates? Does its aggressiveness make it susceptible to overharvest? And do fu­ ture generations of the hybrid revert to characterist ii s »*f either parent? 
Careful 
Ponds at the San Marcos Fish Hat­ chery have been sot aside for pairing of the Florida and Tennessee parent fish' to sot* if the fish will mate without the time and expense of crossing the two strains in laboratories. 
It and when offspring arc obtained, 
Prentice has two private ixmds iii Kerr 
County under contract to the Parks and 
Wildlife Department iii which to stock the fish. 
"W e plan to be very careful in our approach to this hybrid, said P ren ­ tice. "not because the fish is so vicious but because it could genetically conta­ minate existing stocks of small mouths in state waters.

Shorty learned to do something only a very few dom estic cats have m a s ­ tered: Go to the bathroom in the com­ mode. Ile learned it all by himself; no one taught him. 
In fact, Nitu, Z crr’s wife, jumped on other m em bers of the family several times, accusing them of not flushing the john, before she discovered that 
Shorty was the culprit. 
The accom panying photo of Shbrty taking Ins morning toilet was snapped 
Itv /e r r s teenage daughter. Teresa.

SHOAL to TMI [ m i s s N tw s 
\l ST1N — Texas fish hatcheries will In* busy this spring, producing or procuring more than 24 million fish lo stock iii public and private waters. 
All totaled, some 21.7 million fish will In* stocked in public stream s. lakes and waterways around tile state. 
Another 2.5 million will be set aside for private waters. 
'Hus year's fish production season. set to begin in March, will include production of 1.5 million striped bass, 
59o,99o hybrid striped bass, four mil­ lion Florida bass. 794).(Mil) smallmouth bass, HJT.999 blue catfish , 228.999 channel catfish. 31,ooo flathead catfish, 
128.(MNI sunfish and 14 million walleye to be se c u re d from o u t-o f-sta te sources. 
All fish. with the exception of wal­ low*. will be fingerling si/e when stocked. The walleye will be stocked into Texas stream s and reservoirs as try . 
Fish for stocking private w aters include one million native largemouth bass. one million channel catfish and 
495.oo9 hybrid sunfish. 
Hatcheries slated to in* used to pro­ duce the fish include Sun Angelo numbers one and two, Dundee, Pos­ sum K ingdom . 
E ag le Mount a i n, 
U*wisville, Tyler, Jasper, Huntsville, 
San Marcos, Olmito and Fort Worth.

Wildcats shade 
Auburn 

LEX IN G T O N , 
Ky. 

AP) — .lack Givens 

 pumped in 24 points, most of them in the first half Saturday night, to send No. 3-ranked Ken- ucky to an 
89-82 
Southeastern Conference basketball victory over 
Auburn. 

Givens had 16 of his 

 points before intermis­ sion when the Wildcats built leads as large as 15 points, but it remained for Larry Johnson to hold off the stubborn Tigers after halftime. 
Johnson scored 16 of 

 his 18 points in the se­ row! period, two of his baskets putting Kentucky on top by 17 and his final two free throws coming with 27 seconds left. 
Mike Mitchell led Au­ burn with 21 points, while 
Myles Patrick added 18 and Eddie Johnson 16. 
Hick Robey had 16 for 

Kentucky and Mike Phil­ lips 13.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sunday February 13 1 9 7 7 
H 

Cage pairings 

Pairings have been set for the Class AAAA Region IV Boys' Basketball 

Tournament in San Antonio March 3. 
Pour surviving bidistrict winners earlier that week advance to the meet, which 

 will be ut Blossom Athletic Center unless a North East team advances. 
In the semifinals, the Districts 29-31) winner meets the 31-32 winner in an 

 all-San Antonio area battle, thus assuring the Alamo City of a team in the finals. 
That game tips off ut IO a.rn. 
At noon, it's the 25-26 (Victoria-Austin) winner vs. the 27-28 Corpus Christi-Rio 

Grande Valley) winner. 
The finals are set for 8 p.m. 
If a North East team is in regional, then it will play at IO a.m. ut Alamo 

,Stadium Gym and the other game will be at IO a m. at BAC. A North East team iii the finals would play at Alamo again.

CO LLEGE PARK. Md. (A P) — Freshman Jo Jo 

Hunter scored a career-high 24 points us Maryland upset 15th-ranked Clemson 84-78 Saturday, while converting si\ consecutive oneand-one q*ec throw situations in the closing minutes. 
The loss came in a regionally televised Atlantic 

( nst ( (inference game and ended a seven-game v inning streak for Clemson which had thrashed 

L\Iar\l od 93-71 at home last month. 
The Turps. now 16-6 including 5-4 in the ACC!, led 

 by as much as 14 points in the first half and then had 

12-point advantage trimmed to 7o-64 with 4:5o 

 remaining. 
Brad Davis made Maryland's only field goal while 

 playing ball control the rest of the way. and also added six points while converting half of his team's bonus foul shot chances. 
Grog ( oles scored 18 for Clemson, which is now 

18-4 w ith a 6-3 ACC mark. Colin Abraham scored 16 
Igjt Wayne “ Tree-’’ Rollins, who had 22 points and 23 rebounds last time, was held to IO.

ETBC stuns 
TLC 

SOCIAL TO THI EXPRESS NtWS 
M A RSH A LL - East 

Texas Baptist slipped past Texas Lutheran. 
66*65. Saturday afternoon to tighten the Big State 
Conference basketball race. 
The decision knocked 

TLC out of the unbeaten ranks and prevented the 
Bulldogs from earning a berth in the 
NAIA 

 playoffs. 
TLC is now 7-1 in 

 league play. St. Mary's is 
6-1 and East Texas Bap­ tist is 5-2. 
Two free throws by 

James Rogers with eight seconds left clinched the victory for ETBC, which led by ten at halftime, but also trailed by eight in the second half.

Tech prevails 

LU BBO C K (A P ) 
- 

Texas Tech's Doug House hurled a one-hitter in the first game of a season- opening doubleheader as the Red Raiders captured the first contest 8-3 and won the nightcap 12-3. 
Iii the second game. 

Tech's Ernie Helwig drove in three runs to help Skipper Mills, who went six innings, chalk up his first victory of the year, 
House allowed no 

 earned runs and struck out six batters as the 
Raiders committed nine errors in the opening 

 game.

The 
Southwest 
Texas State Bobcats sewed up a berth in the Lone Star Con* 
Terence’s postseason tournament 
Satur­ day night, by slash­ ing Sam Houston, 
69-59, in Huntsville. 

Texas A&l was backed 

 against the wall in its bid to earn a tourney berth for the first time when 
East Zone leader Stephen 
F . Austin ripped the 
Javelinas in 
Nacog­ doches, 91-74. 
A&l and Sam Houston 

 meet Monday night in 
Huntsville and the Javs jail clinch a playoff spot jy winning. 
A 
Sam 

Houston victory will eq­ ually wrap up the spot or the Bearkats, alth- 

_ough not mathematically, 

L o c k 

In the West Zone, 

 toward Payne just about 

• Tut a lock on the zone ti­ le by clipping Angelo 
State, 
84-74. while 

Vbilene Christian kept its layo ff hopes alive by ripping 
East 
Texas, 

)3-7». 
East Texas also has a 

 playoff virtually assured atole the winner of next 
Thursday's 
Abilene 

Christian at Angelo State 
.;amo is the likely third tourney team.

Steve Frontz paced 

SWT against Sam Hous­ ton by scoring 29 points jnd grabbing 
16 

 rebounds, despite play­ ing much of the second half with four fouls. 
Stephen F. /Austin’s 7*2 

Ken 
Beasley played 

 havoc with the Javclinu hopes by tossing iii 28 points, grabbing 
27 

 rebounds and blocking 17 shots. 
SWT held its biggest 

 lead of the night, 18 points, 4o-22, at halftime against the Bearkats. 
Sam Houston trimmed the lead to five with just over six minutes to go before Frontz iced it with six straight points.

O’Brien rewarded 

MILWAUKEE (AP) — Larry O’Brien is basketball’s latest millionaire. 

O'Brien, commissioner of the National Basketball 
Association, was voted a new seven-year, %'2 million contract Saturday by the league's Board of Gover­ nors. meeting in conjunction with Sunday’s All-Star 
Game. 
“ The scope of this new contract sets forth the high est m n and appreciation we have for the job Com­ missioner O'Brien has done in the past 11 ^ years.” said Board Chairman lrv Levin. “ We have torn up his current contract, which had I'., years remaining, and he has accepted a new seven-year contract for $2 million.” 
T u rn e r 
In another major action, the Board voted a clean lull of health to colorful led Turner, approving his purchase of a m ajority interest in the Atlanta 
Hawks. 
A revision of the league’s schedule also was dis­ cussed. hut th*' Board decided to take no immediate action. 
“ The existing schedule concept will prevail for next season,” a league spokesman said. This con­ cept. which has each team playing each other team, an equal number of times regardless of division or conference, had come under considerable criticism in this its first year. 
T rip s 

Its opponents say it creates more long-distance road trips, which are more costly, and that it pre­ vents the development of intra-divisional rivalries. ll also has been given as a reason why home teams are winning significantly more games this season than in recent years. 
The hoard discussed these matters but decided to table the issue for the present. 
O'Brien is credited with engineering the merger between tht‘ NBA and the American Basketball As­ sociation and was negotiating the landmark labor agreement signed last year between the league and the NBA Players Association. 
5 picked for Hall 

SPRINGFIELD. Mass. (AP) - Elgin 
Baylor, Coach Frank McGuire and three stars from another era Saturday were named to the National Basketball Hall of 
Fame. 

.Joining Baylor, elected in his first year of eligibi­ lity, and McGuire as new members of the Ball of 
Fame were Charles “ Tarzan” Cooper, Lauren 
“ Laddie” Gale and William C. “ Skinny" Johnson 
Lee Williams, the Hall s executive director, and 
Adolph Hupp, the Honors Committee chairman, announced that the five new electees will he ensh­ rined at ceremonies May 2 
Their election brings to Kilt the number of indivi­ duals named to the Naismith Basketball of Kame. 
Baylor, a H-Iim4-5 super star. considered one of the greatest forwards in basketball history, prepped in 
Washington. B.C.. and went on to All-American hon­ ors at Seattle in 1H58 
A first-round draft choice by the Minneapolis leakers, he earned All-Star recognition and rookie of the year honors in the National Basketball Associa­ tion in tile season. Ile was a first team All- 
Star the next HI years

Gervin to play in today’s game 

H San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Sunday February I 3 I 977 

GEORGE GERVIN 
. . . on East squad 

Continued from Page IS 

Van Lier (Chicago) in the West’s starting lineup. 
“ My career started in the 
Teaneck Armory when we played the .Jersey Am ericans,’’ said 
Brown, waxing fondly on his ABA roots, -so it’s really great to be here. 
“ Our players are really excited about this game. They've wailed nine years to get here and I know how they feel. I hope we can make the game a big success.” 
Sixers 
Similarly, East Coach Gene Shut* will have three of his Sixers in the starting lineup. Philadelphia for­ wards Julius Erving and George 
McGinnis w ill start along side teammate guard Dong Collins, 

Maravieh and Knick center Bob 
McAdoo. 
Dave Cowens. the NBA’s vanish­ ing red head. had to withdraw be­ cause of a hack injury. He was re­ placed by guard Phil Chenier of 
Washington, so McAdoo will be the 
East's only real pivot man. 
5 guards 
“ The East squad has had a great deal of success in the past.” said 
Shue. 
“ so 
I suppose tomorrow we ll try to win without a center, or at least with only one." 
Trouble is, McAdoo’s game is forward-oriented as he enjoys working around the perimeter. So 
Washington’s Elvin Hayes will spend considerable time at center although he made the team as a forward. 

 problem." noted Brown iii sarcastic response to the questioning of Is­ sei’* selection. “ I'd be crazy to say he is better than Jabhar, hut he is having a great year. 

Don't know 

“ I don't know if there is any right way to select ail all-star team. but our players were selected by the fans who got behind them.” 

While the West has three centers of attention, the East, admittedly, may he far short of sufficient re­ bounding prowess. 
-If we can rebound, we ll run." said Shue. “ Maybe we can pick up some cheap baskets.” 
But the talent is not cheap on 

 either side, so it should be a run­ ning. gunning classic. The East may lack board power, hut with the likes of Earl Monroe. Jo Jo White, 
George Gervin and John Max Meek in attendance, they have plenty of guile. 

Both coaches say they will play everyone in the first half, and then see who is the hottest. 

-This game serves as a show­ case.” said Brown, “ so everyone ought to get an oppotunity to play.” 

But with th*1 number of parties scheduled between Saturday after-’ noon and tipoff time Sunday, it is likely the players will get the least amount of playing time of anybody in attendance. 

-I’ve always wanted to play five guards, anyway,” mused Shue. 
“ ll’s always been a theory of mine and I guess tomorrow will he the perfect time to test it out." 

The most controversial starting pick was Issei, who gained the berth over such tower of powers as Har­ eem Abdul-Jabbar and Boh Lanier. 

Bill Walton, who would have been the fourth center on the West squad, had to withdraw with an inflammed achilles tendon. He was replaced by 
Pacer defensive genius Don Buse. 

“ I heard lots of talk about all our centers and how some of them shouldn’t he here,” said Brown. 
"One of our players is slow. white and fat. so he shouldn’t be any

Some items that can't be appraised 

Sun* i f s a beautiful doll; aud i f s been in the family for decades. But it may md qualify for appraisal during Witte Mu­ seum's Heirloom Discovery Days. 
Also excluded from appraisal are Ro­ man, ( J reek and Egyptian antiquities. stam ps, coins, weapons and jewelry . 
Add to that list American Indian art and artifacts, photographs, h ardw are, do­ cuments, vehicles and co m m e rcia l re­ productions of famous art.

G a ry W r ight: 

A dream rew oven? 
Blues:Hard mistress 

Mire, there are those who p ervert popular music to such cheap, shoddy purposes as en­ couraging young ladies iii T-shirts to do the Lust iii the Heart Hustle. 
But there are others who use their musical talents for far nobler aims. 
There is (Iary Wright. for instance, who uses pop music to spread un­ iversal tru th and e n ­ lightenment. 
Wright is a student of the yogi Paramahansa 
Yogananda. ll is the works of good ole Para­ mahansa that provide much of the basis for 
Wright’s ever so mean­ ingful new album, “The 
Light of 
S m iles" 
(Warner Bros.). 

HIK AGELESS wis­ dom of these guys often sounds deceptively sim­ ple. For instance, a short piece which 
Wright draws from Yogananda, 
“ I Am the Sky," consists of those four words plus 
“ Mother.” 
Country-western si>ng- writers aren't the only ones who try to work mother in when­ ever they can. 
Equally as pithy is the album's single, “ I’m Al­ right.” It is sort of the musical equivalent of all those "Pm OK, you're 
OK, the cat’s OK” books. 
Actually 
W right s close association with the . universe goes way back. 
As a child actor, 
Wright once played on 
“Captain Video,” tele­ vision’s pioneering effort to turn a studio into a space ship through the clever use of cardboard boxes. 

THE MI SIC world did not become aware of 
Wright until later, how­ ever, when he migrated to England and became a member of the British rock group 
Spooky 
Tooth. 
The band had a couple of good years before breaking up in 197o 
Wright s initial try at a solo career failed ami so did an effort to try to put the band back together again 

A year ago, Wright’s career look off again with "Dream Weaver.” 
The new album may decide whether he has made it all the way lo 
Nirvana or just to the 
Mike Douglas Show. 
With 
"L ight of 
Smiles," Wright again dares to produce an en­ tire rock allium without a single guitar 
The seemingly impos­ sible feat is accom ­ plished with a variety of electric synthesizers, pianos, organs and 

Playback 

By Joel McNally 

 whatever 
OII it else has kevs 

SOMETIMES it seems like a roller rink run amuck, but most of the tim e the echoing electronics add to the other worldly tone of the album. So do Wright’s ethereal vocals. 
There is one jarring rock ballad, 
"Silent 
F u ry ," that d o e s n t really fit 
But most of the other songs — “Child of Light," “Water Sign." 
"T im e 
M achine," 
"E m p ty In sid e " and 
“Who Am I" — are in­ teresting trips into inner space. 

OTHERS 
I learn about all of life’s bright and glowing truths, but Jams lan is still hung up on the dark ones. 
A correspondent re ­ cently noted that I ani a sucker for this kind o| thing. "Seduced by the scent of seriousness" was the lyrical phrase that he used. I confess it is so. 
I don’t feel nearly as bail about it, though, as 
Jams lait does about all the times she was se­ duced. Or the times that she wasn’t. 

MECH of Ms 
Lin s new album , "M iracle 
Row" (Columbia), con­ tinues her painful re ­ counting of all kinds of private little agonies. 
There are a few dif­ ferences. She has moved from the hells of the high school dance to those of elaborate affairs with 
“champagne and caviar, cocaine and Shalimar." 
At least she is getting dumped on at more ex­ pensive parties now. 
The familiar themes arc brief and desperate encounters CT Want To 
Make You Love Me") or empty hours of even less than that ( TTI Cry To­ night"). 
Sometimes the pity is for others as in “Sunset of Your Life," which is about human beings dis­ missed as ton old lo care 
And one of the album’s highlights, the title song 
“Miracle Row” flowing into " M a r ia ," draws sharp images of a Span­ ish ghetto. 

SOMETIMES she belts it. Sometimes she breathes it. Sometimes she just plays it on the piano creating haunting music box settings. 
W hatever, she communicates it. 
There is nothing wrong with the fact that Ms. lan has traveled the ter­ ritory before. 
One bit of silliness that has arisen out of jmpular music criticism is the suggestion that artists have to ride off iii some new direction every tune they record. 
Ms. Ian does what she dors wry well A lot of people empathize with lier morbid little ditties. 
I admit it. She got me again. 

There aren t many musicians like Puntay Guitar left Men Uke him have either become inter­ national stars, or just died after years of trying — proof the blues can be a hard mistress. 
But not Puntay. After more than 2o years of playing the blues, he sits at his club on South New' Braunfels Avenue contentedly drawing songs out of his guitar that cover the full span of black music. 

B B. King, who Puntay played with in the ‘5os, now m akes European tours and has become the darling of white college kids. A far cry from the black nightclubs which used to be his bread and butter. 

At the sam e tim e though, Freddie King, another bluesman who 
Puntay says was " th e best," recently died at age 42 without receiving the credit he was due.

And occasionally the local m usician fingers the chords to a song called "Boogie Chillen.” 
He was playing it 2(1 years ago, but recently a rock group nam ed /. Z 
Top came along, quadru­ pled the song’s volume and came up with a na­ tional hit. 

The irony of the situa­ tion isn ’t lost on tile 
52-year-old man. 

"Hey man, you know that group the Beagles 
(the Beatles)? All they did was s ta rt out by taking old blues songs people had forgotten about and suddenly ever­ ybody dug it," he ex­ plains. 

"All rock and roll is nothing but the blues made more technical by young white k id s,” he explains with a shrug, implying anybody with any sense knew that. 

"The blues have been real fickle man. Some people are millionaires off of it, while others died trying to make it or have just given up," he says. 

When Puntay speaks it s with the same inten­ sity he uses while playing 
Ins 2o-year-old electric guitar. And whether he’s talking or playing, Pun­ tay is out to tell the truth about his life and music. 

Pulling his guitar up so it leans against his ro­ tund belly, Puntay gives a lesson iii what the blues is all about. Almost tick­ ling his in stru m e n t’s strin g s, they respond with a stinging twang in the style of B. B. King. 

And then he goes on recreating note for note the songs of blues gui­ ta rists like John Lee 
Hooker, Muddy Waters and the legion of other m usicians who in­ fluenced m odern pop music. 

Despite his virtuoso guitar abilities, the na­ tive San Antonian swears he’s not a musician. Ac­ cording to Puntay’s de­ finition he’s just a soul guitar player because the blues isn ’t som ething 

 studied in a conserva­ tory. 

"When you’re a blues player, you don’t learn it 
You’ve got to have it when you sta rt and if you’re not born with it you’re up the creek,” he says with a glim mer in his eyes. 

Puntay started putting his talent to use to feed his family in 1958. “ I got my first guitar from a missionary woman who wanted me to play in church. 

“ Pretty soon though I was playin’ w uh these other guys who wanted me to play the blues in bars and since I got paid with them, that s where I had to go," he says. 

Before long he had gained such a reputation that East Siders quit calling him by his Chris­ tian nam e of Celester 
G onzales and dubbed him Puntay Guitar. 

By 1958 his name be­ came part of almost any poster advertising the 

 blues shows which traveled through the 
Southwest playing black night dubs and lounges. 

As his children grew old enough to hold a gui­ tar or saxophone, Puntay trained them, formed his own band and started making the grueling club circuit. 

His stories of those days take hours to tell and arc filled with images of musicians al­ most tired to stay awake through a job and Pun­ tay’s m other traveling with the hand wrapped in quilts with a pile of gui­ tars on her lap. 

Recently, Puntay and his five sons have settled down to manage and play at the Disco Party House on 322 S. New Braunfels 
Ave. 

They can he found there throughout the week picking into the night keeping an impor­ tant part of A m erican music alive in San An­ tonio.

Classical record review 
Tschaikowsky for 

 your collection 

Bv DAVID ANTHONY RICHELIEU 

RGA is repackaging and remarketing some of its best recordings and one of them is an outstanding entry. 
It is one of those special offerings designed for people who really haven’t lilied out their classical collections and want to make a purchase of a major addition without worrying about the quality of the pressing, recording or performance. 
This first-class package is dubbed “ The Three 
Great Symphonies’’ and features the 4th. 5th and 
6th symphonies of Tschaikowsky as performed by the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Or- mandy (URIA-1838). 
Ormandy has always had the best versions of the 
6th ever recorded. He is the only one who captures all the fervor and passion of this masterpiece without racing through the third movement. 
He first outclassed the competition with a spec­ tacular recording for Columbia and this latest repackaged ECA sounds defiantly similar to that earlier Columbia release — indicating RCA either got the earlier Columbia masters or Ormandy’s performances are solidly consistent. 
In any event, it is an outstanding version of this very popular symphony. 
Equally noteworthy performances art* turned in' for the fourth and fifth symphonies. There are newer versions out by Bernstein on Columbia of the fourth and by Solti of the fifth. 
But these Ormandy performances hold their own against the splashier Bernstein and more serious 
Solti versions. 
All in all, “ The Three Great Symphonies” is a worthwhile offering which offers first-rate record­ ings, pressings and performances. This should be more successful than some of their other repack­ aging efforts simply because of Ormandy and the 
Philadelphia and the three favorite Tschaikowsky symphonies selected 
But the best part of all is that the three-record set is offered at a s|>ecial price as well — the whole collection for the price of a two-record album That all adds up to an attractive and irresistible com­ bination for the collector with a growing classical record collection. Its a first-class steal.

Finding Your Roots 

Even before the television best-seller and the television show 
‘ Roots,’ you may have wondered who you came from. lf you’ve wanted to find your roots, but don't know how to go about it, check into a new book, 
“ Tracing 
Your 
A n cestry: 
A 
Step-by-Step G uide to 
Researching Your 
Family H istory." 
W ritten by F. W ilbur Helmbold, director of the Institue of G en ealog y and Historical 
Research, the book details the sources you can use to uncover your fam ily history 
— letters, censuses, wills, land records, church, cemetery and military records. 
To accom pany the book Helmbold has also compiled "Tracing Your Ancestry Log­ b ook," a 256-page personal record book of forms on which a researcher can chart his findings and document progress. 

“ Tracing Your Ancestry” /By F. W il­ bur 
H elm b o ld / $ 9 .9 5 / ’ ’ Tracing 
Your Ancestry Logbook*' / * $ 3 .9 5 
/ Oxm oor House Publishers. 

Savings 

Even though we may have hoped so a few years ago, saving energy is not a fad. Ifs a necessity. 
But how to do it is something else again. A group called 
Am biente Environm ental 
Concerns, made up of San Antonio educators, has come up with a practical guide to saving energy. 
The 28-page guide is full of simple tips for saving energy. For example, don't use hot water for routine cleaning that doesn t call specifically for hot water. Clean light bulbs and paint with light colors for more light. Use a dishwasher only once a day. 
Other topics include space heating and cooling, water heating, bathing, clothes washing, clothes drying, cooking, refrigerating, and driving. Plus there s a list of the w attage consumed by common household appliances to let you know where your m oney’s going. 

“ Slash Energy Bills” /Am biente/P. O. Boe 13622, San 
Antonio Texas 7821 3 / $ 1 .5 o . 

Relating to Humans 

H ow to get along with others has becom e something of a science. 

Exactly how to use the science will be the topic of a 3o-hour course to be offered by San Antonio 
College Continuing Education. 

“Concepts of Human Relations’ will be taught by D avid W ilkinsonn, marketing service m anager for 
Sw earingen 
Aviation 
Corp, who holds a m aster’s degree in human relations from the Uni­ versity of O klahom a. 

The course will use a laboratory method of instruction so that participants will do what the course preaches through skill exercises, simulation games and group discussions.

Feb l l . 12, and 13 

KATHY HODGES 
163 A ppleton 
JOHN JA Y HIGH SCHOOL 
Kathy Hodges has distinguished herself as a leader at John Jay High 
School in the drama department, extra-curricular activities and scholastics. 

Having starred in such plays as Alice in W onderland. Little Women and 
Antigone, drama is Kathy’s first love. She has received a certificate of award in speech and a certificate of excellence in oral interpretation at a summer workshop at Stephen F. Austin State University. 
In tournament competition, she earned a first place in one-act plays at' district and area University Interscholastic League tourneys and has been named to the all-star cast in both district and regional contests. She has been named outstanding Jay speech student. Kathy’s talents even expand to directing, as *he assisted in a presentation of “The Wizard of Oz.” 
She participates in the Lackland and Fort Sam Houston little theaters. 
Kathy also served as president of Jay’s International Thespian Society and corresponding secretary of the state organization. 
In addition, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles U. Hodges was elected president of her senior class. She is a member of the National Honor 
Society, Spanish Club and Mu Alpha Theta. 

Chaplain of her Christian Youth Organization, Kathy also enjoys swim­ ming and skating. She plans to major in drama and minor in Knglish at either Baylor, Trinity or Stephen F. Austin. She will soon be honored by the Optimist Club for her achievements.

CB e ts a re tu rn in g to h a m se ts 

CB Convac 

(H ers by the thou­ sands are leaving citi­ zens band for the more complicated and, to some extent, more rewarding amateur radio system. 
They've been turned off by the rudeness of many fellow ( Bors, bla­ tant disrespect for the law and the sometimes disappointing range of 
CB transceivers. 
“ There are probably 
25.ooo people taking amateur (radio) courses now, compared with 
3,(MHI to 4,(MIO taking them in 1974,” says Charles 
Harris, club and training manager for the Ameri­ can Radio Relay League, a nationwide club repre­ senting 132.ooo am a­ teurs. or hams as they're usually called. 
“ About 9o per cent of these new hams are coining out of CB.” he estimates. 
Consider Je rr y and 

By INK DIPPER 

Editor o f The CH Titnes-Joiirnal 

Lillie Murchison, who bought CB equipment four years ago, well be­ fore the explosion of in­ terest in CB that has increased in CB that has increased 1o-fold the number of people on the band. 
“ Jerry could call me and say he was 
3o minutes from home, and 
I could start dinner,” says Mrs. Murchison. 
But since that time , 
CB has become congest­ ed. Many operators use overpowered equipment, obscene language and bad manners. 
The Murchisons sold their 
CB equipment 
(which cost about $35o) and bought amateur gear for nearly twice as much. 
Now they can communi­ 

 cate vvilh “ friendly, po­ lite. vv ii I ing-to - help* * hams who may be on the other side of town or the other side of the world. 
But switching to ham isn’t as easy as just spending some money. 
Hams have to I m * able to send and receive the In­ ternational Morse (’ode at speeds that vary with the four classes of li­ censes. And they also have to know radio theory and techniques which grow more com­ plicated with each license step. 
Of course each license step also allows hams more freedom. While 
(’Hers are limited to four watts of transmitting power, many hams are able to use up to l.IMMi 

 watts. 
They communicate with faraway hams in technically exotic ways 
— bounding their signals off satellites or the moon in some instances. And while, like CBers, they help other people, hams assist iii emergencies 
■ which occur thousands of miles away. They relay messages, tie in distant hams with telephone communications and pick up distress calls from aircraft, ships at sea and scientific expe­ ditions. 

People who’vc been in ham radio for years are feeling the CB-relatcd growth. Old-time hams complain about the crowding of their pre­ viously wide open air­ waves. There is also hostility among hams towards CBers. They re­ sent the CBers because obtaining a license is no more complicated than filling out a form and mailing it to the right address. 

But hams have begun to w e b time ( Hers. 
“ We're all for it," says 
H arris of the A RRI.. 
“ CBers are like convert­ ed alcoholics. They know how bad it G on the other side. 

“ They bend over to do as good job as hams. They come in with less know­ ledge but more enthu­ siasm, and they turn into excellent hams." 
And many hams also become CBers. They see advantages in having a 
CB unit on the highway and being able to reach someone locally without searching the fre­ quencies for contact. 
But don’t count on these hams admitting 
' that they also have CB rigs, especially while talking to other hams. 
Harris, for instance, is a ('Ber. “ A tremendous number of hams are 
CBers” he says, “ but a lot of us are a little re­ luctant to admit it until we find out the other guy is too."

I think it’s a good idea

They camp on bar­ bered lawns. In tents that look like colored supply parachutes. Their clothes are by Cardin, their sandals by Gucci. 
They're beautiful, by heaven!

Europe.” $4 95 from Ha­ lo Publications, Inc.,

 downtown, a new jewel in the crown of the City of 
Los Angeles. 
T h is new downtown has taken shape after years of careful planning by the city and county. 
The stellar beginning of this Renaissance was the M u sic C en ter. 
A com p lex of three theatres, the center has done much to bring a new sense of “ theatre” to the g r e a te r 
Los 
Angeles area. 
Such prestigious resi­ dent companies as the 
Los A n g eles P h i lh a r ­ monic Orchestra. Center 
Theatre Group and the 
Civic Light 
Opera Com­ pany provide en tertain ­ ment year ’round at rea­ sonable prices. 
Down the road from the Music Center, just 

 between the new “ m-ci- ty * * a p a rtm e n ts of 
Bunker Hill, is the World 
Trade Center. 
The center is the first privately financed trade ce n te r in the U nited 
States. 
Its sculptured concrete mural, stretching the full length of the center, de­ picts the history of free trade from pre historic to modern times. 
Free, guided tours are available. Aud with the cen ter gath erin g such countries as Brazil and 
Great Britain for inter­ national trade n eg otia­ tions, shoppers will find

Los Angeles downtown has the distinction of en compassing three ethnic communities. The best known of these is Olvera 
Street — the birthplace of Los A ngeles. L A ’s humble beginning is ac­ tually a block-long cobb­ lestone s tre e t in the heart of Old Los Angeles. 
Vet the street is alive with m a ria ch i m u sic, colorful pinatas and ser­ apes. 
T h e ow ners of these individual stalls are fo u rth -g en eratio u 
A n gelenos, th eir f a ­ milies, part of the ori­ ginal settlers. 
The Oriental influence is represented by Little 
Tokyo and Chinatown 
LA’s Japanese commun­ ity is the largest outside of Japan 
And 
Chinatow n, its 
Mandarin int luenceevery- where. is a delightful step into another world. 
Shops and restauran ts are plentiful in all of these communities.

 hour or sightseers, LA's new downtown 
M all should not be missed. 
Some call it the hallmark of inner-city planning and developm ent. T h e two-level Mall, adjacent to City Hall, weaves a blend of dandelion water fountains, lush tropical g a rd e n s and re ta il stores. A six-story T r i ­ folium theme sculpture will b ro a d ca st m u sic against the backdrop of this new, downtown Los 
Angeles. 
While shopping has al ways been an attraction downtown, it’s a prime 
\ lsitor attraction today 
ARC O Plaza, a 52 story twin office building, fea­ tures the largest subter­ ran ean shopping c o m ­ plex in the world. 
Nest led one floor below street level. ARCO Plaza is a maze of intimate* b o tiq u es, fa sh io n a b le m en’s stores and superb dining establishments. 

A few blocks away in a red brick block, B ro a d ­ way Plaza has brought the sotting of Italy to Los 
A ngeles. T h e c en te r is set amidst gas lights, a two-story stained glass skyline and a profusion of co n tin u a lly b lo o m in g flowers

A tale of the returning 
2-34 cam era 

Have you heard? M edium form at has been given new life. 
Small form at, 35mm and HO pocket c a m e r a s 
( 1 6 m m ) a p p e a r e d to be dealing a d eath blow to 2-*4 inch m e ­ dium sized ca m eras. But in the past two years these so called “ professional c a m e ra s " have m ade a strong com e­ back. 
M edium form at i* generally twice as expen­ s e e as 35mm. 
T he c a m e r a s and lenses a re u sually about twice as o s te n s iv e for c o m p a rab le eq u ip m en t and film is twice as expensive per fram e But are they twice as good? 

PROBABLY NOT. 
But th ere a re som e a d ­ v a n ta g e s 
It is th e s e a d \ o u t a g e s w h ich a r e causing tin* boom in 2-H inch c a m e ra p opulari­ ty- 
Im age quality has alw ays been superior with m edium form at cam eras. A negative four tim es larger than 35m m can resolve detail not possi­ ble with sm aller negatives. if Dux Kl lle m m in g s in Blow-up had been us­ ing a H asselblad instead of a Nikon the body limier the tree would have been identifiable. 
T h is d oesn t p iea n that N ikon isn t a fine cam era ll is But negative im ag e size is limited. 
With equal quality, the sam e film and sam e exposure, a photograph taken with a 2-*4 inch f o r m a t c a m e r a w ill b e s h a r p e r a n d f in e r grained because less e n larg em en t is necessary. 

THIS ll \S ALW \Y S BUEN the clincher for professionals. E as e of handling and light weight have been less im portant than im age quality for the m an m aking a buck with his cam era . 
Today s a m a te u r has discovered som e other gin id reasons to use m ed iu m form at. 
P rices have drop|>ed. As 35mm c a m e ra s have been m ad e m ore sophisticated prices have risen considerably. 
The alway s-expensive 2-*4 c a m e ra has bene* fntcd from a m a te u r interest and m ass production has kept p rices stab le or dropped them slightly. 
Flash sync is possible at all speeds on most m ed iu m form at cam eras. Even those with focal p lan e s h u t t e r s o ffer one or two le n s e s w ith built-in shutters that syncronize with electronic flash to 15tMltl) of a second. Fast enough even for bright sun. 
S u p e r s lid e s a r e p o s s ib le w ith 2 -H film . 
Breaking the monotony of strong horizontal and vertical pictures with a big sq u are slide adds interest to slide shows. 

Photo Tips 

W i t h Ron 
Jones 

WITH INCREASED INTEREST by a m a te u rs 
(they a r e th e p h o to g r a p h e r s w ith m o n ey to spend on e q u ip m e n t), c a m e r a m a n u fa c tu re rs have m ad e an effort to shave off excess weight from m ed iu m form at equipm ent. 
Not only is today’s 2-H inch c a m e ra s lighter. it handles easier and ap p ro ach es 35mm picture boxes in speed and accessories. 
A trick that com es easy on 12o film is the Mail 
Mary! 
Don't look to F en n in g er for elaboration on this method. I believe i f s original. At least purely practical. 
W hen you m u st shoot blind — not looking through the view finder — in photography it is called a “ Hail M a ry .” You point the c a m e ra , trip the sh u tter and pray. 

WHEN SHOOTING OVER a crowd (as d uring 
P resid en tial visits), hold the c a m e ra at a r m s le n g th o v e r h e a d a n d h o p e y o u r s u b j e c t is som ew here on the negative. T he w ider the lens the g re a te r the chance but the sm aller the su b ­ ject on the film. 
It seem s like you c a n ’t win. Like ju m p in g out of a burning airplane without a parachute. 
With 2-i4- your p a rac h u te is larg er form at. 
Im age size on film is dependent on subject distance and focal length of the laking lens lf you use a 5omm lens on a 35m m c a m e ra that is considered a norm al lens. 
A 5omm lens on a 2-l 4 inch c a m e ra is consi­ dered a w ide angle. 
But two negatives m ad e from the sa m e dis. la n c e w ith th e s e tw o c a m e r a s a n d p r in te d without m oving the e n la r g e r or c h a n g in g e n ­ larger lenses, will In* the sam e. 

THE MKDIl M FORMAT n eg ativ e will in­ clude a bunch m ore set'ne around the subject but everything in the picture will be the sa m e size on the negative. 
Consider the possibilities. 
G rad shots and Hail M ary 's are twice as easy. 
F a st m o v in g s u b j e c t s c a n be m o r e loosely fram ed with no loss of quality, .lust point and shoot. Leave tight fram in g to the e n la rg er lf you are bored with 1.5 to I ratio pictures, think sq u a re. Moll film c a m e r a s a re co m in g back and i f s alioul time.

But play is all in its cast 

A play such as “ An Inspector f a l l s " succeeds, not so m uch because of its worth as a piece of theater, but because of the blind faith a cast has it in. 
“ An In sp ecto r f a l l s , ” in o t h e r w o r d s , w o r k s because the east believes it should. They believe in the play, which is. after a ll. a p ie c e of h e a v ily m o r a lis tic m e l o d r a m a , that th rea te n s with each new line to tu r n into a self-parody. And because they believe in the play, the audience does too. 
And its with a true be­ liever’s zeal that m ost of the east presents the play u n d e r R i c h a r d J o n e s ’ d irec tio n al the C h u rch 
Theater. 
J. B. P rie s tle y ’s play, written in the early 19oos. lacks the innate subtlety th at m o d e r n a u d ie n c e s ap p rec ia te. "A n In sp e c ­ to r f a l l s ” la y s o u t its m o r a l les s o n w ith th e m ethodical su ren ess of a brick-layer. 
It begins with a happy occasion, a well-to-do fa­ mily. who if not likeable a r e w e ll-b e h a v e d , c e le ­ b ra tin g the e n g a g e m e n t of th e ir d a u g h te r to an e q u a lly w e a lth y y o u n g m an T he celeb ratio n is in te rru p te d by the a r r i ­ val of an Inspector Goole. 
It se e m s that a young p r e g n a n t w o m a n h a s killed herself by drinking d is in f e c ta n t, a p a r t i c u ­ larly painful Way to go. 
T he inspector painfully exposes the way in which each one of the persons at the c e le b r a tio n e n c o u n ­ tered the girl and contri­ buted to her suicide. 
T h e f a th e r , a c o n s e r ­ vative b u sin e ssm a n who b e lie v e s in lo w er c o sts and h ig h er prices, fired th e g i r l a f t e r s h e organized a strike lo get an extra three shillings a week. 
The d au g h ter in a chil­ dish p iq u e had th e g irl fired from her next job. 
T h e d a u g h t e r ’s f ia n c e m a d e th e g irl h is m i s ­ t r e s s b r ie f ly a n d th e n dropped tier. 
T h e f a m i l y 's son im* p r e g n a te d th e g irl and s to le m o n e y f r o m h is father-firm to support h e r u ntil the girl found out aud refu sed tain ted m o n e y . P r e g n a n t , th e girl went to a ch aritab le co m m ittee headed by tile m o th e r, who re fu s e d to a id th e g ir l on th e g rounds that the c h ild 's tallier should help her. 
None of these facts are re a lly g iv in g aw ay th e story. T he plot d e v elo p ­ m en ts are telegraphed to th e a u d ie n c e w ith o b ­ vious clu es. T h e r e ts a last twist to the story that is w o rth h a n g in g on to although it is also fairly predictable.

 the heav ily moody — al­ m o st m y s tic — a t m o s ­ p h e re the play w a s d e ­ signed to create.

C a u s e r is p a rtic u la rly im p re s s iv e as the daughter. Her role is less than a caricature.

Danny 
Spear in the crucial role of the in sp ecto r. As the g u ilt for t h e i r a c tio n s , o th e r c h a r a c t e r s p o in t 

Although only alxiut til) years old, “ Au Inspector 
Calls” is already a period piece. To try lo m ake it match the m o rality and the character su b tleties of the present is to deny the nature of the play. 
J o n e s ’ d irectio n gives tile play its head to rom p through its own p a rtic u ­ lar m ilieu. W hile Jo n e s d raw s out p e rfo rm a n ce s th at a r e as r e a lis tic a s possible given the play. he doest! I q u e r ie r with

C o u s e r ’s e m o tio n set a s t a n d a r d by w h ich th e c o ld n e s s of th e o t h e r c h a r a c t e r s can be m e a ­ sured. 
The m other becom es a delicious ease of irony in 
M arianna Blaze s p erfor­ m ance. Blaze m ak es the m other a sim ple crea tu re u n a b le to c o m p r e h e n d even in the slightest how h e r a c t i o n s m ig h t be wrong. 
D a v id B o w en a s th e father m akes what could easily be a stick fig u re in to a f u ll- b o d ie d b e lie v a b le e m b o d im e n t of c o n s e rv a tiv e s e lf is h ­ n e s s . B ow en g iv e s th e c h a ra c te r fine overtones of true villainy. 
The rule of the fiance is th e le a s t m i n e a b le a s w ritten iii the script. It is a b la n d c h a r a c t e r — 

 out. th e in s p e c to r d o es not beh av e as an o r d in ­ a r y p o l ic e m a n , b u t 
S p e a r s p e r t b r m a n c e fails to find a consistent way for the inspector to liehave. The one note he hits most often is one of d e li b e r a t e a n t a g o n i s m , w hich te a r s aw ay w hat l ittle s u b t l e t y t h e r e m ig h t be fo u n d in th e play . 
"A n ln sp tv to r C alls” is c e r ta in ly not s t a r t l i n g dram a. It is fam iliar ami c o m fo rta b le , an d m u c h of its e n jo y m e n t c o m e s from w atching o n e’s ex* pectations for plot twists a n d c h a r a c t e r re v e la * lions tieing fulfilled. 
And it s a good oppor* t u n n y to w a tc h how a good cast and d ire c tio n can m a k e e v e n an old, tir e d sto ry fin d a new life,

North Star Moll 
FCSTIVAL OF FMC ARTS 

S T A R T S W E D N E S D A Y F E B 1 6 2 6 

2nd Sem i A n n u al Invitational Artists' T o u r 

C o m e to N orth Star Mall Feb. 16 thru 26 and enjoy a festival of fine arts throughout the Mall. A rtists and craftspersons from all over the U .S will display, and have on sale, their w o rk s along with a tre m endous participation of Texas artists. Oils, watercolor, pottery, jewelry, metal sculpture, photography, and w oodcarving just to give you an exam ple of the variety of media and talent there!

T H EY ’V E GOT RHYTHM: The 
Raymond Johnson Dance Com­ pany is one of the well-respected black modern dance troupes. 
The company will be in San 
Antonio this week for three free performances and a series of free dance workshops at the 
Carver Community Cultural 
Center. 
Friday and Saturday the com­ pany’s performances w ill in­ 

 clude “ Scintilla,’’ “ Wolfman,” 
“ As the World Turns Out.” 
“ Feathers" and “ Landmark.” 
On Saturday they will perform 
“ Sugar ( ane.” “ Cham ber,” 
“ Threshold.” and “ Corridor." 
Tuesday through Thursday members of the troupe will be giving free dance classes, in­ cluding movement for athletes and for actors. 

Check out Dunce and Etc. for details. 

EN D ER TH E BIG TOP. The big top tent used to be synonymous with circuses. Today most cir­ 

 cuses play in civic arenas and coliseums. 
But not the Circus Vargas. It’s the largest circus still being pro­ duced under the big top, and its tent will be raised this week at 
South Park Mall. 
More than 5,ooo persons w ill be able to see the two-hour circus including trapeze acts, animal acts, jugglers, clowns and high wire artists. 
A fret' preview show will be held 11:3o a.m. Saturday with free balloons for the kids. 

Look to Etc. for more info.

S .A .’s Stoney a C&W pioneer 

NASHVILLE, Tenn. - 
B lack co untry m usic singer Stoney Edwards has a rather revolution­ ary experiment in the works he hopes w ill im ­ prove his career: 
An all black country music band to back him up on personal appear­ ances! 
He freely adm its it isn't going to be easy to recruit the players, but says, “ there is bound to be some black musicians who play country m u­ sic.” 
“ In fact,” continues 
Edwards, who lh es in 
San Antonio but does his recording work (on Ca­ pitol label) in Nashville, 
“ my business partner 
(Anthony Pittso of Me­ dina, Tex.) and I have already got some good leads on a fiddle player and a steel guitarist. 
‘ ‘We th o u g h t,” he laughs, “ a black fiddler and steel man would be the hardest to find.” 
Edwards emphasises he isn't going to “ organ­ ize just any old band.” 
-Our s e a rc h l’ he in ­ sists. “ is to be thorough. 

Nashville Sound 

By REO o 

We want genuine, good pickers.” 
Edwards laughs again when asked if his plan m ight be a form of segregation. 
“ I never thought of it that way,” he says. “ All my white friends, in and out of music, agree it is a good idea. 
“ Frankly,” he adds, “ I need something to perk up my career. I* want to make it ‘big.’ Yes, ‘big' like 
C harley 
P ride. 

DONNELL 

Maybe even bigger.” He grins.” 
“ My records sell good. 
I’ve been with Capitol for six years and that should tell you something about my popularity as a re­ cording a rtist," he says. 
“ Too,” he adds, “ my personal appearances — about 1411 a year — are money-makers. 
"Y et, I want more re­ cognition. 
I'm a m b i­ tious.” 
E dw ards, born and

Nnm fijofl! int 

 raised iii Seminole, Ok­ la., can neither read nor write. Discussion of the subject isn’t sensitive for him. 
“ I suppose,” he re ­ calls, “ I only went to school two or three times in my life. I was a first grade dropout. I had to go to work when I was very young. I’m the pro­ duct of a broken home — one of eight kids. I can’t remember when I didn t have some kind of a job; most of them rough; some of them very tough. 
Too numerous to list 
“ Yes,” he confesses. 

“ there have been times when I wish I was better educated. 
Perhaps 
I should have done some­ thing about it. Working at some sort of a job al­ ways got in the way. 
‘ ‘A c tu a lly ,” he says with a smile, “ not being able to read or w rite hasn't I)et“n all that big a problem in m aking a 
In mg. I suppose the big­ gest problem is convinc­ ing people I can't read or write. 
"Sometimes it's worth a c h u ckle ,” says the 
45-year-old entertainer.

Dear Hook I d itor: 
For some years. F u been reading and re viewing books that have cashed in on a single, salable idea. 
The idea is something that, with hard-sell pro­ motion. catches the pub­ lic’s fancy. The books 

 themselves usually arc poorly written, the plots are loaded with coinci­ dences and the dialogue wouldn’t pass muster for a soap opera script. 
You know what 
I mean. “Jaws.” (There is this big white shark, see. and ...) “ Raise the Ti-

 away all the good it 
Covers ARE important to .judging books, despite what they say. 
The cover for my book will have a pro football helm et 
(Cowboys or 
Sutlers) with a red and black swastika superim­ posed over tho team emblem. And a mansion 
(probably the 
White 
House) with a forlorn, sexy woman in the fore­ ground. This is for Goth­ ic fans. And a mushroom cloud in the background 
I believe this is a m ar­ ketable product. 
Of course, some of the de­ tails will have to be fleshed out and the lawyers will have to draw up the contracts and all. 
Even if it doesn’t make a book and a movie, it could fill at least part of a show for “ Kojak” or 
“ McCloud.”

A play by a San An­ tonio man has been in­ cluded in a recently published book on 
Mcxiean-American 
Theater. 
The play. “ La Raze 
Paia. or Racial, Racial.” is included iii ‘‘Contem­ porary 
Chicano 
T h e a te r,” edited by 
George Garza and pub­ lished by Nolle Dame 
Press. 
The play iv written by 
Ruben Sierra It was or­ iginally produced at St. 
Mary’s University. It is one of eight plays select­ ed for the book. 
D isco d a n c e 
& m o re 

San Antonio Fine Arts 
Center wants to get San 
Antonians off on the right foot the next time they re out on the town. 
And there s something at the MacArthur Plaza center for home-bodies too. 
Beginning in March, and scheduled for Tues­ day evenings, 8 to 9 p.m., classes in disco dancing will be offered. The six- weeks instruction will be capped by an evening at a local disco where class members can put into practice what they have learned 
Classes, taught by 
Kathy Marlin, will cost 
$3(1 including the final night's party. 
For those preferring to stay around the old ho­ mestead. SAFAC is of-' fering classes in art for children and adults. 
Classes will be held from 
4 to 
5 p.m . each 
Wednesday and are cur­ rently in progress. 
More information is available at 653-7241.

Tie up spring fashion with Air Step casuals on a polyurethane bottom 

These great sporty shoes have all the smart style you want for spring and summer. They're just right for pants, shorts or casual skirts and dresses. Plus, they have an all new polyurethane molded one-piece bot­ tom that's flexible enough to give you total walking comfort. Choose the 
Scuff above left, a slip-on mule style with contrast stitching Red, navy, whiskey or white, 23.oo. Rhythm’, above right, is a quarter- strap sandal in white, navy or camel, 24.oo. Both have soft leather uppers and come in sizes 6V2-IO narrow and 5-1o medium. Women s Shoes, Down­ town, North Star, Windsor Park, Austin. Charge it!

Bronson, Jill and sex 

Prince’s young mistress is left empty-handed 
AMERICAN bom Christine Week ert (above) was the mistress of the late Prince Stanislas Radzi will And when he died last J urn', he left her $7o,ooo in his will. 
But the shapely Miss Weckert is unlikely to ever to see any of her lover's money 

For the Prince, 61, formerly wed to Jackie Onassis' sister l„ee 
Had/iwill, left a million dollars in legacies—bul nothing to pay them with 

Legal experts have told THE 
STAR that his estate, which is mainly tied up in property, is vir­ tually worthless because of debts 

The Polish-bom Prince became a prominent figure in the london property market after World War ll 

After divorcing Lee Radziwill in 1974, the Prince moved into a town house near Buckingham Pal­ ace with Miss Weckert His for­ mer wife was not named in the will.

The money goes to students wh< agree to practice in Martins Per ry, Ohio, for at least three year* after they complete their residen­ cy programs

All hell’s a-poppin’ 

THE show was called Hellzapoppin. But the real sparks were flying off-stage between feuding co- stars Jerry Lewis and Lynn Redgrave (above). The 
$l-million musical collapsed three weeks before its scheduled Broadway debut with an angry Lewis re­ fusing to rehearse its “sub-standard” songs with 
Miss Redgrave. Still simmering, the actress says of his decision: “Jerry has a right to his opinion, but he’s wrong.” 

The Governor’s girl... 

WHEN California’s Jerry Brown mounted his short­ lived bid for the Presidency last year, singer Linda 
Ronstadt was one of the first showbiz stars to help his fund-raising effort. The campaign soon died, but their friendship hasn t. 
Word is that bachelor Jerry, 39, and the lovely 
Linda have now become an item. They are frequent dinner partners and he squired her to President 
Carter s Inauguration in January. 
However, friends of the couple say it’s too soon to talk of a romance. Brown has also been seeing 
Candice Bergen. And Linda, 3o, sees Mick Jagger 
A woman who knows Brown told THE STAR: 
“Jerry is a marvelous escort and he enjoys the company of attractive women. There's no more to it than that.” 

HENRY FONDA (above), was back at work last week, 48 hours after emerging from a hos­ pital’s intensive care unit. The 71-year-old ac­ tor had surgery on his heart pacemaker after becoming sick while completing his lastest movie, The I .ast Of The Cowboys. With some dialogue still to be dubbed, Fonda summoned rookie director John Leone to his beside for a recording session Leone said later "They just don't make stars like Fonda anymore.” 

THE Siberian like snow that gripped the North 
East must have seemed just like home for ex lied Soviet author Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, 58 It inspired the bearded novelist to take a walk near his estate in Montpelier, Vt Solzhenitsyn is so publicity-shy that a recorded voice warns would be visitors to his property: "There is no­ body to talk to. You can’t come in.” 

Swimmer taking a new plunge 
HANDSOME John Naber, the swimmer who won four gold medals at the Montreal 
Olympics, is looking for a new career. The 
6-ft 6-ins tall 
Californian is tiring of his grueling three-hour training sessions, six- aays-a-week. Naber, who graduates from 
University of California in April, says: “ If 
I stop swimming nobody will be disappoint­ ed, but I’ll wait and see what work I can get.” 

! Ever seen a 
Manhattanite on the rocks? Well here s one, from the crazy world of photographer 
Alfred Gescheidt victim of this winter’s severe wind chill, this 
New Yorker was about to crack under the icy con­ ditions when a giant pair of tongs came to his res­ cue 
After last month s sub-zero temperatures, millions of Ameri­ cans know just how he felt. 

DOCTOR’S 
CASEBOOK' 

Mysterious disease is a crippler of women 

Mrs louise Keller. 5o. wife of a successful engineering executive, was one of mv healthiest patients. 
She d come into nu office only occasionally—for her regular checkup—and I d always check her out to bt4 in tile best of physi­ cal health then, one night, without warn­ ing. she was overcome In a dis­ ease that could change the very course of her life 
One night, she turned over in her sleep—and broke her arm! 
Unfortunately, the worst was yet to come 
I immediately ordered special 
X rays hoping my worst fears would be wrong But the problem. as I had suspected, was extrem e­ ly serious. 

 louise had developed osteopo­ rosis, an illness not familiar to most Americans but one in 15 million know can bt* crippling and disabling because they suffer from it 
For example, the shrunken old woman bent over by an unsightly 
“dowager s hump between her shoulders blades surely has osteo­ porosis. 

It is a disease that gradually thias the bones by robbing them of calcium and it can be both painful, disabling and disfiguring 

We also don’t know whether the onset of menopause contrib­ utes to the gradual loss of vital minerals from the tomes 

Why Sophia Loren won’t live in America 

Even worse, scientists have yet to resolve whether osteoporosis is truly a disease or merely the nat­ ural result of aging 
Nor can they tell why it strikes about four times as many women as men, or why it most often strikes women of Anglo-Saxon and 
Northern European ancestry 

Navy faces a new Menace 

DENNIS the Menace has traded in his sling shot for Navy blue. Jay North (left) the actor who played the little TV ter­ ror, has enlisted for a four-year tour in the U S. Navy. 
There to welcome him at the Recruit Training Center in Or­ lando, Fla , was another former child actor Jackie Cooper 
(top,right), now a captain rn the Naval Reserve. 
North. 25, joined the Navy because he hasn t had an acting 
V rn 
J°b in three years ‘‘The work situation in California had got­ ten so slow,’ he complained 

Fortunately for Louise. I was able to detect the problem before critical bone loss occurred 
So I immediately add«*d flounde to her diet until it reached IO nul- ligrams a day 
But this is where I stopped be­ cause too much can do more harm than good 
Next. I put her on a diet high in calcium and containing a good supply of rich green vegetables 
Even more important, 
I pre­ scribed exercise featuring lots of walking and swimming 
It has been demonstrated that lack of exercise can lead to osteo­ porosis and that women who. growing older, walk less and stop participating in sports, mav be making trouble for themselves 
Still, I made certain louise was not on so vigorous a regimen as to put too much strain on her now- brittle bones 
There are indications a hor­ mone called calcitonin, produced by the thyroid gland, mas help os­ teoporosis sufferers 
Meantime, all we can do is hope and wait, and prescribe to the best of our ability 

She’s 24, beautiful, a millionairess, and has the entire world of gold and jewelry by the throat 

Stevie, 16, the wonder jockey, races to $ 1 rn 

APPRENTICE 
.jockey 
Steve 
Cauthen (above) is the biggest sensation in thoroughbred racing since Secretariat 
The 16-yr-old son of a Kentucky blacksmith has been riding horses since he could walk. Steve had his grounding at mid-West tracks, rode his first winner last May, and came to New York in Decem­ ber with 25o winners under his belt. 
He's still able to claim five pounds for another four months — an apprentice can claim the weight allowance for a year after he rode his first winner 
Stevie rode a phenomenal 62 winners in just over a month 
The baby-faced rider is earning up to $2o,ooo a week—and when he went to Santa Anita. Calif., for a day's racing recently he put 1o.ooo on the attendance. 
When he finishes his day at 
New York's Aqueduct he apes home to trainer Fred Tuffarriel- io's house to be tutored. 

At 24. Nathalie Hoca (above) has the entire world of diamonds and jewelry by the throat. She s man­ aging director of Cartier s—and globe trots regularly between the company’s stores in France, En­ gland and America. 
The beautiful millionairess has emerald eyes, flawless pearl teeth, a gold-plated suntan and a business head as hard as a 
4o-carat diamond 
“These days, if a woman really wants something enough to work hard for it, she can get it,” says 
Nathalie, snapping shut her $15oo gold cigar lighter. 

In the three years she s been running the business—since her father Robert Hocq bought it in 
1972—profits have soared 2oo per­ cent 
“ My father s interested only in figures and if they're good he doesn t interfere with the way I get them ,” she said. 
She s got them by blowing the dust off C artier's solid, heavily- encrusted image. 
Her most successful venture has been a senes of trendy -bou­ tiques selling luxury lighters, watches and luggage—all bearing the exclusive Cartier name 

In the next two years, she plans to bring her boutiques to every major city in the U S. 
Nathalie, who lives in a two-ter­ raced apartm ent in a fashionable section of Paris and travels to work in a white Rolls-Royce, says: 

 i 'm not stupid enough to see myself as another Louis Cartier 
He was a genius. I just see myself as a good businesswoman 

One day. she wants to m arry and have children 
“There s no reason why a high-powered wom­ an can t do both,” she says. 

SHAPELY Sophia Loren, on her first visit to Hol­ lywood in 16 years, revealed that she and her mov­ ie producer husband Carlo Ponti have decided against living in the U S 
The couple, who now live in Paris, were report­ ed ready to move to New York But Sophia, 42. says: “ Paris is where my two sons go to school and Paris is where we ll stay until they grow up.”

Rich Man star is single 

PLEASE tell me everything von can about James Carroll Jordan, that terrific young actor on Kith Man. Poor Man. — Hanna Jackson. Cincin­ nati. Ohio. 
JIM. 27, was born in Germany and traveled the world with his father, a career military officer He attended more than a dozen schools before he was 18 and graduated from the London Academy of Dramatic Art. 
After playing several small parts in TV series, he landed his plum role in Rich Man. Poor Man. He lives alone in a Hollywood apartment and is a very eligible bachelor.

LAURIE BRADY 

Doctor tells how to remember yow medication 

DOCTORS are adopting a psy­ chological approach to help pa­ tients who forget to take daily medication 
‘‘People often forget their pills when they’re feeling good,” says 
Professor W Stewart A gras, a be­ havioral scientist at the Univer­ sity of California in Davis 

Dr, Agras found that patients are more likely to rem em ber it if their daily doses are reduced. 

“ lf thev were taking two pills a day, we bring it down to one,” he explained. ’ This makes it much harder to forget ” 

Here are other tips: 
• If you come home in the eve­ ning and the first thing you do is get a soda, put the pills next to the soda. 
• lf you lake pills last thing at night, put them next to your tooth­ brush as a reminder.

Sally Fields: She goes where ever
