NIXON HATCHET 
MAN IS HAPPY 
PREACHING THE 
GOSPEL IN JAIL 

By ROGER LANGLEY 

CHARLES COLSON, President Nixon's hated hatchet man. told this week how he has found peace of m ind . . . preaching the gospel inside prisons. 
"God has called me into prison work,” Colson told THE STAR. “ I have the credibility to talk to those guys on their level and they listen to me and they believe, they honestly do 
' There is a bond between anyone who has served time in prison.” 
Colson served seven months in jail and was fined $5,ooo for ob­ struction of justice after a ‘dirty tricks” campaign against Daniel 
Ellsberg, the man who leaked the secret Pentagon Papers. 
Colson fed false information about Ellsberg to newspapers in an attempt to color the case against the young lawyer who was under indictment. 
Colson says he voluntarily pleaded guilty because of his con­ version to Christ. 
He explained 
* Although 
I knew nothing of the break in at the office of Ellsberg’s psychia­ trist, I thought it was justified. 
’ So why should my guilt or in­ nocence turn on the particular day I learned of the misdeed? Le­ gal niceties make moral non­ sense.” 
Now disbarred as a lawyer, 
Colson devotes his time to preach­ ing in prisons, working for a non­ profit organization called Prison 
Fellowship. 
But it wasn’t always that way. 
Many people are still convinced that Colson was behind all the 
’ dirty tricks” associated with the 
Nixon Administration. 
But he says: i f one-tenth of the things printed about me were true, I wouldn't be sitting here.” 
Colson is often fingered as the man who hired Howard Hunt to form the Watergate Plumbers, the burglars who broke into the 
Democratic offices at the Water­ gate complex in Washington, D C. 
“ I didn’t hire Hunt,” he said. 
“ And I never asked the President to offer him clemency.” 
Colson said he still doesn’t know why the Watergate break-in took place 

( huck Colson: Loyalty blurred his sense of right and wrong- 

But he s often wondered wheth­ er there was any connection be tween the fact that Larry O’Brien, whose office it was that was bro­ ken into at the Watergate, had once worked for Howard Hughes 
“ I think the Hughes Tool Co was an enormous corrupting influ­ ence in Government,” said Col­ son. 
"They were penetrating every­ where — putting everybody on their payroll — Democrats and 
Republicans alike. 
"The CIA-connected people in 
Watergate got off better than the rest of us. 
' The fact that Dick Helms 
(CIA chief) could openly perjure himself so many times ana a guy like Gordon Liddy sits in jail shows the old boy establishment still doses ranks and takes care of its own.” 
Colson admits he was guilty of some dirty tricks 

By VAUN WILMOTT 

Still wearing their wet clothes, the five skated back to shore, jumped into a pick up truck and circled the mile-wide lake to the other shore. 
Roping themselves to 
J uts 
Lake residents Phil Middleton, 
Larry Hughes and Jim Moyer, t'.e hockey players inched across the ice. crawling on their stomachs some of the way. 
Hanna was barely conscious when they pulled him from the waler and his wife had vanished 
Miller stripped and dove through the ragged hole in the ice. 
We didn t have time to debate it.” said the 2oo-pound Miller 
“ Because I vc got a good layer of meat over my bones and can shun cold. I went in. I'd already had two dunkings and didn t think I could get any colder/' 
Miller made two deep dives but couidn t see Mrs. Hanna. Finally the cold forced him from the wa­ ter. 
She just wasn’t there," Miller said * And I was wrong about not getting any colder I could and did I was frozen.” 
His teammates gave him cof­ fee. wrapped him rn blankets and rubbed his body to restore circu­ lation 
Later fie soaked in hot 

 baths and stood over a fire until his body warmth returned. 
Meanwhile, others on shore stripped Hanna and placed him in a sleeping bag Nordan Hall got in with him 
“That’s the best way to restore body heat when .somebody is froz­ en.’ Miller explained 
All the hockey team members had taken IOO hours of paramedic training “ And this was where it paid off,” Miller said 
Nominated for a heroism award. Miller minimizes his role in the rescue 
“ It was definitely a group effort by the team and townspeople," he told THE STAR. 
I just happened to be one of them." 

FREEZE KILLS PESKY 
SUMMERTIME INSECTS 
AMERICA'S big freeze mas bring an end to the swarms of fleas, flies and ticks that have plagued recent summers. 
Temperatures this winter have been consistently cold enough to destroy the insect larvae, said Dr. 
Paul Lutz, chairman of the Uni­ versity of 
North Carolina al 
Greensboro. 
He said if the cold weather con­ tinues. many insect eggs normally resistent to temperatures in the teens and 2os will be killed. 

Tennis super-couple 

 fry sex for insomnia, say doctors 
HOOEY PLAYER DIVES THROUGH 
ICE IN AN AMAZING LAKE RESCUE 

Bjorn Borg and his fiancee Mariana Simonescu — they have their love and $1.5 million to keep them warm. 

BJORN Borg and Mariana Si­ monescu have it all—each oth­ er and $1.5 million. 
That’s the price tag on the contract the Swedish superstar 
Borg has just signed with the 
Cleveland Nets of the World 
Team Tennis Association. 
Borg insisted that Mariana be part of the deal. They have been inseparable ever since they met last year. They’re now engaged. 
Mariana is an impressive tennis talent herself— number two among women players of her native Romania. 
Until the Cleveland offer, 
Swedish officials had been able to convince Borg not to join team competition. 
But the Nets offer was too good to pass up, especially with its $2o,ooo a year for Mar­ iana and the same for Borg’s coach Lennert Bcrgelin. 
It means they can continue their seemingly charmed life as tennis's happiest young cou­ ple Both are 2o. 
“ We are in love and it feels great,” 
Borg said at their apartment in Boca Raton. Fla. 
Mariana added: “ He’s ev­ erything I ever dreamed of in a man.” 
Even doing the laundry’ to­ gether delights the young lov­ ers. 

FIVE hockey players struggled across crumbling ice. som e­ times on their stomachs, in a courageous bid to save two ska­ ters who had fallen through the ice. 
One of the hockey players stripped off all his clothes and dived twice to the bottom of the lake. 
Finally they rescued Frank Hanna. 35. but were unable to save his wife Diana. 38. The drama began as the five frineds were practicing hockey at 
June 
Lake, a popular skiing resort in the mountains near California’s Yosemite National Park 
The five. all members of the 
June Lake hockey team are B Z. 
Miller. 26, Keith Potter, 27, both ski patrolmen. Mark Sanders. 21. a carpet installer, Nordan Hall, 
28, a ski shop manager; and 
Chuck MacLaren. 25. a ski shop employee. 

DON'T take drugs to get to sleep 
Make love. 
That's the advice of group of 
London doctors who have formed 
CURB—the Campaign on the Use and Restriction of Barbiturates. 
In their panel on going to sleep without pills, they place lovemak­ ing at the top of their list of way s to relax and get a good night's rest 
They warn. however, that it’s not the best remedy for compul- j sive worriers about sexual per­ formance. Post-sex anxiety is just something else to keep such peo­ ple awake. 
For them, the doctors recom­ mend a long walk before bedtime and a good book until drowsiness descends. 
Another type who should be­ ware of lovemaking to induce sleep is the middle-aged man with a young mistress. 
The doctors cited a study by the 
Medical Department of West Ber­ lin University, whose Prof. Ber- j nard Kruland said: 
“ Sex outside marriage is dan­ gerous for the heart because it is | more exciting. A girlfriend is usually more demanding and more exhausting than a wife.” 
Of 114 men who died wfiile mak­ ing love, according to the German study. 9o were middle-aged gents sleeping with girlfriends. 

Suddenly, the five heard screams from skaters near the center of the lake The Hannas had plunged through the ice about 
5o feet from the opposite shore 
“The quickest way to reach them was straight across the lake.” Miller told THE STAR 
“ But between us and them were varying thicknesses of ice.” 
Even as the hockey players skated toward the Hannas, ice was crumbling under their skates, 
Five hundred feet from the cou­ ple. ail five men plunged into the water. 
They‘swam to thicker Ice and climbed out But their way was blocked by a passage of open wa­ ler. 
Hockey players Nordan Hall and 
Mark Sanders at rescue scene.

By ROSS GREGOR 

 nest egg 

STAR LETTERS • STAR LETTERS • STAR LETTERS • STAR LETTERS 

I WANTED a cup of coffee, but didn’t want to make it my­ self. I silently wished my hus­ band would get up and do it. 
Suddenly, he got up and headed for the bathroom, stopped and went to the kitchen and cam e back with a cup of coffee. 
I asked him why he got me the coffee, but he really couldn’t ex­ plain. except to say that a feeling came over him. 
Since then we’ve experim ented with num bers and find that we can mentally communicate. 
I ll have him pick out a number between one and IO and visualize it in his mind I get one chance to guess the number. 
I have guessed right many times and have since enlarged the numbers all the way to 25. 
Another exam ple: I had started this letter to THE STAR when I decided to put it off until morning. 
I went and sat on the floor by ray husband’s feet. He was sur­ prised, and told me that only mo­ ments before he had wished I'd do just that. 
I rarely sit that way because it is uncomfortable. — Mrs. Richard 
Silcox, Kent, Wash. 
• HAVE you ever m entally communicated aith an>one? Tell us about It. $5 for every letter published. Write: MENTAL TE­ 
LEPATHY, Sa* Antonio Express, 
P.O. Box 2171, San Antonio, Texas 
7H297. bine tuning

 them , the wife said to her hus­ band. "You know, honey, if we miss two paym ents on the wash­ ing m achine and one on the re­ frigerator we ll have a down pay­ ment on a TV set." — J.L., West 
Palm Beach, Ela.

Heel... 

I WENT to pick up my shoes 

 from the repair shop and discov­ ered I d lost my claim check. As the shoem aker was trying to dis­ cover which pair of shoes was mine, my dachshund, 
Doxie, started sniffing at a row of shoes. 

Suddenly, he grabbed one and brought it to me. then ran back for the other Sure enough, they were mine. 
— G.G. C rabtree, 
Lansing. Mich.

When she wasn’t looking, he poured a little wine in the stew

WEIL FIND LIFE IN SPACE IN 
NEAR FUTURE 

LIFE could be discovered in outer space within our lifetime, a top 
U.S. scientist predicted this week. 
Dr M ark Chartrand, chairm an of New York’s Hayden P lanetar­ ium, m ade the forecast following the recent dram atic discovery of concentrations of w ater molecules in a distant galaxy. 

"W e have just recently learned to com m unicate over the vast dis­ tances in space," he said. ‘ We’ve just begun to search. 

" It is unlikely we ll find life in our solar system , but chances are good we ll find it somewhere else. 
I think it could happen in our lifetim e." 
W ater molecules were first dis­ covered in space in the 196os, but the recent discovery by West Ger- 
I man scientists using the world’s 

 largest portable radio telescope puts them in greater concentr a 
Hon than any found before. 

The discovery was m ade by the 
Max Planck Institute of Astrono­ my in Bonn using the 1o8-foot Ef- felsberg radio telescope. 

Dr C hartrand said he had one wish when life is eventually found on another planet: 
The chances are they would be more advanced than we are. I just hope they are sm arter than we are, too, and leave us alone. 
"E very tim e we’ve found a prim itive civilization on E arth, we’ve destroyed it. I hope that doesn't happen to the E arth as a whole."

By STEVE DUNLEAVY 

TOUGH G U Y 
Charles 
Bronson has given his beautiful wife Jill 
Ireland the go-ahead for a sepa­ rate movie career of her own— but it w ont include any sex scenes. 
“ No sex scenes in future m ovies for J ill," Bronson told THE STAR in revealing that he and Jill, after eight years, won’t be co-starring together any more. 
“ I’m not prudish. It s just that 
Jill and I don’t want her involved in that sort of stuff. We discuss sex at home— straight, frank talks with the kids. 
“ But we don’t like sex on the screen. 
“ I have been asked to sim ulate the sex act on screen. I have re­ fused to do it. We both agree we don't like sex up there on the screen. I don’t condemn anyone for doing it, but not us." 
Jill has already turned down one role, the lead in a film called 
Good Luck Miss W'ycoff. She ad­ mits it was too hot to handle. 
Miss Ireland and an actor were to simulate m aking love. 
“ How could I do that to my husband, the man in m y life?’’ she said. 
“ I didn’t even ask C harlie’s advice. I knew what his reaction would have been. 
That would have been a scene all by itself. 
“ Also, I wouldn’t want m y boys to go to school and have their friends say that they saw their mother do that."

For eight years Jill has pain­ stakingly been a fulltime mother to their five children— two by his previous m arriage, two bv hers, and their own five-year-old daugh ter, Zuleika.

I’m not a prude, but we don’t do those explicit scenes on film

That's why I’m so keen about the future challenges." 
Bronson, secure in his booming career, doesn’t feel at all threat ened by J ill’s new ambition.

She s very independent, which is one of the things I like about her

HOUSEWIVES WHO STEAL FOR LOVE 

MOST kleptom aniacs are secure middle-aged housewives who don’t need the things they steal, says a top psychiatrist 
“ They are driven by emotional need,” says Dr 
Jack Chernus, acting chief of psychiatry at Gou­ verneur Hospital, New York. 
"The most common feeling they express is one of not being loved, 
(rf having been slighted 
"T his lack of love occurred in these women's childhoods and it 

 becomes reactivated when they are older. 
“ Stealing helps soothe the wounds o f a childhood in which they missed love." 
Persons with kleptom aniac im pulses should review their child- hoods for exam ples of insults. slight, and lack of love, Dr Cher nus said. 
"If you realize where the im pulse com es from, this will help you overcom e it," he said 

He also advised kleptomania sufferers to think through the con­ sequences of their thefts, includ­ ing possible arrest and publicity, and to avoid places where they get the stealing urge. 
Discussing the problem with a psychiatrist, m inister or the fam i­ ly can also help, he said 
And, he warned, everybody in eluding kleptom aniacs should avoid the "m ild kleptom ania" ot stealing such item s as towels 

 from hotels and paper clips from the office 
He said teenage boys who steal cars for joyrides can often be helped by getting them involved with tile fam ily car and by help­ ing them prepare to be responsi­ ble drivers 
Young girls who steal trinkets from stores, Dr. Chernus said, are expressing love fantasies and can be helped bv discussing these feel­ ings with them. 

“ No secret," he says, “ it s a job. I'm in it for the money.

“ A lot of bankers want in on that kind of action 
They figure they can’t lose 
“ People can identify with the roles I play

I ve played a cop, a businessman, a farm er, a pilot, a boxer. 
“ This is a job for me. and I'm good at it. O kay, so I never win an Oscar. I prefer that Golden 
Globe Award they gave me, nam­ ing me the world film favorite. 
"The exhibitors rank me am ong the top ten. That m eans people like me 
I don't care about Hie critics. I'm no Brando, I'm no

"I don t practice any school of acting 
I think all that business about art is so much rubbish. I in not in m ovies for social reform. 
I’m in it for the money " 
Jill differs 
" I ’m a little selfish because I make them for m yself." she said.

Doctors warn on measles: Children are being vaccinated at wrong age 

TEST YOUR BIBLE KNOWLEDGE '

Moses but grace and ~ carne by 
Jesus Christ

Spirit of God cann1 down in the shape of a —. 
3 
For what is a man profited if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own — 

4 
Jesus cured the blind man with clay made from dirt on the ground and —. 

 a J«*sus said "The Son ot man cometh at an hour when ye — nor " 

From The Complete Bible t^uiz 
Book by Dan Carlm.sk> < Berkley 
Paperback. $1 95>. 

By CH RISTIN A KIRK 

SCIENTISTS believe they have found the cause of recent outbreaks of measles among children who had been vacci­ nated against the disease. 
Studies showed that the vaccine was not as effective when given to babies under 13 months as it was in older children. 
The reason, the scientists found, is that babies a year old or youn­ 

 ger still carry natural antibodies against measles. 
These anti­ bodies, which they receive from their mothers in the womb, fight off the live measles virus when it is given to the child as a vaccine. and lower the child s immunity to the disease 
As the child gets older, these antibodies disappear from his blood and the vaccine becomes more effective. 
The findings have led medical authorities to recommend that 

 doctors delay giving the vaccine until the child is 15 months old. and that those who were vaccinat­ ed before they reached 13 months be revaccinated. 
More than 8o million children have been immunized since the program of vaccinating with live measles virus began in 1963 
The number of measles cases reported in the U.S. has dropped dramatically from 5oo.ooo a year in the pre-vaccine era to about 
35.ooo a year today. 

There has also been a corre­ sponding reduction in the number of cases of encephalitis, an often fatal disease which frequently fol­ lows a case of measles. 
But outbreaks of measles have occurred during the last five years, and they have affected adolescents as well as young chil­ dren. 
One study of an outbreak in 
Santa Clara County, Calif., in 1975 was reported in the January issue of the Journal of the American 
Medical Association. 
There were 93o cases of mea­ sles reported in the county that year, compared with 51 cases in 

I 1974. Two cases of encephalitis oc­ curred, and one was fatal. 
Doctors tested the blood of 465 of the children who had come down with the disease, despite the fact that they all had been vacci­ nated against it. 
The most important finding was that children who were immu­ nized at 12 months had a much lower level of immunity than those vaccinated at 13 months or later. 
"The data suggest that mater­ nally derived antibodies may persist in some 12-month-old in­ fants and interfere with immuni­ zation. the researchers conclud­ ed 
The doctors also noted that the peak incidence of measles has shifted from preschool children to adolescents. 

Robert the lion chases pie in the sky 

The report said: "Susceptible adolescents, many of whom had been unsuccessfully immunized, previously escaped having mea­ sles as young children because of good community control, but ac­ quired the disease when ex­ posed.” 
The doctors involved in the San­ ta Clara study made these recom- mendat ions: 

THIS feathered visitor is clearly nobody's pi­ geon...least of all Robert the lion cub s. 
Robert thought his food was coming air mail when this pigeon alighted on a log in his cage. But some fancy footwork soon put him out of Robert’s reach. 
Which goes to show that all this king of the jungle stuff really is for the birds. 

• Measles immunization should probably be deferred until 14 or 15 months of age. The only exception should be if there is a measles outbreak, in which case children younger than 12 months should be immunized. 
• More importantly, all chil­ dren who were immunized before 
13 months of age, especially those immunized prior to 1974, should be revaccinated the doctors urged: "A serious effort should be made to reim- munize susceptible adolescents before they reach adulthood, when travel or entry to the mili­ tary service may increase their chance of acquiring measles as adults, with its attendant risks and inconveniences.” 
DON’T BE TOO KIND’ TO YOUR KIDS 

DEAR LOIS: 

IT IS important for parents to learn how to deny things to their children, a top psychiatrist said this week 
"A child can learn as much from occasional frustration of his needs as he does from gratifica tion of needs,” said Dr Alfred A 
Messer, of Atlanta, Ga 
"Giving a child everything he wants is not realistic child rear­ ing Where else in life will he be treated so kindly?” 
Dr. Messer gave this advice to parents on their kids: 

• Praise the child’s actions when they merit praise and con­ demn his actions when they are wrong 
It s important to approve or dis­ approve the child s 
"actions" rather than the1 child himself be­ cause every child needs assur­ ance that he is loved regardless of his behavior 
• Exercise your authority whenever the clinid is unable to use his own judgment A young boy might ask permission lo ride his bicycle to school through 

 heavy traffic each day. Use your authority to say "no” because his judgment of the traffic hazards is not valid. 

• Help your child learn to con­ trol his anger. Teach the child that feeling anger is different from acting it. It is better for him to use words to express his anger than to start a fist fight 

If the child has a temper tan­ trum, use mild physical restraint until he "kicks himself out” and regains control of his own behav­ 

 ior Only then can you reason with him. 
• Give privileges as a reward for good behavior and withhold privileges for unacceptable be­ havior This can be a powerful learning device for the child and a good method of discipline for parenLs. 
• Don t feel guilty about using babysitters. Exposing the young to a number of responsible adults and teenagers of different per­ sonalities prepares them for what they will face later in life. 

Lasagna with a difference 

Dip into your magic recipe file and come up with something that tastes Italian and is a diet food for my dieting moth­ er-in-law who thinks she will die of monotony now that her pasta is past. Janet. Beltsville, Md. 

DEAR Janet: Run to the store and buy the ingredients for this dish. Some call it diet Lasagna, I call it Italian Strata. You'll both call it delicious. Here it is: 

Italian Strata 

I pound ground veal or beef, *4 cup minced onion. I 8-ounce can tomato sauce. I teaspoon basil, I teaspoon parsley. ‘ » teaspoon ore­ gano. 4 ounces mozzarella cheese, dash garlic salt, dash pepper, I 
4-ounce can mushrooms, drained, 
I 
IG-ounce package frozen chopped spinach, thawed, 
8 ounces cottage cheese. 
Saute onion and ground meat until onion is transparent. Add to­ mato sauce, basil, parsley, ore­ gano. garlic salt, pepper, and mushrooms. Squeeze liguid from thawed spinach and combine with cottage cheese. Cut mozzarella cheese in strips. 
In 7” x ll” baking dish arrange in layers spinach mixture, meat mixture, then mozzarella cheese. 
Repeat, ending with hard cheese. Bake in 375c oven for 15-2o minutes or until hot and bubbly. 
Recipe serves 4 for dinner. Reci­ pe contains 4*2 limited vegetable allowances and the equivalent of 
24 oum es of cooked protein. 

Boyfriend problem 

DEAR Lois: For the first time in my life I have a real boyfriend and I love him and he loves me 
But i'm afraid that I II lose him if 
I get any fatter. I am 16, and I weigh about 175 
The only time I ever succeeded in losing weight was when 
I pined one group last year and I ost 6 lbs in one week. But I can t seem to lose any more. Please help me before I lose him — C K ., 
Texas. 

DEAR C.K.: Whoa up! I take it from your letter that you only at­ tended one group one week. That won’t help I suggest that you try another weight group (the one you attended does not have a set diet program; look for one that does. I 
Keep your attendance up, and your weight will go down. 
Just remember this: 16-year-old loves are great fun while they last. Enjoy it. but don't think that if you lose weight and you sudden­ ly fall out of love it’s because you're thin. It will probably be be­ cause you're growing up. So lose weight and have a happy boy­ friend!

Ahead of them was a clearing in the woods with a few wooden store­ fronts at the intersection of the road they were on and another one crossing it at right angles 
Three white men — one sitting on a nail keg, another in a rocker, the third propped on the back legs of a stool with his back to a clap­ board wall and his feet on a hitching post—nudged one another and nodded at the line of dusty wa- 
______________________________ 

Chicken George (Ben Vereenj and his wife Matilda (Olivia ('ole! arrive together in Tennessee, the promised land. This time, no white man’s laws will tear them apart. But death awaits . . . 

*ers gons and their passerine boys rolling a 
A cou­ ple of white boys rolling a hoop stopped in their tracks and stared, the hoop rolling on beyond them into the middle of the road, where it twirled a few times and fell 
An elderly black man sweeping off a stoop looked at them im pas sively for a long moment and then broke into a small, slow smile. A large dog that was scratching himself beside a rain barrel paused, leg in the air, to cock his head at them, then went back to scratching 
“ I done to!’ y’all dis here a new settlement, ” said 
Chicken 
George, talking fast “ Dey’s only a hundred or so white folks livm roun' here yet, so even wid jes' our fifteen wagons lef after all dem dat dropped off to settle on de way here, we’se jes’ bout goin’ double de pop lation We se gittin’ in on de ground’ flo’ of a growin' town ” 
“Weel, ain't nothin’ it can do but grow, dais sho',’ said Chicken 
George s boy L'll George without smiling. 
“Jes wait’ll y all sees de prime farmlan dey got.” said his father brightly, rubbing his hands with anticipation 
“ Prob’lv swamp,” muttered

BOOK BONUS PULLOUT 

Li’I George's brother Ashford, wisely not loud enough for his fa­ ther to hear. 
But it was prime—rich and loa­ my. thirty acres of it for every family, scattered on checkerboard plots from the outskirts of town all the way to the white-owned farms that already occupied the best land in Lauderdale County, on the banks of the Hatchie River six miles to the north. 
Many of the white farms were as large as all of their property put together, but thirty acres was thirty more than any of them had ever owned before, and they had their hands full with that. 
Still living in their cramped wa­ gons, the families began grubbing up stumps and clearing brush the next morning 
Soon the furrows had been plowed and their first crops plant­ ed—mostly cotton, some com, with plots for vegetables and a patch for flowers. 
As they set about the next task of sawing down trees and splitting logs to build their cabins, Chicken 
George circulated from one farm to another on his horse, volunteer­ ing his advice on construction and trumpeting how he had changed their lives 

Even among Henning’s white settlers lie boasted about how those he had brought with him were going to help the town grow and prosper, not failing to men lion that his middle son Tom would soon be opening the area’s first blacksmith shop 
One day soon afterward, three white men rode up to Tom s plot as he and his sons were mixing a load of mud with hog bristles to chink the walls of his half built cabin. 
“Which one of you is the black­ smith?” one called from his horse 
Sure that his first customers had arrived even before he could get set up for business, Tom stepped out proudly. 
“We hear you’re figural’ to open a blacksmith shop here in town,” one said. 
“ Yassuh, Been lookin’ fo‘ de bes’ spot to build it Was thinkin’ maybe dat empty lot nex* to de sawmill ifn nobody else got his eye on it.” 
The three men exchanged glances “ Well, boy,” the second man went on. “no need of wasting time, we’ll get right to the point. 
You can blacksmith, that's fine. 
But if you want to do it in this 

 town, you’ll have to work for a white man that owns the shop 
Had you figured on that?’’ 
Such a rage flooded up in Tom that nearly a minute passed be­ fore he could trust himself to speak. “ Nawsuh, I ain't,” he said slowly. 
“ Me an’ my family's free now, we's jes' lookin’ to make our liv­ ing like anybody else, by workin' hard at what we knows to do.” 
He looked directly into the men's eyes. “ If I cain’t own what 
I do wid my own hands, den dis ain’t no place fo’ us.” 
The third white man said, “ lf that’s the way you feel, I speck you’re going to be ridin’ a long way in this state, boy ” 

“Well, we’s used to travehn .” said Tom. “ Ain t wantin’ to cause no trouble nowhere, but I got to be a man I just wisht I could o’ knowed how y’all felt here so my family wouldn’t of troubled y’all by stoppin’ atail ” 

“ Well, think about it, boy," said the second white man “ It s up to you.” 
“ You people got to learn not to let all this freedom talk go to your heads.” said the first man 
Turning their horses around 

 without another word, they rode off. 
When the news went flashing among the farm plots, the heads of each family came hurrying to see Tom. 

“Son," said Chicken George, 
“you’s knowed all yo’ life how white folks is Cain’t you ies’ start out dey way? Den good as you blacksmiths, won t take hardly no time to git em to turn roun .” 

“ All dat travelin’ an’ now pack 
S an’ co again!” exclaimed Ma­ rfa “ Don’t do dat to yo’ family, son' ” 
Irene joined the chorus “Tom. please' Tse jes’ tired! Tired*” 

But 
Tom's face was grim 
“Things don't never git better lf*ss‘n you makes ’em better'” he said 
“Ain’t stayin’ nowhere I can't do what a free man got a right to do 
Ain’t axin' nobody else to go wid us, but we packin’ our wagon an’ leavin' tomorrow .’* 
" I’m comm’, too'" said Ashford angrily. 

That night Tom went out walk­ ing by himself, weighed down by guilt at the new hardship he was imposing upon his family. 

He played back in his mind the

The Star takes up the story where TV left off 

By Alex Holey 

THEY stood, ail of them, on the ridge, and looked around at the rolling green hills that stretched as far as the eye could see 
“Dis is it?” asked Tom. 
“ De promised Ian ?" asked Matilda. 
“Where dem pigs an’ watermelons poppin' out'n de groun asked one of the children, as Chicken George reined his horse to a halt. 
They stood there a long time, just looking Then they got back up on their wagons, and went on down the rutted road through the woods until Chicken George signaled them to stop 

THE TV serialization off Alex Haley’s book Roots caught everybody’s imagination. An estimated 13o million people watched the dramatized story of Hal­ ey’s ancestors, starting with the young African boy 
Kunta Kinte, snatched from his home by slave-trad­ ers and sold to a Southern plantation owner. We saw 
Kunta’s only daughter, Kizzy, torn from her parents and raped by her new owner, and met Chicken 
George, the son of the brutal assault. After the Civil 
War, Chicken George, now getting old, arrives In 
Tennessee to start a new life with his wife Matilda, his blacksmith son Tom, daughter-in-law Irene, and several wagon loads of family and friends. That’s where the TV series ended. What happened next? 
READ ON. . . . 

Tom shows guts and ingenuity.. .Cli 

FROM PRECEDING PAGE ordeal they had all endured in the wagons, rolling for weeks on end 
. . . and he thought of something 
Matilda had said often: 
“You search hard enough in sump’n bad, you’s jes’ liable to find sump'n good.” 
When the idea struck him, he kept walking for another hour, let­ ting the plan become a picture in his mind Then he strode quickly back to the wagon where his fam­ ily was sleeping and went to bed. 
In the morning, Tom told his brothers James and Lewis to build temporary lean-tos for Ir­ ene and the children to sleep in, for he would need the wagon. 
As the family stood around watching him in amazement— 
Ashford with rising disbelief and fury—he unloaded the heavy anvil with brother Virgil’s help, and mounted it atop a newly sawed stump. By noon he had set up a makeshift forge. 
With everyone still staring, he next removed the canvas top of the wagon, then its wooden sides, leaving the bare flatbed, on which he now went to work with his heaviest tools. 
Gradually they began to per­ ceive the astounding idea that 
Tom was turning into a reality. 
By the end of that week. Tom drove right through town with his rolling blacksmith shop, and there wasn’t a man, woman or child who didn t stand there gaping at the anvil, forge, and cooling tub, with racks holding a neat array of blacksmithing tools, all mounted sturdily on a wagon bed rein­ forced with heavy timbers 
Nodding politely at all the men he met—white and black—Tom asked if they had blacksmithing jobs he could do at reasonable rates. 

 gun. 

 head for them, and everybody laughed as hard as he did. 
‘T se surprised dat hat don't fit,” cracked L’il George, “dumb as you is to try it on in dat sto’.” 
Ashford, of course, got so angry that he threatened — emptily — to “go down dere an’ stuff it down dat peckerwood’s throat.” 
However little use the white community had for them—and vice versa—Tom and the others knew very well that the town’s tradesmen could hardly contain their elation at the brisk increase in business they’d been responsi­ ble for. 
Though they made most of their own clothes, raised most of their own food, and cut most of their own lumber, the quantities of nails, corrugated tin, and barbed wire they bought over the next couple of years testified to the rate at which their own communi­ ty was growing. 
With all their houses, barns, sheds and fences built by 1874, the family—led by 
M atilda- turned its attention to an enter­ prise they considered no less im­ portant to their welfare: the con­ struction of a church to replace the makeshift bush arbors that had been serving as their place of worship. 
It took almost a year, and much of their savings, but when 

Within days, his services were being requested at more and more farms around the new set­ tlement, for no one could think of a good reason why a black man shouldn't do business from a wa- 

By the time they realized that he was doing far better with his rolling shop than he ever could have done with a stationary one. 
Tom had made himself so indis­ pensable around town that they couldn’t afford to raise any objec­ tions even if they’d wanted to. 
But they didn t really want to, because Tom seemed to them the 

*lf only 
Mammy 
Kizzy could be here with us* 

 kind of man who did his job and minded his own business, and thev couldn’t help respecting that. 
In fact, the whole family soon es­ tablished themselves as decent 
Christian folk who paid their bills and kept to themselves—and 
“stayed in their place," as OI’ 
George Johnson said a group of white men had put it in a conver­ sation he’d overheard down at the general store 
But OI’ George, the white man who, with his wife Martha, had become virtually part of Chicken 
George s family, was treated by the townsfolk just as other mem­ bers of the family were 
He was shunned social ly, kept waiting in stores till ail the other white customers had been taken care of, even in­ formed once by a merchant that he d “bought’’ a hat that be d tried on and put back on the shelf when he found it was too small. 
He told the family about it lat­ er, perching the hat atop his 

 rus of The Old Hugged Cross again—led by Matilda, looking more radiant than 
Chicken 
George had ever seen her—the congregation dried their eyes and filed out past the preacher, pump­ ing his hand and slapping him on the back. 
Retrieving their picnic baskets on the porch, they spread sheets on the lawn and proceeded to rel­ ish the fried chicken, pork chop sandwiches, deviled eggs, potato salad, cole slaw, pickles, corn­ bread, lemonade, and so many cakes and pies that even L’il 
George was gasping for breath when he finished the last slice. 
As they all sat chatting, or strolled around—the men and boys in coat and tie, the older women all in white, the girls in bright-colored dresses with a rib­ bon at the waist—Matilda watched misty-eyed as her brood of grandchildren ran about tire­ lessly playing tag and catch. 
Turning finally to her husband and putting her hand on his, gnarled ana scarred with game­ cock scratches, she said quietly, 
“ I won t never forget dis day, 
George. We done come a long way since you first come courtin' me wid dat derby hat o’ yours. 
“Our fam’ly done growed up an’ had chilluns of dey own. an’ de I^awd seen fit to keep us all to- gedder. De onliest thing I wish is your Mammy Kizzy could be here to see it wid us.” 
Eyes brimming. 
Chicken 
George looked back at her. “She lookin’, baby. She sho’ is!” 

PROMPTLY at the noon hour on 
Monday, during their break from the fields, the children started fil­ ing into church for their first day of school indoors. 
For the past two years, ever since she came to town after being one among the first grad­ uating class from Lane College in 
Jackson. Tennessee, Sister Carrie 
White had been teaching out un­ der the bush arbors, and this use of the church was a great occa­ sion. 

Tom, his brothers, and their boys had finished building the last pew, and Irene’s beautiful white handwoven cloth—emblazoned with a purple cross—had been draped over the pulpit in front of the 
$25o stained glass window they’d ordered from Sears Roe­ buck. every OTR? agreed that the 
New 
Hope 
Colored 
Methodist 
Episcopal Church was well worth the time, effort and expense it represented 
So many people attended tne service that first Sunday—just about every black person within twenty miles who could walk or be carried—that the crowd spilled out the doors and windows and across the lawn surrounding it. 
But nobody had any trouble hearing every word of tne ringing sermon delivered by the Rever­ end Sylus Henning, a former slave of Dr D C Henning, an Illi­ nois Central Railroad executive with extensive land holdings around town. 
In the course of his oration, L’il 
George whispered to Virgil that the Reverend seemed to be under the* impression that he was Dr. 
Henning, but no one within ear­ shot would have dared to question the fervor of his preaching 
After the last heartrending cho 

The New Hope CME stewards— 
Chicken George, Tom and his brothers—had contributed the money to buy pencils, tablets and primers on “ readin , writin an’ 
’rithmetic.” 
Since she taught all the children of school age at the same time, in her six grades Sister Carrie had pupils ranging from five to fif­ teen, including Tom s oldest five: 
Maria Jane, who was twelve; El­ len; Viney; 
L’il Matilda; and 
Elizabeth, who was six. 

Tom and his wife Irene (played on TV by Georg Stanford Brown and 
Lynne Moody, above! found the new promised land had its problems too. 

 fell in love with John Toland, a newcomer to Henning who had gone to work sharecropping on the six-hundred-acre farm of a white family out near the Hatchie 
River. 

Young Tom, next in line, began the year after that, and then Cyn­ thia, the youngest. 
By the time Cynthia was grad­ uated in 1883, Maria Jane had dropped out, gotten married, and f ven birth to her first child, and lizabeth, who was the best stu­ dent in the family, had taught their father Tom Murray how to write his name and had even be­ come his blacksmithing book keeper. 
He needed one, for by this time he nad become so successful with his rolling blacksmith shop that he had also built a stationary one 
—without a murmur of objection 
—and was among the more pros­ perous men in town. 
About a year after Elizabeth went to work for her father, she 

She had met him in town one day at the general store and been impressed, she told her mother 
Irene, not only by his good looks and muscular build but also by his dignified manner and obvious in­ telligence. 
He could even write a little, she noticed, when he signed for a re­ ceipt 
Over the next several weeks, during the walks she d take with him in the woods once or twice each week, she also found out that he was a young man of fine repu­ tation, a churchgoer, who had am­ bitions of saving up enough to start a farm of his own, and that he was as gentle as he was strong 
It wasn't until they’d seen each other regularly for almost two months—and had begun to talk se­ cretly about marriage—that Tom 
Murray, who had known about them from the start, ordered her to stop skulking around and bring him home from the church the following Sunday. 
Elizabeth did as she was told. 
John Toland couldn’t have been friendlier or more respectful when he was introduced to Tom 
Murray, who was even more taci­ 

 turn than usual, and excused him­ self after only a few minutes of painful pleasantries. 
After John Toland left, Eliza­ beth was called by Tom Murray, who said sternly: “ It s plain to see from de way you act roun’ dat boy dat you's stuck on im. You two got anythin’ in mind?” 
“What you mean, Pappy?” she stuttered, flushing hotly. 
"Gettin’ married! Dat’s on your mind, ain’t it?” 
She couldn’t speak. 
"You done tol’ me. Well, I d like to give you my blessin's, 
’cause I wants you to be happy much as you does. He seem like a good man—but I can’t let you hitch up wid im." 
Elizabeth looked at him uncomprehending iy 
"He too high-yaller. He could nigh bout pass fo’ white—jes’ not quite. He ain’t fish or fowl Y’un- nerstan’ what Tse say in’? He too light fo’ black folks, too dark fo’ white folks.

 ed, seizing her around the shoul­ ders “Grandmammy!” She put her head to her chest and lis­ tened There was still a heartbeat. 
But two days later it stopped 
Chicken George didn t cry. But there was something heartbreak­ ing about his stoniness, the dead­ ness of his eyes. 
From that day on. no one could remember him ever smiling again or saying a civil word to anyone. 
He and 
Matilda had never seemed really close — but when she died, somehow his own warmth died with her. 

And he began to shrink, dry up, grow old almost overnight — not turning feeble and weak-minded but hard and mean-tempered. 

Refusing to live anymore in the cabin he had shared with Matilda, he began to roost with one son or daughter after another until both he and they were fed up. when old gray-headed 
Chicken 
George moved on. 

When he wasn’t complaining, he d usually sit on the porch th the rocker he took along with him and stare fiercely out across the fields for hours at a time. 

He had just turned eighty-three 
— having cantankerously refused to touch a bite of the birthday cake that was baked for him — and was sitting late in the winter of 189o in front of the fire at his 

 eldest granddaughter 
Ma na 
Jane s house. 

She had ordered him to sit still and rest his bad leg win Ie she hur­ ried out to the adjacent field with her husband’s lunch 

When she returned as quickly as she could, she found him lying on the hearth, where he'd dragged himself after falling into the fire. 
Maria Jane s screams brought her husband running. 

The derby hat, scarf and sweater were smoldering, and 
Chicken George was burned horri­ bly from his head to his waist 
I^ate that night he died. iNearly everyone black in Hen ning attended his funeral, dozens of them his children, grandchil­ dren, or great-grandchildren 

Standing there by the grave as he was lowered into the ground beside 
Matilda, his son 
L'il 
George leaned to Virgil and whis­ pered "Pappy so tough speck he wouldn't o’ never died natural.” 

Virgil turned and looked sadly at his brother. “ I loved ’im,” he said quietly. "You too, an’ all us ” 

“ Cos we did,” said 
L’il 
George. “Nobody couldn't stan’ livin’ wid de cockadoodlin’ ol’ ras­ cal, an’ look now at everybody snifflin’ ’cause he gone!”

Brave baby defies odds as she fights rare heart disease 

The world’s ] first drive-in funeral heme 

TMK world's first drive-in funeral parlor has opened in the U.S.— and it is proving a big success with mourners in a hurry 

They can now pay their last re­ spects by driving slowly past a window in the funeral home in 
New Roads, La., and viewing the coffins of their loved ones 

They can also lean out and sign a book of condolence 

Funeral home owner Alvin Ver rette said: 
“ We wanted something for working people who didn't have time to dress, but wanted to show their sympathy. 

“ It’s so nice to know someone cares “ 
Verrette has introduced another revolutionary idea for funeral homes — he's banished the color black 
He greets mourners wearing a white jacket, slacks and tie and a golden shirt—which fits into the color scheme of the funeral home and hearses 
Verrette explained 
“ Black tends to bring people down.”

BABY Kristen Di Marino has been fighting to stay alive since the day she was bom 
But now the plucky two year-old is facing a life-or- death operation to repair a rare heart disorder. 
“ It’s her last hope,” her mother Mrs Andrea Di Mari­ no told THK STAR this week “ But there is no guaran­ tee she will even survive the surgery 
“ The doctors say the heart disorder would have al­ ready killed most other children. But she too will die in a few months if she doesn't have the operation.” 
Kristen was bom with three major heart defects — reversal of the great arteries, a malformed valve and a hole in the upper chamber. 
She suffered her first heart attack when she was only r. 
^ .w 
. 
. four months old Late last year r sh*' underwent an o p e r a te in heart wh,ch * vem from h S shoulder 
* ^ was redirected into her heart to provide more oxy genated blood 

Her parents, who live in Bethel, 
Conn., have been told that her heart is not growing at the same rate as her body. 

Doctors at 
Yale New 
Haven 
Hospital, Conn . say this must be corrected or she will die of congestive heart failure 

Heart specialist Dr. William 
Hellenbrand said 
"This disease strikes only about one in 1oo,ooo children ” 

Kristen is scheduled to undergo the complex surgery at the Mayor 
Clinic in Rochester, Minn , rn mid April Mayo is one of the few hospitals with the medical facili­ ties and know how to perform it. 
Doctors have given her only a 
5o percent chance of surviving the operation. But if successful. Kris­ ten will be able to live a normal, healthy life. 
“ It is such a shame she has this problem." said her father, Thom­ as, a 25-year old school teacher 
“She has spent most of her life in the hospital, but never cries or complains ” 
Because of her weak heart, 
Kristen is very susceptible to in­ fection She has twice contracted pneumonia from what would have been no more than a light cold for other children 
“ I’m on edge with her all the tim e.” Mrs DiMarino said “ I get terrified if Kristen even gets a sniffle ” 
She has one other child — a three year-old son. Brian, and is expecting a baby in March 
Brian has never had a sick day in his life, according to his par ents, and doctors have assured 
Andrea her next baby should also bt* healthy. 

The family's medical insurance will cover the cost of the surgery 
But a local newspaper has launched a fund raising campaign to help find the money for the Di- 
Marino's travel and living expen ses m Minnesota 

Nuttiest tax laws in history 

HOT nuts are a taxable item in 
California, but you can get away tax free if the nuts are cold. 
This is just one of the bizarre taxes that have been levied on 
Americans. 
The Internal Revenue Service in Washington. DC., reminds us that there is a tax on both adulter­ ated and renovated butter . . . and a marijuana tax which netted the government $153,ooo rn 1974 
Explanation: lf they can't nail you tor buying the weed, they can get you for not paying the tax. 
Crazy taxes can be traced as far back as 1776 In those days in 
Georgia, there were taxes on marriages, christenings, hogs­ heads. deaths, and slaves. 
Meanwhile, in 
Massachusetts there’s a tax on corset laces bul not on 
Halloween costumes 
There’s also a tax on bottles of holy water, but clerical collars are tax-free. 
Hunting is taxed in most U.S. states through licensing The state of California says that if a hunter shoots another hunter, he could lose his license That is, unless the hunter can prove that the bul- let ricocheted off something. 

 sa wi vs. ill I 

HERE are a couple of ideas if you’re inter­ ested in pleasant scents. 
Abe Shelton, of Brooklyn. N Y. writes: “ If you want your room to have a pleasant odor, put a couple of drops of a scented oil. such as musk oil, on your light bulb, and it will freshen up the area. 
Repeat the process about once a week.” lx)ts of people use soap for a sachet, but Jane Jordan of Ann 
Arbor, Mich, says that doing this can also prolong the life of your soap 
Jane says: “ If you unwrap your soap and leave it in the drawer for a while, exposure to the air will make the soap much harder. 
“ When you use it in your show­ er, it will dissolve slower, last longer and save you money.” 

Doggone clean 

LISA SENATORE, also of Brook­ lyn, N Y., has some ideas for washing your dog and your hair. 
She says: “ Wash your favorite perfume into your hair, and it will be shiny and fragrant. 
“ When you wash your dog. add a little vinegar to the dog s coat, and he or she won t have that dog­ gy smell ” 

Money saver 

TOILET paper can really cost you if you're not careful. 
Alice Kuebler. of Whitestone, 
N Y., writes: “ When my daughter grabs a hold of the toilet tissue, she uses half a roll in one sitting 
“ At 32 cents a roll, a trip to the bathroom can be costly 
“ So, before putting the paper on the roller you should flatten the cardboard tube, and it will supply only a few sheets at a time." 

Best value 

WHILE we’re at it, Alistair Con­ way of Madison, N.H., points out that some toilet paper is two ply while other is single-sheet 
“ The two-ply usually has about 
5oo sheets per roll, compared with the single-ply which has about I,* 
(KH) sheets per roll,” says Alistair. 
“ It s better for your sewer and your pocketbook to get single sheets.”

AMNESTY IS A REAL JOKE FOR DODGER 
PRESIDENT C arter’s amnesty for Vietnam draft resisters won t have any effect on bearded Tom 
Peerbolt 
He simply told his local draft board that ne tiad no intention of serving in Vietnam —- and he got away with it 

He made no attempt to have himself declared a conscientious objector. He did not flee to Cana­ da or Sweden 

He just stayed home in Holland. 
Mich., mid lived his life as usual 
Peerbolt, 26, said “ I rippt*d up 

 my draft card in 197o and told the board I would not obey the Se lee tive Service laws 
“ I never showed up for Army physicals. I don I think they ever classed me as a draft dodger bt cause I never received a formal induction notice ” 

Julie Newmar invents to cheeky give new 

The Patent Office version of Julie's pantyhose: straight out of the 189os,'’ she laughed. 
“ It’s 

A model wearing regular pantyhose (left) and then trying on Julie's '‘cheeky derriere relief.” 

 women a lift 

By M EREDITH CHAPLIN 
LEGGY actress Julie Newmar has hit on a cheeky new way to help American w om en shape up. 
And she’s convinced that once it reaches the nation’s stores, it’ll m ake the bottom drop right out of the traditional pantyhose m arket. 
For Julie has invented a daring new pantyhose with, she says, “ cheeky derriere relief ’ She told 
THE STAR this week: “ The design makes you look m ore youthful because a seam at the back rounds and delineates the fanny and m akes it look like you have nothing on. 
“ It looks as if you have been exercising all your life,” added the 41-year-old beauty, who played the alluring Cat Woman in TV’s Batman series. 
The U.S. P atent Office in Washington D C ., has already issued Julie with Patent No. 4.oo.1 
o94 for her invention. “ And you should see the picture the draftsm an drew of the pantyhose.” she giggled. “ It’s straight out of the 189os ’ 
Ju lie’s pantyhose are not on sale yet, because so far only six pairs have been m ade—by her dressm aker. “ I’m waiting for the right company who will prom ote them in the proper way,” she said. 
“ It is such a practical idea that it can be used in the cheapest pantyhose, and the most expen­ sive ones. The seam at the back is slightly gath­ ered, and that lifts everything up. That naturaliz­ es you, and m akes you look younger.” 
The patent, worded by 
New 
York agent 
Charles F. Baxley, puts it m ore m atter-of-factly. 
Referring to the sm all num bers on the drawing 
(top left), which a re guidelines for all the fea­ tures of the pantyhose, it reads: 
"It is a prim e objective of this invention to produce a cheeky relief for the w earer’s derriere 
19. Toward this objective an elastic shaping band 
21 (substantially m ore elastic than the fabric from which the pantyhose is m ade and typically of the sam e m aterial as a conventional waist band) is connected to the rear panty portion 17. 
“ It extends from the vicinity of the crotch zone 16 to the vicinity 22 of the elastic waist en­ circling band 13. The elastic shaping band 21 fits between the w earer’s buttocks 23, 24, to accen­ tuate their relief and to give the derriere 19 a cheeky appearance.” 
Agent Baxley is im pressed with the design He told THE STAR: 
“ I have noted since I’ve worked for Miss N ew m ar that advertisem ents for ladies underw ear rarely show the rear view. 
That is because m ost panty hose with built in control flatten the back like a board. 
“ There really is a need for Miss Newmar s contribution. She s brilliant.” 
Julie said that when she wore the stockings on stage last sum m er she got reviews applauding her beautiful legs. “ One review er said I had the most beautiful legs this side of heaven,” she said. 
The pantyhose, tradem arked Nudem ar, are not the actress's first design. l^ist year she cam e up with a nude-look bras­ siere, and patented that. But right now she s more interested in prom oting her pantyhose 
“ I designed them because I guess my reputa­ tion dem anded it. “ My legs were once insured for $1 million and I have to live up to that reputation. 
“ But actually they look better on someone whose legs are not as athletic as m ine.”

Ii S. will beat big-city congestion, smog and gas shortages, warns a leading economist.

Rail system s are energy was­ ters and "inferior" transportation when com pared to the auto, said 
Dr. l.ave, an associate professor econom ics at the University of 
California. Dr. Lave said rail sys­ tem s have little to offer the com ­ m uter, over his own car. 
“ They’re not as fast for most kinds of trips, don’t give door-to-

Students build real airplane in the classroom 

A 
TEACHER who believes in 
“ learning by doing” is doing just that with his students. He’s teach­ ing them about flying an airplane bv having them build full-size planes right in class. 
“ I show them how to build an airplane from scratch,” says Joe 
Weber oi 
Willowbrook 
High 
School in Villa Park, 111. 
Situ e Wcher first introduced tin* course in 197o, his students have built two planes and are working on a third 
Their current project is a two passenger, open cockpit, high wing Piet input Air C am per, with a 1941 65 horsepower Franklin en­ gine 
It should sell for (^proxi­ m ately $3,ooo. 
Welter, who had never built a plane before his course, said: “ I try to gi t .students to have pride in their work, so ifs not sloppy. 
After all. if s someone’s life that s at stake once ifs up in the air.” 
CARTER BIBLE QUO TE 
•SHOCKING’ 

PRESIDENT C arter didn't give the inaugural address he wanted to give. His staff wouldn't let him 
The 
President revealed the squabble between him and his ad­ visers during a speech to the Na­ tional P rayer Breakfast in Wash­ ington. 
And he continued to insist he had been right, and his staff — which had felt Americans would resent what he planned to say — had been wrong. 
The inaugural address C arter delivered was based on a quota tion from the Bible’s Book of Mi- cah. But C arter originally wanted to start with the following quota­ tion from 
Second 
Chronicles 
(7:14 >: 

“ If my people which are called by my nam e shall humble them selves and pray and seek my fact and turn from their wicked ways, then I will hear from Heaven and will forgive their sins and will heal their land.” 

C arter adm itted his staff w a; appalled when they read the quo tat ion: 
“ They cam e to me en m asse and said, “ The people wi ’ not understand. 
Ifs as though you, being elected President, are condem ning the other people of the country — putting yourself in the position of Solomon and ‘jay ing that ail 
Am ericans are wicked.’ ” 

The President said he stuck with the quotation through two 

President Carter: He didn’t want to change.

Howard 
Hughes and me: by Jane Russell 

STAR GOSS 

 opera star Brenda Dickson, TV’s 
Young And The Restless, and husband Dr. 
Robert Rifkin, enjoy night in Hollywood. 

JANE RUSSELL, 55, who is wearing better than most of her contemporar­ ies, is in danger of losing her $5o,ooo-a- year from the estate of HOWARD 
HUGHES. 
She received that sum since the termina­ tion of her film contract with the billion­ aire 25 years ago — on condition she never talked about her relationship with him. 
But now she is going to break her silence in an autobiography for New York publish­ ing house Simon And Schuster. 
A Summa Corporation official — the company is still handling the affairs of their former hermit-like boss — tells me: 
“The contract was still in effect at the time of his death and the payments are continuing But if she writes about him the matter will be reviewed.” 
New phone ‘hotline' helps people find a cure for their hang-ups over sex 

A SEX hotline has been set up by a team of psychologists to help people with intim ate sex­ ual problems. 
The service iii-run by the New 
England Institute for Human Sex­ uality in Boston, Mass., and it has already received pleas for help from all over the country Callers have ranged from 
14-year-old girls to men in their 7os. 
“There are a lot of fears and myths about sex in people's minds," said Dr. Peter Wish, ex­ ecutive director of the Institute. 
“What we are offering them is the chance simply to pick up the telephone and talk openly and confidentially to someone who is experienced in human sexuality problems ” 
The hotline, run by four volun­ teer psychology graduates, start­ ed late last year Dr Wish said: 
“ I am amazed at the response there has been in such a short time." 
He added 
* There are many people in America today who are very unhappy and depressed about sexual problems This caus­ es marital problems, because they are very resistent to talking to anyone about them What we are now trying to do is to bring sex out of the closet 
“ We do not give any specific therapy over the telephone 
In­ stead what we try to do is give people some support by listening lf necessary we try to persuade them to get the appropriate help, whet lier it be reading a particular type of book on sex or advising them to seek therapy from a clin­ ic or agency. 
“Our job really is just to break the ice We don’t have set an­ swers to cover all the problems but we do try to point them in the right direction to find a solution 

By ROSS GREGOR 

“ A great many of the caus we receive are extremely intimate but the volunteers have been trained to handle them in a very intimate and confidential way.” 
Dr. Wish said the hotline was being used by as many men as women. The calls covered a whole host of problems, he said, includ­ ing sexual dysfunction, masturba-' lion, transvestism and impotence. 
Dr Wish told THE STAR “The most common problem among men is sexual dysfunction (pre­ mature ejaculation). 
“We try to explain to them that this is not abnormal and that an easily arousable male who had rushed sexual experiences at an early age can end up with the problem simply because of habit 

“These men are usually afraid that they're going to continually fail and not satisfy their partners, but we tell them that sex is not an 
Olympic event and that their problem can be treated it thev take the time to seek help Worry­ ing and getting uptight about it does not help, 

“ In women the most common problem is the lack of an orgasm 
“ Again, we explain that this does not make them abnormal and that recent extensive studies have shown that the majority of women, in fact, do not get an or gasm with sexual intercourse, and nave to revert to other sexual sti­ mulation to achieve their desire 
“ A lot of these women think I they are inadequate and if they I are really hung up about it then we suggest that they go for sex therapy." 
Dr. Wish said the hotline was operating only once a week, but it was receiving calls from as far away as Hawaii. 

“That speaks for itself as to the crying need there is to help thou­ sands of unhappy, frustrated indi­ viduals." he said 

Jane, who once boasted the most famous bosom in Hollywood, has rigidly upheld the condition. But now, with Hughes dead, she feels morally and legally free to talk about their professional and private life together. 
As Archie Bunker, he may be a bigot. 
But in real life CARROLL O'CONNOR has a heart of gold . . . . so much so that mem­ bers of St. Genesins Church in Rome have presented him with a special charitable award.

Talented ALAN ALDA of M*A*S*H. who really cares about his acting, is to play the role of CARYL CHESSMAN who was on death row in California for 12 years in an 
NBC TV film 
Director FRANCIS FORD COPPOLLA's sister TALIA SHIRE, co-star of 
Rocky, will play the doomed con­ vict’s attorney. 
GEORGE C. SCOTT's real hero is not General Patton or any of the characters he has played. It s 
New York throat specialist WIL­ 
LIAM READER who, he insists, keeps Scott’s gravel-voice talk­ ing 
Scott tells how the physician op­ erated on his throat during World 
War II, when he was hit by shell shrapnel. 
"Now you know why I use him 
— he’s a’ miracle man who kept my raspy old voice box intact.” he says.

Alice Faye after soap opera role 

MOVIE aueen Alice Faye, once 
Holly wooers top box office attrac­ tion. wants to appear in soap op­ eras on TV. 

& 

‘ Heaven knows. I don’t need the money," Alice said from her lush 
Palm 
Springs, 
Calif., me “ But I wouldn’t mind get­ ting back into the swim." 
Alice, who is married to band­ leader Phil Harris, made her last film State Fair, in 1967. She re­ tired as one of the top actresses of all time 
Now shes getting fed up with retirement and admits: “ I miss the* excitement of acting 
“Given the right opportunity, 
I d like to try soap operas They used to be trite, but nowadays they are quite sophisticated ."

A TELEPHONE that places your calls for you, tells you how long you’ve been talking, gives you the time and date, counts your money and wakes you in the morning is coming on the market this spring. 
The phone is being developed by Phone Devices 
Corp., a Chicago company that was formed after the courts broke the Bell system ’s monopoly on produc­ tion of telephone equipment. 
Richard Marin, an executive of Phone Devices 
Corp., wouldn’t release advance pictures of the Maid 
Phone but he did say it would have features similar to the firm ’s Figure Phone, shown at right. 
The Figure Phone has a built in calculator that can be operated independently or while you’re talking 

It also shows the time and, ev­ ery seven seconds, the date. 
These appear on a lighted strip above the five rows of pushbut tons. 

AND THIS ONE CAN DO MATH 

 elude an alarm clock, a tape dis- gure rlock, 

 play for the calculator, a tim er tor long distance calls, and a smoke detector that calls an alarm to the fire department 
Phone Devices Corp. offered 
Figure Phones during the Christ­ mas season and they were big sellers at about $2oo each. 
Marin said they were popular gifts for busy executives who 

 don’t like having their desks clut­ tered with a separate calculator. 
The company offers 
Figure 
Phones in most large cities o f the 
United Static and in Venezuela, 
England, Italy and the Mideast. 
OH millionaires of the Mideast and Venezuela have been prime customers for 
Figure 
Phones, 
Marin said 
TELEVISION MAKES JACQUES A DULL BOY 

SKIMPY breakfasts and too much 
TV are making slow learners of 
French schoolchildren. 
Government studies say the lack of morning nourishment is one of the leading causes of prob­ lems the Gallic youngsters have in school. 
Other causes were that the chil­ dren do not get enough sleep— be­ cause they watch television late into the night—and that classes are too long. 
Classes in French schools last 
55 minutes, though doctors say a 

 six-year-old has only a 25-minute attention span, a 1o-year-old 4o minutes and an adolescent 5o min­ utes. 

Rector Henri Gauthier, senior official in the Education Ministry, has proposed more variety in school schedules and teaching methods as a way of helping them learn more. 

Hut he says the breakfast and sleeping problems must be ban­ dlet] by parents. 

French children generally have 

 the same breakfasts as their par­ ents—coffee In some homes, it ’n accompanied by a roll or piece of bread with butter That’s all. 

And though children are be­ lieved to need IO hours sleep. Hie government’s studies showed 3o per cent of French children 7 and 
8 and 7o per cent of those 13 and 
14 years old. don’t get that much. 

'Hie problem, according to the studies, is that many French par­ ents simply don’t know how much sleep their children need 

THE bizarre world of show business is epitomized by the current feud between super- star STEVE MCQUEEN and his next door neighbor KEITH 
MOON of The Who rock band 

It appears the touchy McQueen telephoned the police when he saw the eccentric drummer par­ ading in his Beverly Hills back­ yard. wearing a full Nazi storm- trooper’s regalia. 
Moon retaliated by having car­ 

 penters build a ramp so he can hurtle — Kvel Kneivel-style — over an 18-ft. fence on a motorcy­ cle into McQueen's garden. 
Watch this column for develop­ ments! Anything can happen.

Stroll into summer with this bandeau bikini 

ONE of the new looks for the summer of ‘77 is this bandeau bikini in softly sueded Caprolah nylon simplex. 
It has an ad­ justable side- tied brief and bandeau bra that hug the fig­ ure. 
Made by Bob­ bie 
Brooks it comes in sizes 
3-13. and retails for $21 in most stores. 

Loch Ness-ki Monster 
THE LOCH NESS monster may have a cousin—in Russia. A member of the Soviet Geographic Society, A Pechersky, told the newspaper 
Komsomolskaya Pravda that he and his son saw a giant snako-iike creature in Lake Kok-Koi in the Dzambul area of southern Kazakhstan 
Biologist, Dr. Sergei Kumov, an expert on evolution told the newspaper it would be wrong to dismiss the idea of a monster.

Too skinny? ll golden on the 

SKIN N Y people have a harder time putting on weight than fat people have taking it off, according to Ameri­ ca’s most successful diet doctor, Robert C. Atkins. 
The second part of THE ST A R ’S exclusive five-part ex­ cerpt of Or. Atkins' newest book, Dr. Atkins’ Superener­ gy Diet, includes a food, vitamin and mineral program to make you feel better than ever before while helping you achieve your proper weight and look your best. 

 rules to put pounds and boost your energy 
Dr. Atkins: How to gain weight. 

★ 
★ 
★ 
I OFTEN meet attractive, slim people who tell me “ Dr Atkins, I don’t need your diet. I’m skinny " 
Or. “ I don’t have to diet, I never gain weight.” 
Such statements really concern me There is a misconception that slim people do not have to diet, and that leads them to more im­ proper eating habits than any oth­ er group. 
Some want to gain weight 
When they see their overweight friends getting fat from eating sweets, thin people often make the big mistake of filling them­ selves up with empty calories, which are in fact anti nutrients 
Slim people may use sugar in huge quantities, unaware that this is what prevents proper nutrition from filling out their slim frames 
Other thin people try to gain weight by drinking malted milks and eating a lot of desserts and sugary junk’ food 
They wonder why they don't gain weight, with out realizing what all those sugars and starches might be doing to them inside 
It rarely occurs to the slim that their diet might bt* the cause of fatigue or other unexplained health symptoms 
My Diet #2 is for those of you who are tired, or depressed, oc have other diet related problems and happen to be underweight 
This diet was not primarily de­ signed to help you gain weight, but for giving you energy 
Chances are that it will help you gain weight, but there are some who will not put on a single pound 
Believe it or not. it is usually harder to get an under weight person to put on weight than it is to get a fat person to take weight off 
Unfortunately, the diet I consid er the best diet for superenergy 
(l)ic*t kl. in last week’s STAID is not good for thin people Thin pen pie don’t seem to tolerate Diet kl because they do not have the fat reserves to mobilize a ready food supply. 
The underweight person will be forced to burn up his vital tissue proteins on Diet kl. something that no dieter should ever do 
Suppose you are fatigued un derweight. but free of any known disease except for a possible sus pinon of low blood sugar How do you change your diet ’ 
Here are the basic principles of my Diet #2 
• Your new diet must be higher in calories than your present one, otherwise you would not tx* likely to put on the desired weight 
• All your calories must consist

FRUIT JUICE—limit to less than a glass per day.

FRUIT—apples, pears, oranges, grapes, and cher­ ries, facing sweeter, are allowed In small quantities. 
Alc tons, berries, bananas, avocado are all preferable. 

MILK—no name than two cups for an adult, three for a child. Yogurt and buttermilk would be included 
Id ibis comb. Be aware of the possibility you may have a lactose deficiency, especially lf diarrhea follows milk-drinking If you do, milk should be avoided. 
SNACKS—popcorn (homemade only), fried pork rinds, whole grain wafers, sugarless cookies, corn chips, mbs, seeds. 

ALCOHOL—wine in cooking. Otherwise your limit should he two drinks per day. 
You should not eat any sugar. This includes sugary desserts, Jams and preserves, sugared sob drinks, can­ dy, cookies, cora syrup, dextrose, honey, catsup, sweet relish. 
Do not eM white flour or aay food from which fiber or bran has been removed. 

 of foods which contain other im­ portant nutrients, and very little should be of the empty calorie, antinutrient variety, such as sug­ ar, refined flour, or alcohol. o F’eedings should be frequent and preferably balanced as to 
E rotein, fat, and unrefined ear- ohydrates. 
o The ideal level of carbohy­ drate for you must be* determ ine through trial and error. lf you are underweight it is probably because of one of two reasoas: 
One. is that you are not as effi­ cient in using fuel for motabo lism A higher percentage of the food you eat is wasted instead of being turned into useful energy 
Two. is your appestat, the hy­ pothetic* hunger signal which regulates body weight, is set so low that the presence of hunger is not made known as quickly as in other people. 
With these special considera­ tions in mind, here are the golden rules for superenergy Diet WI 
1 Determine your vitamin and mineral program, using the guide­ lines given you last week in THE 
STAB 
Try the vitamin mineral regimen for four days before bt* ginning the other diet changes 

This allows you to begin to cor­ rect any glaring problems before you begin metabolic changeover, and helps you to know which ben efits can be attributed to vitamins rather than diet 
2 Determine your present daily carbohydrate intake, using a car­ bohydrate counter. If you are now eating less than IOO grams, in­ crease your carbohydrate intake to that level, 
3. Schedule five or six conve­ nient times spaced throughout the day for snacking. Three might represent your usual mealtimes and two or three would be snack times and at bedtime F*it some thing every three or four hours you are awake. 
4 Divide the number of grams per day by the number of feed­ ings This will give you the* ap­ proximate number of carbohy­ drate grams you should eat at each feeding. 
5 
Carbohydrates should pri­ marily bi* unrefined starches such as whole grains, lentils, vege­ tables. and particularly nuts and seeds Fruits arc less desirable at first than vegetables for they con­ tain a simple sugar rather than a complex carbohydrate. 
F’ruit once is OK in small Quantities. fx*nev should be avoided, milk lf this diet doesn’t work for you 

IF THIS diet does not help you. there may be other reasons you can't gain weight 
There are many nondiet causes of underweight, and if you simply cannot gain weight even alter trying everything I ve told you. you should work with your doctor to see if you might have some other condition 
You should never ignore unexplained weight loss 
It can be an ominous symptom of serious, even life­ threatening disease and demands immediate medi­ 

 cal investigation, particularly if your weight should suddenly begin to drop See your doctor. lf the weight loss is associated with thirst or in­ creased urinary frequency, it could mean diabetes 
Unexplained weight loss can also be caused by something as serious as cancer, especially if asso­ ciated with fatigue 
So if you have fatigue in association with unex plained .weight loss I would suggest you call your physician and make an appointment immediately.

6 No sugar This also means no corn syrup, dextrose or glucose. 
7, No white flour, cornstarch. white rice, or other refined car­ bohydrate 
Eat brown rice and whole grain bread instead. 
8 No caffeine during the begin­ ning week. This includes coffee and colas. Check the labels on drink containers. 
9 No alcohol For most people, this applies only at the beginning of the diet. 
1o Select the permissible car­ bohydrates according to the above rules and decide which ones you will be eating, in what amounts, and at which times Then fill in the remainder of your diet with foods that are primarily protein and fat: F’,ggs. meats, fish, fowl, and cheese. 
11 
Flat as much as you can comfortably enjoy without over­ stuffing yourself. Concentrate on the frequency of your feedings rather than the quantity. 
Follow this diet for at least one week 
If you cheat, by eating sweets—even a single candy bar, or go back to old habits of drink mg colas, coffee or alcoliol. begin again until you get it absolutely perfect for one week 
Then take inventory lf you are feeling better, you are ready to make your diet more liveable An­ swer these questions 
• Are all the feedings still nee essary’* Or do you still feel as

• Are you gaming or losing weight? There is usually a two-to- three pound loss the first week if the total carbohydrate intake has been drastically reduced 
There should be? some regain the second week 
If not. the total carbohy­ drate count should bf* increased 
If the weight remains the same or goes up. the carbohydrate count need not be increased. 
• Which foods would you like to add ’ There is now room for more of the* simple carbohydrates, such as milk. unsweetened yogurt, and fruit. F’oods sweetened with a lit­ tle honey might bt* added now 
If there has been no improve­ ment in your energy, you either need more carbohydrate or less carbohydrate This will take some trial and error to determine 
Increase your carbohydrate in­ take 2o grams per day. If that makes you feel tx»tter. keep add­ ing until you reach a level that gives you optimal well being lf you leel worse, start subtracting 
2o grams of carbohydrate per day until you reach optimal well­ being
