IT’S A MAD 
MAD WORLD 
Experts tell: Why we get a thrill being stared to ■ death by monsters 

King Kong: Movie audiences are paying a fortune to be frightened by this jungle tyrant. 

SELF-DEFENSE FOR WOMEN 

Bv Emil Parkas of National Self Defense Institute. 

“ I 

ONE of Ute weakest parts of the human body is the groin. When an opponent attacks you by putting his hands around you, he leaves his most vulnerable area exposed. Utilize this to your advantage—lift your knee up quickly into your opponent’s groin. Make sure you show no mercy—remember you are the one being attacked In kick­ ing your opponent, use all of your force and weight. Shout loudly as you defend yourself. It will scare your attacker and may bring unex peeled help. Remember: Do not panic. Be calm and catch your at­ tacker by surprise 

A church uses TV to help people cope 

Wife who shot her husband blames weather 
RANDOLPH 
GURGANUS was shot by his wife—all because of the cold snap that hit Florida. 
Gurganus, 26, returned unex­ pectedly to his home in Clear­ water, Fla., one morning after discovering his business was closed because of the bad weath­ er. 
His wife had bolted the door and was taking a shower. She heard the front door rattling as her husband tried to open it. 
Mistaking him for a burglar, 
Mrs. Gurganus grabbed a .22 cali­ ber pistol, opened the front door and fired. Her husband was treat­ ed for a flesh wound. 
Boy, 6, faces arrest 
MATTHEW DIETZ faces a con­ tempt of court citation for not turning up for jury services. Trou­ ble is, he’s not allowed to go to the courthouse alone. 
“He’s only six-years-old,” ex­ plained his father Stephen Dietz. 
“ I think the whole thing is hys­ terical,” said Mr. Dietz. “ I’d like to see the faces of those mar­ shalls when they come to arrest him.” 
—Tower may topple— 
ITALY'S famed leaning tower of Pisa is once again leaning too far. 
Now experts fear that the tower, which attracts 1oo.ooo tourists-a-year, may have to be caged in steel bars to keep it upright. 
The 8oo-year-old bell tower leaned one-sixteenth of an inch again last year, mainly be­ cause there is too much water in the sand and clay surround­ ing its foundations. 

Town ready for 2o76 
THE town of Hebron, Conn., has appointed a commission to meet once a year for the next 99 years to plan celebrations for the Tri­ centennial. 
Meanwhile, the outgoing Bicen­ tennial Commission buried a time capsule, to be opened in 2o76, con­ taining 143 items, “a cross-section of today’s culture." It included three marijuana cigarettes and two pipes to smoke the drug. 
Bandit is a scream 
A BANK robber has hit on a new and effective weapon to use dur­ ing his hold-ups—a piercing scream. 
Dressed as a jogger, the bandit walked into a bank in San Fran­ cisco’s financial district and asked a girl teller for change of 
$5 When she opened her cash drawer, the bandit let out a loud scream. The teller jumped back and the man scooped $1oo from the drawer and fled. 
Language of love 
A COUPLE in Orange County, 
Fla , proved the language of love knows no obstacles recently when they appeared before the Justice 
<rf the Peace to be married 
John Robbins performed the marriage between Virginia Lee 
Pride, who speaks only English, and Jose Guadalupe Estrada, who speaks wily Spanish. “They ought to get along pretty good," said 
Robbins, “they’ve got nothing to argue about ” 

A CHURCH is spending fl-million 
! on a TV campaign to help people cope with their day-to-day prob 
1 lems. 
They include loneliness, lack of trust, too much pressure and a fear of the rat race. 
But, says the Baptist General 
I Convention of Texas, most people i say their No. I problem in life is hypocrisy. 
“Our professional researchers discovered that hypocrisy was the chief problem," 
Dr. 
James 
I .andes, executive director of the 
BOOT, told THE STAR 
“ People appear to find it diffi­ cult to trust one another and it 

 worries them. They want to show trust but sometimes they just can’t.” 
The 1,5 million member church is using 36-second spots on radio and TV and newspaper ads to al­ low people who have had genuine religious experiences to tell their stones. 
We are speaking to people about their fears, and letting them know there are people who understand and care," said 
Landes. 

By ALAN D. HAAS 
MOST people enjoy being ter­ rified by a monster like King 
Kong, say psychiatrists. 
It helps us reach beyond the dullness of our everyday lives. 
King Kong, star of the new Di- no De I>aurentiis movie, is cur­ rently doing record business at the box office. 
But that’s no surprise to psychi­ atrists, anthropologists or histori­ ans. 
Dr. John Napier, a noted Brit­ ish anthropologist, says: 
"We both love and hate monsters. 
“We laugh at them and we fear them. But, overall in a curious way, we respect them simply for being monstrously big." 
Monsters also help channel peo­ ple's anxieties away from disease, hunger, war and other natural disasters, says Dr. Napier. “They reduce to a comprehensible form our inner fears and dread of ex tertial forces beyond our control." 
Joseph Campbell, author of 2o books on mythology, says: 
“ Myths like King Kong are ve­ hicles of communication between the conscious and the uncon­ scious, just as dreams are. 
“They serve four important functions for mankind. 
“ They awaken a sense of awe, even rapture, about the mystery of the universe. 
“They offer an understandable image of the world around him. 
"They support the social order through rites and rituals. 
“They guide the individual through the dependency of child­ hood, past the traumas of adoles­ cence and the trials of adult­ hood." 
Wayne Suttles, a professor of 

 anthropology at Portland State 
University, Ore , says: 
“ When we were little kids, we learned about strange creatures and monsters, and then we grew up, and learned that they weren’t real, that we had to give them up 
“When we find them again, it’s like finding your teddy bear in the attic, it’s very reassuring ” 
Dr. Bruno Bettleheim, the not­ ed child psychologist, says man needs monsters. 
“Unnamed anxieties are much more threatening,” he says, 
“than something to which we can attach a name and form. 
"Anything we know, or think we know, is more comforting than the unknown." 
Dr. June Singer, a Chicago psy­ chotherapist. says: 
“ Monster fantasies lift us out of the known and give us the cour­ age and imagination to create something new. 
“We need the I .ach Ness mons­ ter the same way we need to make trips to the moon— to go be- 
G nd the known to what people ve never before seen or experi­ enced." 
Dr. Gertrude Williams, a St 
Ijouis psychologist, and head of clinical child psychology for the 
American Psychological Assot'la- tion, says: 
“ A belief in monsters repre­ sents un existential desire to get beyond the real, drab world. 
“ There is embedded in the hu­ man psyche a wish for the un­ known, a desire to explore the offbeat. 
“Of course, if there actually is a Loch Ness monster, it doesn’t mean our fantasies will be stifled. 
We will simply look for something else.
